HEADLINE: Korean Famine Toll: More Than 2 Million

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 19

 BODY:
North Korea appears to be emerging from a prolonged severe famine with the help of international food aid, but four terrible years of hunger from 1995 through 1998 may have cost the country two million to three million lives, according to accumulating evidence gathered by a range of experts. Many of the dead were old people and children, or urban dwellers of any age with no way to forage off the land.
During that time, North Korea got nearly 3.5 million metric tons of food donations from abroad, mostly from China, Japan, South Korea and the United States. It still needs more. 
 "The food assistance is essential," said Catherine Bertini, executive director of the United Nations World Food Program, who has just returned from North Korea. "It is the only reason why there might be some stability now in the nutritional lives of many North Koreans.
"Two years ago we saw no food in the country at all," she said in an interview today. "There wasn't much food growing. There weren't small animals around. I remember distinctly not ever hearing a bird sing -- or seeing a bird. I can count on one hand how many oxen we saw.
"This time, there were quite a lot of oxen working in the fields or pulling carts," she said. "There were small herds of goats. We saw a lot of pigs, dogs and many small animals of all kinds. There seemed to be a stable food situation now. That does not mean that it's good. That doesn't mean that there is enough food in the country. And it doesn't mean that there aren't still children who are malnourished, because clearly there are."
Ms. Bertini said that North Korean officials now acknowledge that people are dying of starvation in significant numbers, although the figures they give are much lower than estimates by international aid experts. North Korea says that 220,000 people died in the four-year period. Outside the country, estimates range from 1.5 million to 3 million.
Andrew Natsios, a former vice president of the relief agency World Vision and the author of a new study of North Korea for the United States Institute of Peace, a Congressionally supported research organization in Washington, said Wednesday that the North Korean famine had become "one of the great famines of the 20th century."
"We now know that more than 10 percent of the population starved to death," said Mr. Natsios, who served as President George Bush's emergency aid coordinator in the Horn of Africa during food crises in Somalia and Ethiopia. He said the North Korean famine was comparable to the Chinese famine of 1958 and the famine in the 1930's in the Soviet Union. "I hope and pray," he said, "that this is the last of the great totalitarian famines whose roots lay in systemic dysfunction."
In his report, "The Politics of Famine in North Korea," Mr. Natsios said that confidence in the Government has been shaken. In an interview, he added that the country's belligerence could be an attempt to mask or deflect attention from its weakness and discord. Other experts see the North Korean missile threat as blackmail designed to get desperately needed hard currency from industrial nations in return for concessions.
The economy of isolationist North Korea, based on a bizarre self-reliant socialism known as juche, lost what shaky props it still had when the Soviet bloc disintegrated a decade ago. Its industries collapsed and its collective agricultural system was devastated when tools, fertilizer and seeds could no longer be bought and farmers started hoarding crops for their own use, sometimes in league with soldiers sent to guard the fields.
Then a series of natural disasters struck. In 1995, North Korea was driven to ask for international help for the first time. By then it was to late for many of its 24 million citizens.
Another recent study, by the Johns Hopkins School of Hygiene and Public Health, found that between 1995 and 1997 infant mortality rates rose, family size fell and death rates across the board were at least seven times higher than those recorded by North Korea's 1993 census. The survey, published in the British medical journal The Lancet in July, was based on interviews with people who had fled North Korea for China.
Similar surveys based on varying samples have been made by the Korean Buddhist Sharing Movement, an independent South Korean organization, and by officials representing aid agencies. A former North Korean Government ideologue, Hwang Jong Yop, who defected to the south in 1997, wrote last year in a book, "North Korea: Truth Or Lies," that a high-ranking agriculture official told him that 500,000 people had starved to death in 1995, about 50,000 of them party cadres. The Government expected another 3 million deaths in the next two years if foreign aid was not sought, he said.
Although Ms. Bertini saw encouraging signs of recovery this year, North Korea will not be out of danger for a long time, she and other experts say. Typhoons are threatening crops again, and China has had a low harvest in corn, which is traded across the border unofficially by ethnic Koreans living on both sides. In the longer term, those who survived, weakened and malnourished, will find it hard to resist infections. Medicines are scarce to nonexistent and water supplies contaminated. Without a functioning economy, North Korea cannot engage in international trade or find the money to repair public utilities.
The famine, which reached its peak in late 1996 and 1997, led to acute malnutrition and loss of body mass, known as wasting, in more than 15 percent of children under 5 and stunted growth in 66 percent of that age group, according to a survey by the United Nations, the European Union and Save the Children/U.K. That study was done almost a year after the peak had passed, and many children were already dead.
Hunger also forced between 100,000 and 400,000 people to flee North Korea for China, although it is not known how many may have returned or been sent back. Official North Korean figures acknowledged about 200,000 refugees. Whatever the number, the Chinese were sufficiently concerned to begin detaining North Koreans and deporting them.
The gathering evidence of a major catastrophe has diminished disagreements about what actually happened in North Korea, Mr. Natsios said. Some relief officials were at first convinced that the famine alarm was exaggerated; others argued that it was a Government ploy to get food that would go to troops.
Mr. Natsios said that much of what was known before experts began analyzing data from refugees and others leaving the country was based on what aid workers were able to see on occasional visits to North Korea. "While these visits do provide some information," he said, "neither field visits nor the data provided by the North Korean Government about the food situation are conclusive evidence of anything, because they present conditions as the central authorities wish them to appear to the outside world."

HEADLINE: Chasing Only Bush, Forbes Presses Issues

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19

 BODY:
In the days since the publisher Steve Forbes finished second in the Iowa straw poll, his aides have done plenty of crowing.
They have talked about a "two-man race" in the Republican Presidential primaries, reducing the eight contenders other than Mr. Forbes and Gov. George W. Bush of Texas to starry-eyed asterisks. They have unequivocally designated Mr. Forbes as the only candidate with the organizational agility and economic stamina to keep pace with Mr. Bush. 
 But with the next competitive statewide contest more than four months away, Mr. Forbes faces serious tests, both political and financial, in his effort to maintain the claim that he is Mr. Bush's biggest threat.
Mr. Forbes's aides said this week that one way they would show that the Republican field had narrowed would be to draw pointed attention to contrasts between the positions of Mr. Forbes and Mr. Bush's on various issues. That approach has already prompted complaints from Mr. Bush's aides that Mr. Forbes is poised to take a negative tack and turn the race ugly.
Mr. Forbes's aides challenged that assessment.
"The only thing we'll focus on is an issues agenda," said William Dal Col, Mr. Forbes's campaign manager, "and the one who has to respond to it is the front-runner.
"He's the one who has to be overtaken. He can't keep running and hiding. Eventually, he has to address issues, and when he does, he's on our turf."
Mr. Forbes's aides would not say whether they intend to attack Mr. Bush explicitly in forthcoming advertisements.
But a spokeswoman for Mr. Bush said that Mr. Forbes seemed to be laying the groundwork for a repeat of his performance in 1996, when he unleashed withering television commercials against Bob Dole, the Republican front-runner and eventual nominee, that haunted Mr. Dole well into the general election.
"It appears that he's on the road to doing the same thing," the spokeswoman, Mindy Tucker, said today.
Ms. Tucker said that Mr. Forbes's campaign had begun conducting a poll in Iowa this to week to see if voters would feel more negatively about Mr. Bush if they were given selective information about his record. She said they were told, for example, that he had advocated raising the sales tax in Texas but not that he had supported an overall tax cut.
Keith Appell, a spokesman for the Forbes campaign, said today that he would not discuss the specifics of any polls that the campaign was doing. In a sign of the intensifying friction between the two campaigns, Mr. Appell added that Mr. Bush's aides were overreacting and obviously running scared.
"They're trying to take the subject away from issues by accusing us of this, or accusing us of that," Mr. Appell said. "They're panicking a little bit because they're in trouble. Someone's come along and popped their little bubble."
That is one interpretation of Mr. Forbes's performance in Iowa, the true meaning of which has been dissected and debated more vigorously than the showing of any other candidate. Mr. Forbes won 20.8 percent of the vote, while Mr. Bush, the top finisher, won 31.3 percent. Elizabeth Dole came in third with 14.4 percent, while Gary L. Bauer came in fourth with 8.9 percent.
Aides to Mrs. Dole and Mr. Bauer and several political analysts said that Mr. Forbes's success primarily reflected his lavish spending to woo and entertain voters in a ritual that often rewards the candidates who are the most extravagant, solicitous hosts.
In national polls, Mr. Forbes continues to lag behind Mr. Bush, Senator John McCain of Arizona and Mrs. Dole. The latest survey of registered Republican voters in New Hampshire, a state with an early primary, shows Mr. Forbes near the bottom of the field, even though he has advertised extensively there.
The poll Aug. 15-17, by the American Research Group, which was released on Wednesday, interviewed 450 Republicans. Only 3 percent said they favored Mr. Forbes, putting him seventh place in a field of nine candidates. The margin of sampling error was plus or minus 5 percentage points.
"Nationally, there's no evidence that he's getting any traction," said Roger Stone, a Republican strategist. "I frankly don't know how much more this guy has got to spend before he figures out that money can't buy you love."
Mr. Forbes's aides, however, noted that Mr. Forbes's poll numbers in Iowa built steadily as he spent more time there and said that when voters in other states take as careful a look at the candidates as Iowans did, Mr. Forbes's support will grow in those places, too.
They also said that Mr. Forbes was committed to spending whatever it takes to remain competitive with Mr. Bush, who has raised more than $37 million so far. Mr. Forbes has raised more than $2.7 million, and has added more than $6.5 million of his own money to that sum.
But to keep pumping cash into his campaign, he may have to liquidate some assets, as he did in his 1996 bid for the Republican Presidential nomination. On the way to spending more than $35 million that time around, he had to sell some of his shares in Forbes Family Holdings Inc.
He estimated the amount of the company he currently owns to be worth more than $50 million, according to the financial disclosure form that he filed with the Federal Election Commission in May.
But because the company is privately held, his stake in it is less instantly converted into dollars for his campaign than are his publicly traded stocks, bonds and mutual funds, a portfolio that Mr. Forbes estimated to be worth $5.8 million to $14 million.
Mr. Dal Col declined to discuss the liquidity of Mr. Forbes's assets but said that Mr. Forbes would not come up short on money for the campaign. "He's got the personal resources," Mr. Dal Col said.
Mr. Forbes seems at least as determined as he was in 1996, and possibly more so. Then, he came across as the champion of a single issue: his proposal for a flat tax. Now, he speaks just as loudly about conservative religious themes, like opposition to legal abortion, that seem to depart from past statements that the Christian Coalition did not speak for most Christians and that Pat Robertson was "a toothy flake."
Brian Kennedy, a strategist for former Gov. Lamar Alexander of Tennessee, who dropped out of the race this week, said of Mr. Forbes: "He's a better candidate than he was in 1996. His agenda is much broader. His presentation is more polished."
But Mr. Kennedy added that Mr. Forbes "has a tendency to go a step too far," adding: "You saw that in 1996, with his negative advertising campaign. It ultimately sunk his candidacy."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Share Prices Move Lower On News of Trade Deficit

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
A report that the nation's trade deficit had unexpectedly worsened sent stocks into a skid yesterday and, despite a partial recovery, prices closed lower for the second consecutive session.
The market has been under pressure recently from various signs of economic recovery in Japan and Europe, where currencies tend to strengthen against the dollar as investors buy relatively more appealing foreign shares. The Commerce Department's report yesterday that the country's trade deficit had risen $3.4 billion, instead of experiencing a small decline, pushed the dollar down further. 
 That in turn set off speculation about how Federal Reserve policy makers would view this trend, a fresh source of upward pressure on prices, at their meeting on Tuesday.
"The global economy is recovering," said Lorraine Wang, an equity strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "Where we're concerned is the U.S. dollar, which is bad for inflation." The Fed is widely expected to increase the overnight lending rate a quarter-percentage point next week, and Ms. Wang predicted that the rise would not be its last.
Other analysts disagreed, but investors found little reason to buy yesterday, especially ahead of today's expiration of stock options and index options; these expirations often lead to big price swings.
With most Internet and other high-tech issues in retreat, the Nasdaq market slumped 36.30 points, or 1.37 percent, to 2,621.43, the biggest loss among the main gauges.
The Dow Jones industrial average, which was down by as much as 118 points in the morning, ended with a loss of 27.54 points, or three-tenths of a percent, to 10,963.84. Eighteen of its 30 component issues fell, though none by more than Alcoa's decline of 1 11/16 a share, to 65 3/16.
Reynolds Metals, which accepted an improved takeover offer from Alcoa, fell 2 11/16, to 65 9/16.
"The market's expensive," said Neil T. Eigen, a managing director at J. & W. Seligman. "It's very difficult to make the case that stocks go a lot higher."
Some bank stocks stood out among the day's big losers, with Chase Manhattan down 2 9/16 a share, to 82 7/16, after being downgraded by one analyst. Shares of Bank of New York fell 1 5/8, to 37, after a report that Russian criminals may have used it to launder money, and Citigroup fell 1 5/32, to 45 5/8.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 9.25 points, or seven-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,323.59; 277 of its components fell while 202 rose and 21 were unchanged.
Microsoft accounted for the most damage, slipping 1 3/16 a share, to 83 13/16, while Royal Dutch/Shell Group, up 1 1/16, to 64 11/16, offered the biggest lift.
One of the more optimistic strategists was James W. Paulsen, chief investment officer at Wells Capital Management. He said that the economy was clearly slowing down and that interest rates were likely to ease soon, clearing the way for a resumption of the bull market.
"I think stocks will probably take off again and go on to new highs," he predicted.
At least two companies made successful market debuts. Wink Communications, which is engaged in interactive television, sold 4.75 million shares at 16, and they closed at 35 11/16. The Netro Corporation, which provides broadband wireless access, sold 5 million shares at 8, and they nearly tripled, closing at 23 1/2 on turnover of 18.8 million shares.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was a moderate 684.3 million. Declining issues outnumbered advancing ones by 1,643 to 1,382.
Stocks fell in major European markets yesterday but gained in Brazil and rose more than 3 percent in Hong Kong.

HEADLINE: TENS OF THOUSANDS CALL ON MILOSEVIC TO GIVE UP POWER

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, Aug. 19

 BODY:
Tens of thousands of people gathered on a hot night in front of the Federal Parliament to demand the resignation of President Slobodan Milosevic, but they heard an extremely mixed set of messages from rival leaders of the democratic opposition here on how to get the job done.
A crowd of at least 50,000 people -- some estimates exceeded 100,000 -- represented the largest anti-Milosevic rally since NATO's air war against Yugoslavia, which forced Belgrade's troops out of Kosovo. 
 But the opposition's rivalries and clashing strategies were also on display, with the drama of the night being the effort of Vuk Draskovic, leader of the Serbian Renewal Movement, the largest party in the opposition, to hijack a rally he had sworn he would not attend.
In a clumsy bit of political fakery booed by many in the crowd, Mr. Draskovic, who had withdrawn his name from the list of speakers, essentially crashed the rally, coming on stage surrounded by bodyguards, in response, he said, to the demands of his supporters in the crowd. His ploy was an almost exact re-creation of a sudden appearance by Mr. Milosevic at a rally on the same spot 10 years ago.
While Mr. Draskovic was almost forced by the size of the turnout to attend, he also criticized many of the ideas of other opposition leaders, saying that early elections under fair conditions were the only sensible way to change Serbia and finally oust Mr. Milosevic.
Mr. Draskovic commands more voters than any other opposition politician, up to 18 percent of the vote in recent polls, more than those who favor the parties of Mr. Milosevic and his wife, Mirjana Markovic, combined.
Opposition politicians had been wary of calling a rally in sophisticated Belgrade, where huge street protests against Mr. Milosevic in 1996 and 1997 failed to bring him down. But the numbers tonight were enough to give the opposition a lift, despite its divisions, showing the disgust of many people at their current isolation and poverty.
But the people are also disillusioned by the divisions among opposition leaders, they said, and those were on clear display.
The organizers of the rally -- the Serbian Orthodox Church and Group 17, a confederation of economists and professionals -- are calling for Mr. Milosevic to resign and appoint a transitional Government of experts to serve for a year and then organize new elections.
The leader of the Democratic Party, Zoran Djindjic, Mr. Draskovic's prime rival, called for Mr. Milosevic and the Government to resign within 15 days or face mass protests.
"If they are still there after 15 days then Serbia will go out into the streets, not only in Belgrade, but in all towns, in 50 towns on the same day," Mr. Djindjic said. "Everybody will go out into the streets with one single message -- we will stay here until you go. It's either Milosevic or Serbia, there can be no third solution. This time we will go to the end."
But Mr. Draskovic heaped scorn on the idea of a transitional government of experts -- "of people no one had heard of a week ago" -- and said that it was clear now that Mr. Milosevic would never agree to it. Mr. Draskovic also scoffed at the idea of a new Government formed in the streets, through civil unrest, saying: "It's dust in the eyes of the people."
Mr. Draskovic called for early elections in November, as Mr. Milosevic's spokesmen are themselves suggesting, in their own effort to divide the opposition, but then urged street pressure to insure early elections if Mr. Milosevic does not grant them. And he called on "all responsible leaders of the opposition" to support his ideas.
One speaker for the Alliance for Change called for a new demonstration in Belgrade on Aug. 28, while another, for the Group 17, called for a new demonstration here on Sept. 21.
Leaving the rally, Zoran Stankovic said: "The only real message is change. It's time for this Government to go." But he said Mr. Milosevic could only benefit "when the opposition leaders speak in so many voices."
One important political leader of the Alliance for Change coalition, Nenad Canak, leader of the League of Social Democrats of Vojvodina, said in an interview: "The rally was fine concerning the number of people and their energy. But it was not O.K. in terms of the absence of vision, of how to focus this energy in a serious way."
As the rally gathered, Government officials continued to float the idea of early Serbian elections, perhaps as early as the first week of November, creating further divisions among the opposition.
The Alliance for Change is not ready for elections and not especially eager for them, so the Government would be calling their bluff. Mr. Draskovic, however, favors early elections to capitalize on better polling numbers.
But new elections would not affect the position of Mr. Milosevic, whose single, four-year term as Yugoslav President runs through July 2001. While the opposition is calling for his resignation or removal, early elections may divert the population from that goal.
Normally elections for the Serbian parliament and municipalities would take place in 2001, while federal parliamentary elections would take place in 2000.
It would be difficult for the self-styled "democratic opposition" to oppose new elections, though its leaders would like any vote to be supervised by outside observers from the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe and would also like to see freer, more open news media, especially television.
"Elections are the best way to sober political drunks," Mr. Milosevic's party spokesman, Ivica Dacic, said today. "Our stand is that there are many more important things than elections. But if the other political parties say elections are necessary we are ready to go to elections. But they want to come to power without elections."
Vojislav Seselj, leader of the ultranationalist Radical Party that now helps rule both Serbia and Yugoslavia, said separately today that he favored early elections to resolve Serbia's post-Kosovo troubles. He said there was no agreement with other ruling parties to call them but there was a deal to hold them if the opposition wanted them.
"We are even going so far as to say, 'Let the opposition parties name a date for the elections and we will call them,' " he said. Mr. Seselj then, impishly, suggested that local elections come first -- since the opposition has its only power base in cities across Serbia won in local elections in 1996.
They took their seats only after street protests against election fraud forced Mr. Milosevic to back down -- while saving his own seat, of course.
Mr. Draskovic's power base is the city of Belgrade, with its powerful television station, Studio B. His rivals believe that he would do almost anything to retain the station.
So to divide the opposition further, Government officials leaked a story that Mr. Draskovic had met Mr. Milosevic secretly on Monday to discuss early elections and to agree not to speak at the rally. Mr. Draskovic angrily denied the entire story, as did his top aides, one of whom said "it would be idiotic" to have had such a meeting.
Draskovic aides suggested that the leak was from Mr. Djindjic. Whatever the truth, the leak succeeded in further poisoning the relationship, if that were possible, between Mr. Draskovic and Mr. Djindjic.
"Milosevic is a master political tactician," said one senior Alliance official sadly. "He's great at changing the subject and buying time."
Even so, early elections are a serious risk for Mr. Milosevic. The Government, whose support is weak after the loss of Kosovo, could lose its majority in the Serbian parliament if the opposition could ever mount a united, professional campaign. And there is reliably said to be a debate inside the Government about the wisdom of early elections.
Some senior Government officials expressed confidence privately today that they would win a majority or could create one, despite all their problems, while some senior opposition officials also believe, with despair, that Mr. Milosevic, his wife and Mr. Seselj could retain power in a coalition.
Waiting longer, until winter bites hard and the country is inevitably short of heat and electricity due to inefficiency, sanctions and NATO air strikes, could only harm the Government's standing.
The Government had made various efforts, both subtle and crude, to cut down the size of the rally. On Wednesday night, state television announced the arrest of a Montenegrin man possessing "a highly explosive device" with a timer and warned of other possible bombing attacks at "massive public gatherings," urging caution on citizens and on parents.
The Government ordered the payment of overdue pensions for today and moved the televising of a popular lottery program from Saturday night to tonight.
But the police did not interfere with what was a peaceful rally and were not much in evidence, though riot police were stationed in buildings should they have been needed.

HEADLINE: Eli Chic or Boola Boorish?;
Moral Crisis: Yale Club Goes Casual on Fridays

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
At the Yale Club in Manhattan, in the once-exclusive domain of the jacket and necktie, there are now short-sleeve tattersalls. There are tieless button-downs. There are yellow polo shirts. There are Top-Siders, not to mention Nike Airs. Khakis have been observed in the exclusive Roof Dining Room. There are jeans.
And last Friday, egad, there was a purple Izod.
As if that were not enough, one woman actually won admission to the once-sacrosanct Tap Room in jeans, sandals and a white T-shirt. "I suppose T-shirts are O.K. now, as long as they aren't wet," said David Weild 3d, Yale '52, dressed in a dark blue suit and observing this spectacle with some amusement. 
 In case all these pret-a-porter ensembles have not given it away: the Yale Club has gone casual on Fridays, the first of Manhattan's exclusive Ivy League bastions to do so. No jacket. No tie. Its 21-member board, which unveiled the new dress code last month, did so because it does not want the club to become a, well, secret society.
"We need to engage the interest of more and more younger members, professional people who are not just lawyers and accountants but also architects and people who work on the Web," said William D. Weber, Yale '60, a business consultant in Ridgefield, Conn., who is the club's president. "We lose business when such people feel inhibited about coming to our club."
Mr. Weber declined to disclose the revenues of the privately held club, which has occupied the neoclassical limestone and brick building at 50 Vanderbilt Avenue, between East 44th and East 45th Streets, since 1915.
But do not imagine for one second that such goings-on have been unnoticed over at the Harvard Club on West 44th Street, where jacket-and-tie formality is still de rigueur in the main dining room.
"Even in the late 1990's there should be a few havens for proper attire and decorum," said John D. Sicher, a member of the Harvard Club for 32 years. "I wouldn't expect the rowdies from New Haven to understand."
Apparently, he isn't alone in his sentiment. In the midtown Ivy enclave to the west of Grand Central Station, where the clubs huddle in splendid mutuality, the non-Yale Ivies are making their last stand for manners.
Still holding the line along with Harvard is the Princeton Club on West 43d Street, which requires jacket and tie in its Woodrow Wilson dining room. United in solidarity are alumni of Columbia University, who are compelled to be united, sharing the Princeton Club as they do.
Also fighting the casual tide are the stalwarts of the University of Pennsylvania Club on West 44th Street (the library is off-limits to the tieless and jacketless) and the University Club on East 54th Street, where formality is required at all times, according to the staff. A spokeswoman not only declined to give her name or discuss the dress code, but also lectured a reporter that he was forbidden to print the very name of the club in a newspaper.
Wavering at the balance of modernity is the 6,850-member Cornell Club-New York on East 44th Street. A jacket -- but not a tie -- is required on Fridays in the formal dining room on the second floor. Acquiescing to this equivocation are some 70 members of the Brown University Club, who share the Cornell clubhouse.
But dragged right into the whole dress-down-Friday boola-boola has been the Dartmouth Club of New York, which has shared the Yale clubhouse since 1974. "We take the lead from them," said Barry Weeks, the club's executive director.
For the moment, those subversives at the Yale Club are observing at least some restraint. The casual-Friday rule is in effect only from Memorial Day to Labor Day. And not just any old "business casual" ukase will do. "T-shirts, cutoffs, torn jeans, shorts and provocative or revealing clothing are not permitted," Mr. Weber has informed the membership. The rules apply to both men and women.
(As for the woman in the white T-shirt, members speculated that she had come from the 140-bedroom members' residences upstairs, where no dress code is enforced and where members pay $105 to $215 a night.)
Mr. Weber contended that the club is "solvent," adding that a booming economy meant that "these are happy times at the Yale Club" for its 9,500 members. They pay a yearly maximum dues of $1,124 plus tax; members for less than eight years (and those who are suburbanites or out-of-towners) pay less.
And he said there had been "an unusually high level of response" to the dress-code revision. Do members feel, taking their cue from the legendary New Haven song lyrics, that the gentlemen songsters are off on a spree? Will they be damned from here to eternity?
Most of the reaction "has been positive," Mr. Weber said, "and there have been no resignations over this as far as I know."
Public recrimination would be unseemly for an institution where the entranceway letters spelling out the words Yale Club are but 1 3/8 inches high. But some diehard Bulldogs feel strongly that "the club made an error," said A. Peter Barbaresi, Class of '45, a 77-year-old real estate and construction lawyer in Rye, N.Y. "There are certain manners that should prevail in a club. I am sorry to see good taste go out the door."
Dress-down Friday "doesn't shock me," Mr. Barbaresi added, "but it disappoints me. Americans in general are not at their best when they are casually dressed. So much is failing us. Even our language is gone."
The younger generation, however, is "very much in favor of it," said Jeff Manning, Yale '81, a 40-year-old Manhattan investment banker. The casual-Friday ruling is a reflection of the fact that "the club has gotten younger," he said, adding that "the younger members are beginning to move into positions of responsibility."
Then there are the Old Blue cynosures for whom the club's dress code is not an issue. William F. Buckley Jr., class of '50, author of the 1951 polemic "God and Man at Yale," said he "never uses the Yale Club in New York."
To Mr. Buckley's son, Christopher, the dress-down change is "probably overdue," he said. "I use the Yale Club one-tenth as much as I used to because, being a member of the slobbo journalistic community, I frequently venture out without a tie, and sometimes even in jeans." He edits Forbes FYI, a Forbes magazine supplement.
Then again, the younger Mr. Buckley, class of '75, added that he "read that notice they sent out with a certain wistful, 'Well, there goes the neighborhood, why in my day we dressed in white tie to play squash.' "
He concluded: "This is what happens when you let in people from Dartmouth."
At all of the clubs these days, it is still possible to see traditionally attired older parties who appear to have fled a New Yorker cartoon. But their numbers are dwindling, and the university clubs haven't been impervious to the fashion Zeitgeist of the boomer-and-unders.
Most of the clubs have gone casual on weekends -- save at formal brunches and events. After Labor Day, the Yale Club will still permit informality in its Grill restaurant. Even Harvard has tried to get with the program, permitting "neat casual attire," its managers say, in the main bar and its Grill Room.
"Everyone recognizes this as a general trend," said Susan A. Morison, marketing director of the Cornell Club-New York, referring to the jacketless, tieless condition. "We have seen the shift in volume from the more formal area to our less formal area," she said of dining-room revenues.
Change has always come to the Yale Club gradually but relentlessly. Gone are the days when women were shunted off to the side of the lobby and rapidly elevatored to the purdah of the former Ladies' Dining Room on the 22d floor, now the Roof Dining Room. The club went co-ed shortly after Yale admitted women in 1969.
Last Friday the club declined to admit a nonmember New York Times reporter officially, but he attended as a guest of a member. Visible everywhere were the signs of rampant casualness. The formerly sacrosanct Roof Dining Room, stripped of diners by Loire Valley sojourns and Connecticut weekend getaways, held but 25 diners, 18 of them men, of whom 9 wore suit and tie.
Downstairs, in the confines of the medieval-ish Tap Room, with its beamed ceiling and leaded glass doors, only 11 of 30 men were wearing blazers or suits; 9 had ties. Many of the 15 women present were dressed more formally than the men. And all present were dining from a decidedly de-curmudgeonated menu: while the Yale Club bean soup was still available, members could also fling tradition to the winds and order a New England Seafood Wrap.
In the end, perhaps, the question is not whether casual Friday is bigger than the Yale-Harvard game, but: would the namesake donor Elihu Yale approve? "The portraits show Eli as a bewigged, fashionable 18th-century London merchant," Mr. Weild said. "He might be surprised."
Perhaps only the Whiffs -- Yale's Whiffenpoof a capella singing group -- could sum it all up: Baa, baa, baa.

HEADLINE: Democrats Again Face Voter Doubts Over Party's Values

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Every few months, small groups of local Democratic officials journey to special seminars to learn how to combat a party vulnerability: doubts among voters that the Democrats embrace mainstream family values.
Under the auspices of the Democratic Leadership Council, a centrist party group, Anita F. Gottlieb, a consultant, takes the Democrats through a mental exercise designed to stop them from speaking in the numbing jargon of program names and acronyms and instead to explain policy goals with value-laden statements about social ills and about right and wrong. 
 Ms. Gottlieb tells them to visualize a "values tree." The roots are their values. The trunk is policy goals and the branches are programs. With the tree in mind to reinforce the idea that policy goals should grow from values, they write speeches to explain the ideas of their programs.
That the council feels the need to run such workshops says something about a persistent difficulty facing Democrats as they head into the next elections. Political strategists say the public once again sees the Republicans as the party of values, considering them more trustworthy on a range of moral and ethical matters like honesty, belief in God, belief in personal responsibility and knowing right from wrong.
For the Democrats, this turn of events could not be more frustrating. In his re-election campaign, President Clinton neutralized the long-standing Republican strength on moral issues like religion and violence in movies and on television by putting together a set of policies that added up to a secular family values agenda for his party.
Now, polls show that the Democrats' traditional weakness in this area has returned. And strategists say that just as many Republicans had predicted months ago, some of the party's problems stem from the public backlash against President Clinton's behavior in the Monica Lewinsky matter, particularly among the elderly.
"There's a perception problem here that the Democrats have, I think, on moral questions," said Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut.
"I think certainly a lot of it has to do with the last year and a half and you cannot discount that," Mr. Dodd said, referring to Mr. Clinton's affair with Ms. Lewinsky and his impeachment.
The Pew Research Center for the People and the Press found in a July poll that a greater number of people -- 44 percent -- now think that the House did the right thing in impeaching Mr. Clinton. That figure was 35 percent last December at the height of the battle.
Those figures, coming six months after the Senate trial ended with Mr. Clinton's acquittal, cannot be reassuring to Democrats. At the same time, Presidential preference polls show that Vice President Al Gore is consistently running 15 percentage points or more behind Gov. George W. Bush of Texas.
To be sure, Democrats go into 2000 with advantages. Congressional Democrats have a decided edge onissues like Medicare, health care and education. And the Republican cry for deep tax cuts has not caught on with the public, according to recent polls. Many public opinion surveys show that the two parties are about even when voters are asked whether they prefer the Republicans or the Democrats running Congress.
But the Democrats' disadvantage on values could become magnified, depending on the mood of the voters, who, because of the good economy, have turned their attention elsewhere. At times this year, most particularly after the air strikes against Serbia and the shootings in Littleton, Colo., anxiety over the nation's moral compass has surged as a voter concern.
"I find as I go around Connecticut the public is really more concerned about the moral future of the country than the economic future," said Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, a Connecticut Democrat. "I think we have to speak to that."
 A June poll of 1,002 people, taken by a bipartisan team of Celinda Lake, a Democratic pollster, and Ed Goeas, a Republican pollster, showed the Democrats' weakness and their areas of opportunity.
Asked which party in Congress better represented the values of personal responsibility, voters chose Republicans by 44 percent to 22 percent. On ethics and honesty, they favored Republicans over Democrats by 39 percent to 20 percent. On faith in God, they picked the Republicans by 40 percent to 18 percent. And on knowing right from wrong, they favored Republicans over Democrats by 35 percent to 18 percent.
Only when asked which party better represented the value of community did those surveyed select the Democrats, 39 percent to 33 percent.
The poll's margin of sampling error was plus or minus 3 percentage points.
Political strategists differ on how much to attribute these findings to disillusionment with Mr. Clinton. They also cite factors like public concern with the war in Kosovo, the Republicans' greater comfort with emphasizing God and religion, and lingering public doubts dating from the 1960's over whether the Democrats embrace mainstream values.
Changing a long-standing image of a party takes time, Ed Kilgore, the policy director at the Democratic Leadership Council, said, adding, "I think you have to reprove yourself for two to three administrations before you fundamentally change the perception of the party."
Of the council's seminars held this year in Arizona, Florida, Pennsylvania, Utah and Wisconsin, Mr. Kilgore said: "It's a revolutionary exercise for a lot of Democrats. It's important to make it clear that your policy positions reflect values the public shares and that you are not proposing programs as an end in itself."
The Democrats are heading into the elections with strengths on an array of issues not explicitly related to values. Asked in the June poll which party in Congress would do a better job of improving the health care system, voters selected Democrats over Republicans 53 percent to 24 percent. On which party would better improve education, the Democrats won 46 percent to 31 percent. On which would strengthen Social Security, the Democrats led Republicans 49 percent to 28 percent.
The Democrats have been working on several fronts to respond to the public doubts. Mr. Gore, most notably, has been making a sustained effort to focus on values and define his own character.
He sounds remarkably like Mr. Bush when he declares that America should be judged "not merely by the value of our possessions but the values we possess." Even before Mr. Bush called for more reliance on churches and religious organizations, the Vice President said these groups should be eligible to receive Federal money to help the needy.
And in June he called Mr. Clinton's extramarital affair "inexcusable," adding that "particularly as a father I felt that it was terribly wrong."
Congressional Democrats have aggressively sought to turn the policy agenda to issues on which they believe they have the upper hand. They have pushed Republicans into high-profile legislative battles over gun control and regulation of managed health care. And in his opposition to the Republicans' $792 billion tax cut, Mr. Clinton has led the Democrats in portraying the proposal as an obstacle to reshaping the Medicare system and creating a new prescription drug benefit.
"There are two challenges," said Ms. Lake, who does polling for the Gore campaign on women's issues. "One is to talk about the issues in values-oriented terms, and two, to move the agenda from values to these other issues because we are only going to have so much credibility on values."
The exercise run by the Democratic Leadership Council is just one way that Democrats are trying to teach elected officials to show that programs like their education proposals reflect their party's values.
Republicans, for their part, say they have to be cautious in capitalizing on the Democrats' vulnerability, so that their efforts do not backfire as they have before. Campaign commercials that House Republicans ran last year alluding to the Clinton scandal were widely judged to have backfired, helping cost the Republicans five House seats. And much of the party establishment has been struggling to get safely beyond Pat Buchanan's fiery but divisive 1992 convention speech declaring a cultural war.
"Republicans have to be extremely careful," Mr. Goeas said. "Very often when they see declining moral values they get put in a box on abortion or gay rights. But when people talk values they really talk as much about civility in society and virtue in society."
Some Republican Presidential contenders like Mr. Buchanan or Gary L. Bauer or Alan Keyes, who are vying for the allegiance of the party's social conservatives, still determinedly take stands against abortion or else make a rejection of homosexuality a plank of their campaigns.
But others like Mr. Bush, Elizabeth Dole and Senator John McCain make a more broad-brushed appeal to those concerned with the nation's direction. They do not mention impeachment, but their allusions to it are clear. Mr. Bush talks of showing that "politics, after a time of tarnished ideals, can be higher and better." Mrs. Dole says, "We've been let down -- and by people we should have been able to look up to." And Mr. McCain says that to fight cynicism among young people "we must first challenge ourselves to give them an example worth emulating."
In Congress, the Republican goal is to let the eventual Presidential nominee set the party's themes and do nothing to allow Democrats to change the focus.
"The challenge for Republicans in Congress," said Linda DiVall, a Republican pollster, "is not to do anything that upsets the advantage we have on morals, integrity and ethics."
House Republicans have passed a number of measures highlighting their conservative cultural stands. They have approved a constitutional amendment against flag-burning, taken a stand to allow the Ten Commandments to be posted in schools, passed a measure prohibiting state and local governments from placing a "substantial burden" on a person's exercise of religion, and approved a bill to make it a Federal crime for an adult to take a minor across state lines for an abortion in order to circumvent a parental-notification law in the girl's home state.
Few, if any, of these measures will become law. And strategists said they were likely to become campaign issues only on a district-by-district basis, primarily in conservative areas of the South. "Clearly values is a major problem for the Democrats," said one House Republican strategist. "But because it's a major problem for Democrats, that doesn't mean you launch an expensive national campaign on this one issue."

HEADLINE: Report Says Labor Market Tight

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19

 BODY:
The number of workers filing for state unemployment benefits rose last week, while the less-volatile four-week average declined to its lowest level in more than a quarter-century, suggesting the pool of available employees remains relatively small.
First-time jobless claims increased 4,000 to a seasonally adjusted 287,000 for the week ended Aug. 14, the Labor Department said. Last week was the fourth straight week that first-time jobless claims were below 300,000. 
 The four-week average of claims dropped to 281,250 from 288,250 the previous week. That is the smallest number of claims since the week ended Dec. 22, 1973, when the four-week average was 280,000.
"There's very little evidence that shows conditions are easing in the labor market," said Vincent Boberski of Dain Rauscher in Chicago. "This is just going to be more justification for the Federal Reserve" to raise interest rates a quarter-point either in August or October.
Usually, when job markets are tight, companies increase wages to attract workers. That increase is typically passed on to consumers as higher prices, leading to inflation.
That has not happened yet, but it is a cause of concern for the Fed's policy-making Open Markets Committee, which meets next week to consider an interest rate increase.
The figures show "the economy is still very strong and that most firms are more focused on attracting and retaining workers than reducing staff," said Lynn Reaser, chief economist at Bank of America Private Bank in Jacksonville, Fla.

HEADLINE: Richard W. Jennings, a Titan Of Securities Law, Dies at 91

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES 

 BODY:
Richard W. Jennings, who helped popularize the study of securities law in United States law schools and helped export concepts of market regulation to the postwar societies of Japan and Germany, died at his home in Piedmont, Calif., on Aug. 9 after a brief illness. He was 91.
At his death, he was a professor emeritus of Boalt Hall, the law school at the University of California at Berkeley. He received his law degree there in 1939, joined the faculty in 1947 and continued to teach there well after his retirement in 1975. 
Beyond the students who studied directly with Professor Jennings over the years, countless others encountered his passion for securities law by using the pioneering casebook that he wrote with Harold Marsh Jr., who taught at the University of California at Los Angeles.
A casebook is a collection of statutes, state and Federal court decisions and administrative and regulatory rules, the essential elements of any study of a particular field of law. His securities law casebook -- officially called "Securities Regulation: Cases and Materials" but known to students simply as "Jennings and Marsh" -- was first published in 1961 and is now in its eighth edition.
The fledgling field of securities law had been brought into focus a decade earlier, in 1951, by the publication of the first securities law textbook, by Louis Loss, a professor at Harvard. But it was the Jennings and Marsh casebook that allowed securities law to become a standard element of legal education.
"It was one of the most influential casebooks of all time," said Joel Seligman, dean of the Washington University School of Law in St. Louis. "After four decades, it remains the leading casebook in the field." Mr. Seligman wrote the recent editions of the study guide along with John C. Coffee Jr., a law professor at Columbia University.
Richard Wormington Jennings was born on Oct. 19, 1907, the son of a banker in Bois D'Arc, Mo. A 1927 graduate of Park College in Parkville, Mo., he briefly taught high school algebra before beginning graduate studies in political science at the University of Pennsylvania. But by 1937, his imagination had been caught by the marked changes in business law that were ushered in with the New Deal and he enrolled at the Berkeley law school in 1937.
After a period of private practice and government service during World War II, he joined the law school faculty. He and his longtime co-author, Mr. Marsh, were described by friends and colleagues as "The Odd Couple." In contrast to Mr. Marsh's tough, blunt-spoken demeanor, Professor Jennings was "sweetness and light," said Richard Buxbaum, a law professor at Berkeley. As each wrote half of the casebook, "the personality of the early editions was utterly schizophrenic."
Professor Jennings's influence on securities regulation extended well beyond the classroom. In the early 1960's, William L. Cary, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission under President John F. Kennedy, recruited him as a consultant to the commission's first full-scale investigation of the securities markets in 25 years. Through his work on the study and his testimony at various Congressional hearings, he contributed to the public debate that led in 1975 to the elimination of fixed brokerage commissions on Wall Street. That change led to the collapse of many securities firms and radically altered the competitive forces in the securities industry.
"There was a time, from the 1950's through the 1970's, when there were three people who towered over the field of securities law," Mr. Seligman said. "They were Louis Loss, Bill Cary and Dick Jennings."
Professor Jennings was invited in 1961 to serve as a Fulbright professor at Tokyo University and helped introduce modern securities regulation theory to the Japanese academic community. He was also a mentor, along with Professor Loss, to an influential group of young law professors in Germany in the mid-1950's who helped add securities regulation to the academic agenda there as Germany developed into an economic power.
Indeed, it was as a mentor to young lawyers that he is most fondly remembered among his students, said Lawrence Sonsini, a partner in Wilson Sonsini Goodrich & Rosati in Palo Alto, Calif., who was his research assistant in the mid-1960's and later took over some of Professor Jennings's classes.
"He was the one who encouraged me to develop a securities law practice at the firm when this was just beginning to be called Silicon Valley," Mr. Sonsini said. "He had a vision of what it could be.
Professor Jennings, formal and gracious, was one of the last law professors at Berkeley to abandon jacket and tie for "business casual." But other trappings of legal power did not impress him. "We shared the same office for 13 years -- books, a steel desk, some pictures -- and I don't think it had changed since he first moved in," Mr. Sonsini said.
On campus, he is best known beyond the law school for his service as chairman of the faculty senate at the height of the Free Speech Movement in the mid-1960's, a cultural collision between campus liberals and the conservative establishment in Sacramento that developed against the backdrop of the Vietnam War.
Herma Hill Kay, dean of the law school, said that his patient but authoritative leadership of a sharply divided faculty was a calming influence during those turbulent years.
In 1987, law school alumni expressed their affection for Professor Jennings and two colleagues -- Stefan A. Riesenfeld, who died earlier this year, and Adrian A. Kragen -- by raising an endowment for three faculty positions to be named in their honor.
Professor Jennings is survived by his wife of 64 years, Elizabeth Robison Jennings, of Piedmont; two daughters, Susan J. Stangeland and M. Anne Jennings, both of Berkeley; a son, W. Thomas Jennings of Sacramento; four grandchildren, and a great-grandson.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Dollar's Drop Against Yen Renews Focus On U.S. Policy

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
An apparent shift in Japanese policy and the report of a record United States trade deficit helped send the dollar lower yesterday against the Japanese yen and the new European currency, the euro.
But the dollar, despite its recent 4 percent plunge against the yen, remains healthy against the world's other major currencies. Against the euro, which was predicted by many analysts to rally after its January debut, the dollar is still up almost 10 percent this year. The dollar also rose yesterday against the currencies of two of the United States' major trading partners, Canada and Mexico. Adjusted for trade patterns, the dollar is just above its 20-year average value against all its trading partners, according to Chase Manhattan Bank. 
 "So far, there has not been across-the-board selling against the the dollar," said Paul Podolosky, a currency strategist at BankBoston.
Still, some analysts are worried that the growing American trade deficit could be a problem for the dollar in the future, as it was in the late 1980's. In addition, if the American economy begins to slow down as the rest of the world is reviving, that could put more downward pressure on the dollar as investors leave the American markets and the dollar to invest in markets that appear to have more potential for growth.
In these circumstances, however, a falling dollar would not necessarily be a problem for the United States, analysts said, as long as the decline was orderly and not extreme.
In late trading yesterday, it cost $1.06300 to buy one euro compared with $1.05230 Wednesday, a 1 percent fall in the dollar's value. Against the Japanese yen, the move was smaller because much bigger declines came earlier in the week. Yesterday, the dollar slipped to 111.40 yen against the dollar, down from 112.03 Wednesday. The dollar fell 1.8 percent against the yen on Wednesday.
It has been the selloff of the dollar against the Japanese yen that has refocused attention on the dollar and, at the same time, American policy toward it. During this slide against the yen, some analysts have begun to raise questions about Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers's commitment to the strong-dollar policy of his predecessor, Robert E. Rubin. Although Mr. Summers has supported the policy in public statements, doubts about his commitment -- even if mistaken -- have undermined the dollar a little, analysts said.
The dollar selloff and yen rally began in early July when the dollar was worth about 122 yen. Since then, the value of the dollar against the yen has declined more than 9 percent. The driving force has been the move by big institutional investors back into the Japanese stock market, which has soared this year. That move was prompted by the expectation -- based so far on just one quarter's economic data -- that the Japanese economy is turning around.
The accelerated move this week was set off by comments from Japanese officials that analysts have interpreted to indicate that the Government is not ready to intervene in the currency markets to support the yen. That is a switch from a policy of aggressive intervention to weaken the yen earlier this summer. In June and July, the Japanese sold yen for dollars six times in an effort to keep the value of the yen from rising.
The Japanese Government, through the Bank of Japan, had intervened because of the fear that the rapidly appreciating yen -- as the dollar declines -- would undermine the economy. A stronger yen makes Japanese exports more expensive and less competitive. And a slump in exports could derail what is, at best, a struggling economic recovery.
"I don't think intervention is imminent," said Karen E. Parker, director of currency research at Chase Manhattan Bank. Until this week, many traders expected intervention at the 110-yen level.
One of the reasons for the switch, Ms. Parker said, is the realization by the Japanese that intervention, without the participation of the United States, is not working. In addition, Japanese officials are hoping that their economy is on the rebound, which would make the rebound in the yen less worrisome.
With the apparent change in policy, Ms. Parker said she thought the yen could move to a value of 105 to 108 to the dollar. At that point, she said, intervention would be more likely.
The rally in the euro yesterday was started by a report that the German business confidence index, compiled by the Ifo economic research institute in Munich, rose to 93.6 in July from 92.9 in June, the third consecutive monthly gain. A strong increase in the confidence report in July helped set off the rally in the euro at the end of last month. At that point, the euro, the new currency of 11 European countries, was down 13 percent for the year. Since then, it has risen almost 5 percent.
Later yesterday, the United States Commerce Department announced that the trade deficit jumped to $24.6 billion in June, a record.
The trade deficit has not been a problem for the dollar or the American economy so far. In fact, as the deficit was increasing over the last year, the dollar was strengthening.
Ms. Parker said the deficit could be more of a drag on the dollar now, given the changing circumstances of the world economy. Last year, when Asian economies were in recession and Europe was sluggish, it was easy to attract foreign investment here to cover the deficit. But with Europe and Asia rebounding, that could get a little more difficult. And to attract investors who are seeing new opportunities elsewhere, the dollar may have to weaken, interest rates rise and stocks stop climbing.

HEADLINE: EARTHQUAKE IN TURKEY: DAMAGE;
Economic Loss Estimated To Reach Tens of Billions

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER 

DATELINE: ISTANBUL, Turkey, Friday, Aug. 20

 BODY:
Economic losses caused by the devastating 45-second earthquake will reach tens of billions of dollars, according to early damage estimates announced on Thursday, and the Government probably will have to find several billion more in an already tight budget to pay for emergency reconstruction.
Rescue workers continued to pull survivors and victims from the ruins of buildings, bringing the number of dead to more than 7,000 and the injured to more than 30,000. Turkish officials said thousands were still missing, and the hope that they will be found alive is dwindling. Newspapers predicted that the death toll could soar to 10,000 or more. 
 The director of Turkey's leading observatory, Mehmet Ali Isikara, said he had detected "unusual movement" in seismic structures that could produce another tremor. More than 200 aftershocks were reported in the region on Thursday alone. In response to the warning, the Governor of Bursa, a province south of Istanbul, urged the province's 2 million residents to spend the night outdoors.
Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit sought to calm rising public anger at the disorganized relief effort. Looking pale and shaken as he emerged from a crisis session, he said that although the nation was in mourning, "good news comes from all areas" as more survivors are found.
But instead of ordering an army mobilization or other drastic measures to increase the pace of the rescue effort, as some have urged, Mr. Ecevit announced only a plan to send tents to affected areas.
"Tent cities will be set up in the worst areas," he said on Thursday. "From today, they will be able to make use of health, cleaning and food facilities."
Across the quake area, people complained bitterly about the lack of relief workers and equipment. Television stations broadcast scenes of people picking through rubble with their bare hands and even fighting over scarce shovels and bulldozers. Many towns have not seen a single Government worker, and are relying on foreign volunteers or none at all.
In Izmit, near the epicenter of the quake, the country's biggest refinery continued to burn. Thousands of residents were evacuated as a precaution against explosions.
Aid workers from abroad continued to pour into Turkey. The United States announced plans to send three warships with 3,100 sailors and marines aboard. The vessels are fitted with operating rooms and medical equipment, and the crews include physicians and paramedics.
The State Department announced that five Americans were among the dead.
As the initial shock over the quake eased, Government officials and other specialists began planning what can be done to revive the shattered economy.
"The economy was already in a serious position," Prime Minister Ecevit said. "Now it will be worse."
Turkey is negotiating with the International Monetary Fund for a crucial $5 billion loan, and Turkish leaders have pledged to cut the national budget and make other reforms that may now prove difficult or impossible. At the same time, countless businesses have been destroyed, most of them small and mid-sized companies like those that have fueled this country's remarkable economic boom in the last decade.
"It's more than serious," said Abdurrahman Ariman, general secretary of the Foreign Investors Association. "The loss could be $25 billion, but the effects will be much wider than that. This is the most productive region of our country, and the destruction of infrastructure there is complete, let alone the damage that industries sustained."
"We already had serious problems in other regions, and now we have to talk about reconstructing the whole country," he said. "It's not a one-dimensional problem. It will take years to deal with, and Turkey can't handle all of it alone."
Turkey's economy has boomed for most of the 1990's, racking up growth rates of 7 to 8 percent in most years. Although there has been a slump in exports since last summer's Russian financial crisis, and a near-collapse of tourism after terrorist attacks here several months ago, most experts have agreed that the economy here is fundamentally sound and should continue to grow. But in the wake of the earthquake, no one is certain if those predictions remain valid.
"Industry has been terribly affected, and I don't know how we're going to put it together again," said Ayse Bugra, a professor of economics at Bosporus University in Istanbul. "There are all kinds of problems. Roads are a mess, and there is no rail transportation in the area even though it's the country's main industrial region.
"The destruction of the petroleum refinery will probably mean that oil prices will go up, which will fuel inflation. Many companies were not properly insured, so there will be a lot of bankruptcies and layoffs."
"But even though this is a disaster for the economy, it can be an opportunity if certain decisions are taken," Ms. Bugra said. "The refinery should definitely be moved to another place outside the earthquake zone. Incentives should be given to companies that lost buildings to relocate in other parts of the country, which would not only take them outside the danger area but would address the great regional imbalances in our economy. Insurance and construction regulations should be tightened. These would be rational steps, and now, before people forget about this, is the time to take them."
One sector of the economy that is likely to boom in the coming months is construction. Gazi Ercel, president of the Central Bank, said he expected the Government to allocate about $4 billion to rebuild ruined businesses and $2 billion to $3 billion more to rebuild the destroyed refinery.
"It's a burden on our budget, but we have a G.D.P. of $200 billion, so it should be bearable," Mr. Ercel said. "We'll also have a very low growth rate this year, probably less than one percent, but investments in construction will help somewhat. All in all, it's a sizable burden, but I think the Turkish economy, together with generous and timely foreign aid, will be able to handle it."
Michel Camdessus, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, suggested that the fund might modify its demands to take the needs of earthquake victims into consideration.
"The I.M.F. will do all it can to help the Turkish Government deal with this disaster," Mr. Camdessus said. "We stand ready to help them in any way that we can."
The chairman of Turkey's principal business association, Erkut Yucaoglu, said that even though losses would probably exceed $20 billion, the earthquake was "not completely devastating in an economic sense."
"It will slow down the economy, but we can get through it," Mr. Yucaoglu said. "I hope there will be a level of understanding abroad for the budget increases and other steps we'll have to take."
"Turkey deserves some soft loans and long-term credits at this moment to cope with the rehabilitation of various sectors of the economy, as well as funds to cope with the social side of the problem," he said. "I think foreign lenders are ready to look at things here with softer heart at this moment."

HEADLINE: Going Upstate, Giuliani Backs Dairy Supports

BYLINE: By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

DATELINE: ENDICOTT, N.Y., Aug. 19

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani flew into this Southern Tier town today and announced that he had changed his mind and now supported Federal legislation designed to prop up prices for New York's dairy farmers. Mr. Giuliani said he no longer feared that the legislation would lead to higher milk costs for downstate consumers.
Mr. Giuliani's declaration -- made while attending a steak roast that has become a summer political ritual for Republican candidates and officeholders -- puts him in line with his presumed Democratic opponent in the race for United States Senate, Hillary Rodham Clinton. The First Lady declared her support for the dairy compact, an almost mandatory position in a region with many struggling dairy farmers and a beleaguered economy, during a visit to Syracuse last month. 
 "If I was in the Senate, I would vote for it," Mr. Giuliani said at a news conference at the 11th annual steak roast arranged by State Senator Thomas W. Libous, whose event typically draws more than 3,000 people with the promise of a lot of steak and just a little candidate talk. With that, Mr. Giuliani dived into the crowd to shake hands before sitting down to eat.
Mr. Giuliani said he had changed his mind after being assured by Republican members of the state's Congressional delegation that changes to the pending law, as well as regulations that would govern New York's entry into the Northeast Interstate Dairy Compact, would address the concerns that had once led him to oppose it: that it would lead to higher costs for consumers and raise the cost of school lunches.
The Mayor discussed his position in the midst of a stepped-up schedule of upstate visits in anticipation of a probable run for the Senate. He said he had actually announced his new position at a little-noticed speech in Cooperstown months ago.
But when reporters called Mr. Giuliani's office for comment after Mrs. Clinton weighed in the issue on July 8, his aides made no mention of the speech Mr. Giuliani referred to this evening. At the time, they noted that New York City had lobbied in Albany against the legislation that would have allowed New York to join the compact.
Mr. Giuliani's press secretary, Sunny Mindel, said she was unable to say why the position Mr. Giuliani outlined today had not been discussed at that time.
In any event, Mr. Giuliani's new stance removes what clearly could have a barrier between him and Republican leaders, such as Mr. Libous, in this part of New York.
"My earlier concerns had been satisfied," Mr. Giuliani said. "I announced that, actually, about two months ago. It was at night, it was at a dinner, and there were only two or three members of the press around and you never reported it."
The subject of the Northeast Interstate Dairy Compact has been challenging politically, for both Mrs. Clinton and Mr. Giuliani. The First Lady, in supporting New York's inclusion in the compact, found herself breaking from the policy that had been advocated by her husband's Department of Agriculture.
Mr. Giuliani had to weigh the demands of what is a very important issue upstate, where the Republican Mayor needs to do well against Mrs. Clinton, against the concerns of his current constituents, New York City consumers. Yet another political aspect of the milk compact is the fact that environmentalists support it because it assures the continued existence of small dairy farms.
The compact is scheduled to expire on Oct. 1. The legislation before Congress would renew it and enable New York, New Jersey, Delaware, Maryland and Pennsylvania to join the cartel.
Mr. Giuliani said he changed his mind because his two major concerns had been addressed.
The first was his fear that joining the milk cartel would increase the cost of school lunch programs, because of an increase in milk costs. Mr. Giuliani said that Congressional Republicans had assured him that this would be addressed by regulations that would allow states to reimburse schools for any increases.
Mr. Giuliani said that he had dropped his concern that it would hurt downstate consumers based on the assurances of upstate Republican members of Congress, who had shown him examples of other states that had joined the compact without any increase in costs. "They satisfied me that it would in fact stabilize the price," Mr. Giuliani said.
In Washington, Mrs. Clinton's spokesman, Howard Wolfson, said that Mr. Giuliani's administration had been on record, along with consumer groups, in warning that the higher prices for farmers would inevitably raise the price in supermarkets. "We're glad that Rudy Giuliani has finally decided to join Hillary Clinton in support of the dairy compact," Mr. Wolfson said. "The question is, why it took him so long to change his position."
Mr. Giuliani brushed off a questioner who asked if he had now adopted the First Lady's position. "I have no idea what her position is," Mr. Giuliani said.
