HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
Kiddie Pop: Raffi It's Not, But Just What Is It Anyway?

BYLINE: By ANN POWERS

 BODY:
The sound of young girls screaming has been a main energy source in pop since bobby-soxers greeted the dawn of rock-and-roll. It is amusing to watch music industry moguls and pundits fall all over themselves "discovering" that prepubescents get infatuated with prettily packaged crooners like the Backstreet Boys: just another case of short memories making things seem new.
Still, concertgoers strolling through the fairgrounds of Nickelodeon's All That Music and More Festival, nicknamed Kiddiepalooza by some, were confronted with a new twist on the teen-age pop formula. 
 The shows' teen-age and 20-something artists, including the "boy band" 98 Degrees and the collegiate chanteuse Monica, recalled predecessors ranging from New Kids on the Block to Annette Funicello. Although some of the fans singing along were learning to have crushes earlier than previous generations had, their dewy rapture was nothing new. More telling was the pleasure of the parents who took their offspring to the fair's Jones Beach stop Wednesday or its Holmdel, N.J. date Thursday, as these adults embraced the notion that loud music can be good for America's youth.
Back in rock's bad old days, children hid radios under their pillows and got their older siblings to play their Led Zeppelin records for them surreptitiously. They imagined that their first concert would transport them into a forbidden realm where people sampled illicit drugs, virginal girls considered the propositions of older men and boys gathered in the crowd to sweat out their aggression.
Even teenyboppers, whose tastes were tamer, pushed societal danger buttons by expressing a fervent sexuality. Nostalgia makes it hard to remember that Beatlemania was once considered a menace. Mild or wild, pop music has offered escape, however fleeting, from parental guidance.
The Nickelodeon tour, on the other hand, lovingly and carefully ushers children into a new style of music fandom. The festival does not feature music intended specifically for children; its artists address subjects like dating, sex and even marriage, not learning how to spell. Neither was Kiddiepalooza exactly a family outing, like a state fair, where adult activities share equal space with youthful games. Organized by a children's television network, it aimed squarely at the lunchroom set.
Some observers have cynically remarked that Kiddiepalooza's only meaning is economic, as vendors of music and concert T-shirts learn to exploit the preteen demographic. But children, and their parents, are not merely absorbing this new youth culture as product. Events like Kiddiepalooza signal serious changes in the social meaning of popular music and in the public perception of the young people who remain its most dedicated fans.
Nearly 50 years after rock's emergence, noisy, oppositionally flavored, sexually suggestive music has become a lifetime pleasure for many people, and they do not fear it when they become parents. At the same time children are maturing more rapidly, and adults feel compelled to discuss matters like sex and drug use with them earlier, and feel more comfortable doing so.
Add to this the refusal of adults to totally "grow up" and put aside pleasures identified with adolescence, and a picture emerges of a newly paced life cycle, with music grounded in rock as a soundtrack shared by all ages.
Not only are many adults now more comfortable than ever with their children's interest in pop, partly because they have been lifelong music fans themselves, but more adult-oriented musicians are also showing an interest in bridging the gap between their usual output and children's music. On both ends, the divisions between grown-up fare and kid stuff have blurred.
Young fans are being widely embraced, and not merely in the lecherous manner of heavy metal bands. Jennifer Lopez and TLC, female artists who mainly appeal to young adults, both included tender images of preteen fans in recent videos. Venerable rappers like the Sugar Hill Gang have returned as a part-kiddie, part nostalgia act: the trio has opened for teen-age bands like TN Sync, and just released the album "Jump On It!" (Kid Rhino), which transforms classic hip-hop into educational rhymes.
Alternative rock bands are also cultivating the children's market. Bis, a Scottish band whose members are 19 and 20, created the theme song for the Cartoon Network's Powerpuff Girls show. It was a natural leap for a group that regularly uses superhero imagery to promote its bright, whimsical rock. And the brothers Mark and Clay Harper have written two musical children's stories with the help of underground rock veterans like the Velvet Underground drummer Moe Tucker, the punk icon Wreckless Eric, Cindy Wilson of the B-52's, and Susan Cowsill, a former teen-age artist herself.
Throughout pop music, fans and players alike are realizing that rock's energy can be used to express emotions that are not merely adolescent.
While strains of rock and rap continue to serve teen-agers' need to rebel and establish their own identities (think Limp Bizkit), music culture in general is opening up in other directions. Teen-age bands are musically sophisticated enough to hook adult fans, while the youngest listeners are no longer stuck in the corner with their Raffi records.
This is a healthy development. Yet it raises some thorny issues, ones many parents walking away from Kiddiepalooza must have wrestled with. Bands oriented toward teen-agers may still trade mostly in puppy love, but most also embody up-front sex appeal. At Kiddiepalooza, the boy bands thrust their crotches and show plenty of muscular flesh; young female singers moan about the touch of their lovers. Monica, for example, presented herself as a kind of living Barbie, a princess in perfect outfits projecting a femininity worth emulating. She sang about respecting yourself and waiting to have sex. But she also strutted about the stage in black leather, a bona fide sexpot.
Monica was positively puritanical compared with the festival's opening act, No Authority, a quartet that incorporated male stripper-style moves with gymnastic tumbles. The members of E.Y.C., who followed No Authority, also showed off their bodies, while 13-year-old Baby DC, who played on a second stage, took a tough guy stance while rapping in a pixie's voice. These boy-men tantalized the small girls who shimmied alongside their amused mothers, some of whom probably could see the attraction in the beefcake.
These teen-age idols were far more provocative than earlier heartthrobs like David Cassidy, whose fans were infuriated when a partial nude photograph on the cover of Rolling Stone magazine proved that he actually had pubic hair. At best, their lustiness may lead to some open conversations between parents and their children, who are dealing with sex whether adults acknowledge it or not.
Yet kiddie pop feeds another, less inevitable hunger than sex, and one hopes parents are discussing this one with their concert companions, too. It preys on the urge to ascend within the media spectacle that continues to overtake public life. The aura of manufacture surrounding teen-age artists is shutting out the unkempt individuality of old-fashioned rock stars. Kiddiepalooza encouraged fans to see themselves in a similarly artificial light by offering public auditions for several Nickelodeon shows. Fans stood in long lines to sit in plastic booths and read from scripts, straining to look cute for the camera.
Rock-and-roll has always made room for cuteness, and for commerce. But its rebellious side posed important challenges to the status quo, whether they were major, like the increased visibility of African-American artists, or less earthshaking, like the triumph of scruffy outcasts in leather jackets. The music could make these inroads because of its status as an outsider art. Kiddiepalooza hardly fanned that individualistic spark; these youngest fans will have to find their own ways to ignite it.

HEADLINE: Why Nobody Likes A Loser;
Failure? No, a Bump On the Road to Success

BYLINE: By AMY WALDMAN

 BODY:
There is a curious inversion afoot in Silicon Valley, where Internet entrepreneurs whose start-up companies fail are more marketable to venture capitalists than those who have never failed at all. It is not how business is supposed to work, but there it is: in that corner of the economy, failure has become an asset, a resume-builder.
Perhaps in an industry where people do not know what they are doing, any experience is better than none; perhaps the willingness to fail is admired because it suggests the courage to try. Whatever the explanation, the turning of failure on its head is a reminder of Americans' incessantly ambivalent and constantly mutable relationship with the idea of not "making it." 
 Failure has been with us as the shadow of success since the republic's early days, when Benjamin Franklin lectured that "little strokes fell great oaks" -- that with enough diligence and tenacity, anyone could succeed. In the two centuries since, as capitalism has expanded its hold on American life, success has become that much more important and failure that much more catastrophic. Its definition, in fact, seems to have quietly broadened to encompass not just those who fail outright, but those who do not achieve extraordinary and public success.
As in Silicon Valley, of course, there are exceptions. In the age of instant memoirs and commercial endorsements, for example, Bob Dole, Dick Morris, and others have shown that failure can actually be profitable. Indeed, to judge from talk shows and tabloids, the only true failure nowadays sometimes seems to be obscurity.
But for most Americans the stigma of failing remains, and thus the quest to assign a moral cause for it continues. Whether the blame for those who fail to make it up the ladder lies with larger socioeconomic forces or with the individual is an unspoken subtext of the ideological battle between liberals and conservatives. It is the backdrop of countless policy debates, on subjects from welfare to how hard it should be to declare bankruptcy.
Yet while plenty of Americans have experience with failure, few like to dwell on it, at least outside their therapists' offices.
"Historians in particular and Americans in general don't like to talk about failure very much," said Scott Sandage, a professor at Carnegie Mellon who is at work on a book called "Forgotten Men: Failure in American Culture," to be published by Harvard University Press.
There are, he says, dozens of studies of the ideology of success in America, but until recently, historians have not looked at the experience of failure. Professor Sandage is doing just that -- researching not great men who momentarily stumbled, but ordinary men who despite their honest toil slowly, or sometimes instantaneously, sank.
He has dug through family papers and diaries, credit reports and letters to understand how Americans grappled with failure in a society where hard work was supposed to equal success.
The answer was usually to find some flaw in the person's character. He cites the example of Robert Brown, a farmer and planter in antebellum Virginia who was described in various business records as "one of nature's best sons" -- a decent if slightly naive man -- while he was prospering. But when he went bankrupt some of the same people described him as "a man of no energy" -- a phrase that Professor Sandage says became common in the 1850's and 1860's to describe failures who were not idlers or drunkards.
"It is a profound threat to the fundamental ideology of America if it never comes together" despite one's best efforts, Mr. Sandage said.
So when Fitch Raymond, a Cleveland grocer who failed during the Panic of 1873, requested assistance from a friend, he defended himself against the assumption that he was to blame: "I have been Struggling incessantly trying to re g ain a little foothold but without success," he wrote. "Not because I am imbecile, shiftless, lazy, listlessly, loafing about, no, not a bit of it, but the reverse is true."
Over time Mr. Sandage said, failure has been transformed from an action -- failing at a business or other venture -- to an identity. Today, being known as a "loser" and the words "I am a failure" have become common coinage.
The rise of super-successes like Carnegie and Rockefeller at the end of the 19th century helped breed the phenomenon that might be called failure through inadequacy: unless one achieved and amassed on a grand public scale, one had failed. As capitalism exploded, Americans began grappling with how to process failure in a society that held that the individual made his fortunes or broke them. The notion of treating failure as a bump on the road to success -- still very much evident today in self-help books with titles like "Failure: The Back Door to Success" -- began to emerge.
In the 1920's, the decade when President Calvin Coolidge proclaimed that "the chief business of the American people is business," a little homily called "The Failure" circulated in popular magazines, Merrill Peterson writes in "Lincoln in American Memory." It recounted the defeats Abraham Lincoln had suffered and concluded: "How would you stand in the face of such setbacks? Think it over!"
The list of Lincoln's failures continues to circulate today, most often in advice columns and motivational seminars. That it happens to be somewhat inaccurate -- some of the defeats on the list are exaggerated or did not happen -- has done little to diminish its appeal.
"The Lincoln list" embodies one of the most potent images in American life, one found in politics, Hollywood and certainly sports: the comeback. At its heart the comeback is nothing more than failing, then rising from the ashes, with victory sweetened by the defeat that preceded it.
"As a culture we are very forgiving of failure," said Steven Biel, a professor of history and literature at Harvard, "but failure has to be one moment in a larger narrative where success is secured."
Mr. Biel, the author of "Down With the Old Canoe," a history of cultural attitudes toward the Titanic, notes that when the ship sank in 1912, "everyone who looked at it tried to turn it into a story of redemption -- pulling success out of the jaws of failure." The fact that women and children were saved first, he said, was instantly spun as an example of American male chivalry.
Such public and political efforts to transform grand national failures into a narrative of triumph are not uncommon. Consider the speech William Safire composed for President Nixon in 1969 in case the men who landed on the moon had to be abandoned there. It would have been a disastrous failure, but in Mr. Safire's vision, it became a triumph of American character. "Others will follow, and surely find their way home," the speech read. "Man's search will not be denied."
"American political culture has not changed," Mr. Biel said. "It is hard to envision any national figure not returning to the rhetoric of progress -- that failure is part of the American narrative of destiny."
Still, the turns of history have forced Americans occasionally to adjust their attitudes toward failure. During the Depression, for instance, failure became so widespread that blame shifted somewhat from the individual to the system. The same is true, to a lesser degree, of the wave of downsizing earlier this decade.
Such larger phenomena may briefly elicit more public compassion. But perhaps the gentlest and certainly most honest treatment of failure comes in literature. As Willy Loman, perhaps the archetype of American failure puts it, "A man can't go out the way he came in, Ben, he has got to add up to something."
Robert Polito, the biographer of the crime novelist Jim Thompson, calls failure "one of the great subjects of American fiction" -- perhaps the great subject. From Herman Melville's "Pierre," to Hurstwood in "Sister Carrie," who descends from prosperity to a Bowery flophouse, to Dick Diver's disappearing into smaller and smaller towns at the end of F. Scott Fitzgerald's"Tender Is the Night" -- the list of fictional failures is endless. Often, Mr. Polito notes, they are exploring the burdens placed on the psyche by the enormous expectations of success in America.
In most of these books the failures are men, and Mr. Sandage said his research also revealed failure as a masculine category. "People don't fail unless they are supposed to succeed," he said, and in the 19th century and much of the 20th success was the province of white men.
But Andrew Delbanco, a professor of the humanities at Columbia University, notes that women, particularly in the 19th century, had their own kind of failure to deal with: whether they married and, in a certain milieu, married well. Again, literature tells the story: Lily Bart in Edith Wharton's "House of Mirth," for example, blows her chance to make a good match and is consigned to poverty and ultimately death.
In fact each subculture in American life -- whether gender or region, profession or class -- seems to have its own code of failure: what kinds are acceptable, how to treat those who fail, rules that protect the status of the subculture and its members. Where Silicon Valley exalts failure, Wall Street punishes it ruthlessly, observes Michael Lewis, who is about to publish a book on cyberspace entrepreneurs.
"People can't be seen giving money to someone who has proven inept with money," he said. On Wall Street, to readmit a failure would suggest that the whole business is a crapshoot, based as much on luck as skill.
Among the underclass, conversely, failure has become normalized. Sociologists like William Julius Wilson have devoted a sizable portion of their work trying to establish why the "achievement ethic," the hunger for traditional notions of success, has not permeated the inner city, or how social and economic forces grease the path toward failure.
And then there is politics, which Mr. Lewis, who spent the 1996 Presidential campaign mostly with candidates who failed, calls one of the few fields in American life with room for "noble failure" -- the principled and damned quest, waged by men like Ralph Nader or John McCain.
But even principle does not necessarily make defeat palatable. Mr. Lewis said that he wanted to title his last book, on the 1996 presidential campaign, "Losers," but his publisher refused. Mr. Lewis said he was told there is no market in America for failure.

HEADLINE: Philippine Leader Vows to Alter Constitution Despite Protests

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: MANILA, Aug. 20

 BODY:
President Joseph Estrada said he would go ahead with plans to amend the Constitution, despite protests today by tens of thousands of people who said the changes could endanger the country's democracy.
The protests, in Manila and other major cities, resembled in some ways the revolt that toppled the late dictator Ferdinand Marcos in 1986, with seas of yellow-clad protesters, confetti and the backing of former President Corazon Aquino and Roman Catholic Church leaders. 
 This time, however, protesters acknowledged that the issues are much less clear. Mr. Estrada, who won a landslide victory 15 months ago, remains highly popular and has pledged that only economic provisions of the Constitution will be revised to attract more foreign investment.
"We are not saying that this administration is like the Marcos regime -- but we do have cause to worry," said Mrs. Aquino, whose Government wrote the Constitution after Mr. Marcos's ouster. She and other protesters said they want to prevent a slip back into dictatorship.
However, the President said today that he plans to proceed with the amendments and insisted that he only wants to help the poor.
"I did not become President to preside over a society where the poor become poorer and the rich become richer," he said. "Why is this happening? One of the reasons is because we don't have enough money in our economy to address the needs."
Mr. Estrada argues that the Constitution is overly protectionist and must be overhauled to attract foreign investors.
He wants to remove provisions that bar foreigners from owning land and that limit foreign ownership of businesses in certain sectors to 40 percent.
The restrictions have caused the Philippines to lose out on investment to its neighbors, he says.
But critics fear that the planned economic amendments might lead to political changes once the Constitution is opened to revision by members of Congress eager to extend their terms.
"Who will control the change?" Mrs. Aquino said to the thousands of people who marched in Manila's financial district, Makati, a center of protest against Mr. Marcos in the 1980's. "There is no sound reason to tinker with the Constitution."
A large yellow banner behind her read: "Stand up for democracy." Yellow was the symbol of the 1986 revolt.
Nearby was a statue of her husband, Benigno Aquino, a pro-democracy leader who was slain on Aug. 21, 1983, as he was returning from exile in the United States.
The issue of constitutional change has sharply polarized Filipinos and reverberated in financial markets. Earlier in the week, stock prices slumped to a six-month low while the peso hit a nine-month low. Share prices later recouped some of their losses.
The proposed changes are generally backed by big business, but some smaller companies fear they may be overwhelmed by foreign competition.
Critics also have said Mr. Estrada is attempting to muzzle a critical press and has allowed a return of cronyism, in which close presidential friends receive special economic favors. Mr. Estrada has denied both accusations.
"If the situation doesn't change, it could lead to another revolt," Bishop Vicente Navarro told a rally in Kabankalan in Negros Occidental province.
Rallies -- the first large-scale protests against Mr. Estrada -- were also held in Cebu, Davao, Baguio, Bacolod, Iligan and other cities.
Mrs. Aquino and Catholic Church officials also led rallies two years ago that forced President Fidel Ramos to halt constitutional amendments aimed at extending his term.

HEADLINE: Energy From Waste

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re an Aug. 11 editorial on the improving but fragile state of the Chesapeake Bay: 
 As you note, to have a sustainable poultry industry and meet Federal water-quality goals, regulation alone is not enough. We must have land-use rules that allow farmers to continue to grow chickens for the grocery shelf and dispose of waste in an environmentally sensitive way.
Few people want to face the economic impact of putting many of these farms out of business. However, there is technology that can convert poultry waste into electricity, generating renewable energy. To make this technology economically viable in Delaware and other states, Congress recently enacted a limited tax credit for those governments that use it. This is the kind of initiative needed to meet environmental challenges at the local level.
 
JACK TARBURTON
Secretary of Agriculture
Wilmington, Del., Aug. 18, 1999

HEADLINE: Political Memo;
A Gregarious Bush Warms to Politicking

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: ROANOKE, Va., Aug. 19

 BODY:
Former President George Bush's biggest problem, an old friend of his once suggested, was that he liked policy a lot more than politics.
Nobody who has watched him would ever say that about Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, who plunges into crowds -- a crowd of 10 at an airport late at night, a crowd of hundreds at a fund-raiser, a crowd of thousands at a rally -- with all the enthusiasm of Bill Clinton or Nelson A. Rockefeller or that formidable flesh-pressing Texan of yesteryear, Lyndon B. Johnson. 
 Nobody would ever mistake him for Vice President Al Gore.
It was obvious on a two-day campaign swing this week that Mr. Bush, the front-runner for the Republican Presidential nomination next year, has a lot of work to do on his platform style. Ideas he expressed with vigor and conviction in a private talk in his hotel suite came out sounding tired, flat and mechanical when he tried them later on a ballroom full of 400 New Orleans-area supporters who had given him at least $1,000 each.
Nor was there much on offer for the policy wonk. He wants to set his own pace and his own rhythm, Mr. Bush said, and to that end he plans to make a half-dozen major speeches starting next month. But Mr. Bush -- now referred to by newspapers around the country not as George W. Bush or even George W. but simply as W. -- demonstrated real mastery of one-on-one campaigning.
His style is an amalgam of East and Southwest, Yale and the oil patch. Call him the Madras Cowboy.
Watch him with a classroom full of second graders in Jefferson Parish, near New Orleans. After a relaxed discussion of how caterpillars turn into butterflies, a youngster asked him why the sun had a smiling face. Beats me, the Governor replied; why does the chicken cross the road? Well, his interlocutor said, the cow crosses the road to go to the mooovies.
Good television, of course, but something more as well: it gave the Governor a chance to promote the school, Jefferson Elementary, as a prime example of the kind of public-private partnership he wants to see more of -- in this case, Lockheed Martin and Shell Oil helping a school set up a computer laboratory and Internet connections.
Watch him, again, reading with a group of mostly black inner-city 6- and 7-year-olds at the West End Center for Youth here. When "hop" and "top" sound the same, Mr. Bush asked, what's that called?
"Rhyme."
"Right. Good."
I have two daughters the same age, he said, his hands resting on the shoulder of a tiny child with red and yellow pony-tail holders braided into her hair; what are they called?
"Twins."
"Right. Great."
He told them that his dog, Spot, had been born in the White House, and assured them that, no, he had not arrived in Roanoke by limousine.
By the time he finished, Mr. Bush had worked in a pair of plugs: one for reading as the key to the American Dream, another for more Federal aid to after-school facilities wholly or partly sponsored by church groups, as is the West End Center. Then he stopped for a chat on the playground with some older youths, and as he walked back to his van, Sam Sapp, lanky and 13, walked with him, an arm draped fraternally across the Governor's shoulder.
Then on to the Farmers' Market in downtown Roanoke, which has been around since 1882. It is a traditional local campaign stop, and 250 or 300 people had gathered on a hot August morning to meet a candidate in an election that is not 3 weeks or 3 months but 15 long months away.
Mr. Bush keeps saying it is much too early for long speeches, too early for debates. But his campaign is already an industrial-strength gig, with long motorcades, a private jet, staff and security people talking furtively into their sleeves, White House-style "bibles" detailing every move and seven video cameras (not to mention still ones, tape recorders and notebooks) following along.
Not even Dwight D. Eisenhower, a victor in history's greatest war just a few years before, had this kind of entourage this early in 1951.
Nothing seemed to faze Mr. Bush in the slightest as he moved slowly past market stalls stacked high with peaches, pole beans, Japanese eggplants and Silver Queen corn, the bounty of late summer in the Virginia Piedmont. After he had spent more than an hour shaking hands, posing for photographs, chatting about the military and the local museum and the weather, kissing a baby swathed in pink (and a grandmother or two as well), complimenting Gina Thomas on her "good-looking" family of four children and signing a lot of autographs, a man handed him a $100 bill and asked him to sign that.
"You must be doing pretty darn well," Mr. Bush said.
"Not as well as you and your father," the man replied, and the Governor, laughing, gave him a chummy punch on the upper arm.
Where did this come from, a campaign visitor asked, this knack for putting people at ease, this common touch. Well, Mr. Bush said pointedly, he grew up in Midland, Tex., and not in Greenwich, Conn., like his father. Then he thought a minute and added, "I must get it from my mother."
Except for one thing, it was a loosy-goosey, laughter-punctuated couple of days. Except for one big thing: the never-ending questions about drugs. Mr. Bush tried without much success to fend them off, insisting that he would not talk in any detail about the various "things," never specified, that he did 20 and more years ago and now regretted having done.
This is the same Governor Bush, of course, who has come down hard on young hard-drug users.
"I made the decision not to play the game," he said in a long talk aboard his campaign jet. "No float-a-rumor-and-force-him-to-answer. No more trash-mouth politics. No politics of personal destruction. The baby boomers who are so eager to purge their souls send a very mixed message to the young. You know, if George Bush did it when he was a kid, why can't I?
"Another thing -- people are being turned off politics by all this negativism. I can't control the nastiness and the ugliness of the system, but I sure can do my best to clean it up. People want it to end."
Mr. Bush has staked a lot on that proposition, and he is also betting that the public is repelled by President Clinton's sexual adventures. They want to know "who you are today, not who were you yesterday," he said, "and they want someone to bring dignity back into the White House."
He insisted that he was not bitter about Mr. Clinton's defeat of his father seven years ago, even though he described that defeat as "a pretty nasty experience, limping back into Houston the night before Election Day, knowing that you were beat." If he was bitter about anyone, he said, it would be Ross Perot, who he thinks tipped the election to Mr. Clinton.
But the President's involvement with Monica S. Lewinsky "embarrassed lots of people," Governor Bush said. "They long for someone they can trust, even though they're content with the economic situation. They give Clinton credit for all this prosperity."
One such person, he said, was a woman who approached him in Iowa several weeks ago and gave him a picture of her 3-year-old son.
"She told me to keep it, that she was counting on me to remember that I had a big responsibility," Mr. Bush said. "She was saying that the President had not lived up to his, I guess. But I don't think I can get elected President just by talking about Bill Clinton. He's fading into history. His time is over."
So he talks more obliquely, about the need for a change in leadership and in the nation's values. Two of his favorite lines relate to this. Over and over, he talks about ushering in "the responsibility era" and ending the present one, when "if it feels good, you do it, and if it goes wrong, blame someone else." He promises a "fresh start after a season of cynicism." Over and over, he insists that "prosperity alone is simple materialism" and calls for "a richness beyond money" available to all.
"The worth of America has never been proven by cities of gold," he said in New Orleans, as he has before, "but by citizens of character."
Details to follow on all that, but Mr. Bush is a bit more specific about national security policy. He senses that the American military services are dispirited, "because they think their role is not valued by our leaders" and because military spending has been cut too quickly. Yet he talks of a top-to-bottom reorganization that would lead, for example, to a single fighter-interceptor to be used by all branches of service. That idea has been floated before, only to generate considerable opposition from the services.
He backed President Clinton's action in Kosovo and endorsed his refusal "to let the United Nations act as the surrogate for the United States." He took a swipe at the Administration's Asia policy, arguing that China was a competitor of the United States, not a strategic ally.
But mostly, as the plane headed for Roanoke, the Governor talked politics, swapping tales of campaigns old and not so old, victorious and calamitous. He expected more attacks, he said, like the one started last week by Marilyn Quayle, the wife of former Vice President Dan Quayle, who dismissed Mr. Bush as "a frat boy" who had accomplished very little in life.
"People have tried that before, and it hasn't worked," he said. "Ann Richards called me 'Shrub' in the governor's race, and it backfired. But I like the give and take of campaigning anyway. I grew up with it."

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1737 words

HEADLINE: A Good Credit History, Indeed;
Opening the Books on American Business, 1841-1891

BYLINE: By JULIE FLAHERTY 

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Aug. 20

 BODY:
With his large hands clad in delicate white gloves, Travis B. Blackman gingerly opened the sheepskin-bound book and blew gently on the onion-skin-thin pages to separate them. He treated the aged volume with the reverence normally reserved for a first-edition Dickens or Hemingway.
But all this fuss over a credit report? Or rather, over 2,580 volumes of handwritten credit reports that date back to 1841 and run through 1891. As unromantic as it sounds, for people who study the wheelings and dealings of days gone by, the R. G. Dun & Company Collection at Harvard University is the Holy Grail of business history. 
 For within the books' light blue pages, written in curvaceous script, are titillating details about whether a particular businessman drank too much or attended church, if he got his money from his rich wife or his business was a front for a brothel.
Ne'er-do-wells are boldly named, like one storekeeper in Halifax County, N.C., who in June of 1873 was referred to as a "purchaser of stolen goods, a great scamp." Long before the existence of the Securities and Exchange Commission or the annual stockholder meeting, it was the credit report that told the real dirt on a business.
"These volumes represent the creation of a national business network," said Mr. Blackman, who oversees the use of the archives for what is now the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation, which donated them to the university in 1962. "Every nook- and-cranny village on the frontier, somebody was there sending a report to the company."
And these days, more people are noticing. The number of people poring over the collection almost doubled over the last three years, from about 900 in 1995 to approximately 1,700 in 1998. Mr. Blackman, who must sign off on all the books and theses that quote the Dun collection, said that a few years ago, he might have reviewed one or two manuscripts a month. Now he sees five or six.
Laura Linard, director of historical collections at the library, said use has increased significantly because more scholars appreciate the worth of business records. It is the most used of all the library's historical records, to the point that Ms. Linard is a little frightened for its safety. "The collection is very, very fragile," she said. "It's in incredibly poor condition, because these books were used during their lifetime, consistently, constantly."
To scholars, the credit assessments are invaluable for piecing together American business history, in part because they avoid corporate spin and show the view of a third party -- in this case, the agents, or "correspondents," across the nation who reported back to R. G. Dun's home office on the creditworthiness of local carpenters, grocers and lightning-rod makers.
Robert C. Kenzer, a history professor at the University of Richmond, recently trawled the books for information on Civil War widows who took over their husbands' businesses. "They were broad in their perspective," Mr. Kenzer said of the Dun reporters. "They rate the elite and they rate the common people. Right next to the Rockefellers you find someone you've never heard of."
A June 1870 entry on one J. B. Alford, who sold groceries and liquors, read: "This man is said to be in thriving circumstances. He has some Real & personal estate & I think it is safe to trust him." Alas, the December 1876 entry read, "Failed abt 3 mos ago & went into Bankruptcy."
Sociologists and historians like Mr. Kenzer use the archives to study the growth of a particular industry, like pottery, or a specific topic, like Jewish-owned businesses before the turn of the century. Over the last 20 years, Mr. Kenzer has made many trips to Boston, researching subjects like black-owned businesses in the South. Once, he spent six weeks copying every page of one ledger. "It's pretty exhausting work," he said. "Fortunately, they had good handwriting."
It sounds like the kind of summer reading only a number-cruncher could love, and Harvard business students seem to agree. For although the archive is housed in the Baker Library at the School of Business Administration, it is used infrequently by Harvard's M.B.A. candidates, most of whom are more concerned with strategic mapping and venture capital than the cost of antebellum dry goods. Only scholars with very good reasons -- and white gloves -- are allowed to handle the fragile books. The library no longer allows genealogical research.
Still, there are lessons from the past that young executives could take with them into the business world. For starters, there is the danger of first impressions. One entry from June 1863 reports that a produce merchant named J. D. Rockefeller "is not much of a businessman, but had some capital, it is said, advanced by his father, who is reputed well off." He turned out to be a good credit risk; that was the year he set up a refinery that blossomed into Standard Oil.
Then there is the power of courtesy, as demonstrated in some handwritten requests for payment. Who wouldn't cave at this gentle entreaty: "If you will kindly favor us with a check at your convenience, you will much oblige"?
The Dun correspondents were often inspiring in their objectivity, for although they reported on the race or religion of a business owner, as was common at the time, those facts did not necessarily affect their rating of someone's business acumen. Women, it seems, could sometimes get credit when men could not, because, as one researcher found, they were seen as "cautious" and "economical."
Drinking was another matter. "If you were intemperate, they were not going to extend you credit," Mr. Kenzer said. Ponder the fate of G. H., an Ontario innkeeper, listed as "fond of drinking and gambling. Considered bad stock unsafe for credit."
Millennium watchers might take comfort in the business disasters of the past. Mr. Kenzer, who is starting research on the Chicago fire of 1871, said: "The problem wasn't just the people who were burned out. You don't know who you owe money to, or who owes money to you."
"It might be similar to a Y2K issue," he said. "How do you recover when you lose a lot of information?" Chicago, after all, bounced back fairly quickly.
One can get a snapshot of the early career of businessmen like Frank Winfield Woolworth, who borrowed $300 from former employers to open "The Great Five Cent Store" in Utica, N.Y., in 1879. Or of the catalogue tycoon Richard Warren Sears, a telegraph operator from Minnesota who started a business in mail-order watches and in 1887 took up with a young watchmaker named Roebuck.
Surprisingly, Lewis Tappan, the founder of what would become Dun & Bradstreet, did not like the idea of credit. Mr. Tappan was a Calvinist whose motto was "Owe no man anything but to love one another." But after a depression in the early 1800's left businesses in tatters, the practical Mr. Tappan saw that lenders needed to know whom they could trust to pay debts. Twice a year, correspondents would send their reports to Mr. Tappan's office in New York, then called the Mercantile Agency. The subscribers or their personal clerks could come to the office to hear credit reports on their business associates, read in discreet whispers.
Robert Graham Dun took over the agency in 1859, and it would be known as R. G. Dun & Company until it merged with its main competitor, the Bradstreet Company, in 1933. Throughout that time, credit reporting grew along with American business. When the railroad expanded business horizons, correspondents traveled west to report on saloonkeepers and cattle ranchers. One correspondent wrote of his work: "One method was to go on the railroad as far as possible, then to visit the towns on horseback. I traveled many miles on the hot plains of Texas by saddle, buckboard or mail hack."
Among the correspondents, usually lawyers who received fees for collecting debts, were four future presidents: Ulysses S. Grant, William B. McKinley, Grover Cleveland and Abraham Lincoln. After Lincoln's assassination, an agency clerk marked up an entry on the President, drawing a weeping willow tree and a grave marker and writing in the words: "This office has had the honor of having Old Abe as a correspondent."
Mr. Grant's commentaries could be especially colorful: He reported that a particular young lawyer he evaluated had nothing but an office chair, a barrel with a board for a desk, and a fine young wife. Still, he argued that ability and ambition were as important as capital, and recommended credit.
Executives of the last century were sometimes branded by the company they kept. In 1869, a correspondent wrote that Hannah Griffith, a milliner in Springfield, Ill., was "about to marry a fellow of no account." An entry two years later noted, with some relief, that that plan had fallen through.
Modern credit write-ups, of course, are far less prying, not even denoting whether a business executive is a Mr. or a Ms. The streamlining came about through a natural technological evolution. With the introduction of things like typewriters, telephones and fax machines to do the reporting and computers to do the analyzing, it was easier to have some sort of consistency in the reports, and easier to compare businesses within particular industries.
More important, Dun's clients started demanding more facts and less gossip. "Social mores change," Mr. Blackman said. "All of a sudden our customers stopped asking whether a person drank to excess and started asking things like 'How is World War II affecting this manufacturer?"'
Indeed, today's reports are strictly factual, with their tabulations based on bills, suits, liens and government filings, information gleaned from enormous data bases. For all its pride in its almost 160-year history, Dun & Bradstreet might like to forget the references to a Jewish business owner as "another of the tribe" or the abbreviation "col'd" after the name of every black business. But it does allow today's researchers to track the role of different races and religions in the American economy.
Should 20th-century businesses fear that future generations will entertain themselves with their credit histories? Mr. Blackman said no: New information on a company supplants the old, and when a business closes, its file is left all but blank.
"There will not be anything like this ever again, as far as a snapshot of American business history," he said.

LENGTH: 678 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
WesternersSee a Toothless Japanese Giant

BYLINE: By JOSEPH KAHN 

 BODY:
The proposed merger of three Japanese banks into a behemoth with $1.3 trillion in assets poses little competitive threat to American or European banks, bankers and analysts said yesterday, nor will it do much to disrupt the push by foreign banks into Japan's home market.
Combining Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank, Fuji Bank and the Industrial Bank of Japan would create a powerhouse in assets alone -- not in global reach, profitability, technology or productivity. None of the banks is known abroad as an innovator. Facing loan losses at home, the three have been scaling back their international presence in recent years. 
 "Even if these banks consolidate their operations the way a U.S. bank would, which is not likely, they have pulled away from international markets, and a likelihood of a revived international push is low," said Diane Glossman, banking industry analyst at Lehman Brothers.
The subdued reaction to the planned merger contrasts sharply with the wariness toward Japanese banking power in the 1980's, when those banks financing corporate Japan's sweeping international expansion seemed poised to do to world banking rivals what Japanese electronics makers did to American television manufacturers. Even as recently as 1996, when the Bank of Tokyo merged with the Mitsubishi Bank to form what was then the world's largest bank in terms of assets, some rival bankers saw a rising competitive threat.
Japan's prolonged recession and troubled real estate loan portfolios have radically changed that image. Most foreign bankers say they are more concerned that a Japanese banking implosion might cause a world financial panic than they are about Japanese banks stealing customers from them.
"This is a purely defensive merger," said a senior executive at a leading American bank. "They are trying to protect themselves at home."
The banker said that none of the three banks were considered a sought-after partner for foreign banks. He also said that he did not expect the merger to curb the ability of foreign banks to lure customers away from Japanese banks.
Some American bankers view Japan's banking sector these days as handicapped, even crippled. The Japanese Government in recent years has continuously increased its estimate of bad loans. In February, the Government put the figure at 76 trillion yen ($600 billion), more than double a prevailing Japanese banking industry estimate.
All banks must set aside capital to cover failed loans, so every new yen in bad loans requires that almost that much be added to a loan reserve -- taking away money the banks might have been able to deploy profitably. For Japan in recent years, it has been a vicious cycle: several leading Japanese banks have flirted with falling below a widely accepted international standard for the amount of capital they have to support their loans, risking exclusion from international markets.
Most Japanese banks now promise that they will seek to reach American levels of profitability. But they have a long way to go. Some of the most profitable Japanese banks earn a 2 percent return on equity, a standard way of measuring profits, analysts say. Top American banks earn 5 to 10 times as much.
Measured by assets, many of the largest banks in the world are still Japanese -- though the recent combination of Deutsche Bank of Germany with the American company Bankers Trust made that the No. 1 contender. But sheer asset size does not really measure financial strength or sophistication.
Leading American banks now often serve corporate customers by helping them get access to stock and bond markets, rather than making loans and recording them on their books. Traditional ways of making and recording loans build assets quickly, but are not considered highly profitable. When American banks make corporate loans, they are often syndicated, or sold off to investors.
"You simply cannot equate asset size with financing power or skill sets," Ms. Glossman said. "American banks would be much larger than the Japanese banks if they did things the same way."

HEADLINE: EARTHQUAKE IN TURKEY: THE U.S. ROLE;
American Navy Ships Carrying Aid to Turkey

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20

 BODY:
Three Navy ships carrying more than 3,000 sailors and marines and tons of relief supplies are to arrive off the coast of Turkey this weekend, the spearhead of what is proving to be a large American military response to Turkey's devastating earthquake.
The Navy ships are crossing the Mediterranean and will be ready to provide medical care by Saturday evening, the Pentagon said. Pentagon officials said they scrapped plans to send several Air Force planes to Turkey to help fight fires set off by the earthquake because the fires had largely been contained. 
 The ships, led by the amphibious assault ship Kearsarge, carry 22 helicopters available for medical evacuations and have 6 operating rooms, 5 X-ray rooms and 60 hospital beds. The medical staff includes 8 doctors, 3 dentists, 88 medics and other medical specialists.
A separate 22-member Navy medical team from Naples arrived in Turkey today with 27,000 pounds of medical gear and surgical supplies, including intravenous fluids and anesthesia machines.
The Agency for International Development, which is overseeing the civilian response, said the United States had so far provided about $3 million in nonmilitary aid to Turkey.
Additional money will be committed later to support the reconstruction of towns and cities in Turkey ravaged by the earthquake.
"We're very much in the search-and-rescue phase of this operation," said Harriet C. Babbitt, the agency's deputy administrator.
The United States has depended heavily on Turkey, a NATO ally, in military operations in both the Balkans and the Middle East, and President Clinton said earlier this week that the United States "will do whatever we can to help them get through this terrible crisis."
A 70-member search-and-rescue team from Fairfax County, Va., outside Washington, has been at work in Turkey since Thursday morning, searching for survivors buried under the rubble of the city of Izmit, near the epicenter of the quake.
The team, which uses sniffer dogs and sophisticated electronic equipment in its searches, is under contract to the Agency for International Development and has so far rescued four people from collapsed buildings. It is to be joined this weekend by a second 70-member American rescue team, this one from Miami.
With whole Turkish cities in rubble, American relief officials said that Turkey's most pressing need was for tents and other temporary housing for hundreds of thousands of people forced from their homes. The Defense Department has said that it will provide up to 30,000 tents and more than 100,000 prepared meals.
Ms. Babbitt said the Administration was urging members of the public who wish to help Turkish earthquake victims to do so with money, not through donations of clothing, food or other goods that would take time to ship to Turkey. The Agency for International Development has established a toll-free telephone number to provide callers with a list of charity groups seeking contributions for earthquake relief: (800) 872-4373.

HEADLINE: Phelps Dodge Offers to Acquire Two Merging Copper Companies

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

 BODY:
Continuing a consolidation trend among basic commodity industries, the Phelps Dodge Corporation, the copper producer, made a bid yesterday and then sweetened it to acquire the Cyprus Amax Minerals Company and Asarco Inc., which themselves had just agreed to merge. The Phelps Dodge bid was promptly rejected.
But analysts say that Phelps Dodge's all-stock bid, which started at $2.4 billion and grew to $2.66 billion by day's end, may ultimately be hard for the newly combined targets to resist given the difficult economics of the copper industry. Prices are hitting rock bottom, there is global overcapacity and there are no apparent prospects for a change in this dismal combination. 
 "The Phelps bid is a bold move; it is a complex move, and, at the end of the day, it will prevail," said Vahid Fathi, a metals industry analyst with ABN Amro in Chicago. "The combined trio would be propelled to the top of the chain as the No. 1 producer. Truly, this is remarkable."
An equally bold note was sounded yesterday by Phelps Dodge's chief executive, Douglas Yearley, who said, in a call to analysts, "We are now prepared to take all necessary steps to make this happen." Among those, Mr. Yearley said, was perhaps raising the bid again.
Cyprus Amax, which is based in Englewood, Colo., and Asarco, based in New York, yesterday reaffirmed their intention of going it alone. On Thursday, the boards of the two companies met separately, and both voted to reject the Phelps Dodge bid, saying that the directors of both companies had "determined that pursuing the Asarco-Cyprus merger was in the best interests" of both companies' stockholders.
It is unclear whether Cyprus and Asarco are simply holding out for a higher price from Phelps Dodge or if they are firm in their determination to resist it. Also unclear is whether their shareholders will allow them to continue to reject this offer. The sweetened Phelps Dodge offer would give 0.4098 share of Phelps Dodge stock for every Asarco share and 0.3135 share for every Cyprus share.
At yesterday's closing price of $59.125 for Phelps Dodge, which was up 56.25 cents, this would be valued at $24.23 for every Asarco share, which rose $4 yesterday to close at $22.4375. And it would be valued at $18.54 for every Cyprus share, which rose $2.875 yesterday to close at $17.375. The sweetened Phelps Dodge offer values Cyprus at some $1.7 billion and Asarco at roughly $960 million.
"The question of should the shareholders accept is a pretty easy one," said Raymond Goldie, an analyst at St. James Securities in Toronto. "Cyprus and Asarco have given their shareholders returns in the minus-20 percent range, while Phelps has had something like a 160 percent return in the same time period. I'd take the money and run."
If the three-way deal goes through, it would create a company that would surpass Chile's state-owned Codelco as the world's top copper producer and would unite production in the copper-rich American Southwest. Right now the world copper market is being flooded with copper from Chile and Indonesia, where the mining costs are lower and the mines are newer. Many analysts expect that copper prices, which have plunged in the last few years, should remain relatively flat for the foreseeable future. Copper has been trading at around 70 to 75 cents a pound lately, the lowest levels in over a decade.
"The world is swimming in copper," said John C. Tumazos, an analyst with Sanford Bernstein & Company. "And North American companies realize they are in big competitive trouble. It's a given that things have to change."
Mr. Tumazos, however, said that Cyprus and Asarco shareholders might be persuaded by management to give the newly combined entity a chance on its own. That would leave Phelps Dodge, the world's No. 4 producer, out of a global merger wave unless it raised its bid even further. If it did so, it could run the risk of overpaying for assets.
Yesterday's bidding was part of a large consolidation trend sweeping not only copper but all basic commodities -- aluminum, chemicals and oils. Commodity giants have been pairing up to gain market share and reduce costs in a world flooded by raw-material overcapacity and declining demand. This week, the world's largest aluminum maker, Alcoa Inc., won agreement to acquire Reynolds Metals, which would make it even bigger. This comes on the heels of a three-way merger on both sides of the Atlantic to unite a Canadian, a Swiss and a French aluminum maker into one giant company rivaling Alcoa.
Cyprus and Asarco announced their merger plans in July, and have set a Sept. 30 date for shareholders to vote on the deal. Those two companies say this union will save $200 million in costs. Mr. Fathi of ABN Amro said that a merger with Phelps Dodge could realize another $200 million in savings by eliminating redundant operations.
J. Clarence Morrison, an analyst with Prudential Securities, said a three-way deal "makes a great deal of sense" for all three companies.
"There needs to be a lot of rationalization of copper assets in the United States, and this has been discussed at considerable length through the years," he said. But when asked whether Phelps Dodge would be successful in its quest, Mr. Morrison responded: "It's too early to tell."

HEADLINE: Federal Budget Showed Deficit Last Month

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 20

 BODY:
The Federal Government had a budget deficit of $25.16 billion in July as money flowing into the Treasury slowed after an influx from quarterly income tax payments the month before. But the Government is still on track to post a big surplus this year.
The Treasury Department said today that last month's budget deficit of $25.16 billion was slightly higher than the $24.08 billion deficit reported in July 1998. 
 In July this year, Government spending totaled $147.07 billion, while receipts totaled $121.91 billion.
Government receipts from individual income tax payments in July came to $59.98 billion, after totaling $92.99 billion the month before. And corporate income tax payments totaled just $3.4 billion, compared with $39.26 billion in June.
For the first 10 months of the fiscal year 1999, which began on Oct. 1, 1998, the Government posted a surplus totaling $69.11 billion, up from the $42.98 billion surplus for the corresponding period last year.
In its midyear economic forecast, the Clinton Administration projected that the surplus, which totaled $69.2 billion in 1998, will climb to $98.8 billion in the current fiscal year, which ends on Sept. 30, and $142.5 billion in 2000. Congressional accountants are predicting a surplus of about $120 billion for all of 1999.
Last year, the Government had its first surplus since 1969. Assuming Administration projections come through, this will be the first back-to-back surpluses since 1956-57.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Latin America Confronts New Uncertainty

BYLINE: By SIMON ROMERO 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, Aug. 20

 BODY:
Latin America's currency and bond markets came under pressure today as worries over the possibility of default by Ecuador, one of the smaller Latin countries, collided with concern that political gridlock would slow the region's juggernaut, Brazil.
Ecuadorean officials assured investors that the Government would not default on a $93.5 million bond payment later this month, but markets were skeptical. Ecuadorean bonds plunged more than 11 percent on speculation about a default. 
 An Ecuadorean default would be the first on Brady bonds, the repackaged securities designed by the former United States Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady, which helped Latin America emerge from a debt crisis in the 1980's.
Brazilian markets, which often come under selling pressure when troubles emerge in Latin America, showed unusual signs of strain. Brazil's currency, the real, weakened nearly 3 percent. It fell almost 2 reais to the dollar, its lowest value in five months, before rebounding to 1.89 on news that the Government sold six-month dollar-linked bonds, offering investors protection against further falls in the currency. In New York, the real settled at 1.99 to the dollar, down from 1.94 on Thursday.
Brazilian bonds were mixed. A basket of Brazil's dollar debt lost as much as nine-tenths of a percent, according to J. P. Morgan & Company. The widely traded "C" bond gained as much as nine-tenths of a percent, to 58.813, with the yield narrowing to 16.970 percent.
In neighboring Argentina, where the economy has been hurt by a drop in commerce with Brazil, rising borrowing costs added to concern about other countries in the region. Moody's Investors Service placed the nation's credit ratings on review for possible downgrade today, a move that led Argentine bonds to fall in tandem with the debt of other Latin American countries.
Ecuador, which in population and economic might is substantially smaller than Brazil or Argentina, accounts for just a sliver of investors' holdings of Latin American securities. Yet the psychological effect of a rapidly deteriorating economy there, and of concern that neighboring countries could be influenced if it defaults, has led to a fresh assessment of risk throughout the region.
"The potential for contamination is there," said Arturo Porzecanski, the chief economist for the Americas at ING Barings. "Just like Russia showed the world a former superpower could default, Ecuador could show its neighbors that avoiding a moratorium is not sacred."
As problems in Ecuador prompted some investors to trim their exposure to Brazil, growing concern over the ability of President Fernando Henrique Cardoso's administration to control spending led to additional anxiety. There have been several examples in recent days of pressure on Government finances.
This week, thousands of farmers marched on Brazil's capital city, Brasilia, to call for a reworking of about 11 billion reais, or $5.7 billion, in debt owed to state-controlled financial institutions. Although Mr. Cardoso refused to accede to their demands, Congress overwhelmingly showed support for the farmers. And it is in Congress that the President hopes to win approval for austerity measures to prevent a worsening of the budget deficit.
At the same time, members of Congress began considering raising their own pay. If the raises are approved, cries for similar pay increases could cascade throughout the civil service. Worries that the central Government may assume some debt obligations of state administrations contributed to the gloom over its effectiveness in dealing with these challenges.
"Brazil did a very good job handling the economy in the first half of the year, but the challenge now is political rather than economic," said Carlos Novis Guimaraes, the head of investment banking for Latin America at Lehman Brothers.
Some indicators show an improvement in the economy, among them rising direct foreign investment, which climbed 64 percent, to $17.1 billion, in the first half of this year. Such inflows of long-term capital helped fuel the second consecutive quarter of economic growth.
Yet concern over the deficit or over problems in neighboring countries could keep the central bank from lowering interest rates, now at 19.5 percent. That possibility adds to anxiety over the effect that such rates have on public finances, because the Government needs to pay higher premiums on its bonds to attract investors.
"Latin America is hurt by these momentary spikes of concern," said Thomas Trebat, an economist with Salomon Smith Barney. "But really, what we see after taking a deep breath is a region that's lagging the rest of the world into recovery. Problems that put a chill on capital flows now will be forgotten by next year."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japan Merger Of Three Banks Signals a Trend

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 20

 BODY:
Japan signaled the start of a far-reaching consolidation of its bloated and debt-ridden banking system today with official word that three of the country's biggest banks would unite to form the world's largest financial institution.
The merger agreement announced by Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank Ltd., Industrial Bank of Japan Ltd. and Fuji Bank Ltd. was viewed by economists and investors as a significant change, but not because of the combination's colossal size. Rather, they said it would hasten mergers among other Japanese banks, winnowing the weakest and helping to reduce what has been one of the biggest drags on the Japanese economy. 
 While executives of the three Japanese merger partners said they were determined to become a global force, American and European banks saw little competitive threat from the combination, nor did they see it as an obstacle to a push by foreign banks to enter Japan's market. Page C2.
Banks in Japan have suffered from years of bad loans, low profits and antiquated technology despite numerous Government efforts to strengthen the system. Many continue to lose money or are marginally profitable but there has been little pressure on them to find partners. Analysts said the three-way tie-up announced today, which was strongly endorsed by Government officials, suggested that era was over.
"Size of course is not everything, but this does show a major change in the mindset of Japanese bank management," said J. Brian Waterhouse, an analyst for HSBC James Capel. "Up until this year, Japanese banks were determined to be independent, and suddenly we have three major banks getting together."
The announcement caused a surge in bank shares on the Tokyo Stock Exchange, as investors bet that the 18 major Japanese banks would eventually fall to fewer than half that number and make the survivors far more profitable simply by reducing the number of competitors.
The three-way alliance, which the partners hope to formally establish by the fall of 2000, would create a giant with $1.3 trillion in assets, the benchmark for measuring a bank's size.
It would dwarf the current world leader, Deutsche Bank, which has $866 billion in assets, as well as the biggest bank in the United States, Citigroup, which has $668 billion. The bank would be twice the size of what is now the largest bank in Japan, the Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi, which has about $580 billion in assets.
"Although we will be the world's top bank in terms of assets, we will not remain content just at that," Masao Nishimura, Industrial Bank's chief executive, told a news conference. "We aim to be among the world's top five banks in terms of capital, profits, services and other areas."
The union of three major Japanese banks comes at a time when there have been signs of a revival in the Japanese economy, which has been experiencing the worst recession since World War II. The yen, the most visible symbol of the country's economic might, has risen to the strongest levels in seven months. Japan's stock market has soared this year on a bet by many international investors that the country may finally be turning around.
The banking merger in Japan also comes against a backdrop of consolidation among the biggest banks elsewhere. Deutsche Bank recently acquired the Bankers Trust Corporation of the United States; Citicorp and Travelers Inc. merged in the United States; UBS was created through the combination of Switzerland's two biggest banks, and Banque Nationale de Paris is acquiring control of a rival, Paribas.
Under the Japanese merger deal, the three partners will put their retail banking, investment banking, and brokerage subsidiaries under common management and cut costs by combining overlapping businesses. The banks said that by uniting, they also expected to save on the huge costs of installing new information technology.
The banks said that once the merger becomes complete they plan to eliminate 6,000 jobs, reducing the entire work force to about 29,000 people, and cut the total number of branches from the current 704 to 620.
Some analysts said that the employee reductions did not go far enough and reflected what they called a resistance on the part of Japanese banks to shed one of the biggest drains on profitability, a bloated work force.
"Despite their size, I'm rather skeptical that they can compete on an international scale unless they undertake some serious restructuring," said Toru Nakakita, a professor of economics at Toyo University. "I hate to say this but I think we've created another Titanic: we have the biggest bank in the world but it's certainly not the most competitive."
Others said that unless such mergers make banks more profitable, they would not help the banks absorb the hundreds of billions of dollars in bad debts that still litter their books. The Government has sought to help by cutting interest rates to nearly zero, which lowers the cost of borrowing for the banks, and has injected money into the largest banks to strengthen them. But many of these old debts, vestiges of loans made during the speculative real estate boom in the 1980's, will never be repaid.
"It's evident that this Government is better at reforming the banking system than previous governments," said Mary Davis, chief economist for emerging markets in Asia at Credit Suisse First Boston in London. If such mergers strengthen the banks she said, "it could be a significant development, but they've had this enormous bad-debt problem which they have just begun to address and there's so much more to do."
Despite the size of the three-way merger, industry officials and analysts said today that they doubted Japanese regulators would challenge it as anticompetitive.
"Regulators think that there are too many banks in Japan, so merging banks makes it easier to improve profits," said Yoshinobu Yamada, an analyst for Merrill Lynch. "I'd be surprised if the Government tries to block this."
Indeed, Hakuo Yanagisawa, chairman of the Financial Reconstruction Commission, Japan's regulatory body, said: "We sincerely welcome the move, which meets expectations for creating a top-notch institution from Japan that can withstand stiff international competition."
The shares of all three banks, which rose Thursday on news that they were in talks, surged today on the announcement of a deal. Shares of Dai-Ichi Kangyo gained 11 percent, Fuji rose 9.4 percent and Industrial Bank of Japan was up 10.2 percent. The Tokyo Stock Exchange's bank index, a measure of bank stocks, rose 10.2 percent.
The three banks are among 15 major Japanese banks that received 7.5 trillion yen (about $675 billion) in public funds from the Government to help resolve their huge loan problems.
In exchange for the cash infusion, the banks agreed to revamp their operations and become more profitable. The banks are now under pressure to make good on those promises.
Officials of the three banks that plan to unite said today that they would concentrate investment in computer systems for payment settlements, management of data bases, credit risk assessments and other electronic banking operations.
Most Japanese banks are far behind their foreign competitors in the use of computer systems.
Under the agreement, the three banks will jointly establish a holding company by the fall of 2000. Bank operations will be gradually integrated into the holding company over two years.
Individual shares of the three banks will be exchanged for a new share in the holding company, which will be listed on stock exchanges after the three banks exit the exchanges, the banks said.
Two other major Japanese banks confirmed today their intention to combine operations under a similar holding company arrangement, which could also lead to a merger.
In response to inquiries from local reporters, a spokesman for Tokai Bank Ltd. and Asahi Bank Ltd. said that the two institutions planned to establish a joint holding company in the year 2001. The banks originally announced their intention to form a link last September.
The combined assets of the two banks are about $531 billion, which would make the new entity Japan's second-largest bank and the seventh largest worldwide.
"It's not scale that we are aiming for in this union," said Tsuyoshi Yamashita, a spokesman for Tokei Bank.
"We are investing in our ability to offer customers a wider range of products. For example, it's too costly for us to do investment banking alone, so we are seeking mutual effectiveness with our merger."

Off the Endangered List
Interior Secretary Bruce Babbitt took the peregrine falcon off the endangered species list. Pesticides devastated the falcon population in North America and Europe to the point that in 1970 there were only 39 breeding pairs in the continental United States, all west of the Mississippi. The United States Fish and Wildlife Service now estimates that more than 1,650 breeding pairs live in North America. Experts say about 6,000 of the birds, raised in private and government centers, have been released into the wild. Falcons can reach speeds of 200 miles an hour as they swoop down on their prey, which include ducks and pigeons. (AP)

SECTION: Section A; Page 4; Column 4; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 842 words

HEADLINE: Paris Journal;
Solidarity and the Price of Apricots

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, Aug. 19

 BODY:
Sometimes the French really do seem to think differently.
In the country that Descartes imprinted with Cartesian logic, people side with transit workers when bus, rail and subway strikes make it impossible to get to work on time. 
 Drivers entering traffic at many intersections don't even cast a glance at cars approaching from their left. By the logic of French traffic rules, traffic from the right has priority and an accident would therefore, a priori, be illogical.
And because paid vacations have been a right only since the 1930's, and are a scrupulously observed August rite now, Paris shuts down at the height of summer, leaving hordes of tourists to fend for themselves. Therefore, the most celebrated ice cream parlor in town, La Glacerie Berthillon on the Ile Saint-Louis, is closed for vacation until Sept. 1.
And logically, at the height of the summer fruit and vegetable season, prices should be lower. But by a logic perhaps only the French can understand, fruit and vegetable producers are hoping that a new Government regulation requiring retail stores to post the wholesale prices they paid for the produce alongside the retail price -- which is always much higher -- will pressure wholesalers to pay the producers more.
What would American consumers do on learning that the price they pay for apricots at the supermarket, the equivalent of $1.48 a pound at the G20 supermarket in Paris this week, cost the store 70 cents or less at the wholesale market? Ask the store to pay more for the fruit wholesale, or to charge customers less?
"You're thinking capitalistically," a Frenchman who understands Americans well, Prof. Patrice Higonnet of Harvard University, explained to an American in Paris. "This is French republican thinking."
By Gallic logic, French consumers seeing the wholesale and retail prices on the shelves will side with underdog farmers, just as they do with underdog railway workers, and show their solidarity by pressuring wholesale distributors to be fairer to producers, explained one farmer, Guy Savanier, from his apricot orchard and vineyard near Nimes.
"The consumer will know that every product with two prices listed is a product in difficulty," Mr. Savanier said. "We hope they will buy more, which will increase demand and raise prices."
That sounded like economic logic, but Mr. Savanier hoped there would be something more. "We also expect a civic attitude by distributors, in the sense that they will accept a more equitable sharing of profit margins," he said.
Ergo, French supermarkets, the villains in Mr. Savanier's eyes, will pay producers more for French fruit and vegetables, but not raise supermarket retail prices. "We don't want consumers to pay more," he said.
Last Saturday, 200 farmers blocked the center of the historic Rhone River city of Avignon with 2,500 shopping carts to protest falling prices. The day before, the Minister of Agriculture, Jean Glavany, posted an order requiring supermarkets to list both wholesale and retail prices for peaches, nectarines, apricots, melons and pears for a month, for grapes and apples for two months, and for tomatoes and cucumbers for three months.
"We're not naive," Mr. Savanier said. "We'll see what happens and decide what to do then."
Nothing will happen, Christian de Boissieu, an economics professor at the Sorbonne, told the daily Figaro on Monday.
"The producers are counting on consumers to put pressure on distributors," he said. "But even if this solidarity mechanism comes into play, it has no way of influencing the prices paid to producers, which depend on many other factors like handling and transportation costs, without mentioning phenomena like overproduction.
"It's hard to imagine the consumer writing letters to supermarket managers accusing them of pocketing scandalous profit margins."
Chouki Abebessa, who runs a vegetable store on Rue de la Pompe in Paris, agreed. "Consumers know there's a markup, and if the quality is good enough, they're willing to pay for it," he said. "Telling them what the supermarket paid won't change anything."
Michel-Edouard Leclerc, the head of a chain of supermarkets that bears his name, called the new regulation "a political solution responding to a demand by agricultural unions that won't make prices rise."
He told the daily Liberation that when supermarkets eventually posted wholesale prices, they would be national averages provided by the Ministry of Agriculture, not the actual prices supermarkets negotiate with producers' cooperatives, which are jealously guarded trade secrets.
Mr. Savanier said heavy spring frosts last year cost him most of his grape crop, and now bumper fruit crops were making him sell at a loss.
"I got as little as 3 to 3.50 francs a kilogram for apricots this year," he said, the equivalent of about 25 cents a pound for the fruit that G20 was getting $1.48 for today. "The average loss for medium-size orchards around here this year has been 500,000 to 700,000 francs," he said, roughly $83,000 to $116,000.
