HEADLINE: ART REVIEWS;
Collective Spaces, but Individual Visions

BYLINE: By Phyllis Braff 

 BODY:

April Gornik
Glenn Horowitz Bookseller, 87 Newtown Lane, East Hampton. Through Sept. 19. 324-5511.
 
 In the last 20 years, April Gornik has built a strong reputation as a painter of moody, introspective landscapes that create a sense of otherworldly dislocation. Solemn, with a haunting stillness, they can also seem challenging and oddly confrontational as they pit reality against imaginative visions and the privacy of dreams against the inherently public character of landscape.
Her large canvases are well known, but the smaller-scale works featured in this exhibition will come as a revelation. Their power to transport proves it is possible to detach from perceptual links to the outside world without the aid of a sizable painting surface. In fact, the smaller scale actually provides an accessible, concentrated force and makes the suggestion of mystery all the more absorbing.
Emphasizing sky, water and forest, these non-specific, unpeopled scenes frequently achieve the quality of suspended time.
Physical dimensions compress the intense light establishing the emotional spell in each painting. The illumination is broad and compelling, and sometimes appears to follow the viewer. Often, the light source is behind the configuration of trees, rocks or land masses, creating shadows that thrust into the foreground and add to the sense of visual involvement. "The Seine Imagined" and "Rocks and Reflections" are especially good examples.
Extreme tonal contrasts allow configurations to be interpreted as crisp, flat, nearly abstract shapes. Everything has equal importance across the surface and seems carefully calculated for maximum effect.
 
'As American as . . .'
Parrish Art Museum, 25 Job's Lane, Southampton. Through Sept. 19. 283-2118.
At any number of points in this large exhibition, subtitled "100 Works From the Collection," there is cause to admire the smart, sensible interpretation of the museum's holdings. The installation consistently delivers visual and intellectual messages, and it underscores the importance of context in art presentations. An obvious but nevertheless satisfying example based on strong paintings is the juxtaposition of references to artists' studios in Phillip Guston's "Visitors" and Jim Dine's "Little Blue Palette."
Basically. the show is about the subjects and themes, styles and approaches that have fleshed out 19th- and 20th-century American art. The paintings and drawings are not all first-rate, but everything plays its role in the sequences of small essays organized by the guest curator, Klaus Kertess, and the museum's curator, Alicia Longwell.
Early on, the genre paintings seem appropriate for a young nation that valued work and the rights of the individual. A nice touch is the pairing of pieces by Tompkins H. Matteson (1849) and Hughie Lee-Smith (1958), which are linked by an interest in human emotion. Although the styles are quite different, both capture moments of psychological tension between a man and a woman.
A portraiture section begins with 19th-century canvases that have rich potential for symbolic readings, and goes on to include Alex Katz and Chuck Close. In another grouping, the sitter is treated as part of a powerful composition in works by Larry Rivers, William Merritt Chase and Robert Henri.
Landscape groupings make points about attitudes, meanings and use. Seascapes raise some similar issues and are wonderfully displayed under the sweeping natural illumination that falls from the gallery skylight. Other sequences call attention to American abstraction in the 1940's through examples by Peter Busa and Will Barnet, and to gestural and organic abstraction in the next decade.
This tribute to the collection receives a vibrant boost from one of the newest additions: a bold airplane-and-ship composition by Malcolm Morley that combines psychological resonance with precise structuring.
 
'Vintage New York'
Hofstra Museum, Hempstead Turnpike, Hempstead. Through Sept. 12. 463-5672.
As a visual spectacle, New York City has long held iconic status. The richness and range of the imagery that documents its history inspired this traveling exhibition of about 70 etchings, engravings and photographs dating from 1850 to the present. Most pieces are either by anonymous artists or by those who never achieved fame, and a number of the earliest works are from 19th-century periodicals like Harper's Weekly.
Translations of newsworthy events into dramatic images provide much of the show's value. Granville Perkins, easily the most distinguished artist here, was responsible for the powerfully drawn "Brooklyn Theater Fire, 1876."
Other strong designs that convey the vitality of a special moment date from the 1880's and include depictions of the stampede and panic on the Brooklyn Bridge one week after its opening; the fireworks accompanying a demonstration by 30,000 people in Union Square on behalf of Grover Cleveland, and the huge cloth sheet -- a forerunner of a billboard -- hung in Madison Square to proclaim, "Harrison carries the state by 12,000!"
Weighing things down a bit are city images prepared in the spirit of a nostalgic souvenir, and a few mundane examples by artists intrigued the with the sculptural character of buildings observed against an unbroken sky.
Momentum revives, however, in the selections portraying social history. A view of hundreds of women sewing clothing in a department store and another of an immigrant tailor receiving garments gathered by his family are among those that make a significant impact.
Joys and fears stand out, too. A clever pairing juxtaposes a photograph of turn-of-the-century street entertainers with one of long-haired 1960's street musicians playing guitars. There is also a wonderful 1890 view of crowds cheering the carriage races in Madison Square Garden.
Major social and economic troubles receive a full measure of attention. Selections include an engraving of Wall Street during the panic of 1884 and a photograph of the same area at the height of the 1929 panic.

HEADLINE: Helping the Adoption Of Russian Children

BYLINE: By CYNTHIA MAGRIEL WETZLER 

DATELINE: YORKTOWN HEIGHTS

 BODY:
THE best thing about her family is having a mother and father and a brother, said Zoe Berman, 6, who was adopted in 1994 from an orphanage in Yoshkar Ola, a town 600 miles east of Moscow in Russia.
Zoe's mother, Karen Klein Berman of Larchmont, national chairwoman of Families for Russian and Ukrainian Adoption -- which opened its Westchester chapter in 1997 -- a support network of 2,000 members for adoptive families with children from the former Soviet Union, said: "Zoe is fantastic. She has artistic talents and athletic abilities I could never give birth to biologically." 
 Zoe is among the many Russian children adopted by American families. In 1998 the United States Embassy's immigrant visa unit in Moscow issued 4,521 immigrant visas to Russian orphans adopted by American citizens, making Russia the No. 1 source of foreign adoptions for American families.
Many adoptive parents with well-adjusted children say Russian orphans have been stereotyped as children with serious medical and emotional disorders. Dr. Andrew Adesman, director of the Evaluation Center for Adoption in New Hyde Park, said recently: "The media has concentrated on high-profile, unusual cases, which haven't reflected well on the whole adoption process. As a result, the all-important question has arisen, 'Are these children damaged goods?' All children who have spent an appreciable amount of time in an institution are at risk for developmental delays and/or emotional problems. There is neglect and undernourishment. But not every child at risk presents problems. Risk sounds scary. Yes, there are increased risks, but the majority do well."
Over the last five years, pre-adoption and post-adoption consultation services are more readily available, parents are more enlightened about risks and more children are adopted under the age of 1, Dr. Adesman said.
Dr. Boris Gindis, a psychologist specializing in international adoption evaluations and services in Suffern, said, "While there are no reliable statistics on the number of internationally adopted children in need of rehabilitative and remediation services, the majority of adoptions from overseas are rewarding, successful experiences."
Dr. Jane Aronson, director of International Adoption Medical Consultation Services in Mineola on Long Island, said: "Video and medical reports from Russia are limited, only a moment in time in a child's life in an institution. The decision to adopt is based on parents' intuition, what they see in a child's eyes. These reviews with prospective parents are tender experiences. I take them very seriously."
Terry and Francis Naumann, adoptive parents of biological siblings, Roland, 6, and Bea, 8, said, "We went into this with our eyes open." Bea was 3 when the Naumanns brought her home with her brother. She weighed 17 pounds and could not sit up. But, five years later, Ms. Naumann said, Bea is an active, normal, healthy child.
Because of the current economic crisis in Russia, a lack of food in orphanages leaves children undernourished. Many adopted children overcome their problems with affection, nutrition and perhaps remedial intervention. But some parents report a continuing effort to help an adopted child overcome early orphanage experiences.
The New York State chairwoman of Families for Russian and Ukrainian Adoption is Liz Evans of Katonah, who with her husband, Scott, have adopted two children from Russia. She can be reached at 232-9742 by those needing adoption information.
At a Fourth of July gathering here of Families for Russian and Ukrainian Adoption, where the Naumann family was the host, 22 adopted Russian children and their families had a barbecue with a group of Russian lawmakers. The Russians were visiting to learn about the American adoption process and to satisfy any doubts about the well-being of the children.
Nina Reznik, a representative from the Russian Parliament, said: "We have seen happy families and happy children. To actually see this is very important."
Barbara and Robert Wolff returned to their home in Yorktown Heights from St. Petersburg four months ago with Andrei, a 17-month-old baby with a bright smile and a round face. "He came from a caring orphanage," Mrs. Wolff said.
Ms. Naumann said: "Visiting an orphanage in Russia leaves an indelible impression on your soul. Parents going over to pick up a child bring an extra suitcase full of clothes, food and medicine."
She continued: "Families for Russian and Ukrainian Adoption is a buddy system with a Web site -- www.frua.org -- and a chat room. We help with the pre-adoptive paperwork, which can be daunting, and we plan social events where the kids can grow up knowing children who share their background." She touched her son Roland's cheek. "I just want to see more people go to Russia and get these kids," she said.
The average cost to adopt a child from Russia is $15,000 to $25,000, Ms. Nauman said. Adoptions are begun through adoption agencies specializing in international adoption.
Another organization involved in adoptions is the Bridge of Hope project, a collaboration between the Cradle of Hope international adoption agency in Washington and the Golden Bridge of Friendship, a nonprofit organization in Suffern, which brings Russian orphans 7 through 12 to the United States for a five-week summer stay. The children attend day camps and live with families that are considering adoption.
Lea Sigiel-Wolinetz, founder of the Golden Bridge of Friendship and organizer of the Bridge of Hope project, now in its third summer, said, "Our commitment is to find adoptive parents for all these children, but part of what we want is a cultural experience for them." The first year all 13 of the children that were brought to the United States were adopted. The second year 34 of 36 children were adopted. Fifty children came this year. Bridge of Hope barbecues and pool parties give prospective parents a chance to meet the children. Information about them is also available on the Internet at www.cradlehope.org and from Bridge of Hope at (301) 587-4400.
"I felt at first that maybe it would not be fair to the children to bring them here, thinking they are going to stay," Ms. Sigiel-Wolinetz said. "So we tell them they are coming for a vacation. The alternative, not bringing them, is worse. Older Russian children have virtually no chance of being adopted in Russia." All the children go back to Russia after the five-week stay. Russian adoptions, which may take several months, must be processed in Russian courts.
There is a growing trend, particularly among parents who have delayed their childbearing years, to adopt an older child, Ms. Sigiel-Wolinetz said. "Both parents and children need a second chance in their lives," she said.
George and Susan West of New Castle adopted Zhenya, now 11, two years ago through the Bridge of Hope program. Their biological daughter, Sophia, is 6. Ms. West said, "It was important for us to have a trial to check out the family dynamics. We fell in love."

HEADLINE: Island Heirlooms That Speak Volumes

BYLINE: By JENNIFER OLSHIN 

 BODY:
WHEN Bob McKay and his staff stumbled into a hidden chamber above the carriage house of the Hewlett family farm in Port Washington, they discovered a forgotten legacy. It was 1979, and this team of curators, architectural historians and property managers from the Society for the Preservation of Long Island Antiquities had uncovered a room filled with antiques spanning centuries, including the homestead's original door from 1711 and a map of what is now Route 25A, circa 1837. The trove above the carriage house linked six generations of Hewletts to their home and told stories of continuity and change in Long Island life.
Now, the society is taking a fresh look at this material in "Made on Long Island: Recent Discoveries in the Decorative Arts," on view at the society's gallery in Cold Spring Harbor. Concurrently, the East Hampton Historical Society has mounted "Made on Long Island: A Time to Remember," also focusing on the region's decorative arts over time. 
 For nearly four centuries, Long Island's shores have welcomed settlers from varied backgrounds, beckoned by personal freedoms and nature's bounty. Like the Hewletts, many Long Islanders can reconstruct their family trees, but far fewer have been able to imagine their heirlooms within the context of the region's broader history.
In the last 25 years, "we have been able to recover the lost cultural language of Long Island's earliest forebears," said Mr. McKay, the society's director. That language was first articulated in "Long Island Is My Nation," the exhibition and the accompanying book by Dean Failey, then its curator, produced by the society for the Bicentennial in 1976. The book, updated and reissued this year, serves as a guide to the current exhibitions.
"The process of discovery has been fascinating: sleuthing and poking around Long Island like detectives, piecing the history together with found anecdotes, documents and property," said Randy Staud inger, the society's exhibition installer. "The rule of thumb has always been that as long as someone has a barn, a loft or a cellar, nothing gets thrown away."
In the gallery, furniture, clocks, silver, textiles and paintings from the 17th to the 19th century breathe life into the Island's history. Groupings of material from specific families, like the Hewletts, the Coopers of Southampton, the Townsends of Oyster Bay, the Smiths of Smithtown and the Dominys of East Hampton illustrate the major stylistic influences and domestic context of the Island's cabinetmaking, metalsmithing and artistic patronage.
Lewis Samuel Hewlett, the patriarch, was an Englishman who became a prominent landowner on the Island in the early 18th century. Accordingly, the family's objects shown together offer case studies in the assimilation of English traditions into American cabinetmaking practices of the late 18th and early 19th centuries.
A double-paneled blanket chest, made around 1730, is of particular interest. Painted blue-green and constructed of framed panels simply joined together with pegs or nails, it has the basic form and construction characteristics of the rural chests made by English carpenter-joiners in the 16th and 17th centuries. This chest, however, was designed with "bun feet," compressed bulbous supports that are considered a sophisticated Northern European feature. The configuration of the double-paneled facade has no direct precedents in Europe and has been found only among Quakers living in Long Island. This combination of decorative elements from a variety of sources combined Anglo-Dutch American aspects common to many Long Island objects from the earliest period, as "Long Island Is My Nation" explains.
The show also includes Long Island products more similar to European forms. Resembling twisted ropes, vigorously "sausage-turned" horizontal elements join the legs of an early-18th-century table that once belonged to the Smiths of Smithtown and has its obvious roots in Elizabethan furniture design. Similarly, a rare cabinet on display indicates the Dutch influence in New York. This carved cabinet, with its stepped and molded cornice over deep panel doors, its sturdy mortise-and-tenon joints and its ball feet, is known as a kas, meaning cupboard, and directly derived from the Dutch kast form.
By the end of the 18th century, traditional styles had begun to be replaced by more contemporary styles, inevitable byproducts of the Island's increasing population and commercial traffic. "These objects underscore the fact that Long Island was close enough to the major urban centers for trade but far enough to develop its own traditions," Mr. McKay said.
Trade across the Sound with the Connecticut River Valley, Boston and Newport, R.I., was vital not only to Long Island's grain and whaling trades but also to the development of the decorative arts. Commercial traffic resulted in a cross-pollination of design ideas, as exemplified by the cabinetmaking of the Townsend family of Oyster Bay. A group of distinctive Oyster Bay furniture made or influenced by the Townsends exemplifies the links to Rhode Island cabinetry. A carved high chest of drawers reveals characteristics reminiscent of Rhode Island design, but the dovetails and joined construction point to its Long Island origins.
Another factor that affected Long Island design was the American Revolution. The Battle of Long Island and the subsequent British occupation destroyed property, divided people and disrupted many conventional craft traditions. The years after the war and the beginning of the 19th century, however, were characterized by an unprecedented expansion of towns, with encroaching industrialization, new commercial ventures and alternative craft systems.
The Dominy shop of East Hampton illustrates the continuum of tradition and evolution amid these political, economic and social changes. This extraordinary dynasty, typical of rural craftsmen, not only made furnishings and mill parts but also were active builders, farmers and prominent citizens for nearly three centuries. At Cold Spring Harbor, clocks, chests and chairs made by the Dominys, both before and after the Revolution, show the versatility of their skills and their adaptability to the changing tastes of their local patrons. The most recent discovery on display is a lap desk, signed by Nathaniel Dominy 5th in 1849 -- the very last known chapter in the Dominy oeuvre.
While the preservation society's show celebrates a variety of decorative leitmotifs running through the larger scope of Long Island design, the East Hampton show focuses on the factors and influences contributing to the local esthetic culture. Its centerpiece is a stunning array of Dominy clocks from 1772 to 1828. With their attenuated, sparsely ornamented cases and precise manufacture, these clocks are the signature Dominy form. This lineup of clocks, rarely exhibited side by side, forms a Dominy family tree, dramatically demonstrating the passage of time and commemorating the fourth century of the town's history.
Aside from Dominy productions, this show presents a variety of themes related to the decorative arts of East Hampton. In one corner, an imaginative homage to the Rev. Samuel Buell (1716-1798) has been assembled. Buell, the minister of the Presbyterian Church and first headmaster of Clinton Academy, arrived in East Hampton in 1746 from Coventry, Conn., and his influence on the decorative elements of the church meetinghouse was considerable. His portrait is displayed along with his own chair, table, hatbox, microscope, inkwell, cup and saucer, and across from these personal items, the painted pulpit of the meetinghouse is exhibited. As the gallery label indicates, this pulpit, commissioned around 1758 during Buell's tenure and attributed to the Connecticut carver Alexander Grant, effectively transported design ideas across the Sound.
The curators of this show remind the viewer that this small town, founded in 1648, experienced the same historical evolutions as other Long Island settlements.
"There are poignant stories connected to these objects," said Karen Hensel, director of the historical society. "We have pieces here that have returned to East Hampton after many years of ownership in other towns, and we have pieces that have never left our vicinity."
This exhibition is to be the first of several at the Clinton Academy this year. In each, the core collection of clocks will be surrounded by changing exhibitions of clothing, architectural elements and furniture.
"It's amazing that everything in history has touched Long Island," Mr. McKay said. "From the European settlement on, we were the maritime cradle, the cradle of aviation, of most of the major forms of American recreation, of suburbia. We played a role in the American Revolution, and the conflicts thereafter. Its as if everything had to pass by Long Island before it was set in history."
 
"Made on Long Island: Recent Discoveries in the Decorative Arts" remains on view through Dec. 6 at the Society for the Preservation of Long Island Antiquities, 161 Main Street, Cold Spring Harbor; 692-4664. "A Time to Remember" is on view through December at Clinton Academy, 151 Main Street, East Hampton; 324-1850.

HEADLINE: A New Tax With Extra Bite;
Nassau Levy Could Affect Home Sales

BYLINE: By JOHN McQUISTON 

 BODY:
THE tight real estate market in Nassau County, where demand for homes has far outpaced supply and pushed prices to record highs, may be getting even tighter and less predictable under the new 1 percent property transfer tax approved by the Nassau County Legislature to help bail the county out of debt.
The tax went into effect last Sunday, creating a rush to contract by anxious sellers, brokers and real estate lawyers who found themselves pleading with buyers to sign sales agreements and put down their deposits no later than Saturday, Aug. 14. 
 Sellers who missed the deadline now find themselves having to share some of their profits with the county. For the average Nassau homeowner, the tax adds about $2,500 to the cost of selling a house.
Brokers, real estate lawyers, economists and legislators who oppose the tax are saying sellers may withdraw from the market until the transfer tax expires in nearly 18 months, on Jan. 31, 2001.
If that happens, it is unclear what the effect might be on housing prices. Some believe that the tax, coupled with other factors, could result in lower prices; others, however, believe that a tighter housing market could push prices higher.
The tax measure, proposed by County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta as the cornerstone of a plan to help solve the county's growing deficit -- as much as $300 million by some accounts -- is designed with hopes that it will add $60 million to the county's coffers. But that all depends on a continued strong real estate market. The combination of the tax and rising mortgage interest rates may begin to dampen sales and force prices to retreat, officials said.
Pearl Kamer, chief economist of the Long Island Association, said the transfer tax was only a small part of the real estate puzzle in Nassau. "But its impact could lead to slower home sales, especially now that interest rates have passed the 8 percent mark," she said.
"I think home sales will slow in any case," she said. "Most sellers and buyers have been trying to beat the increase in interest rates. At a rate of 8 percent or higher, many buyers can no longer afford as much house. The tax only adds to the problem."
The Long Island Board of Realtors led a coalition of organizations opposed to the tax, including the Long Island Association, the Association for a Better Long Island and the Long Island Housing Partnership. The coalition ran full-page newspaper ads calling for budget reform in Nassau, not more taxes.
"Nassau County's fiscal crisis is serious and demands creative solutions," said Randy Kaplan, a spokesman for the Board of Realtors. "Solely adding new taxes to one of the most already overtaxed counties in America is not one of them."
Dr. Kamer described the tax as inequitable in that it falls on one class -- home sellers. "And it's not an ideal revenue source for the county," she said. "It only lasts for 18 months and will not impress those who rate the county's bonds." The bonds are just two basis points from junk-bond status.
Opponents say the tax is harmful to both home sellers and home buyers in Nassau. They say that what is needed is a complete overhaul of the county's real state assessment system, not just a one-time tax fix. They note that each year, the county pays millions of dollars in refunds because of errors in an assessment system that is based on 1938 property values and is the cause of a significant number of tax judgments against the county in which property owners get refunds, with interest.
The assessment system is also the target of a Federal lawsuit, which charges that the system discriminates against minority homeowners.
Mr. Gulotta, meanwhile, remains steadfast in support of the assessment system and his new tax.
"This legislation, adopted with support from both Democrats and Republicans in Albany, as well as an overwhelming majority of the Nassau County Legislature, is important to the fiscal health of the county and is part of an overall plan to insure its long-term fiscal health," he said in a statement released by his office.
When asked if he planned to seek an extension of the tax beyond its current sunset in January 2001, Mr. Gulotta demurred.
"It is impossible to predict at this time whether any extension will be sought," he said. "We will be submitting a budget to the County Legislature in about a month, which must be adopted by the end of October. Once that budget is implemented, and we monitor the expenditures and revenues in the next year, we will be in a better position to do such an analysis."
Mr. Gulotta, a Republican who will be seeking re-election next year, is said by his critics to be pursuing a course of proposing measures that offend the fewest potential voters. Although Republicans outnumber registered Democrats in the county by three to two, Mr. Gulotta is widely seen as being in trouble because of the county's fiscal crisis at a time when its economy is enjoying a boom.
Homeowners who now hope to cash in on the boom by selling their homes at a time of record-high prices are potential voters, but only if they plan to remain in the county. If they are retirees heading, for example, to Florida or Arizona once they sell their homes, they will have no way of voting against Mr. Gulotta for the extra tax they must pay on leaving. County statistics indicate that between a quarter and a third of all home sellers leave the county.
The sellers will be able to list the tax payment as a local real estate tax deduction on their Federal income tax form, but for many retirees, it will be another bite out of their nest egg, according to opponents of the tax.
Real estate brokers and lawyers say the tax will no doubt be shared or passed along to buyers, especially in the current market, where they often end up in bidding wars and pay well above the asking price because of the limited number of homes on the market.
Brokers say they will also feel the pinch. Instead of taking the traditional 6 percent of the final price, they may be forced by sellers to take 5 percent to help pay for the transfer tax and close a deal.
Sellers of high-priced homes, especially those in the million-dollar range, are rethinking their plans to enter or stay in the present market so long as the transfer tax is in effect, brokers said.
While some buyers are being forced out of the market by steadily rising prices, those who remain are not only encouraged by the continuing strength of the economy, but are also backed by heavy profits from a still bullish Wall Street. Not even rising interest rates have curbed their desire to buy.
"But none of us has a crystal ball and can't say how long this is going to last or how the new tax will impact the market," said Kathy Borg, a director of the Long Island Board of Realtors and a broker for Daniel Gale Associates in Locust Valley, which like other agencies had a rush of clients hoping to beat the new tax.
"The real estate market is cyclical and is based on supply and demand, and right now we don't have the inventory to meet demand. It's still a seller's market, but the new tax has not made the sellers happy," she said as she helped conduct an inspection of a home she recently sold on Perry Avenue in Bayville.
Audrey Livingstone, a broker at the Century 21 Annettes Real Estate in Uniondale and the treasurer of the Long Island Board of Realtors, said that the number of sellers and buyers going to contract by last Saturday was three times normal at her agency, but that she had not detected any collapse in the market in the first few days after the deadline.
"All our sellers are still serious about selling, despite the tax," she said. "Many of them are relocating and their plans have been in motion for many months. As of now, no one has pulled out."
Frederick R. Parola, the Nassau County Comptroller, said his biggest concern about the tax was that it could have been avoided had the county administration and Legislature listened to his advice three years ago.
"The county should have held the line on spending," he said. "These things catch up with you if you don't correct them when you have the chance."
According to data based on real estate sales in 1998, Mr. Parola said the tax may provide Nassau with as much as $60 million in revenue. "But that all depends on a continuing high rate of sales at high prices," he said.
"If some people now decide to put off their sales until the end of January 2001, then the county's share would be less," he said. "It's too early to say whether the tax and rising rates will have a chilling effect on the market."
"But remember, home sales in Nassau over the last four years have seen a dramatic increase, and now homeowners find themselves sitting on a large equity. Many may still decide to jump in, despite the tax, even if they are retirees. They can get a break on their Federal taxes and still make a profit."
Mr. Parola said that the tax was only a quick fix and that what the county really needed was "probably a small tax increase, beginning three years ago." He added, "You can't balance a budget with a lot of false one-shot gimmicks."
Thomas D. DiNapoli, a State Assemblyman and the chairman of the Nassau Democrat County Committee, was among those who said the transfer tax could have a chilling effect on the housing market. "The risk is high that the tax will not produce the projected revenues," he said. "There are those sellers who may now say, 'I'm not going to give the county any more than I have to,' and wait another 18 months before they enter the market."
"Clearly, what's needed in Nassau is a well-thought out budget and an end to phony one-shot revenues," he said.
State Assemblyman Phil Boyle, a Republican from Islip, said he generally voted against any tax increase. "This tax hurts the real estate market in general," said Mr. Boyle, a real estate lawyer. "Even though I'm from Suffolk County, people selling homes anywhere think such a tax is unfair.
"And the rate, 1 percent, is a very high rate. It's out of pocket, and you pay just because you happen to live in Nassau."
Mr. Boyle noted that New York State's real estate transfer tax was less than half of 1 percent, or $4 on every $1,000.
"But it's just to early to say how this will all impact the market," he said. "The problem now is that there are tons of people looking to buy and not enough to go around. Things could get even tighter if some sellers decide to wait until the tax sunsets, and that could push prices even higher. Then again, higher interest rates could work to push them lower."

HEADLINE: Maker of Custom Kitchens Finds a Niche

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
WHEN Dr. Annie Kramer and her husband, Dr. Barry Kramer, bought their new house in Armonk, it was still under construction.
"We took the opportunity to finish the interior exactly the way we wanted to," Dr. Annie Kramer said. "And that meant customizing the kitchen, the library, the bathrooms, the closets and built-ins for two of the children's rooms, which was a very large undertaking." 
 The Kramers are both dentists who practice in Manhattan. Their three children range in age from 2 to 7.
"We're pretty busy, but we knew what we wanted: a wood-paneled library, an English-style kitchen, closet built-ins, desks in the girls' rooms. But we didn't have time to search for someone to carry out the project," Dr. Annie Kramer said. "Our builder recommended All Star Fabricators in Thornwood. We met with them and they immediately understood what we wanted."
Les Vissers, 51, co-owner with Peter Cuneo of All Star Fabricators, formerly All-Star Kitchens, held the first design meeting with the Kramers. The company has been in business since 1978 but is not well known since it does almost no advertising. "Customers like the Kramers come to us through word-of-mouth referrals," Mr. Vissers said.
Mr. Cuneo, 31, a native of Pleasantville, started in business as a carpenter when he was 17. "I learned woodworking from my dad, and I always wanted to do it for a living," Mr. Cuneo said. "But like most kids graduating from Westchester high schools, I felt obliged to go to college." He attended Pace University for a year before going back to All Star full time. "It was really a cabinet shop then. There were only three of us. The owner, Mauro Scopino, was really talented. He could do everything from design to building and installing the finished product."
Five years later, Mr. Cuneo became Mr. Scopino's partner. and when, in 1996, Mr. Scopino retired, Mr. Vissers bought half the company.
"This is a complete change of career for me," Mr. Vissers said. "I was in the computer industry in Manhattan until I got so fed up with the pressures and the commuting that I called a business broker to see what was out there near my home in Mount Kisco."
There were abundant opportunities, Mr. Vissers recalled. "I was offered everything from pool maintenance companies to photo stores to golf driving ranges," he said.
But All Star was different. "I've always been interested in woodworking, and when I walked through the shop and saw the machines and smelled the saw dust, I was hooked," Mr. Vissers said. "Mauro agreed to stay on for a year as a designer, and I learned a lot from him. I handle all the administration, sales and marketing. Peter takes care of production. We're a good team."
About 75 percent of All Star's work is done in kitchens, although the company also does offices, libraries, countertops, cabinets, refacing and more unusual jobs like church altars and office lobby walls.
Mr. Cuneo said that everything they do is custom built from scratch. And with the booming economy, he added, has come a booming demand for top-of-the-line projects like mahogany-paneled libraries, cherry or maple English-style kitchens with intricate cabinets, crown moldings, elaborate wooden bathroom cabinets with carved legs, and so forth.
The value of alterations and additions in Westchester is $50 million a year, judging from the number of permits issued for work of more than $50,000, said George Frank, executive vice president of the Builders Institute, a professional trade group based in White Plains.
Nationally, gross receipts for home remodeling rose by about $4 billion to $54 billion in the second quarter of this year over the same period in 1998, an 8 percent rise, according to a report released last month by the Joint Center for Housing at Harvard University.
"We're busy, but it has eased up some since we bought an expensive piece of equipment that can do the work of four men," Mr. Vissers said. The equipment, a computer numeric control machine, cost $70,000. Mr. Vissers said that despite the high cost, the machine saved the company an equivalent amount in just three weeks.
"The C.N.C. is a no-brainer," he said. "It's a computer-operated robotic arm that drills shelf holes, hinge holes and pre-drills for draw slides within one 100th of an inch."
The staff of 21 employees is made up of designers, carpenters, installers, cabinet makers and countertop specialists.
"We're lucky to have good skilled workers," Mr. Cuneo said. "They're hard to find, and so far we haven't lost anyone we've liked. We offer a good package of benefits, which is not usually the norm in a nonunion shop." Jobs are priced individually, and customers are most likely to pay anywhere from $10,000 to $50,000 for custom kitchen cabinets for a small apartment.
"We can make anything in just about any style," Mr. Cuneo said. "Every piece in our factory is an original for a specific order. We have no middleman or subcontractors."
Mr. Vissers' goal, to turn a cabinet shop into a larger business, has been realized. This year, he estimated, the company will gross $2 million in contrast to the $500,000 to $600,000 it earned in 1995, the year before he arrived.
"Of course, we've been helped by the economy," Mr. Vissers said. "Yet it's a more complicated business than I had imagined. There are a thousand and one details to worry about. But we're creating something special, and the reward comes when customers tell you they love the results."

HEADLINE: A Dispute Within a Dispute on Fire Island

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
LIKE some strange sea creature on the beach, Fire Island's high-season political life can seem baffling when it washes inland. It can also have a bad smell.
The odor has seldom been stronger than in the aftermath of accusations by a newly formed group of Fire Island concessionaires and their supporters against the superintendent of the Fire Island National Seashore, Constantine J. Dillon. The group said he made homophobic remarks that it called an affront to gay summer communities in Fire Island Pines and Cherry Grove, and grounds for his dismissal. 
 The group, calling itself Beach -- for Balance, Ecology, Access, Commerce and Homes -- held a news conference on Aug. 13 to back its accusation with affidavits asserting that Mr. Dillon had told the owners of the ferry company that serves Fire Island Pines and Cherry Grove that residents' behavior was not conducive to a national park.
Mr. Dillon, who became superintendent in April 1997, emphatically denied the allegation of homophobia and said he had been talking about misbehaviors like trampling fragile dune grass and letting dogs run unleashed, not the sexual habits of gay visitors.
"It never occurred to me anyone would interpret what I said that way," said Mr. Dillon, who said he was aware of the social diversity of Fire Island when he sought the job. Mr. Dillon, 45 and a native of Groton, Conn., was previously posted as superintendent of Homestead National Monument in Nebraska.
Gay rights groups did not join in condemning Mr. Dillon, and the influential Fire Island Association, which represents the island's 38,500 property owners, said it could have nothing to do with Beach's campaign. In any event, the news conference was sprinkled with indications that Mr. Dillon's accusers were using the homophobia charge to pursue an unrelated issue: Mr. Dillon's failure to champion a $55 million to $60 million Federal beach-and-dune rebuilding project.
Much of Beach's news conference was devoted to the sand replenishment issue. The group's president, John Lund, said that although Mr. Dillon's jurisdiction was confined to the national seashore, "his decisions about beach replenishment can have an adverse effect on the entire South Shore of Long Island."
"He has been dragging his feet," Mr. Lund said. "Either he should come out and say something in favor of the project or get his superiors to do it."
The long-sought project is fervently supported by residents in the communities on Fire Island, where beach erosion is a threat to property.
"Anyone can look at the situation on Fire Island and see that this project is needed so that the island can fulfill its function of protecting the South Shore mainland communities," said Gerard Stoddard, the Fire Island Association's president.
But Mr. Stoddard drew the line on trying to force Mr. Dillon's ouster, saying the Fire Island Association had advised Mr. Lund's group that "we cannot be associated with their efforts."
"The association has been around for 50 years and we recognize that we are going to have to do business with the national seashore," Mr. Stoddard said. "And you don't do that by telling them who they should have running the park."
A draft environmental study for the project prepared by the Army Corps of Engineers is now under review by the Department of the Interior and other Federal agencies. Some on Fire Island who support the project as long overdue believe Mr. Dillon opposes it.
Mr. Dillon has said he is under strict orders from superiors to make no public comment about the project. "That's not an issue for me to address," he said. "The Secretary of the Interior is going to make the decision."
Yet feelings persist among some project supporters that Mr. Dillon should emulate his predecessor as park superintendent, Jack Hauptman, who spoke in favor of Federal action to rebuild beaches devastated by storms early in the decade.
"Since his appointment almost two years ago, Mr. Dillon has failed to take a public stand" on the project, Mr. Lund said.
To advance, the project will also need approval from the Interior Department and New York State.
The Army Corps environmental study may become public and the subject of hearings as early as this fall, though the project, if approved, is still probably more than a year away.
Mr. Stoddard said that property owners had pledged to pay up to $4 million of project costs in what he said was the "wave of the future" for coastal communities where similar projects were proposed.
The Federal Government would pay 65 percent of project costs. The remaining 35 percent would be divided between the state, local government and the property owners.
Mr. Stoddard said that even if there were no houses on Fire Island, the project would be necessary to protect the mainland from storm damage, including storm surge associated with major hurricanes.
Environmental groups opposed to the project say dumping sand on the beach would waste public money, principally benefit Fire island property owners, have unknown and possibly devastating effects on the ever-shifting barrier island and provide no provable storm protection for the mainland.
"The effect of these projects is to turn the beaches over to beach engineers," said Lorna Salzman, executive director of the Long Island Shorefront Defense Committee. "You can't protect both property and the beach at the same time."
"You are talking about a real subversion of science," she said. "The beach in its natural state is the best and perhaps the only protection for the mainland. The argument that the project would protect the mainland is totally phony."
The controversy over the project also involves delicate negotiations between the Interior Department and Army Corps over how much beach engineering is warranted in a national park that, although it is visited by more than four million people a year, places a premium on undisturbed nature and natural systems. The park contains the only Federally designated wilderness in New York.
When it was created in 1964, Fire Island National Seashore was already dotted with summer communities and Congress had recently approved a major dune building and storm protection project from Fire Island Inlet to Montauk Point. It has never gotten off the drawing board. The Fire Island plan now under consideration would be an interim project to be integrated later into the larger project.
The Interior Department objected to an earlier Corps version of the interim project that would have committed Interior, the Army Corps and New York State to a 30-year maintenance program of redepositing sand and rebuilding dunes as necessary.
The revised plan soon to be made public attempts to overcome the objection by reducing the maintenance program to six years. Clifford S. Jones, the Army Corps of Engineers project manager for both projects, said the six-year term could be extended to 30 years once the larger project was approved.
The Interior Department and the Army Corps signed an agreement in June setting terms for the scaled-back interim project that would make it more acceptable to the Interior Department. Under the agreement, the interim project will not include dune building and beach widening in the park's wilderness area, nor would it foster development.
With the controversy over the interim project likely to reignite with the release of the environmental study, the concessionaires' charges against Mr. Dillon were an opening act of a larger drama.
In another layer of complication, the concessionaires also appeared to be embroiled in a dispute with Mr. Dillon over terms and conditions in their franchises to run ferry services, marinas, restaurants and other businesses on Federal land.
As superintendent, Mr. Dillon holds final authority over who gets franchises. New National Park Service rules for concessions also shift costs for maintenance and other items once assumed by the Government to the concessionaires.
Mr. Dillon said the homophobia charge stemmed from a misinterpretation of what he meant when he said at a meeting with concessionaires more than a year ago that some Fire Island visitors engaged in behavior that was inappropriate in a national park.
"I think it's a misunderstanding of that phrase 'inappropriate behavior,' " he said. "In the park system, we know internally when we say inappropriate behavior we mean chopping down trees, starting fires and letting you dog run around.
"To a person who is not in the park business, they may hear that phrase and it means something else because they are bringing their background to it."
But the group called his explanation preposterous.
"The outrageous remarks attributed to Mr. Dillon, combined with his failure to adequately address beach and dune replenishment, in addition to the numerous other concerns of homeowners, residents, visitors, environmentalists and business owners on Fire Island" had compelled his group to conclude that "Mr. Dillon is the wrong man for the job," said Mr. Lund at the news conference, held near park headquarters in Patchogue.
Mr. Lund distributed affidavits from three concessionaires attesting to Mr. Dillon's allegedly homophobic remarks.
In them, Kenneth Stein Jr., the president of Sayville Ferries, his son Kenneth Stein III and Stephen J. Rose, whose family holds a concession contract for a 44-slip marina, snack bar and general store on Federal land at Sailors Haven, said at a meeting in February or March of 1998 Mr. Dillon said that "he did not believe that the behavior and lifestyles of members of the communities of the Fire Island Pines and Cherry Grove were acceptable or conducive to a national park."
The affidavits also said Mr. Dillon proposed placing rangers on Sayville Ferries, which goes to those communities, "in order to monitor or modify the behavior of the residents in those communities."
Mr. Dillon said he proposed putting rangers on ferries to educate visitors not to feed deer, climb dunes or let dogs off leashes.
But the senior Mr. Stein said there was "no doubt whatsoever" that Mr. Dillon's remarks were homophobic. "It was a shock to us," he said.
Duncan Osborne, a senior editor at LGNY, a New York City-based fortnightly newspaper for a gay and lesbian audience, was having none of it, saying the charges reflected "a dispute that is really about the concessions."
"The charges of homophobia are really groundless," Mr. Osborne said. "It's a tactic in an economic dispute those guys are having with the National Park Service."
Mr. Dillon, who has taught sensitivity classes to park personnel on dealing with diversity, said he had no intention of resigning. "This is a great park," said Mr. Dillon, who earns $67,000 as superintendent. "I look forward to resigning on my 75th birthday."
In a statement, Dale Ditmanson, an official in the National Park Service regional office in Philadelphia, said the service would investigate the charges by Mr. Lund's group "if and when a complaint is lodged."
The statement said the service viewed Mr. Dillon "as a role model for others in addressing diversity issues."
Edie Shean-Hammond, a spokeswoman for the regional office, said no formal complaint had been received. Mr. Lund, who in addition to being president of Beach is the president of the Property Owners Association of Davis Park and a part-time captain for Sayville Ferries, said a formal complaint would be lodged.
He said the park service was aware of the allegations and should have already begun investigating. "These accusations first surfaced 15 months ago," he said. "How can they honestly say they don't know about them?"
At their news conference, members of Beach stopped short of charging Mr. Dillon with any overt action targeting gays.
But Warren C. McDowell, who identified himself as the president of the Fire Island Tourism Bureau, said last summer a ranger ticketed two men for having sex in a beach area between Fire Island Pines and Cherry Grove known as the meat rack.
Mr. Dillon confirmed that a seasonal ranger issued a ticket for creating a public disturbance to two men who were having sex next to a house where the ranger resided.
Asked whether open-air sex was inappropriate behavior in the park, Mr. Dillon responded: "People visiting a National Park have an expectation that it is gong to be a safe family experience, and rangers have to make sure that anybody visiting a national park is safe and protected."
"Activities like having sex in public is something you don't do anywhere, and it would not be appropriate in a national park either."

HEADLINE: Giving Away Greenhouses for Health

BYLINE: By RITA PAPAZIAN 

 BODY:
WHEN Douglas Jay Schwartz died in a car accident shortly before his 20th birthday in 1987, his parents, Annabel and Fred Schwartz of Westport, wanted a memorial to honor their son's life.
They established the Douglas J. Schwartz Living Foundation, which administers the Greenhouse Grants Program in conjunction with the American Horticultural Therapy Association. The foundation provides greenhouses or matching grants to purchase greenhouses to horticultural therapy programs that serve people with physical, mental and emotional disabilities. 
 Horticultural therapy teaches vocational skills, leading to employment in the horticultural industry. The greenhouses enable the therapy programs to function year-round.
Elizabeth Messer, 33, a landscape architect who teaches at West Virginia University in Morgantown, W. Va., administered the grant program this year for the therapy assocation and the Schwartz family.
Ms. Messer, a member of the association's board of directors, is familiar with the benefits that horticultural therapy can have. Her brother, Walter, 30, had a playground accident when he was 3 years old and has used a wheelchair since. Through horticulture, her brother has improved his communication skills and his ability to function more independently.
"It's a role reversal," Ms. Messer said. "These are people who have been taken care of. Now they are taking care of something. The success is phenomenal at many different levels, especially for the physically disabled who improve their dexterity. Sometimes it's as simple as their using a misting bottle."
There are other, more complex, benefits as well, said Ms. Messer who in 1993 founded and directed a horticultural therapy program at the Misericordia Home, in suburban Chicago suburb, where her brother lives.
"There's such a strong spiritual connection working with plants," Ms. Messer said. "People just feel it; sometimes they might not be able to express it."
Ms. Messer praised the Schwartz family not only because the greenhouses enhance individual horticultural therapy programs and the individuals who benefit by them, but also because the awards program gets the word out about horticultural therapy.
Karen Barnes, a spokeswoman for the Master Gardener Association of Fresno County, Calif., a 1998 recipient said, "The Schwartz family has made the commitment to better the world that we all live in and what a better way to do so than to make it possible to beautify the landscape as well as to engage the mind, hearts and hands in the healing art of horticulture."
Since its founding 10 years ago, the Douglas J. Schwartz Living Foundation has awarded 78 greenhouse grants, worth over a half million dollars. Recently, the Schwartz family announced the 1999 grant awards, totaling $48,400. This year's awards include one free greenhouse and nine 50 percent matching grants toward new greenhouses.
Rubicon Program Inc., of Richmond, Calif., will receive a free greenhouse this month. Since 1975, Rubicon has provided intensive day treatment and outpatient services for chronically disabled adults. It also responds to needs of disadvantaged, unemployed, and homeless individuals through a variety of services, including employment training, housing stabilization, money management services, and intensive case management.
Dr. Carl Gerard, who is the director of mental health services at Rubicon, said the greenhouse would be an adjunct to its Urban Garden Project, which offers horticultural therapy. The program's activities include gardening and landscape tasks under close supervision by a horticultural therapist and life-skill trainers.
"We're thrilled," said Dr. Gerard, of the greenhouse grant. "Our clients will learn to develop new vocabulary skills with the plants."
To be eligible for a greenhouse, the applicant must have or propose a horticultural therapy program and document the program with the people it would serve; demonstrate a financial need; verify staffing; and if applying for a matching greenhouse, document the availability of matching funds.
The Association of Retarded Citizens of Greenwich was one of the first greenhouse recipients. The agency, which was founded in 1951, serves 550 families with special needs. It received a matching greenhouse grant award in 1991. The greenhouse is attached to the association's administrative office building. Outside is a large vegetable garden with eggplant, corn, beans and zucchini and other vegetables. The horticultural program is under the supervision of John Ritchie, a member of the staff at A.R.C. and Walter Jamroga, a horticultural consultant of Stamford and a master gardener.
A.R.C.'s clients grow flowers and vegetables from seed in the greenhouse and then care for them during the growing and selling season.
"I love all the plants. It's one thing I'm good at doing," said Micaela Moye, an A.R.C. client who was working in the greenhouse recently, under Mr. Richie's supervision.
Knowing that the greenhouse programs are successful brings joy to the Schwartz family. Mr. Schwartz said his son was very much like his mother in his love for plants.
"Douglas loved plants; he had 30 plants in his apartment at college," Mr. Schwartz said of his son's days at Syracuse University. "When he came home, he would take more plants back to college with him. We thought the Living Foundation was the best way to keep his name alive.
"What better way to help neglected and abused youth and people with disabilities," Mr. Schwartz added. "There are 78 greenhouses out there. We're serving thousands of people, who may not have had anything to do if it weren't for horticultural therapy."
Mr. Schwartz founded and is president of Sunporch Structures, Inc., a manufacturer of greenhouse kits. He and his son Dean run the company, from offices not far from the Westport home where Mrs. Schwartz tends to her plants in her own greenhouse.
Mrs. Schwartz is known around Westport as the plant lady. She provides and cares for plants at the town's homeless shelters, the town hall, a synagogue and a church.
"They reach out to hand out, but don't pull their hands back to take," said Deborah Gilmore, an accountant in the town hall comptrollers office, filled with Mrs. Schwartz's plants. "They are just wonderful human beings."
 To inquire about the Douglas J. Schwartz Living Foundation's Greenhouse Grants Program, call Elizabeth Messer at (304) 293-4832, ext. 4486, or write to her at Post Office Box 6108, West Virginia University, Morgantown, W.Va. 26506. Ms. Messer can also be reached at
emesser@wvu.edu.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island;
For Calverton, a New Focus on Making Movies

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN

 BODY:
THE sale by the Town of Riverhead of 2,900 acres it owns in Calverton is being delayed until zoning changes can be implemented. But the stage is already set for the first new occupant to move into the property once leased from the Navy by Northrup Grumman.
Under a lease signed July 20 with Lazarus Burman Associates, a Syosset developer in contract with Riverhead to purchase 472 acres of the Calverton site, Camelot Studios of Calverton will take over the 1.1 million square feet of industrial buildings once used by the military contractor to build fighter planes. Camelot intends to convert the complex, which includes huge hangars, into sound studios, which it will then rent out to movie production companies. 
 "Camelot saw the opportunity to take over buildings that would cost them $100 million to duplicate," said Jan Burman, the president of Lazarus Burman. "These buildings have few columns, very high ceilings and huge overhead doors, which makes them ideal for movie production."
Under the terms of a 21-year lease for 322 acres of the site, which was brokered for Camelot by Theodore P. Sasso and Edward F. Fitzsimons, senior managing directors at the Syosset office of Insignia/ESG, the international brokerage firm, Camelot will be paying a net rent of $3 million a year, which means that it also will pay the property taxes and all other expenses. Any improvements will also be the tenant's responsibility. Camelot has a purchase option and can build an additional 900,000 square feet of industrial buildings.
"Camelot identified this site a long time ago when it became clear that this was going to be an excessed facility," said Mr. Sasso. "What made Calverton so attractive to them is that it is much closer to European markets than the West Coast, and many of the movie producers already have homes on the Island."
Camelot's principals declined to be identified until the company moves into Calverton. However, in a written response they said that the five-member board of directors consisted of three institutional investors and two venture capitalists.
They also said that they expected to invest $10 million in improvements to the property and to start operations in the late fall, creating 2,500 jobs once the studios operate at full capacity. Rentals for the 32 sound stages that are expected to be created will range from $2,000 a week for the smallest, 3,000 square feet, to $14,000 a week for the largest, 50,000 square feet.
"Camelot is not competing with New York," the statement said. "Nothing can replace the New York backdrop. We will draw from Los Angeles and Europe and will provide location production support space for New York."
Lazarus Burman, which has formed a subsidiary, Camelot Calverton, to purchase the property, has retained about 155 of the 472 acres on which it intends to develop 1 million square feet of industrial space as it is permitted to do under the proposed zoning change. A 10,000-foot-long runway adjoining the Lazarus Burman site will continue to be owned and maintained by the town.
Mr. Burman signed the purchase contract on June 15, but the closing will not take place until the planned industrial development zoning, which must be approved by the Suffolk County Planning Department, is adopted. That approval is expected next month, said Andrea H. Lohneiss, Riverhead's Community Development Director.
Northrop Grumman closed its operations at the Naval Weapons Industrial Reserve Plant, as the Calverton site was called, in 1996 and laid off 3,000 workers. Since then, the Town of Riverhead, which under an act of Congress received the property from the Navy at no charge, has been working to restore lost jobs and generate tax revenues. The Navy turned over ownership of the property last September.
The town's only revenue so far has been from the National Transportation Safety Board, which has been leasing one of the buildings to house the remains of Flight 800, the TWA airliner that crashed into the Atlantic in July 1996. The remains are being moved to a smaller building on the site.
A re-use strategy plan prepared for the town in 1996 by Hamilton, Rabinovitz & Alschuler, a Manhattan real estate and economic development consulting firm, proposed turning the 550-acre industrial core of the property into an industrial park that would retain the existing buildings, where up to 2 million square feet of additional space could be added, and where the the larger of the two runways would also be retained.
The plan also outlined sports and leisure-oriented uses for the remaining 2,350 acres with the exception of about 500 acres that will be set aside for parks and open space.
The Navy owned a total of 5,900 acres at Calverton, but the 3,000 acres outside the fenced-in portion used by Northrop Grumman is in the Pine Barrens and will be left undeveloped.
LAST year, town officials accepted an offer by First Industrial Realty Trust, a Chicago-based real estate investment trust, to buy 472 acres of the industrial core for $17 million.
But First Industrial, because of management changes, decided to withdraw its offer. Mr. Burman of Lazarus Burman, who had been affiliated with First Industrial but severed his relationship in July 1998, said he subsequently decided to purchase the industrial property on his own.
An offer made to the town in February by Donald J. Trump to purchase the entire site for $55 million was rejected. Mr. Trump originally wanted to bring in a car-racing operator, but when that idea failed, he proposed building 2,000 houses.
"Our plan did not contemplate 2,000 houses," said Ms. Lohneiss. "Our intent is to maximize jobs and the tax base."
The Lazarus Burman deal is one of three the town has been negotiating through its representative, Jack O'Connor, the executive managing director of the Melville office of Grubb & Ellis, an international real estate brokerage.
Two additional offers, on which contracts have not been signed, involve a total of 1,100 acres of vacant land.
Landmark National of New Albany, Ohio, a developer of golf-oriented luxury communities, has offered to purchase 800 acres for $13.6 million. It would develop the property as a 300-room hotel-conference center, two 18-hole golf courses, and up to 300 housing units for buyers 55 and older that would be grouped around the golf courses.
MHC Investments, the sports and entertainment subsidiary of Mentmore Holdings Corporation, a Manhattan-based conglomerate that owns steel, life insurance, entertainment and development companies among other entities, has offered to purchase 300 acres for $5.4 million. The Mentmore plan is to build a skating and sports complex, a family entertainment center and a baseball stadium for a minor league team.
If the two additional deals are signed, the town will still have about 900 acres for sale zoned for a mix of uses. The land which is currently on the market for $20,000 an acre, is likely to increase substantially in value, in some cases doubling in value, once all the pending deals close, Mr. O'Connor of Grubb & Ellis said.
Interest by industrial users in the Calverton site has been extremely strong, said Mr. Burman of Lazarus Burman, noting that he already had prospective users for 300,000 square feet of the 1 million square feet he intends to build. He added that he expected to have the entire 1 million square feet committed within six months.
A major attraction is the designation of 1,248 acres of the site as an economic development zone. Companies that locate within the areas they encompass receive a variety of tax reductions, job incentive tax credits, favorable utility rates and property tax abatements on new construction and improvements.
Mr. Burman said that companies he is currently negotiating with include a boat manufacturer; a high-end furniture, window and door manufacturer; a fabricator of highway signs and a picture-frame manufacturer.
Both counties already have an active film industry, a spillover from New York City's thriving film and television production activities, which often need suburban settings. Mr. Burman said that 8,000 members of the International Alliance of Theatrical and Stage Employees already live on Long Island.
Film studio companies have been querying Nassau County about another former Northrop Grumman site, this one in Bethpage, where the Navy intends to turn over 1.2 million square feet of industrial buildings on 105 acres to the county early next year.
One building of 800,000 square feet, has in particular attracted queries from film makers, said Stephen G. Latham, Nassau's Commissioner of Commerce and Industry.
The arrival of Camelot Studios in Calverton should not affect plans for Bethpage, he said. "The closer you are to the city the better it is," he noted. "But I believe there certainly is enough activity out there to allow room for both."
