HEADLINE: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY;
For Hospital Services, Pleasant Settings

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
THE Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center is world famous for its research and treatment of the disease. But at 67th Street and York Avenue on Manhattan's East Side, it is distant from subway lines and can be difficult for patients to reach.
The hospital opened an outpatient clinic in June at 53d Street and Third Avenue in 190,000 square feet of space on the lower floors of what had been an office building. In doing so, it was following the trend to deliver more care to patients on an ambulatory rather than an in-patient basis, rather then admit them to hospitals. 
 It was also seeking to hold onto its share of the medical services market by establishing a more conveniently located clinic, with a friendlier atmosphere than is usually found in a typical hospital setting.
The lobby of what is formally known as the Laurence S. Rockefeller Outpatient Pavilion resembles the entrance to a good hotel rather than a hospital waiting room. Original artwork decorates the walls, soft music plays in the background and small pools with waterfalls add to a calm ambiance.
Upstairs, the diagnostic and treatment areas have been decorated in subdued tones and designed so that changing rooms are adjacent to imaging equipment, meaning that patients in skimpy gowns do not have to walk hallways.
"We tried to create an environment that was as warm and comfortable for patients was we could," said Dr. Paul A. Marks, president of Memorial Sloan-Kettering. "We wanted to make a statement that we can provide high-quality care in a warm environment."
The establishment of satellite facilities by hospitals is being driven in part by the decision of more young doctors to forgo the establishment of independent practices and instead to join groups, such as the DOCS chain in the city and Westchester County, to share costs and reduce risks.
The Memorial Sloan-Kettering treatment center is now seeing 800 patients a day. In a few weeks, St. Vincents Hospital Center will be opening its own cancer-care center in the old Port Authority building on the block bounded by 15th and 16th Streets and Eighth and Ninth Avenues.
Earlier, Beth Israel Medical Center established a broader-based treatment center in what had been the commercial space in Zeckendorf Towers on the east side of Union Square. And the Columbia Presbyterian Center of New York Presbyterian Hospital satellite occupies three floors of an office building at 60th Street and Madison Avenue to serve people who find it difficult to reach its main campus at 168th Street in Washington Heights.
Taking this trend to its logical conclusion, the Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital has proposed selling its main building on 64th Street between Second and Third Avenues and using the $41 million in proceeds to establish or enlarge clinics in Harlem and other areas of the city where specialized care is hard to find.
Hospitals in boroughs other than Manhattan and in the suburbs are establishing satellite facilities as well, but the tight market conditions in Manhattan make finding suitable space a more daunting challenge.
Hospitals are setting up these satellite operations for a number of reasons, according to Kenneth E. Raske, president of the Greater New York Hospital Association, which represents 175 health-care facilities in the metropolitan area.
The most important is cost pressure, he said, adding that "the payers are looking for lower-cost alternatives to inpatient treatment." Meanwhile, technological developments like laser eye surgery and new types of chemotherapy enable treatment on an ambulatory basis for ailments that once required hospital stays.
The association says there were 11.04 million inpatient days at hospitals in New York City in 1990. The figure declined to 8.94 million in 1997, the last year for which statistics are available. At the same time, the number of outpatient treatments grew to 18.16 million in 1997 from 14.79 million in 1990.
Hospital managers are using these new treatment centers to hold on to their existing patients and, perhaps, take a few from their competitors. St. Vincents is opening its new cancer treatment center in partnership with Salick Health Care, a for-profit organization noted for its popularity with cancer patients.
Everyone agrees that cancer care is a growing market with an aging population. The managers hope that a new center plus the Salick touch will attract patients who would otherwise not immediately think of St. Vincents when diagnosed with the disease.
"We were a small player in oncology, only the 11th largest in the city," said Leonard Walsh, the vice president for operations for St. Vincents. "I'd be happy to push that up to No. 3 or 4."
Finding space for these treatment centers in crowded Manhattan has not been easy, hospital executives say. But it has become necessary, as small outpatient clinics at traditional hospitals have become hopelessly overcrowded.
"We were desperate for more space," said John Gunn, an executive vice president of Memorial Sloan-Kettering. "We were swinging from the rafters here." The new space was designed by the Perkins Eastman architectural firm.
In a way, Memorial Sloan-Kettering officials have the late Robert Maxwell to thank for their space in 866 Third Avenue, once known as the Macmillan Building. When Mr. Maxwell's publishing empire collapsed in the early 1990's, Macmillan was sold and its offices were vacated.
Metropolitan Life, which took ownership, put the building on the block in 1997 and the hospital bid $49.5 million for it in association with the Related Companies. However, they lost out to a $50 million offer by the Witkoff Group.
SINCE the hospital is a nonprofit institution, it pays no property tax on real estate it owns, so it was still interested in making a purchase. After considerable negotiation, Steven Witkoff decided to divide the structure into three condominiums: the retail space on the first two floors; a hotel, now a Marriott, in the building's tower on floors 14 through 31, and the Memorial Sloan-Kettering satellite sandwiched between. The hospital bought 200,000 square feet of space, with the Witkoff Group retaining the two other condominiums.
Seeing a high volume of patients at a location far from the main hospital has forced the center's doctors and managers to an all-electronic system for patient records and images. The system will offer doctors and other medical personnel the ability to access lab results, treatment histories and diagnostic images from any of 550 computer terminals in the center's facilities. Use of this system has cut the volume of paper by 40 percent since 1996, officials report.
The image of doctors peering at X-ray pictures clipped to a light box belongs to the past as well. All the diagnostic picture- taking at the center, -- X-rays, CAT scans and magnetic resonance imaging -- will be captured, viewed and analyzed electronically. And because electronic images can be transmitted more easily than a piece of film can be shipped, doctors can consult with colleagues more quickly across the country and across the world.
It was the growing volume of outpatient care for a wide variety of conditions at its main location at 16th Street and First Avenue that drove Beth Israel to seek more space elsewhere. "The buildings we were in were designed in the 1950's and they mixed ambulatory and acutely ill people in an unsettling way," said Peter Kelly, chief operating officer of Beth Israel, which is now working collaboratively with St. Luke's-Roosevelt and Long Island College Hospital under the name Continuum Health Partners.
In addition, officials wanted to eliminate a two-class treatment system, in which patients with private medical insurance were treated by private doctors, while Medicare and Medicaid patents had to wait in an outpatient clinic to be seen by residents.
After a joint venture with a nearby Y.M.H.A. did not work out, Beth Israel started shopping for commercial space, which was available and still reasonably priced in the early 1990's.
When a corporate bankruptcy left 325,000 square feet of condominium office space available on the second to fifth floors of Zeckendorf Towers, Beth Israel paid $34 million for the property. Mr. Kelly concedes that the space was not ideal, with a large central atrium, but says that the location next to the Union Square subway station, the third busiest in the city, was excellent. In addition there is parking in the basement.
And by January 1996, when the Phillips Ambulatory Care Center opened, it was clear that Union Square and its surrounding areas were well on their way to economic revival.
In addition to the area it occupies for itself, Beth Israel leases space in the building to doctors in private practice who are affiliated with the medical center. "When we suggested combining clinic patients with private patients, some people predicted it would be a mess in six months," Mr. Kelly said. "But four year later, it still looks like new."
The Phillips Center space is laid out so each medical specialty has it own small waiting room, to eliminate the "take a number and wait" feel of big waiting rooms. All the waiting rooms face the naturally lighted atrium, which has a sheet metal waterfall as it centerpiece.The space was designed by Larsen Shein Ginsberg & Partners.
The pediatric-care waiting room is furnished with a big fish tank, curved mirrors that reflect distorted images and the inevitable television screen, while the orthopedic and spine treatment areas are near a gym with weights and workout equipment.
As has become fashionable, the breast cancer diagnostic and treatment area is somewhat isolated from other cancer treatment areas. "Breast patients never see the hospital," said Marilyn Halper, executive director of the Phillips cancer center. "As a result, they feel healthier."
In all, there are 44 separate medical modules in the center, plus a store and a 90-seat auditorium for medical meetings and conferences.
MOVING medical services to more convenient locations is a reversal of a long-term development in the medical business, said Susan Parker, director of Columbia Presbyterian's 80,000-square-foot midtown care center at 16 East 60th Street, at Madison Avenue.
"In the past, poor people came to the hospital to have a clean place to get better, while the rich people were taken care of at home," she said "Now we are coming full circle."
The center was first opened in a different location in 1982 and moved to its current location on three floors in the heart of the Madison Avenue shopping area in 1994. The purpose, Ms. Parker said, "was to bring the Columbia faculty to midtown."
Like Beth Israel's ambulatory care center, the Columbia Presbyterian facility contains most medical specialties, including a center for women's health, psychological treatment and dental services.
Patients interested in doing a little shopping before and after treatments do not have far to go. Retailers including Ralph Lauren, Donna Karan and Armani are right in the neighborhood. "We're in the middle of the Madison Avenue experience," Ms. Parker said.
Just as technological developments, like improved chemotherapy that reduces the side effects of drugs, have made ambulatory care for cancer more practical, developments like laser eye surgery have made community-based clinics more sensible than a central hospital for Manhattan Eye and Ear.
"In the last five to six years, there has been a paradigm shift in eye care and there is almost no need for overnight stays," said Paul Aschkenasy, a senior director of Cushman & Wakefield, who was involved in the proposed sale of the hospital's 64th Street building.
"They went from having an average of 120 overnight stays to six," he added. "The new equipment is small and relatively inexpensive, so it makes sense to have four or five clinics affiliated with local hospitals in underserved areas of the city."
If the transaction, which has been challenged in court, is completed, half the building will be sold to Memorial Sloan-Kettering for an expanded breast cancer treatment center, Mr. Aschkenasy said, and the rest to private developers for probable conversion to housing.
Housing is also on the mind of officials of St. Vincents, which has many of its business offices in a former apartment building on West 12th Street. "We need affordable housing for staff, but 50 percent of this building is offices," said Mr. Walsh, vice president for operations.
Since the growth of ambulatory care will inevitably lead to a reduction in hospital beds, the space required by a hospital will shrink, allowing real estate assets to be redeployed. "If we could convert this building back to housing, we might do a floor as an inn for out-of-town patients," Mr. Walsh said.
St. Vincents has been buying medical practices and establishing clinics in the city's ethnic enclaves, which has produced some unexpected developments for an institution that is owned by the Sisters of Charity, a Roman Catholic order. "We have a clinic in Chinatown that is now open seven days a week," Mr. Walsh said. "The Asian community wants these services on Sunday. It's one of our busiest days."
The latest St. Vincents venture is its Comprehensive Cancer Center, on 15th Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, in 70,000 square feet of what were once the street-level loading docks of the Port Authority's Inland Freight Station. The center is planning to start treating patients later this month, with a formal opening on Oct. 4.
Designed by the architectural firm of Gwathmey Siegel, the center has a recessed entrance so that patients arriving by car are protected from bad weather. The lobby is equipped with a concierge desk to make arrivals feel welcome.
The center has two fully equipped operating rooms and the other manifestations of hard science, but the system is intended to relieve anxiety as well as try to cure disease. In the breast-treatment area -- isolated from the rest of the center -- several medical tools and specialties have been grouped to speed diagnoses.
"The standard is to reduce the time to diagnosis," said Jill D. Anderson, executive director of the center. She said radiologists would be available to read images and pathologists to analyze cells taken for testing. "The pathologist will live here," said Ms. Anderson, indicating that the doctor's principal office will be at the center rather than the hospital. "He can read a slide and render an opinion."
She said the goal was to be able to provide a diagnosis the same day as tests are administered, avoiding the worrisome delay of five to 30 days of the past.
BECAUSE of its industrial past of the building, 111 Eighth Avenue, fitting the center into it was not simple, said Charles Gwathmey, the principal architect.
"We had to interact with existing mechanical rooms and loading docks," he said, "and there was a lot of existing infrastructure -- pipes, ducts and so forth -- that we couldn't move."
The upside was that the building is strongly built, with a higher ceiling than would found in a typical office building. This was useful for the four-foot-thick reinforced concrete wall and floors needed to shield the rooms where radiation therapy is administered.
Just as St. Vincents uses community-based clinics to draw patients into its system, Beth Israel bought a chain of primary care centers called DOCS to extend its reach into the boroughs and suburbs.
Dr. Joseph J. Sozio said he started the DOCS operation in 1983 with a formula of emphasizing convenience for customers. "We started in Westchester as a primary care office that was open from eight to midnight, seven days a week," he said. "The idea was to provide people with health care when they needed it."
The DOCS operation began as Doctors Office Center, but later the name was changed to DOCS after a legal dispute with another company. It has grown to 25 centers in Westchester, Manhattan and Brooklyn.
Most of the DOCS centers have been established near shopping centers and other retail locations, for visibility and convenience. For specialized care there are DOCS centers staffed by doctors with specialized training. Major surgery is referred to hospitals in the Continuum partnership.
Dr. Sozio said joining a group operation like DOCS is attractive for doctors coming out of medical school and training laden with debt.
"Setting up an independent practice is both capital and labor intensive and we are in the era of managed care," he said. "With something like this, you have the feel of a private practice with the support of a larger group."

HEADLINE: One Eye On the Ball, The Other On the Majors

BYLINE: By STEVE STRUNSKY 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
DEEP below the stands at Mercer County Waterfront Park not too deep, since the stands only have one tier -- is a door with a simple plaque that says "Umpires."
The Trenton Thunder, a Class AA affiliate of the Boston Red Sox, were about to play a night game against the Reading Phillies, and behind the door the game's three umpires, one short of the four used in the majors, were suiting up. 
 The home plate umpire, James Hoye, already in his chest protector and shin guards, resembled anything but the stereotypical big-bellied, square-jawed umpire with the gruff demeanor and gravelly voice to silence whole stadiums and eject ill-tempered managers. Mr. Hoye, who would preside over two dugouts full of cocky ballplayers and savvy coaches plus 7,000 rowdy fans, was a skinny 28-year-old college graduate who looked more like a ballplayer, or even a Boy Scout, than the burly umpire a fan might see on television.
The third-base ump, David Glass, a year younger than Mr. Hoye, could have passed for a bat boy. Only the first-base umpire, Neil Taylor, 29, had a hint of a paunch. But Mr. Taylor, a Phoenix native with a baritone drawl, seemed more suited to punching cows than punching outs. Although that's just what he did, and with panache, taking a hop-step and making a compact jab of his clenched fist on one suitably dramatic pick-off play.
New Jersey has no major league franchise of its own, so the Thunder and five other teams -- one of them, like the Thunder, affiliated with big-league teams (and thus rated Rookie League through Class AAA), and four independent -- are the biggest brand of baseball that fans can see in New Jersey. And the umpires calling the games are either young men like Mr. Hoye, on an up-or-out track toward the majors, or journeymen umpires whose best calls may be behind them.
All three in the crew working the Thunder game have spent most of their young working lives umpiring, and a career in the Major Leagues is the goal. "You're not here if you don't want to be in the majors," Mr. Taylor said.
None of them started out with professional umpiring in mind, and all of them earned college degrees unrelated to sports before they enrolled in umpire school, the first step to working at any level of the minor leagues.
For Mr. Taylor, umpiring was an economic necessity while he majored in finance at the University of Arizona, where he worked the college games. "That's how I put myself through college," he said. "And then I just didn't want to do amateur ball anymore. I knew if I was going to continue I had to go professional or not do it anymore."
Mr. Glass, an Atlanta native who also majored in finance, said he took up umpiring on a lark only after he graduated from the University of Georgia. "When I got out of school, I thought it would be fun to learn how to umpire," he said. "I thought it would be a nice diversion on weekends."
Mr. Hoye said he started umpiring as a hobby and as a way to make extra money in the summer while growing up in Cleveland. He got more serious about it, he said, after entering Ohio State University, where he was a computer science major. "I started umpiring more and more, and I met some guys who worked on Columbus Clippers games in Columbus, Ohio. That's Triple A, International League. And then, I graduated in December of '94, and I went to umpiring school in January."
 
THE DREAMERS
From Extra Money to Full-Time Passion
The three young umpires on the field at Riverfront Park performed like seasoned veterans. Not one call was disputed, and no base was left uncovered. The crew also kept control of the game until a Thunder home run won it in the bottom of the 12th.
With constant hand signals, constant eye contact, and rotations that on one play precisely paralleled the base runners' double steal, the umpires interacted with a sophistication that only the keenest fan would notice, much less appreciate.
"For the most part, these umpires are pretty good," said James Gross, 70, of Ewing Township, a lifetime observer of minor league baseball. "Yeah, they really hustle. You can tell, those are the ones who are going places."
That is their hope, anyway, especially after 22 big league umpires resigned last month in what was meant to be a labor ploy of a mass resignation. Major League Baseball accepted 13 of them; a complaint by the union with the National Labor Relations Board is pending.
Mr. Hoye said "there's a real good possibility" that several of his colleagues in the Class AA Eastern League would be bumped up to AAA next year as the Class AAA umpires moved to the big leagues. "Generally, it's usually one year at each level of A," he explained, as he carved into a slice of overdone pot roast brought into the umpire's locker room after the Thunder game. "Now, there's three levels in A, there's rookie ball, low A and high A. Usually, two years of three years in Double A. Rarely does a guy go one year in Double A and then go to Triple A, just because Double A's usually the better ball, you learn a lot of stuff down here. So, usually, a guy won't be in AAA before his sixth year.
"To become a major league umpire, you start to fill in. Then they would send you to American League spring training, and then you would, hopefully, get called up during the season and fill in for vacations. That could go for six, seven, eight years, called up and down without a contract."
"By then," Mr. Taylor interjected, "you're talking 15 years, getting your big league contract then."
In May, the 230 umpires who work in the minor leagues that are affiliated with Major League Baseball voted to create their own union, the Minor League Umpires Association. They have yet to negotiate a contract, however, and Mr. Hoye said they are still looking for a lawyer.
Money, of course, is an issue.
The Class AA umpires start at $2,300 a month over their five-month season, although, Mr. Taylor noted, "We get a hundred dollars more because we're veterans of the league."
They are not paid at all during the off season. Mr. Taylor worked as a collection agent for a watch company last winter. Mr. Smith did financial consulting along with his brother in Atlanta. Mr. Hoye said, "I drove a beer truck last winter."
Their meal allowance may be what helps keep them trim. "Seventeen dollars, that's the per diem," Mr. Hoye said. "Our clubhouse dues range from $3 to $5 per day, so each of us will pay $5 per day for the food in the locker room and the guy that brings us towels. So that drops us down to $12 per day. So we're struggling."
Hotel accommodations, arranged by the home team, range from Hiltons to Quality Inns in scary neighborhoods. The three-man crew gets two rooms, so they must work out who gets the solo room. The McIntosh Inn, the hotel in Bensalem, Pa., where umpiring crews are put up for Thunder games, "could be better," Mr. Hoye said. "Sometimes you wish there was a little more of a standard, especially when you get farther up. You know, Trenton, they have 7,000 people here every night. They pack them in here, you know. So an extra hotel room, a little nicer place, you wonder."
Unlike Major League umpires, and occasionally their AAA counterparts, who fly between cities, minor league crews split driving duties, usually in vans provided by the leagues. In Class A ball, the umpires drive their own cars and submit gas vouchers.
"You have a game like tonight, and then have to drive 400 miles. Whew!" Mr. Hoye said.
 
CAREER PATH
Many Are Called, Few Are Chosen
Professional baseball's lower echelons are often lumped together as the "minor leagues" despite a widely disparate mix of leagues, some affiliated with Major League Baseball, some independent.
The teams in the 16 affiliated leagues are what make up Minor League Baseball, a trademark name of the National Association of Professional Baseball Leagues, an umbrella group based in St. Petersburg, Fla.
Minor League Baseball umpires are employed jointly by the American or National League and by the Professional Baseball Umpire Corporation, said Pat O'Conner, the association's vice president for administration.
Much as players are drafted out of school, Minor League Baseball umpires are selected by the umpire corporation after graduation from a five-week course at an accredited umpiring school. Currently there are two such schools in Florida -- the Jim Evans Academy of Professional Umpiring in Kissimmee and the Harry Wendelstedt Umpire School in Daytona Beach.
Umpires are selected by the corporation's evaluators at camps held at end of March. The past two years, the camp was held at the Coco Expo, in Cocoa, Fla., the former spring training camp of the Houston Astros. College baseball teams provide the action.
"P.B.U.C. will tell schools how many graduates they would like to see during an evaluation period," Mr. O'Conner said. "If we know we're going to have 15 jobs, we'll invite 30 grads."
There were 37 invited this year and 35 the year before. Of the roughly 230 umpires in the affiliated minor leagues each year, 15 or so retire. Only one umpire was elevated to the big leagues in 1998, Mr. O'Conner said.
"This year will be substantial," he added, referring to the 22 resignations by Major League umpires. "We'll know at the end of this year how many umpires will be released."
As with players, minor league umpires earn far less than money than their counterparts in the majors, although the disparity is far narrower. Salaries for big league umpires start at about $75,000 a year, compared with $1,800 a month or $9,000 over the season, for umps in Rookie League, the lowest order of affiliated baseball. Class AAA pay starts at $3,400 a month. Minor League umpires get health insurance.
The professional baseball association ranks the 16 affiliated minor leagues as Class A, AA, AAA. In turn, each team is affiliated with a Major League franchise. For example, the Thunder plays in the Class AA Eastern League, and is a Boston Red Sox affiliate.
New Jersey's other affiliated team is the New Jersey Cardinals of the New York-Penn League, a Class A affiliate of the St. Louis Cardinals who play at Frankford's Skylands Stadium in Sussex County.
Four of the six professional baseball teams in New Jersey belong to independent leagues. In fact, half the six teams in the independent Atlantic League, founded in 1997, are in the Garden State. They are the Newark Bears, the Atlantic City Surf and the Somerset Patriots of Bridgewater. The fourth independent team, the New Jersey Jackals, who play in Yogi Berra Stadium at Montclair State University, are in the Northern League.
And while independent league teams are not officially designated A, AA, of AAA, their front offices, players, fans and umpires insist the quality of play and officiating is comparable to Minor League Baseball's, somewhere between Class AA and AAA.
Indeed, crossovers are not uncommon, and the Atlantic League's 10 full-time umpires went to the same umpiring schools attended by affiliated and Major League Baseball umpires, and most of the Atlantic League umpires once worked in the affiliated ranks.
Full-time work in the affiliated leagues is the career path to the majors. Still, most migration seems to flow from affiliated to independent ball, especially as careers head into extra innings.
 
THE VETERANS
Glimpsing the Big Time From Far Below
Michael DeCello was a 58-year-old substitute umpire for Trenton Thunder minor league games who thought his chances of umpiring a New York Yankees game had long since past. But a beam collapse at Yankee Stadium on April 13, 1998, gave him a moment in the House that Ruth Built. The collapse canceled the next day's regular season game, giving coaches a chance to evaluate prospects on their Norwich Navigators farm team in an exhibition against the Yanks themselves. But the American League umpires had decided to take the day off and their reservists in Class AAA ball were busy, so someone found Mr. DeCello.
"I was sitting in my house about 10 o'clock and my phone rang," said Mr. DeCello, an administrative analyst with the New Jersey Department of Transportation. "I says, 'You're kidding me.' So the guy says to me, 'Here's my number, call me back.' Sure enough, I got through to his office, and he explained to me he wanted me there at 11 o'clock."
"I was absolutely floating on air," he said. "The cop said, 'Where you going?' I said, 'I'm the umpire for today's game.' He goes, 'Come right in.' I parked my car right next to Joe Girardi's."
He also got to kid a good-natured Derek Jeter about Mariah Carey, hear Bernie Williams play guitar, and scoop a handful of hallowed ground from the infield. The Yankees paid him $150, far short of the $240 per day that big league umps get just for hotel and food, but more than the $65 Mr. DeCello gets for Thunder games.
"I'll tell you something, it was quite a moving experience to walk on the same spot where past umpires had called World Series games," he said. Mr. DeCello said he drove home "very slowly."
"That night I had to do a Rutgers University game in Newark," he said. "I'm sitting on the field over there and I'm saying to myself, 'Jeez I just left Yankee Stadium and here I am doing Rutgers-Newark.' It wasn't so much a letdown, it was more like, what a swing," he said. "Welcome back to the real world."
The real world for minor league umpires can be found at parks like the Atlantic City Sand Castle, home field of the Atlantic City Surf, and the brand-new Waterfront Park, home of the Newark Bears. Both teams are independent, which makes them a big step farther from the major leagues than affiliated teams are.
Unlike Mr. Hoye, the up-and-comer in Trenton, Bob Willman, 50, an Atlantic League umpire, looks like the veteran professional umpire that he is. Solidly built, with a shaved head to make him look extra tough, he is the league's umpire-in-chief. His experience includes stints in various affiliated leagues, including the Class AAA International League. In 1991, Mr. Willman worked home plate before 66,000 fans at Riverfront Stadium in Pittsburgh for a National League game between the Pirates and the Montreal Expos.
His experience also includes 17 years dealing blackjack and other games in Atlantic City, where he lives, and where his involvement with the fledgling league began a few years ago with an effort to build support for the Sand Castle. "I didn't even know what I what I wanted to do," Mr. Willman said. "I just knew I wanted to be involved."
Asked if he still thinks about the major leagues, Mr. Willman points out that he is under contract with the Atlantic League. "Right now, it's a moot point to even think about it," he said.
But one of Mr. Willman's Atlantic League colleagues, John Ramsey, does think about the majors. Mr. Ramsey, 34, who played catcher at Kearny High School and later at William Paterson College, said he had wanted to be a major league umpire since he was 19. But it was 11 years after he first attended umpire school at age 20 that Mr. Ramsey got his first professional umpiring job in 1996, in the independent Northern League. He returned a call from a league official on a Monday night, "and Tuesday morning I was on a plane to Fargo, N.D.," he said. "It was great, I was elated to be, finally, in some kind of professional baseball, even though it was independent."
His ambition cost him a fiancee. "She wanted to do stuff during the summer and I was out umpiring," he said.
And even his wife of three months, Lisa, knows that umpiring is his first priority. "She knows, we have an understanding," he said. So far, baseball has not divided the couple, who live in Montclair, and they travel together on weekends in their new Volvo, staying in hotel rooms paid for by the Atlantic League. For Somerset Patriot games in Bridgewater and Bears games in Newark, Mr. Ramsey commutes.
Mr. Ramsey said he gives "100 percent" to his day job as a sales manager with a security company, Sanitrol in Rutherford, from which he often heads directly to a night game. He said he would quit his day job if an offer came that took him closer to the big leagues. "If the affiliated ranks offered us contracts, we'd be crazy to say no," Mr. Ramsey said, sipping a beer with fellow crew members in the umpires' locker room after a Surf game on a recent Saturday night.
Mr. Hoye, the young Class AA umpire, is philosophical about his chances of making it to The Show.
"The easiest way to look at it is: Neil and I went to umpire school in 1995, and Dave went in '96," he said. "If I'm still sitting in Double A and all my class are in Triple A, and then Dave's class of '96 is all in Triple A, I might have to say to myself, 'Well, what am I still doing?' Like, hey, it was great while I tried it, but I just don't have it anymore."
 
Fighting Not to Be in a League of Her Own
 THE independent Atlantic League wants to be viewed on a par with the leagues affiliated with Major League Baseball. Perry Barber, an Atlantic League umpire, is carrying on another of baseball's struggles for equality.
Ms. Barber, 46, of Manhattan, is one of 10 full-time umpires in the Atlantic League, in which four of the six teams play in New Jersey, and one of two women known to be calling balls and strikes in professional baseball. The other, Maria Papageorgiou of Rock Island, Ill., was hired earlier this year by the Professional Baseball Umpire Corporation, run by the minor league teams affiliated with big league organizations. She was sent to Florida's sub-Class A Pioneer League. "We've been few and far between, unfortunately," Ms. Barber said.
As a trivia buff and a one-time Jeopardy contestant, Ms. Barber said she became a baseball fan after she read up on it as a trivia category in the late 1970's. "By 1981 I was completely hooked," she said. "That was the summer the major league strike happened, and I just started umpiring Little League just to have some association with baseball. I wasn't deterred by my shortcomings, although there were many people, I'm sure, who thought I should be, and did many things to try to make me feel inadequate, like I didn't belong or something. As they still do sometimes.
"The simple, cold, hard truth is there is opposition to women's participation in organized baseball, and to deny it is to have your head in the sand," she said
Ms. Barber, who said she is "married to baseball," attended the Harry Wendelstedt Umpire School in Florida in 1982, when she dragged her twin sister, Warren, along for support. She was passed over by Minor League Baseball that year, and again when she re-enrolled at Wendelstadt in '83, '84 and '85. But she starting calling intra-squad games for the New York Mets, where she met Bud Harrelson, the former shortstop and coach, who was the Atlantic League's first president.
The Atlantic League does make some accommodations for her; each locker room has a special shower and dressing area for her.
"I always tell myself," said Ms. Barber, a songwriter who used to open for a very young Bruce Springsteen. "I'll know that I've made some mark on history if I ever see myself as a Jeopardy question: 'Who is the fifth woman in professional baseball?' " STEVE STRUNSKY

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (93%);

CITY: BOSTON, MA, USA (92%); TRENTON, NJ, USA (90%); ATLANTIC CITY, NJ, USA (86%); PHOENIX, AZ, USA (74%);

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Three New Red-Brick Town Houses;
A Genteel Touch for TriBeCa

 BODY:
A row of three five-story red-brick town houses with penthouses are scheduled to go into construction next month on Reade Street in TriBeCa, the first row of new single-family houses to be built in the neighborhood in 150 years.
Named the Reade Street Houses, they will go up on a site between Greenwich and Hudson Streets, where clearance is nearly completed. Though modern in design, the houses will pay homage to a time before warehouses and office towers replaced all but a few private homes in the area. 
 "They take the classic essence of the town house and marry it with a downtown loft feeling," said John L. Petrarca, who lives on the block and is a partner at Guenther Petrarca, the architect for the project.
The developer is Downtown Development L.L.C., a joint venture of Guenther Petrarca, Wildman & Bernhardt Construction Inc. and Hamlin Ventures of Manhattan. The houses are on the market through Bruce L. Ehrmann of the firm of Stribling Wells & Gay for $4.2 million. Occupancy is expected in March.
Downtown Development acquired the 4,125-square-foot site last year from the family that ran a factory that produced pats of butter under the Cremoland name for decades. The factory closed in 1995.
After demolition for new construction began in June, the project came to an abrupt halt because of an accident on the site that proved fatal to Richard Wersan, the foreman of the construction crew. A month later the demolition work resumed.
The houses, with 25 feet of frontage on Reade Street, will have 6,700 square feet of space and basement vaults of 1,000 square feet, usable for a pool or music studio or wine cellar. Facades will feature stone and cast-iron details, blending with surrounding buildings in the nearby TriBeCa West Historic district.
The houses will have a limestone central staircase, a rear glass staircase and a private elevator. Two will have drive-in garages. A ground-floor skylit eat-in kitchen includes Bulthaup cabinets and Viking appliances.
A double-height parlor, featuring floor-to-ceiling windows, a formal dining room and butler's pantry, can be combined into a 1,338-square-foot entertainment area on the second floor. There is a fireplace in the parlor, as well as in the fourth floor master bedroom. Three more bedrooms can be found on the fifth floor. A guest room or den is on the third floor, and there are two tiers of terraces at the roof.
Although details are provided down to the polished chrome Dornbracht towel ring and Julius Blum metal handrail, buyers have a chance to custom-fit interiors over the next couple of months. The ecological design includes geothermal heating and cooling and nontoxic glues and paint.
Two similar town houses -- one the architect plans for his family on the block and an 8,500-square-foot town house at 333 Greenwich Street -- are to be completed later. Only 2,854 one- and two-family town houses now exist in Manhattan, according to the Real Estate Board of New York.

HEADLINE: THE ENVIRONMENT;
Fuel Company Proposes Dumping Dredged Silt, Touching Off a Dispute

BYLINE: By STEVE STRUNSKY 

DATELINE: SANDY HOOK

 BODY:
On a recent breezy morning, four miles east of here, the Atlantic was a deep blue under the azure sky as whitecaps and glints of sunlight danced on the two-foot chop. There was no hint of the federally designated ocean cleanup site 53 feet below the waves.
"It's as beautiful as any other surface," said Andrew J. Willner, New York-New Jersey Baykeeper for the American Littoral Society in Sandy Hook, bobbing in a powerboat. "That's the beauty -- for the corps -- of ocean dumping. It's like sweeping something under the rug." 
 Kristen Milligan, a scientist with Clean Ocean Action, concurred: "Out of sight, out of mind.".
But the dumping ground has been very much on some people's minds lately as a fuel oil company, Castle Astoria Terminals, seeks approval from the United States Army Corps of Engineers to use the site to dump 90,000 cubic yards of silt that the company hopes to dredge from its tanker berths in the Astoria section of Queens, N.Y. Environmental advocates who believe the corps is predisposed to approve the application are trying hard to make sure the issue of dumping is not swept under the rug.
The cleanup area off Sandy Hook, known as the Historic Area Redemption Site, or HARS, surrounds a two-square-mile area six miles offshore that is commonly known as the mud dump, where dumping has been concentrated throughout the century. It is a gooey patch of ocean floor used as a dumping ground mainly for toxic sludge dredged from shipping channels and berths in the New York area. Ms. Milligan said barge skippers would open their hull's bay doors like toxic bombardiers, sending mounds of contaminated mud to sea floor -- and wherever else the current carried it.
Restrictions on the type of material dredged up and permitted to be dumped were tightened by Federal regulators in July 1996, when the 16-square-mile cleanup area was designated. Even so, the Astoria silt has been judged by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency as clean enough to be dumped on top of the existing sediment. A comment period is set to expire tomorrow, although no date has been set for a decision.
Environmentalists and others opposed to Castle Astoria's application insist that the silt contains higher levels of some contaminants than is already at the dump site, and that approving the project would amount to legalizing pollution of the ocean. "You cannot clean up an area by capping it with material that is more contaminated," Ms. Milligan said.
Representative Frank Pallone and Senator Robert Torricelli are among the New Jersey officials who have written to the corps opposing the project. Governor Whitman has remained publicly neutral on the application, deferring to the judgment of the corps, for which the Clean Ocean Action has criticized her.
Castle Astoria says the project is necessary to keep the berths deep enough to accommodate the tankers. Oil carried by the tankers is then used to heat businesses, schools and hospitals that buy oil directly from Castle or from oil dealers who buy from Castle. "The city runs, to a large extent, on fuel oil, and it's got to come from someplace," said Michael Meadvin, Castle's lawyer. "It's as simple as that."
The application could also have ramifications for future dredging projects in the region, where port officials say 170,000 jobs and $20 billion in economic activity are dependent on the shipping industry.
"Dredging is vital to commerce," said Allen Morrison, a spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. "If Castle Astoria's material meets those standards, its disposal as capping material at the mud dump, or HARS, should be allowed."
On a recent overcast morning, the steel gray waters of Castle Astoria's two berths, where Steinway Creek branches off from the East River, were not nearly as appealing as the ocean off Sandy Hook. The company's neighbors include a Consolidated Edison generating plant to the west, New York City's Bowery Bay Sewage Treatment Plant to the east and Rikers Island across the river. The Steinway & Sons piano factory next door is heated by Castle oil.
The company handles about eight million barrels of oil a year delivered on two dozen oceangoing tankers and about 150 barges, loaded onto other barges and up to 350 trucks a day in winter. The barges are not a problem, Mr. Carey said. But the tankers require a depth of about 35 feet, and the berths are as shallow as 25 feet on their southern end, which extend into the creek, a dead end, forcing the tankers, which range from 600 to 1,000 feet long, to pump their oil into forward compartments to back into the berths on an uneven keel.
Depending on how much longer the silt is allowed to accumulate, Mr. Carey said, the terminal, which employs 350 people, may no longer be viable. Castle's other terminal, in the Bronx, does not have a silt problem because it lies directly on the East River, where a current of five miles an hour carries the sediment along.
Opponents of Castle's application said there have been several oil spills at the site since the silt was tested, although company officials said only one -- in January -- occurred in the area being dredged and involved only 100 gallons of heavy-grade No. 6 oil that was fully recovered. Corps officials said they were aware of the spill and would determine whether new silt testing was needed.
The cost of dredging is about $7 a cubic yard or a total of $630,000 if the silt is ultimately dumped in the ocean. Environmentalists want the material disposed of differently, such as by using the silt to cap landfills. But Mr. Meadvin said that other methods of disposal, which would require some cleaning of the silt, costs up to 10 times as much. The company, a family-owned venture based in Harrison, N.Y., simply cannot afford it, he said.
The mud dump, an alphabet soup of PCB's (polychlorinated bi-phenols), PAH's (polycyclic aeromatic hydrocarbons), dioxin and other harmful substances, should not be confused with a sewage sludge dumping ground 106 miles off shore that is still fully active.
The chief concern of Clean Ocean Action and other opponents of the dumping is PAH's, which cause deformities in marine life. Ms. Milligan said testing indicated that PAH's were at a level of 750 to 1,500 parts per billion in the tissue of worms found in the Astoria silt. Tissue of worms at the HARS site had 550 parts per billion.
That may be so, say the dumping proponents. But the acceptable level for PAH's in marine animals is 40,000 parts per billion, as set by the E.P.A., said Mary Mears, a spokeswoman for the agency. And, Ms. Mears said, the Astoria silt is cleaner than what is at the dumping site in terms of many other kinds of contaminants.
"It's factual to say that the levels of that particular contaminant are higher than in the HARS, but it's also somewhat misleading because we don't agree with what they're saying about what the levels should be," Ms. Mears said.
Proponents of the dumping project criticized Clean Ocean Action's attack on the application, noting that the group embraced the new restrictions on the mud dump when they were announced in July 1996. Under the restrictions, dredge material is judged as category I, II or III, with I being the cleanest, and the only category permitted on the dump site. Some category I material dredged from local waters has already been dumped on the site since restrictions were tightened.
"The fact is, this is category I material and it is suitable for remediation," said Monte Greges, chief of the dredged material management section of the Corps of Engineers' New York district.
But Cindy Zipf, executive director of Clean Ocean Action, said specific levels of contaminants for each category were not announced by the environmental agency until December 1997, when her group objected to some levels as too high.
"The bottom line is, the goal is to clean up the area out there that's harmful to marine life," Ms. Zipf said. "This does not meet that goal."

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF;
Firefighter Applicants Short of Expected Total

BYLINE: By KAREN DeMASTERS 

 BODY:
The deadline for applying to be a member of one of the state's 69 paid fire departments has been extended two weeks until Sept. 3 because applications fell far short of the number anticipated, said Bill O'Brien, spokesman for the state Department of Personnel.
At least 10,000 applications were anticipated when the recruitment campaign began in June, but only 5,000 had been received by the middle of last week. Some 200,000 applications were made available by the state to supplement the ones distributed by local departments. 
 Approved applicants will take tests in November. The tests are the first statewide exams given in 19 years, following a long standoff with the Federal Government over the test's fairness to minorities. The new exam is made up of a physical test, a written test and a test of teamwork skills, Mr. O'Brien said.
Applications may have fallen short because of the good economy, which gives people more job options, Mr. O'Brien said. KAREN DeMASTERS

HEADLINE: Roomies on Wall Street

BYLINE: By JENNIFER 8. LEE

 BODY:
ON a Saturday afternoon that offered the first break from an 80-plus-hour work week, investment bankers lay bronzing on the rooftop terrace of 45 Wall Street. Sipping Evian and Corona beer, they took in a 29th-floor view of the landmarks of the financial district, close enough to reach out and touch: the Goldman Sachs building, the New York Stock Exchange, the World Trade Center, the J. P. Morgan building.
Other residents worked out in the building's mirrored penthouse gym, or shot pool in a wood-paneled lounge. The logos on their workout clothes formed a lineup of prestigious names: Harvard, Wharton, Morgan Stanley, Merrill Lynch -- all alma maters and employers. 
 The residents of 45 Wall Street are relatively young. They are urban. They are brazenly professional. The converted office building in which they live, one block from the New York Stock Exchange, has become known as an upscale dormitory of sorts for armies of fresh college graduates, who invade Wall Street from the country's premier universities.
"The question here is what Wall Street company do you work for, not what do you do," said James Im, a University of Chicago graduate, who was doing stomach crunches in the gym. "Forty-five Wall is famous. It's known to be an analysts' dormitory. If you're an analyst, you know someone who lives in 45 Wall."
To most financial investors, a Wall Street analyst is a respected stock picker. But "analyst" is also the title given to the foot soldiers of the industry who fill the lowest level of the Wall Street hierarchy. They put in back-breaking hours, pull all-nighters regularly and grease the capitalist machine through I.P.O.'s and mergers and acquisitions. They are intimate with Microsoft Excel and Powerpoint. "You're in the bottom of the food chain," said Valerie Zonenberg, 23, a Harvard University graduate who has worked for two years for a major Wall Street firm and lives at 45 Wall.
When it was converted two years ago to residential use, the building, which is managed by the Rockrose Development Corporation, was designed for professionals, with home offices; some apartments even have high-speed Internet access. But few take advantage of that option. Today, half of the residents work in the financial industry. The average age is 28. The average salary is $70,000.
The address has resonance. The Wall Street subway stop on the No. 2 and No. 3 trains is beneath the building. "It's all part of the mystique: 'I live on Wall Street, I work at Goldman Sachs,' " said one recent college graduate, tanning on the rooftop of 45 Wall, where he shares a three-bedroom apartment with two other analysts for $3,400 a month. "It's a culture. You walk downstairs in the morning and everyone is in suits. You feel like you're at the center of the world. Everything happens here."
The location is convenient, even though the financial district becomes a ghost town after 6 P.M. Half the residents live less than a 15-minute walk from work. "From door to desk, it takes me 2 minutes," David Saenz, an analyst with J. P. Morgan, said during a round of pool in the lounge.
Analysts say the proximity helps ease the life style. "When you are working 100 hours a week, you want to be able to walk to work," said Ms. Zonenberg, who pays $1,400 a month for a studio apartment. "Especially when you have three hours of sleep at night, you want to be able to run home and take a quick shower."
She is one of a group of people fulfilling a high-cost, high-payoff contract. They have agreed to serve as Wall Street's drudges for two or three years, in exchange for another blue-chip credential on their resumes. For many, Wall Street is just a stop on the way to business or law school. Others will stay in the financial industry. It's a combination rat race and paper chase. The end of the road is a place in the American aristocracy, earned through grit and luck.
The doormen at 45 Wall don't find it unusual when residents stumble in at 4 or 5 A.M. Tenants regularly arrive home as others are leaving for work. "They shower, sleep for two hours, get up and go to work again," said Thomas Wright, who was on the midnight to 8 A.M. door shift in the marble and redwood lobby. Doormen often give wake-up calls to rouse the employees from their naps. "I have some people come in so disgusted, they say the job is killing them," Mr. Wright said.
The analysts concede that their salaries are comfortable for a first job, but they are quick to point out that computed hourly, they are within a few dollars of minimum wage. "The joke is a McDonald's worker makes more per hour than we do," Ms. Zonenberg said. "Eighty hours a week is two jobs."
Residents of 45 Wall say they find strength in sharing the ordeal. "When you come home at 3 in the morning, you can always expect someone to walk in at the same time, also in a suit, also as exhausted as you are," Ms. Zonenberg said. "In the elevator ride, you're too tired to talk but you give each other that nod: 'I'm there, too. Thanks for being there.' "
"I don't see how they can work 100 hours a week," Mr. Wright said. "I tell them, 'Your health comes first. I don't care how much money you are making.' "
In return for the fatherly counsel, the financial professionals offer their doormen advice of their own. "I don't know anything about investments, but my tenants told me what to do with my money," Mr. Wright related. "They said take my money out of my savings account. Now, I'm in the stock market," he said, brandishing the current issue of the Janus fund report.
In many ways, the building is a high-class dormitory at sky-high Manhattan real estate prices. The young professionals live in groups of up to five in an apartment. Living rooms are partitioned to carve out bedrooms and economize. Bookshelves are filled with textbooks from summer finance training courses like "Essentials of Accounting" and "Principles of Corporate Finance."
Like many dorms, 45 Wall even has a common area -- the rooftop lounge, complete with pool table, big-screen television and a party-size wrap terrace, which can be rented for $100 a hour. Parties are a big part of life at 45 Wall. "Before, I had sublet in a building with older tenants," said Novisi Atadika, a recent Harvard graduate, who works at Credit Suisse First Boston. "There, they posted up signs that said, 'I'm sorry, I'm having a party.' Whereas here it's commonplace to party." Instead of beer kegs and pretzels, parties at 45 Wall typically have full bars and caterers.
Children are unusual, though becoming slightly more common. Older people wandering the hotel-like hallways are presumed to be parents of residents. "You are 35 in this building, you stand out," Ms. Zonenberg said. "If you are 45, you are the parent visiting the kids, bringing food to a son."
Other differences between college and the real world: the furniture is nicer, the televisions more expensive. Ikea is the furniture store of choice for the young professionals. This being Wall Street, the building has an indoor practice golf course. It also has a dry cleaning service, critical to appearing well groomed in a culture that hasn't fully taken to summer casual. Dry cleaning bills for the young analysts can approach $100 a month.
Residents rarely cook, and kitchens are barren. The analysts eat breakfast on the way to work, lunch in the office and dinner at a restaurant, traditionally paid for by companies for employees who stay late. Even when they're not working, the residents dine out or order in. The doormen see a steady stream of pizza and Chinese food deliveries on weekends.
"I have not once shopped for groceries in a year," Mr. Im said. "It's not out of the ordinary to go a few days without toilet paper and not care enough to do anything about it." His apartment refrigerator contains water, beer and leftover Chinese food. Ms. Zonenberg ate at home so seldom that she didn't buy a dining table and chairs until eight months into her lease.
For those who actually do purchase groceries, the scarcity of supermarkets in the financial district leaves them scrambling to stock their cabinets. Many analysts will have the company cars that drive them home make a loop to 24-hour groceries and delis so they can pick up basic necessities at 2 in the morning.
"Free meals, free rides home, free cell phones and pagers -- it appears to be a glamorous life style," one analyst said. "But there's no such thing as a free lunch. It's hard work. I would give up all those free meals to come home earlier."
Residents compare life at 45 Wall to a financial version of "Friends." The narrow pool of colleges and companies makes for only a few degrees of separation between people. "It's a great way to start a conversation," Mr. Saenz said. " 'Hey, you work at Salomon? I have a friend who works at Salomon.' 'Really? What group?' "
But the intensity and sameness of the work can result in narrow discussions. "You can't say, 'I saw this movie' or 'I went on vacation' because your life is filled with work," Mr. Im said.
Unsurprisingly, 45 Wall reflects the demographics of the financial industry. There are two men to every woman. Some say the building, like the Street, has a socially conservative cast. "There are fewer other gays in the building than anywhere else I've lived in New York City," said Jim Nellis, 45, a a senior vice president at Commpeople, a telecommunications company, who is one of the few baby-boomer residents. "Wall Street is so closeted."
Ms. Zonenberg, who still keeps her stuffed animals next to her financial textbooks, said that for her a building that is an extension of college is just fine for now. "I'm not ready to be in a place where there are babies, dogs and cats and real families everywhere," she said. "We know this is not the real world."

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS;
Erica Feldman, Daniel Bases

 BODY:
Dr. Erica Fran Feldman, a daughter of Jane Feldman and Dr. Melvyn Feldman of Otis, Mass., and Long Beach, N.Y., is to be married this morning to Daniel J. Bases, a son of Judith Bases and Dr. Robert Bases of New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi Abraham B. Eckstein is to officiate at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.
Mrs. Bases, 29, is a school psychologist for the public schools in Tenafly, N.J. She graduated magna cum laude from the University of Pennsylvania, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, and received a doctorate in psychology from Rutgers University. Her father is a dentist in Long Beach. Her mother is a docent at the Mission House, a house museum in Stockbridge, Mass. 
 Mr. Bases, also 29, was until July a financial reporter in Manhattan for Reuters, the news agency. He graduated from Columbia University, where last week he began a Knight-Bagehot Fellowship in Economics and Business Journalism. His father is a radiobiologist and a cancer research scientist at Montefiore Medical Center and a professor at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine, both in the Bronx. The bridegroom's mother is a caterer in New Rochelle.

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Upstarts' Risky Challenge to Baby Bells

BYLINE: By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
FOR a long time, investing in the local telephone business meant buying sleepy yet bedrock-solid stocks like those of the Baby Bells. Substantially protected from competition until the enactment of the Telecommunications Act of 1996, the Bells and other local phone companies provided steady if unspectacular earnings growth, healthy dividends and next to no surprises.
As investments, these companies are still relatively conservative and stable. But decades-old companies no longer have the local communications business to themselves. Dozens of upstarts, known in the communications business as competitive local exchange carriers (or CLEC's, pronounced "SEE-lecks"), are out to provide competition in local communications markets ranging from phone service to corporate data applications. The companies hope to use new communications technologies and lean cost structures to undercut the local giants while still making money. 
 Their stocks provide investors a new way to participate in the local end of the communications revolution, but they are also an entirely different breed of investment vehicle -- risky and erratic, because of their dependence on borrowed funds. From mid-June to mid-August, most of these stocks lost about 20 percent of their market value, though they have started to crawl back.
"They bring a lot of rocket fuel to a portfolio," said Mark Kastan, who tracks the stocks for Merrill Lynch. "They could significantly enhance performance. But it's obviously high-risk, high-reward."
Consider the RCN Corporation, one of the few upstarts that is aimed at residential customers, rather than at businesses. Along with Nextlink Communications Inc., which was founded by Craig O. McCaw, the cellular phone pioneer, RCN is one of Mr. Kastan's favorite CLEC's.
RCN's stock opened 1998 at $17.0625, climbed as high as $30.625 and then fell that October to $8.75 as the bottom fell out of the high-yield debt market. By April 1999, the shares had surged to $54.50. But with interest rates rising, RCN's shares have swooned again, closing on Friday at $39.50.
"MCI was the only competitive player on the long-distance landscape for a long time, and it was an unbelievably volatile company," said Alex J. Mandl, chairman of Teligent Inc., a local service provider that uses fixed wireless links. "In a sense, I think you're seeing a similar situation in the local environment," he said. "As 30, 40, 50 percent of the local market is occupied by new players, I think that volatility will go away."
In the meantime, said Alex W. Peters, a communications analyst for Franklin Advisors and co-manager of the Franklin Global Utilities fund, "these are high-beta stocks, so they outperform the market in good times and underperform in bad times." Among Mr. Peters' favorites is McLeodUSA Inc., one of the more established of the upstarts, which focuses on the Midwest and Rocky Mountain regions.
Perceptions of whether times are good or bad for the CLEC's tend to change swiftly, because creating local networks is very expensive. Pulling optical fiber under downtown streets, for instance, can cost tens of millions of dollars in one city. So to maintain their growth, almost all of them will have to return to the high-yield well in the next 12 to 18 months. If interest rates go up, so will the companies' cost of borrowing. Because Wall Street values them on a discounted cash flow model that focuses mostly on results in some distant year, a small change in interest rates can imply a big swing in long-term valuations. Some Wall Street analysts estimate that a 1 percent change in interest rates can result in a 15 percent change in the value of one of these companies.
But there have been other, more industry-specific concerns, too -- for example, the impact of a proposal by a coalition of big local and long-distance phone companies to lower the per-minute fees that long-distance carriers pay to their local counterparts for beginning and ending calls. In exchange, the local carriers would be able to charge their customers higher fixed monthly fees. If approved by Federal regulators, the plan would have a small but negative impact on many of the local upstarts because they focus on serving high-volume business users.
But the essential issues facing investors in all these stocks concern the basic structure of the telecommunications industry, not relatively small regulatory questions.
"Fundamentally, is the 100-year-old AT&T and Bell company network the network for the next 10 or 20 years, given the way people communicate now over the Internet?" said David C. McCourt, RCN's chairman. "If the answer is no, then a basket of CLEC's is a good investment. If the answer is yes, then CLEC's are not such a great idea."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Competition is rising in local phone markets. Splicers, above, installed fiber-optic cable for RCN in Manhattan. At left, the interior of a connection box, or splice. (Frances Roberts for The New York Times)
 
Chart: "Dial Tones for Strong Stomachs"
Competitive local exchange carriers, or CLEC's, offer alternatives to the Baby Bells in local phone and data services. But they make for nerve-wracking investments, as shown by their betas, a measure of volatility. A beta of 1 means a stock's volatility equals that of the Standard & Poor's 500; higher numbers represent greater volatility.

HEADLINE: GRASS-ROOTS BUSINESS;
A Suburb Sees the Future In Its Old Downtown

BYLINE: By JOEL KOTKIN; Joel Kotkin is a senior fellow at the Pepperdine Institute for Public Policy. His column on the Main Street economy appears the fourth Sunday of each month. E-mail: grassrts@nytimes.com

DATELINE: DOWNERS GROVE, Ill.

 BODY:
ELLEN K. DEAN has seen the future of this middle-class Chicago suburb, and it lies in its past.
Until recently, commercial development in Downers Grove and hundreds of similar towns across the country meant accommodating strip malls and "big box" chain retailers. But Ms. Dean, Downers Grove's economic development director, says that model is played out. If her city wants a vibrant retail future, she believes, it will find it on its old Main Street. 
 "A lot of cities are getting into the idea that the big box is the future, but I think they are becoming commodities, and their product can be gotten on the Internet," Ms. Dean said, stepping carefully through the reconstruction work the city has undertaken to brighten its downtown streetscape, including installing new sewer pipes and new pavement on Main Street. "We think specialty retailers like the ones here are the future, and so is downtown. The future is more interactive and people-friendly."
The ambitious effort to revitalize downtown Downers Grove, where many of the brick buildings date from around the turn of the last century, reflects a broader trend seen in other smaller towns around the country. Taking a cue from successful projects in big cities like Chicago, suburban communities that for years seemed content to allow malls to proliferate while old downtowns deteriorated have begun to reverse course and rediscover the potential in their historic cores. The trend is epitomized in Downers Grove, Evanston and Highland Park around Chicago, and Santa Monica and Pasadena near Los Angeles, among others.
Communities have tried to re-inject life into their downtowns before. One wave of such projects crested about two decades ago, as cities and towns in many regions tried to combat the burgeoning strength of new edge-of-town shopping centers by sprucing up Main Streets, turning busy shopping blocks into pedestrian malls and erecting parking ramps downtown. Some projects succeeded in forestalling shoppers' flight to the malls for a time, but many proved as futile as they were expensive, as vacant storefronts continued to proliferate.
More recently, urban commercial neighborhoods have turned to organizing business improvement districts, which use money from parking fees or local tax surcharges to pay for cosmetic improvements and stepped-up services like street cleaning -- but again with mixed results.
But one important factor is different this time around. The new wave of Main Street projects is a response not to the strength of shopping centers but to their perceived new weakness, prompted in part by the explosion in Internet retailing.
For the same reasons that new shopping centers once emptied old downtowns -- convenience and lower prices -- the Internet has now begun to siphon off a significant share of sales from shopping centers' big tenants. And just as important to city officials like Ms. Dean, it has cut into sales tax revenue in mainstay categories like airline tickets, books, records, clothing and, especially, cars. "I was shocked when one of our car dealers told me that 25 percent of his sales now go on the Internet," she recalled. "That's the kind of thing that makes me shake in my boots."
To be sure, many communities are still trying to attract as many new big-box retailers, strip centers and malls as possible. Towns and small suburban cities like Downers Grove still depend on them for a huge share of the sales and property taxes that finance their budgets.
Yet there are clear signs, even in a healthy commercial market like metropolitan Chicago, that this style of retail development has passed the saturation point. Richard Knitter, president of Great American Realty in Oak Park, another Chicago suburb, estimates that there are already roughly 200 giant, empty store buildings surrounded by acres of parking in the region, representing 10 million square feet, with an additional 5 million square feet due to become available in the next year.
Mr. Knitter said a number of factors are contributing to the oversupply, with revenue losses to Internet commerce fairly low on the list. He cited intense competition among national chains that has flattened many second-tier local competitors, as well as many retailers' unwillingness to occupy space deserted by failed stores.
"Some of it is superstition about going into a failed location," said Mr. Knitter, a retail real estate consultant whose firm specializes in the Midwest market. "But people often want to build their own building with their own footprint, rather than go into someone else's. A Walgreen's is always a certain number of square feet -- they don't want to change the configuration; they want them to look the same and be the same."
The casualties are scattered liberally between downtown Chicago and its western suburban ring. Some have been razed and redeveloped, occasionally by other retailers, while others have been converted into educational or medical centers. The rest remain vacant, awaiting new uses, which Mr. Knitter thinks could eventually include housing, recreational facilities or even pet cemeteries. In Downers Grove, the trend is manifested in a big store on Ogden Avenue that has been vacant for five years and in the city's failure to attract new retail development on several shopping-center-size parcels.
So the city has decided to concentrate instead on restoring Main Street to what it once was: an attractive strolling, shopping and dining destination for the surrounding region and a convenient and desirable place for singles and "empty nesters" to live.
Ms. Dean points to the many essential services found downtown -- city hall, the library and the post office are there -- and its intimate, pedestrian-friendly atmosphere, rare in newer suburbs. The 300 retail businesses operating downtown differ markedly from typical mall fare and include independent bakeries and restaurants; the city's one brew pub, the Founder's Hill Brewing Company; a consignment store; a locally owned five and dime, and a movie theater, the Tivoli, that dates from 1928. An adjacent park features a band shell for outdoor concerts.
"Downtown provides something unique -- the entertainment, meet-and-greet venue," Ms. Dean said over a soft drink at Founder's Hill. "This can't be duplicated on the Internet at all. Virtual reality is not reality. This is."

HEADLINE: Word for Word: Neology;
In the Dictionary Game, Yada Yada Yada Is Satisficing to Some, Not Others

BYLINE: By ELIN SCHOEN BROCKMAN 

 BODY:
THE people who compile dictionaries always have "news" (n. pl. Oxford English Dictionaries' in-house word for new words). But neologisms are not always newly minted. Take "yada yada yada," which long before "Seinfeld" was used by Lenny Bruce. 
 Jesse Sheidlower, the senior editor in charge of new words at Random House, became convinced of yada yada yada's staying power not only by its history, but also by the existence of well-established parallel expressions (blah blah blah, for instance). He put it in the 1996 Random House Webster's College Dictionary.
However, Michael Agnes, editor in chief of Webster's New World College Dictionary, excluded yada yada yada from his 1996 edition. And having tracked a decline in its use, he is glad that he did. "This year we would have had to take it out," he said.
New words help give each dictionary its personality. The differences among them may not be readily apparent to the average reader, but when the editors of four dictionaries provided their unabridged new word lists for comparison, there was no overlap. One of the editors, on hearing just six words from the list of a competitor, was able to guess its identity immediately.
What follows is only a brief sampling of the news. The fourth edition of Webster's New World College Dictionary, the only one represented here for which a final count is available, because it has been published, added 7,000 entries. One of them, Nunavut, just made the deadline, because the editors had to wait until Canada officially declared the new territory of Nunavut.
There are always late-breaking news, words waiting to be accepted. Oxford U.S. Dictionaries, for instance, which publishes several dictionaries including the Oxford American Dictionary and Language Guide, has this on its waiting list, pending more evidence: "Fuggedaboudit." ELIN SCHOEN BROCKMAN
