HEADLINE: A Domestic Sort With Global Worries

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
When President Clinton made a televised address to the nation about Kosovo last March 24, he uttered a sentence for which he was belabored that day and every day for the next 10 weeks, until he finally declared victory on June 10: "I do not intend to put our troops in Kosovo to fight a war."
On May 18, with the outcome of the bombing campaign still in serious doubt, the President sharply altered course with the comment, "I don't think we or our allies should take any options off the table, and that has been my position from the beginning," which of course it had not. 
 It was Mr. Clinton's national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, known as Sandy, who wrote the initial offending sentence. Both he and his boss saw fairly quickly that it was a mistake, because they realized that having plunged into the conflict with President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia, there was no acceptable alternative to a NATO victory. If ground troops were needed to get the Serbian tanks out of Kosovo, then ground troops it would have to be.
Mr. Milosevic may well have held out longer than he otherwise would have because he believed that he faced no danger of land combat, and he certainly gained time to savage ethnic Albanians in Kosovo and drive them out. Mr. Berger told a friend as early as April that he should have put in something about leaving all options on the table.
He did not do so, Mr. Berger said a few days after the bombing had stopped, because "the American people would not have supported the war without European participation, and we never could have gotten all 19 allies on board at the outset if they thought we had any plan to use ground forces." In keeping with that view, Mr. Clinton cut his rhetorical cloth to fit the politics of both NATO and the United States.
The explosion of criticism crossed party and ideological lines. In an op-ed article in The Wall Street Journal, Zbigniew Brzezinski, President Carter's national security adviser, accused the Administration of indulging in "a new technological racism" based on the premise that the life of "one American serviceman was not worth risking in order to save the lives of thousands of Kosovars." The Economist headlined an editorial, "A Bungled War." Michael Kelly, a columnist, suggested that a ham and cheese sandwich could run foreign policy better than Mr. Berger and his colleagues.
Mr. Berger's place at the nexus of Kosovo strategy was no surprise, nor was his concentration on the political aspects of the matter. Widely regarded as the President's closest foreign-policy aide, perhaps the most influential national security adviser since Henry A. Kissinger, he is at bottom a political rather than strategic figure. Unlike the professors, diplomats and military officers who have for the most part preceded him in his job, he made his way to the White House by way of the salons and back rooms of Democratic politics while pursuing a public career as a trade lawyer.
"He has the lawyer's inherent caution," said John Dyson, a New York investor and political operative who has known Mr. Berger since college. "The craft is a tactical craft. You focus on the downside, always worrying about avoiding negative results."
Beefy and chubby-cheeked at 53, serious and formal in dark suits and white shirts, Mr. Berger makes a sharp contrast to his elfin predecessor, Anthony Lake, whom he served as a deputy during Mr. Clinton's first term. Mr. Lake wore professorial tweeds. He was so seldom seen in public that friends called him "the submarine." But Mr. Berger's is a familiar face on television and on Capitol Hill, where he has built strong links to both parties.
 
The Style
A 15-Hour Day, And a Modest Ego
In the first term, Mr. Lake and the other main foreign-policy figures were older than Mr. Clinton. Now they are contemporaries. Mr. Berger, who has known Mr. Clinton since the McGovern Presidential campaign of 1972, helped him in small but important ways at low points in his career.
He has a closer relationship to the President than Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright, who is better at formulating policies than in selling them to Mr. Clinton, or Defense Secretary William S. Cohen, a Republican who spent the first Clinton term in the Senate.
It is difficult to find anyone who knows him who does not like Mr. Berger personally. You might as well try to find someone who doesn't like Sara Lee.His ego is of normal dimensions. He buys his reading glasses at the drug store. In a city where backbiting is the preferred contact sport, he is widely considered a gentleman. In a culture of 12-hour-days, he regularly puts in Stakhanovite stints of 15 and 16, fueled by endless glasses of iced coffee, which he took to drinking when he gave up smoking. Colleagues worry that he might fall victim to the same tensions as Leon Fuerth, Vice President Al Gore's foreign-policy counsellor, who suffered a heart attack this year.
But Mr. Berger gets very mixed reviews as a security adviser from those outside his immediate circle. A European ambassador said he lacked "the indispensable ability to see around corners, to anticipate events and to see how one problem relates to another." A friend and sometime Administration colleague said Mr. Berger lacked strategic vision but "wants to be accepted as a kind of Sandy Kissinger."
Mr. Kissinger himself commented rather condescendingly, "you can't expect a trade lawyer to be a global strategist."
Dick Morris, Mr. Clinton's former political guru, wrote recently that "there are hundreds of members of the Council on Foreign Relations who know more about foreign policy than Berger," but he added that Mr. Berger was "just right" for the President's concept of foreign policy which, he said, centers on domestic political and economic considerations, not on strategy.
In his defense Mr. Berger's friends note that Mr. Clinton's attention to events abroad is intermittent. One retired American diplomat blamed "a disastrous Balkan policy in which every aspect has been treated incrementally" mostly on the President. During the Lewinksy matter, a Cabinet member added, "The whole rhythm of the Government was thrown off, because the big guy had something more important on his mind than any foreign-policy crisis -- a 900-pound gorilla that was always in the room with him, named impeachment.
Finally, Mr. Berger has to deal with a world seismically remade by the end of the cold war.
"Everyone wants a new framework for American foreign policy," said Harry McPherson, a Texan who worked in the Johnson White House and has closely watched all the White Houses that followed his. "Well, great. But who has produced one? Sandy's a carpenter, not an architect, like everyone else these days. He's a good one, and that may be the best we can hope for now."
As things turned out in Kosovo, Mr. Milosevic buckled under the pressure of bombardment. But it was "an exceptionally close-run thing," a senior Administration official said, with talks about peace terms taking place at the same time as discussions about sending in the troops if no agreement was reached by the end of June. And the allies were unable, in the end, to prevent the slaughter of many of the Kosovo Albanians they acted to protect.
Mr. Berger said "the President truly believed, as I believed and no more than three other people in America did, that air power would prevail."
But it is not yet clear that the war has been won. It is not clear how many ethnic Albanians will ultimately be able to rebuild their lives, or how successful the NATO alliance will be at achieving the multi-ethnic society it says it wants for Kosovo. There is little prospect of stabilizing the Balkans, an important goal of American policy, without a stable Serbia. Yet that land is in ruins, Mr. Milosevic remains in office and Mr. Clinton has vowed to give only minimal rebuilding aid as long as he clings to power.
 
The Beginnings

Mr. Berger grew up in Millerton, a then-isolated rural community of 900 people in the dairy country of Duchess County, N. Y., northeast of Poughkeepsie. His father died when he was only 8, and his mother ran a struggling Army-Navy surplus store. The White House
A Friend of Bill's Who Never Left

 CORRECTION:
A profile on Aug. 25 about Samuel R. Berger, President Clinton's national security adviser, referred incompletely to the context of a comment he made in 1991 that "grand strategies" were mostly rationales developed after the fact to explain successful ad hoc decisions. Mr. Berger made that remark at a panel discussion in which he talked about the 10 years in which he was developing an international law practice for his firm, Hogan & Hartson. After the article appeared, his office said his comment applied only to the specific work of putting together a law practice and not to his vision of American foreign policy in his current job.

HEADLINE: Following the Money, Through the Web

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE

 BODY:
WITH the 2000 Presidential race cranking up especially early, the denizens of that fabled ZIP code, 90210, are beginning to do what they do best in every election cycle: dust off their checkbooks and let their money fly.
If money is the mother's milk of politics, then 90210 is one of the biggest cash cows around. That Beverly Hills ZIP code gave more to Federal candidates last year than any other in California, by a long shot, and more than most other ZIP codes in the country. This year, the rich and famous are starting early: Candice Bergen has given the Gore campaign $1,000, Rob Reiner kicked in $2,000, Jack Nicholson gave $250 and Hugh Hefner $1,000. 
 Barbra Streisand, one of 90210's biggest givers in 1998, with more than $38,000 in donations, has also given Al Gore $1,000 this year, though she has since switched her address to Santa Monica (90401). Warren Beatty, a 90210 resident who says some people are urging him to run for President himself, has given nothing to anyone -- perhaps deciding to save his money for his own bid.
Where does this information come from? The Web, of course, where technology is shedding new light on political contributions. Once hidden in dusty archives and often kept in hard-to-find spots that politicians did not make any easier to locate, campaign finance records on the state and national levels are now available on a growing number of user-friendly Web sites.
And, of course, it is not just the rich and famous whose donations can be tracked but everyone's -- even yours and your next-door neighbor's. All campaign donations are considered public information, and the records are readily available for public view.
This technological development is adding a new dimension to political discourse. Where political races once focused primarily on personalities, partisanship and issues, an awareness of -- and concern over -- the role of money in politics has grown. In large part, technology is driving and accelerating the debate by providing more and more information.
Hardly anyone knew who gave money to Franklin D. Roosevelt or Dwight D. Eisenhower or Harry S. Truman. But that ignorance -- which was sometimes the result of political calculation -- has been replaced by a new transparency.
The Internet is making it easy for journalists, competing candidates and ordinary citizens to connect the dots between politicians and their sources of money. And that has come about despite efforts by many in Congress to keep the activities of the Federal Election Commission, the Government agency that collects much of this data, to a bare minimum.
"Now people can sit at their terminal and pull up all this information," said Charles Lewis, executive director of the Center for Public Integrity, a Washington policy research group. "For the Presidential race, you don't have to leave your work station, and this means the barriers to getting this information have been substantially removed. This is an extraordinary development. Anyone, anywhere in America, can click onto one of these Web sites and see who is behind their lawmaker. And they couldn't five years ago."
"I don't want to sound pie-in-the-sky," continued Mr. Lewis, whose group has state-level campaign finance information on its Web site, www.publicintegrity.org. "But this brings democracy and accountability much closer to the average citizen. Frankly, it's wonderful."
To some, however, it is not so wonderful. As the availability of financial records has grown, so have attempts to evade disclosure. In the last few years, independent advocacy groups have cropped up to to sponsor televised political attack ads that are not connected with any candidate or party. These groups enjoy legal protections that allow them to stay out of Government records and spread their money in secrecy.
"One of the unintended effects of this new visibility is a growth in some of these subterranean activities," said Kenneth Gross, a Washington lawyer who specializes in election law.
Right now, there are around a half-dozen campaign finance Web sites, each offering slightly different information or different ways to connect candidates and dollars.
Some sites focus on the relationship between campaign donations and votes on Capitol Hill. Others provide information on every shred of campaign finance data filed with the Government, including copies of the often-obscure filings. Still others focus on candidates at the state level.
Ground zero for all this information is the Federal Election Commission. Each Federal candidate and party must provide filings with the commission on how much money is raised, who donated it and how the money is spent.
For decades, the information was stored on paper in one spot in Washington or on computers that required a trip to the commission's offices to use. But in the 1996 elections, the commission began putting much of the information on line, though the site was not easy to use then.
Campaign finance rules adopted after Watergate limit individual contributions to $25,000 a year. They permit individuals to give no more than $20,000 to a national party, $5,000 to a political action committee and $2,000 to a candidate -- up to $1,000 for the primary and $1,000 for the general election. Corporations and unions are prohibited from donating to Federal candidates.
Those restricted contributions are often called hard money. By contrast, soft money is the name often given to what individuals, unions and corporations can give in unlimited amounts to national party committees for "party-building" activities. While ostensibly earmarked for generic activities like voter-education programs, soft money has become a way for big donations to go almost directly to candidates.
Whether hard or soft, all donations must be reported to the elections commission.
At www.fec.gov, everything anyone could possibly want to know about Federal election rules and donations is available. And, borrowing some of the user-friendly techniques of campaign finance Web sites run by public policy groups, the commission has made its site much easier to navigate. It is now easy for anyone to punch in a person's name under the View Contributions category on the home page (try William Gates, for instance) and see their donations.
The site lets a person view the actual documents filed by the candidates (for instance, the page listing Mr. Gates's $3,000 donation to the Republican Majority Fund, a political action committee, in which Mr. Gates describes his occupation as "C.E.O."). And, unlike on other Web sites, all spending data and every document filed by candidates and political committees with the Government can be seen.
"We always thought of ourselves as being responsible for providing the basic raw material at this Web site," said Robert Biersack, the site's Webmaster. "We also want to provide a very close, visible connection to the original source document. The connection between computer data and the original document is very important to us."
"What's also new is the way our data interrelates," Mr. Biersack added. "You can go to a candidate's filings and then find out who else is giving to that candidate or committee in a stream-of-consciousness way."
The granddaddy of all independent campaign finance Web sites, and perhaps the most comprehensive, is www.tray.com, which was set up in 1996 by two former Federal Election Commission employees who formed a Washington research firm called Public Disclosure Inc.
Their site takes often-fragmented commission data and organizes the information into an accessible, logical and simple-to-use format. Whether it's following individual donations, looking at the Clinton legal defense fund, tracking the 2000 Federal candidates or exploring soft money donations, the site is a one-stop shopping center for campaign finance data.
For instance, in the section about the 2000 Presidential race, a search for information about Dan Quayle shows not only donations, but also transfers to his campaign from party committees as well as all his disbursements and the locations of all his contributors. The contributor list can also be sorted by employer and occupation.
The page on Senator Phil Gramm Republican of Texas, shows donations back to 1980 and links to political action committees that have given to Mr. Gramm, the Texas Republican. It also includes money he has given to other candidates and his personal financial statement.
"We're interested in putting this information out without any spin," said Tony Raymond, who founded the site with a former commission official, Kent Cooper, "because we feel the dollars speak for themselves."
Mr. Raymond said the site was averaging around 7,000 to 12,000 visits a day early this summer, a number that he said would "go through the roof" when the 2000 election got into full swing later this year.
At the Web site for the Center for Responsive Politics (www.opensecrets.org), the emphasis is on the correlation between contributions and votes in Congress.
The site has easy-to-read reports on different industry groups and which candidates got their contributions. And its candidate profiles are comprehensive, showing raw data for who gave money as well as data for industry groups, presented with colorful graphs and charts.
The site shows, for instance, that George W. Bush, the Republican Presidential hopeful, is getting more money from every sector of the economy -- except labor unions and lawyers -- than any other candidate, including Vice President Al Gore. While Mr. Bush has received more than $1 million from the oil and gas industry, Mr. Gore has received $56,700; while the health care industry has given Mr. Bush more than $1 million, Mr. Gore has received $340,000.
"We are building a sandbox for people to play in," said Larry Makinson, executive director of the Center for Responsive Politics. "We want people to grasp things easily. That's why we use lots of charts. We want people to see what they got from their candidates from all this money spent. After any vote in Congress, we want people to know whether money bought something or failed to buy something."
Has all this disclosure and potential public scrutiny made some donors squeamish? The answer is: sort of.
And one side of politics that often does not show up on campaign finance sites involves issue advocacy groups. In the last Presidential election, such groups poured millions of dollars into television advertisements attacking candidates or praising them -- but without expressly advocating a candidate's election or defeat. Because the groups operate independently of the candidates and their ads do not contain the words "vote for" or "vote against," the law does not require that they register with the F.E.C. or list their donors.
"I suspect that all this Internet data is leading to some of the current pressure to move donations off the radar screen," said Trevor Potter, a Washington lawyer and former Federal Election Commissioner. "A lot of people who didn't want their activities disclosed in the first place are more threatened and trying more vigorously to avoid that spotlight."

HEADLINE: In America;
A Nation Losing Its Citizens

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT

 BODY:
In the bitter cold of a January day in 1961, with snow on the ground and a crystalline sky overhead, a day on which the world's most powerful men were dressed in morning coats and top hats, a young President declared that the "torch has been passed to a new generation of Americans," and he urged his fellow citizens, the young in particular, to join with him in the great work of the nation.
You could still talk like that in 1961. Idealism had not yet suffered the near-fatal wounds of the decades that followed. An awful lot of people, young and old, found themselves responding as John F. Kennedy said, "With a good conscience our only sure reward, with history the final judge of our deeds, let us go forth to lead the land we love, asking His blessing and His help, but knowing that here on earth God's work must truly be our own." 
 "John Kennedy drew a whole generation to public service," said Patricia McGinnis, who heads the Council for Excellence in Government, a nonpartisan group in Washington that works to improve the quality of government and the relationship between government and the people it serves.
"President Kennedy encouraged people to participate, and I think that was his greatest legacy," she said. "Where is that leadership now?"
A national poll sponsored by the council and released last month found that a large majority of Americans now feel disconnected from government. And in what appears to be an ominous trend, it's the younger Americans who feel the most estranged.
The poll was conducted by Democratic pollster Peter Hart and Republican pollster Robert Teeter. It found that more than twice as many Americans (64 percent) feel "distant and disconnected" from government than feel "close and connected" (30 percent).
Americans for the most part view government, especially the Federal Government, as remote and far more responsive to special interests than to the public interest. And the scandals that have erupted around one top official after another -- from Watergate to Monicagate and beyond -- have further turned people off.
Said Mr. Hart: "Voters see all of the transgressions or supposed transgressions going on in political life and they say, 'Why should I participate?' "
What is most pronounced in the poll is the degree to which younger Americans feel out of touch with the government. A report that accompanied the poll said, " The gulf between the citizens and their government grows larger with each successive generation."
In the lowest age group surveyed, 18 to 34 years old, 68 percent of the respondents said they felt disconnected from government.
The authors warned: "If each new generation continued to form a weaker attachment to government than the one before, the country would fairly soon find that only a small minority of citizens was connected to and involved with government."
The report is titled "America Unplugged -- Citizens and Their Government." It found that a majority of Americans tend to think in terms of the government as opposed to our government, and said: "To talk about government as "ours" is to state -- even if unconsciously -- a sense of ownership, and perhaps also a sense of belonging or involvement. People who think in terms of the government, by contrast, are revealing their feeling that government is not accountable to them."
Over several decades in this century Americans were drawn into closer contact with the government, and to a certain extent each other, by major crises, including two world wars and a Depression.
"Government was very important to people," said Mr. Teeter. "Almost anything people wanted, whether it was the civil rights movement or the environmental movement or whatever, government was what they turned to as the vehicle to do it."
There is no sense of crisis at the moment. The economy is humming, the stock markets are high and inflation is low. But there is more to the life of a great nation than the bottom line. We have shown that we can be prosperous, but it's hard to imagine how we can be better without more citizen involvement in what John Kennedy saw as a great and joint endeavor.

HEADLINE: U.S. Lawmaker Faults Japan for Halting Food to North Korea

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 25

 BODY:
A United States Congressman sharply criticized Japan today for cutting off food aid to famine-stricken North Korea as millions of tons of surplus rice are sitting in Japanese warehouses.
The Congressman, Tony P. Hall, a Democrat from Ohio who has a long history of fighting world hunger, passed through Tokyo today on his way to North Korea, where he plans to begin an unofficial visit on Thursday to survey the famine situation and deliver medicine donated by United States religious groups. 
 "North Korea has sent out an S O S that it can't feed its people, and Japan, the world's largest donor, is ignoring that cry for help because of political reasons," Mr. Hall said in a meeting with reporters. "The Japanese are sitting on a tremendous amount of food which they are using as a weapon while millions of people are starving."
Mr. Hall said that Japan had stockpiled between three million tons and five million tons of rice after having a bumper crop. He suggested that Japan sell the rice surpluses at "friendship prices" to international aid organizations.
"Humanitarian aid should be given in an unconditional way," Mr. Hall said. "If any of you have seen people starve to death, you'll never forget it."
The Japanese Government ended its relief aid to North Korea last August after North Korea test-fired a medium-range ballistic missile that flew over the Japanese mainland and into the Pacific Ocean. A spokesman for Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi said Japan had no plans to resume food aid to North Korea.
"We are waiting for a constructive signal coming from North Korea to improve the bilateral relationship," said Akitaka Saiki, a deputy press secretary. "So far, that signal has not come from the North Korean capital."
Before the 1998 missile launching, Japan supplied North Korea with 500,000 pounds of rice and a $500,000 contribution to United Nations aid organizations in 1995; $6 million to international aid agencies like the World Food Program in 1996; and $27 million to the food program and $841,389 in medical assistance to the International Red Cross in 1997, according to the Foreign Ministry.
An official of the Agriculture Ministry, who requested anonymity, said that bumper crops during the last four years had allowed Japan to stockpile almost three million tons of rice. The official said the ministry planned to reduce those reserves to about two million tons of rice by the end of this year through crop reduction.
The official said that such large surpluses of rice are not necessarily available for donation, as Japan often uses them to offset shortages.
Mr. Hall's comments on aid echo those of Catherine Bertini, executive director of the United Nations World Food Program, who after a recent trip to North Korea said that there were signs the famine situation was improving but that people were still starving and that more aid was needed. Ms. Bertini called on the United States, Japan and other countries not to end their aid to North Korea, even if it launches another missile.
Some experts have estimated that between two million and three million people, mainly old people and children, died during the worst years of the famine, from 1995 to 1998.
While Mr. Hall was critical of Japan, he also had strong words for North Korea. He said that he would use his fifth visit to the Communist-run country to warn officials that if they proceeded with plans to test-fire a new long-range missile their country would suffer dire consequences.
"My message to North Korean officials will be very simple," Mr. Hall said. "Don't fire the missile. You'll be really, really hurting yourself if you do."
The United States, which Mr. Hall said supplied 83 percent of all aid to North Korea last year, has threatened to end its assistance if the missile is fired. South Korea said it would end its agriculture and economic development programs to the North, while Japan has threatened to cut off the flow of financial remittances from North Koreans living in Japan.
Mr. Hall said he was convinced that if North Korea proceeded with the missile launching, the Republican-controlled Congress would suspend all United States aid to the country. "The votes are already there and I'm afraid there wouldn't be much we could do to stop it," he said.
The Congressman said that on his last visit to North Korea, last year, he saw North Korean children with patchy hair, protruding bones, open sores, and other signs of severe malnutrition.
He said the Government was distributing what officials there called "substitute food" -- dried leaves and straw, so coarse that even cattle would not eat it.
Mr. Hall said that medicine and medical supplies were so scarce in North Korea that many operations are conducted without electric lights or anesthesia and that gauze and cotton balls are washed and reused.

HEADLINE: What the Apollo Means for Harlem

 BODY:
Harlem was once the center of life for the African-American middle class and a storied gathering place for artists, writers and musicians. Middle-class flight, business closings and the urban disorders of the 1960's robbed the district of its grandeur and have presented a formidable challenge to private entrepreneurs and government agencies that have been striving to restore Harlem as a desirable place to live and work in Manhattan.
No institution personifies Harlem's problems -- or its promise -- more clearly than the Apollo Theater, a music venue whose name is recognized around the world but whose management has consistently failed to maximize the theater's value or keep it in good working order. In addition, the board that now runs the theater has been sued by the State Attorney General, who has accused it of questionable fiscal practices over a period of several years. 
 The theater is owned by the state but operated by the nonprofit Apollo Theater Foundation. The suit accused the foundation's board of failing to collect millions of dollars owed it by Percy Sutton, a businessman and former Manhattan Borough President, whose company produces a weekly variety program for television at the theater.
The Attorney General, Eliot Spitzer, has offered the Apollo a chance at commercial success -- and a way out of legal trouble -- saying he will drop the lawsuit if the foundation's board yields control to the entertainment giant Time Warner. The agreement requires Mr. Sutton and associates to pay the foundation about $700,000 and stipulates that the foundation expand its board, giving Time Warner power to appoint the majority of the members. Charles Rangel, Harlem's Democratic Congressman, would also be required to step down as the board's chairman.
Last week the relevant parties seemed to have agreed on a settlement that would bring the theater a fresh infusion of both cash and talent and get Mr. Spitzer to put aside the suit. But the settlement was derailed by some of the board's more powerful members. As the current chairman, Mr. Rangel has a special responsibility to put aside political gamesmanship and sign this agreement promptly. Time Warner has threatened to abandon the deal if there are more shenanigans.
If the settlement goes through smoothly, Harlem's commercial area could get a boost that might entice other companies to follow Time Warner's lead. But if the board drags its feet or the deal falls through, the negative fallout could harm both the Apollo and the prospects for an economic recovery along Harlem's business strip, 125th Street. Put another way, the deal sets the tone for the entire revitalization effort.

HEADLINE: Gore Cultivates the Idea of Change

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 19

 BODY:
Tucked into Vice President Al Gore's stump speech these days is the germ of an idea that his aides say will grow into a full-blown campaign theme in the months ahead: that Mr. Gore will be the steward of change as the world hurtles into the next millennium.
In a way, he is trying to redefine the political use of the word change. While he wants to convey that a Gore Administration would be a change from the Clinton Administration, Mr. Gore also seeks to reassure people that he stands for stability and will carry the successes of the Clinton years into a world that is anxious about how rapidly it is changing. 
 These are somewhat conflicting messages. On the one hand is a desire for a break from the status quo, while on the other is a sense that the nation needs someone who can provide continuity and reassurance.
A top Gore strategist explained the campaign's thinking this way: "In 1992, there was a classic desire for change," he said. "It was focused around economic issues and health care. In 1999 it's different. People understand they are living in a period of profound change. Working families don't get up saying, 'Am I going to lose my job?' They are saying, 'Is my kid going to be safe at school?' There is a whole host of livability issues that the press laughs at but I can assure you are pretty profound issues for people. We are beginning to bring a coherent theme to them."
In a sense, all candidates promise change and want to represent it, if only because voters eventually tire of the status quo and want something fresh and different.
This is what led Ronald Reagan to declare, somewhat improbably, "We are the change," when he spoke on behalf of his Vice President, George Bush, at the 1988 Republican convention. Mr. Reagan at the time was concluding eight years in the Oval Office.
In 1992, the Clinton-Gore ticket offered itself as the "agent of change," breaking with the Bush Administration. But that was a different kind of change from what Mr. Gore is talking about as he competes for the Democratic Presidential nomination against former Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, who has many positions similar to Mr. Gore's, and against a raft of Republicans, most of whom are painting Mr. Gore as the status quo that needs to be upended.
In fact, one goal of the Gore campaign theme, said Stephen Hess, a Presidential scholar at the Brookings Institution, is to pre-empt other candidates from using the slogan of change. "Before the Republicans stand for change, Gore wants to make it his very own," he said.
So far, Mr. Gore speaks of change in only the vaguest terms.
"At a time when the world is going through a more rapid and tumultuous period of change than ever in human history, as Americans, we have to provide leadership," he told a small group of Democratic donors in Washington the other night.
He added: "Change is always resisted. And we have been bringing change. The question is whether or not that change will continue, whether or not the prosperity will continue, whether or not we'll use it to make sure that no one is left behind. That's what I stand for."
To underscore to his listeners that he is prepared to lead the world into a new dimension beyond the Clinton years, Mr. Gore asserted: "We've built a foundation. Now it's time to reach for the stars."
Mr. Clinton is a complicit partner in the message of change, just as audaciously as Mr. Reagan was in 1988.
"The issue in this election will not be whether we should vote for change or not," Mr. Clinton told the same audience as he introduced Mr. Gore. "The issue is what kind of change we'll vote for. We're living in an inherently dynamic time."
Mark Mellman, a Democratic pollster and adviser to the Gore campaign, said Mr. Gore wanted to convey confidence to voters who feel an underlying anxiety about school violence, keeping up with technology and remaining prosperous.
"People recognize that the world is changing at a faster pace than ever before, and they want a President who is going to help make the future work for them," Mr. Mellman said. "In focus groups, people talk about education and not being able to do the things that their kids can do on computers and fitting into the new economy and all these issues in medicine -- genetic testing and genetically modified food and the right to die. Their moorings have been loosened a bit."
Mr. Hess said that beyond the tactical goal the Gore campaign was trying to accomplish several tasks with the word change. One is to assuage a natural fear about change. Another is to jazz up Mr. Gore's image because change is a word that conveys "excitement."
"Change in a political context is usually identified with reform, so there is a subliminal message that they aren't just stuck in the mud," Mr. Hess said. "They're also trying to sort out how Gore can take credit for what's been, take advantage of the President's strengths and differentiate himself enough so that he has his own persona."
As for pre-empting his rivals with the change slogan, so far it does not seem to have worked too well. Gov. George W. Bush, the Texas Republican whose candidacy represents an inherent change from Mr. Clinton, has been leading Mr. Gore in the polls for six months.
Mr. Bradley likes to put forward the notion that he is the one who offers a "fresh start." Anita Dunn, a top adviser to Mr. Bradley, said the desire for change would be "one of the major factors in this election, and a vice president is de facto the candidate of the status quo."
Though Mr. Gore leads Mr. Bradley among Democrats, he still has had obvious difficulty in separating himself from Mr. Clinton. Earlier this year, he toyed with the idea of change as a natural break in the calendar, an epochal divide that necessarily would leave President Clinton (and his scandals) in the past and allow Mr. Gore to proceed unencumbered.
"It's not only the beginning of a new century and a new millennium," Mr. Gore said in March. "It's the beginning of a whole new era in human history." This, he said, posed a new set of challenges and new solutions.
But some aides thought this was too elliptical, and Mr. Gore dropped that formulation. In June he called Mr. Clinton's extramarital behavior inexcusable and said he would bring his own values to the Oval Office, a split that some Democrats, including those in the White House, found too stark and that Mr. Gore's staff said news organizations "overinterpreted."
Mr. Gore talks less now of separation from Mr. Clinton and more of a sense of continuity. "We know the policies that work, and we know how they can be applied to the brand new circumstances and the brand new problems that will confront us at the beginning of the new century," Mr. Gore said last week. He specifically mentioned balancing the budget, overhauling the Government's regulatory structure, opening new markets and investing in education.
Education is one of the top concerns of voters, and Mr. Gore is so adamant about offering changes in public education that he describes his approach as "revolutionary." This usually leaves his audiences a little puzzled, because he talks about reducing class size by adding teachers and connecting classrooms to the Internet, efforts already under way.
In his stump speech, Mr. Gore injects a note of uncertainty about the future, which may reflect his vacillating relationship with Mr. Clinton. He has taken to quoting the Spanish poet Antonio Machado, saying: "Traveler, there is no path. You make your path as you travel."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Dow Gains 42.74 Points For Another Record High

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Stock prices moved up yesterday, carrying the Dow Jones industrial average to a new closing high, as investors grew more confident that the latest interest rate increase would enable the economy to grow without runaway inflation.
The Dow advanced 42.74 points, to 11,326.04, topping its previous record close of 11,299.76 set on Monday. 
 Broader stock indicators also closed higher. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 18.29 points, to 1,381.79, and the Nasdaq composite index gained 53.23, to 2,805.60. The Nasdaq, which lists many of the nation's leading technology companies, notched its fourth consecutive increase and is edging back toward its July 16 record close of 2,864.48.
Bond prices, which rose after the Federal Reserve's decision to raise interest rates, propelled stocks higher yesterday. The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to 5.86 percent, its lowest level in almost three months, making bonds a less attractive alternative to stocks. Bond prices and yields move in the opposite direction.
"People were looking for an excuse to buy, and the Fed provided it," said Richard A. Dickson, a technical analyst at Scott & Stringfellow Inc. in Richmond, referring to the quarter-point rate increase announced by the Fed on Tuesday.
Technology stocks rose most sharply as investors bet that those companies would continue to grow, with interest rates stable. Microsoft extended a string of recent gains, rising 3 1/8, to 955/16 . Amazon.com jumped 12 13/16, to 132 7/8, and America Online rose 4 3/8, to 103 1/8.
Many of those shares faltered earlier this summer amid the threat of rising interest rates. Investors buy those stocks on the promise of strong future earnings, and high rates can hurt profits by making it more expensive to borrow to finance growth.
Now, investors are back looking for value in the Internet sector.
"At their current levels, they look like bargains to some people," Mr. Dickson said.
Bank stocks, which should benefit from good news on interest rates, dropped after Bank One warned on Tuesday that 1999 profits would fall short of Wall Street's expectations, largely because of slower growth in its credit card business.
The Chicago-based bank's stock plunged 12 5/8, to 43, and dragged other financial-services stocks down with it. Chase Manhattan fell 1 1/16, to 85 1/2.
But a wide range of Dow components gained ground. AT&T rose 2 5/8, to 49 1/4; General Electric increased 2 11/16, to 11 95/16, and Johnson & Johnson gained 2 9/16, to 105 3/4.
While many analysts said the Fed's announcement enabled stocks to make further gains, Gail Dudack, chief equity strategist at Warburg Dillon Read, said investors were likely to continue their watch for signs of inflation that could prompt the Fed to raise rates again.
"Soon the markets will refocus on economic announcements for direction," she said, noting that the next employment report, expected on Sept. 3, would indicate whether labor costs are escalating sharply.
Advancing issues outnumbered decliners by 1,607 to 1,429 on the New York Stock Exchange, where volume totaled 864.7 million shares, up from 719 million in the previous session.

HEADLINE: Durable Goods Production Rose 3.3% in July

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER

 BODY:
Orders to United States factories jumped 3.3 percent in July, but analysts said the sharp increase did not suggest inflationary pressures of the kind that Alan Greenspan and the Federal Reserve moved to head off earlier this week.
The rise in production of such durable goods as cars, airplanes and computers, reported by the Department of Commerce, was offset by a drop of 3.9 percent in the sale of existing houses. 
 While the drop in housing sales, reported by the National Association of Realtors, tells only part of the story because residential real estate represents a much smaller portion of the economy than does manufacturing, analysts said yesterday that several other factors left them optimistic.
Arguing against the idea of significant new pressures on inflation, for example, Chris Varvares, the president of Macroeconomic Advisers in St. Louis, noted that the rise in orders for factory goods was coming as the overall economic growth rate appeared to be moderating.
"The 3.3 percent rise is not particularly worrisome with respect to prospects for inflation," Mr. Varvares said.
Clearly delighted by the July figures, David Huether, the director of economic analysis at the National Association of Manufacturers, said that orders fluctuated considerably from month to month. "Next month," he said, "I would say it's probably going to cool down to 1.5 percent or so."
The trend in recent months has been good for the manufacturers. "The main thing here, is that manufacturing is coming back," said David Wyss, the chief economist at Standard & Poor's DRI in Boston. "Manufacturing has been soft most of the last year, but we've been seeing it pick up."
Mr. Huether said he believed that many of the new orders were coming from American business. But the Standard & Poor's economist, Mr. Wyss, said he believed at least part of the upturn reflected the economic recovery under way in Asia.
Mr. Wyss said that while rising orders could force manufacturers to hire more workers in an already tight employment market, with a potential inflationary push, American manufacturers' pricing has been restrained by increased exports from Asia.
"They're in a recession in Asia, and they've got supply coming out their ears," Mr. Wyss said. "Our manufacturers can't push up prices or the imports will take over."
Mr. Huether said that much of the long-term growth in manufacturing had been in the computer industry. Computers have led to increased productivity, he said, and that has offset rising wages as a check on inflation.
On Tuesday, brushing aside arguments from farmers, labor unions, some political leaders and manufacturers that there was no inflation to fight, the Federal Reserve, led by Mr. Greenspan, raised interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point, the second increase in less than two months. The Fed raised the main rate it controls, the Federal funds target rate on overnight loans among banks, to 5.25 percent from 5 percent. It also raised its more symbolic discount rate, on loans to banks from the Federal Reserve system, to 4.75 percent from 4.5 percent.
Banks quickly raised their prime lending rate to 8.25 percent from 8 percent, a step that will lead to higher rates on some consumer and small business loans.
The rate increase earlier this year and the anticipation of the rise this week played a role in the decline in existing housing sales, the analysts said. Rates for mortgages just before the Fed's most recent action, for example, had risen to a little more than 8 percent, up from just under 7 percent a year ago.
"You are beginning to see higher interest rates beginning to slow demand in the most interest-sensitive sectors like housing," Mr. Wyss said, "which is what the Fed has been hoping for."

HEADLINE: Insurer Is Said To Seek a Deal

BYLINE: ByBloomberg News

 BODY:
Metropolitan Life Insurance, the No. 2 United States life insurer, is reported to be in talks to buy the General American Life Insurance Company for $1.2 billion. Such a move could mean that customers would be repaid as much as $6.8 billion they have demanded from General American.
It is believed that Met Life would complete the transaction by buying the Genamerica Corporation, which controls General American Life. Met Life, of New York, would take responsibility for repaying General American clients. 
 The St. Louis-based General American has been looking for a buyer for the last two weeks, since money market funds sought repayment of short-term investments and the insurer was unable to sell assets fast enough to meet demand.
The company's problems began after it doubled the assets it had tied up in short-term investment contracts called funding agreements. General American, along with the ARM Financial Group, had jointly sold the agreements for six years, offering interest rates higher than comparable investments. They profited by reinvesting the money in securities that paid higher rates.
This arrangement crumbled when falling bond prices and a weak market for asset-backed securities led to a decline in the value of the assets backing the investments.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Shares Plunge At Bank One Over Earnings

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr.

 BODY:
Shares of Bank One, the Chicago-based banking giant, plunged 23 percent yesterday after the company stunned the financial community with its warning late Tuesday that intense competition in the credit card business would cause profits to fall short of expectations.
Wall Street analysts flocked to reduce their ratings on the bank, the nation's fifth largest, and shares of other major card issuers were caught in the downdraft, although some later recovered a good portion of their losses. 
 "Bank One's announcement raises concerns about the overall health of the card industry," said Jeffrey Evanson, banking analyst at U.S. Bancorp Piper Jaffray in Minneapolis. Visibility of earnings growth, he concluded, has become questionable.
The Metris Companies lost $4.25, to close at $31; Providian Financial fell $3.9375, to $87.50, and Capital One Financial gave up $3.3125, to $43.375. American Express skidded more than $5.50 but climbed back to finish at $147.25, down only 62.5 cents.
Bank One's situation was seen as especially troublesome. Its First USA operation is likely to earn $500 million less than anticipated, putting 1999 earnings in the range of $3.60 to $3.65 a share, it said, in contrast to a consensus of $3.92 from analysts surveyed by First Call.
Still, analysts saw the episode as pointing up the increasingly fierce struggle for credit card profits. Among other things, it is prompting some reappraisal of the industry and a backlash by consumers. Bank One shares fell $12.625 to $43.
Traditionally, the card business has been highly profitable, with interest rates on revolving balances often running into the high double-digits, more than offsetting monthly administrative costs and the inevitable 1 or 2 percent of the debt that ultimately proves uncollectible.
But intense competition has forced rates down, both regular ones and introductory teasers, so far that banks and others in the business have increasingly tried to make up the revenue through fees, such as for late payments and over-the-limit spending. In many cases, even annual fees have been competed away to oblivion.
Bank One "seems to have a severe case of the affliction plaguing the entire industry," said James Daly, editor of Credit Card Management, an industry monthly. He described profit margins on this mature and now largely commoditized business as under "extreme pressure." And growth has slowed to about 5.5 percent a year from more than 20 percent as recently as the mid-1990's.
Warren Heller, research director of Veribanc Inc., a bank research and rating service, made the case more pungently.
"The whole card business is living in a wonder world," he said, pointing to high delinquencies and chargeoffs at a time of unsurpassed prosperity and to increasing reliance on customer-unfriendly fees when it has become so easy for customers to go elsewhere.
"What a crazy business model the card business of the majors has become," Mr. Heller added.
Bank One, which boasts the nation's second-biggest card business after Citigroup as a result of the 1997 acquisition of First USA, found out in the spring just how peevish consumers have become. They left in droves after the company dropped a one-day grace period, quickly reinstated, for late payments.
"Consumers who are paying attention, who are savvy, are going to find other options" when displeased, said Gerri Detweiler, education adviser to Debt Counselors of America. This is especially true now that the better deals are so readily found on the Web -- at, for example, getsmart.com and cardweb.com.
Travis Plunkett, legislative director of the Consumer Federation of America, called the situation a backlash to heavy-handed industry practice. "The fact that customers are leaving Bank One in droves says they are getting wise to the tricks they play to wring out unwarranted profits," he said.
Industry executives, not surprisingly, reject the pessimism. "We believe the business is extremely healthy," said Sean Healy, a spokesman for Visa USA. He cited opportunities on the Internet and for debit cards, which allow banks to save money in processing checks.
Mr. Daly agreed that the Internet offered hope for the surviving companies in a rapidly consolidating industry, but cautioned that this "won't be a slam dunk."
Despite the forces working to undermine the industry, various analysts including Katrina Blecher of Brown Brothers Harriman and Joseph Duwan of Keefe Bruyette & Woods called Bank One's shrunken profits mostly its own fault.
"First USA took their eye off the ball," Mr. Duwan said. "They got maybe a little too aggressive on pricing and fees," prompting customers to consider other options.
And there may be more grief to come, Mr. Heller of Veribanc suggested. Bank One had a whopping $732 million, or 3 percent of its card portfolio, seriously delinquent at the end of the first quarter, well above the industry average. And this was after charging off as uncollectible 1.2 percent, just as much as the rest of the industry.
And if the economy should slip into recession, he added ominously, things really "could fall apart."

HEADLINE: 3 Copper Concerns Jockey in Merger Deal

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER

 BODY:
Two copper companies in the midst of a merger said yesterday that they were willing to discuss being taken over by the Phelps Dodge Corporation, one of the world's largest mining companies.
But the companies, Asarco Inc. based in New York, and Cyprus Amax Minerals of Englewood, Colo., demanded a 25 percent premium yesterday to the original offer of $2.66 billion from Phelps Dodge, which they had immediately rejected last week. 
Phelps Dodge called the new proposal "totally unreasonable."
In a statement issued at its headquarters in Phoenix, Phelps Dodge said it would review the Asarco and Cyprus proposal, but said it believed that its original offer was "fully priced."
As a condition to discussions, the two companies also said that Phelps Dodge would have to take responsibility for any "antitrust problems" that might develop in a three-way combination.
It was not immediately clear whether the latest offer was a sincere invitation to discuss combining forces or a ploy to fend off Phelps Dodge.
But in what appeared to be an effort to dampen criticism by investors of the combination of Asarco and Cyprus Amax alone, the chief executives of the companies, Francis R. McAllister of Asarco and Milton H. Ward of Cyprus Amax, said they planned to make a special payment of $5 a share to stockholders of the new company.
In a joint statement, Mr. McAllister and Mr. Ward said the Phelps Dodge offer "fails to reward our stockholders for the values derived from the Asarco-Cyprus transaction."
They said their demand for $3.33 billion for the two companies "gives recognition to the fact that our shareholders would be contributing approximately 50 percent to the value of a three-way combination."
Phelps Dodge said the Asarco-Cyprus Amax proposal "would deliver nearly all of the economic value of the three-way combination to Asarco and Cyprus shareholders."
Raising questions about the tactics of Asarco and Cyprus Amax, Douglas C. Yearley, the chief executive of Phelps Dodge, said that if they were "not just posturing, we would be more than willing to begin real discussions."
He added, "Neither company has attempted to sit down with us."
One mining expert said that "almost no takeovers in this industry are executed on the first bid."
"Almost invariably, if agreement is reached," he said, "it is with some bartering. The first offer is usually unacceptably low and the counteroffer unacceptably high. I would expect this process to go on for sometime."
If the three-way deal goes through, it would create a company that would surpass Chile's state-owned Codelco as the world's top copper producer and would unite production in the copper-rich American Southwest.
The world copper market is now being flooded with copper from Chile and Indonesia, where mining costs are lower and mines are newer. Many analysts expect that copper prices, which have plunged in recent years, will remain relatively flat for the foreseeable future. Cooper has been trading at about 70 to 75 cents a pound, the lowest levels in more than a decade.
The jockeying among Phelps Dodge and the two other companies is part of a larger trend involving all basic commodities including aluminum, chemicals and oils. Commodity giants have been pairing up to gain market share and reduce costs in response to a surplus of raw materials as well as declining demand.
Last week, the world's largest aluminum maker, Alcoa Inc., said it was acquiring Reynolds Metals. That came on the heels of a three-way, trans-Atlantic merger to unite Canadian, Swiss and French aluminum makers into a giant competitor to Alcoa.
Phelps Dodge made its bid to take over the two companies last week in two stages. Early in the day it offered $2.4 billion. Then a few hours later it sweetened the deal to $2.66 billion.
The offer, all in stock, was based on a Phelps Dodge closing price on Aug. 20 of $59.125. Phelps Dodge's top offer was calculated to give 0.3135 of a Phelps Dodge share for every share of Cyprus Amax and 0.4098 share of Phelps Dodge for every share of Asarco share.
In the counterproposal, the two companies increased the ratio to 0.4055 a share of Phelps Dodge for a share of Cyprus Amax and 0.5330 a share of Phelps Dodge for a share of Asarco. At $57.625, the closing price of Phelps Dodge yesterday, the total at the higher price would come to $3.33 billion.

HEADLINE: Group Will Expand Program to Help Troubled Schools

BYLINE: By LYNETTE HOLLOWAY

 BODY:
One of the city's largest business groups announced plans yesterday to expand to a second Brooklyn school district a $29 million program that would boost the salaries of superintendents, principals and teachers if they improve students' academic performance.
The business group, the New York City Partnership and Chamber of Commerce, will widen its efforts to help troubled schools by bringing the program to Community School District 23 in Oceanville-Brownsville, officials from the Board of Education and the partnership said. 
 The program is already in place in neighboring District 19 in East New York, which along with District 23 is one of the most troubled districts in the city.
If academic goals outlined in the program are achieved, it could mean up to $30,000 more a year for superintendents, $15,000 for principals and $2,000 for teachers during the next five years in District 23.
The announcement comes as the partnership is poised to hand out bonuses from the program's first year in District 19, which has 30 elementary and middle schools.
Officials are awaiting the results of the statewide tests administered in June to decide which schools will receive the awards, said Stefan Pryor, executive director of the program, which is known as Breakthrough for Learning.
The results are to be released early this fall, he said.
Lewis H. Spence, the Deputy Chancellor for Operations, speaking yesterday after a board meeting, said he expected at least two schools in District 19 to receive bonus money this fall.
Mr. Spence and Mr. Pryor declined to name the schools.
District 19 was the first of the city's 32 districts to adopt the program.
In other cities, disputes have erupted between teachers and principals over who deserved the bonuses, and there have been charges that teachers cheated to increase student test scores and that schools have inflated grades.
But Mr. Spence said New York City's program differs from others in that it emphasizes teamwork and awards money to all teachers in an improved school, not just to those whose classes improved.
He also said that Schools Chancellor Rudy Crew has the authority to change the program if he finds flaws.
William C. Thompson, the Board of Education president, predicted that the incentives would improve the schools in the long run. A third district is expected to participate in the program, starting in the fall of 2000.
"I honestly believe creating incentives is a good idea," Mr. Thompson said. "It's an experiment worth having."
Under a complex system intended to monitor improvement in the schools, the districts will try to improve students' scores on two kinds of standardized tests.
One shows whether the students are learning at or above their grade level when their school is compared with similar schools each year; the other shows how much students, even those doing badly, are improving.
The dual tests provide a more accurate measure of schools' improvement than other systemwide tests, officials said.
If students in all a district's schools reach all the necessary goals on those tests, the bonuses for educators could add up to $10 million a year for that district.
But even if districts collectively receive less, the financial impact for those who earn the bonuses will be great. Superintendents now receive about $128,000 a year. Principals make between $70,000 and $80,000. Teachers, who school officials said would receive less per person because bonuses would be given to every teacher in a successful school, make between $29,000 and $70,000.
Dr. Crew recently seized control of some of the lowest-performing schools in the city, including some in Districts 19. He also removed some top district administrators, including the District 19 Superintendent, Robert Riccobono, whose replacement, Joan Mahon-Powell was announced this week. Mr. Spence said Mr. Riccobono's removal was not related to the incentive program.
Ms. Mahon-Powell, who was principal of Intermediate School 292 in District 19 last year, said she looks forward to implementing changes in schools districtwide.

TYCO INTERNATIONAL TO PARE JOBS AT RAYCHEM

BYLINE: Bloomberg News

 BODY:
Tyco International Ltd., one of the world's biggest makers of electrical connectors, said yesterday that it would dismiss 2,200 employees, or about a quarter of the work force, at the Raychem Corporation, less than a week after buying the company. Workers at Raychem, a maker of wiring and tubing that is based in Menlo Park, Calif., and employs 9,000, were told of the job cuts on Tuesday, a Raychem spokeswoman said. Tyco has about 87,000 workers and expects the cuts, half of which are in the United States, to save about $250 million. It does not expect to take a charge. Tyco has its headquarters in Hamilton, Bermuda, and is run from executive offices in Exeter, N.H.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Asarco and Cyprus Amax Weigh Phelps Dodge Deal
Two copper companies in the midst of a merger, Asarco and Cyprus Amax Minerals, said that they were willing to discuss being taken over by Phelps Dodge, one of the world's largest mining companies.
But the two companies flatly rejected Phelps Dodge's initial offer of $2.66 billion, saying they wanted at least 25 percent more than that. Phelps Dodge called the new proposal "totally unreasonable" but said it would review it. Page C2. 

Treasuries Rally on Fed Move
Bond prices rallied on the prospect that the increase in short-term interest rates announced by the Federal Reserve on Tuesday could be the last of the year. Yields were down to a one-month low even after the Government reported that durable goods orders rose 3.3 percent in July, far exceeding expectations. The 30-year Treasury bond rose 1 5/32, to 103 29/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 5.85 percent from 5.93 percent on Tuesday and was the lowest since 5.77 percent on July 21. C8.
 
Stocks moved higher, carrying the Dow Jones industrial average to a closing high as investors grew more confident that the interest rate increase would enable the economy to grow without runaway inflation. The Dow advanced 42.74 points, to 11,326.04. The Nasdaq composite index gained 53.23 points, to 2,805.60, and the Standard & Poor's 500 Stock Index was up 18.29 points, to 1,381.79. C9.

Brazilian Job Ad Opens Floodgates
As many as a million people -- or one of every 160 Brazilians -- are competing for about 10,000 entry-level jobs advertised by Banco do Brasil. The flood of applications highlights the bleakness of Brazil's job situation, even as the country slowly emerges from recession. C4.
 
Alaskan Outrage at Cruise Line
Despite a visit and apology by Jack L. Williams, the president of the Royal Caribbean International cruise line, which has pleaded guilty to dumping pollutants in Alaskan waters, the city of Juneau is likely to impose a $5 "head tax" on each passenger as cruise ships dock there. C2.
 
Metropolitan Life Seen in Deal
The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company is reported to be in talks to buy the General American Life Insurance Company of St. Louis for $1.2 billion. That could mean that customers would be repaid the $6.8 billion they have demanded from General American. C2.
 
Rite Aid Shares Jump on Speculation
Shares of Rite Aid, the nation's third-largest drugstore chain, jumped $3.4375, or 17.6 percent, to $22.875, in after-hours trading after the company said it was discussing a possible deal. Analysts said that Rite Aid might sell all or part of the 1,000 under-performing West Coast stores it acquired from Thrifty Payless Holdings in December 1996. C9.
 
Factory Orders Climb 3.3 Percent
Orders to United States factories jumped 3.3 percent in July, but analysts said the sharp increase did not suggest inflationary pressures of the kind that Alan Greenspan and the Federal Reserve have moved to head off. The rise in production of such durable goods as cars, airplanes and computers, reported by the Department of Commerce, was offset by a drop of 3.9 percent in the sale of houses. C8.
 
Ecuador to Delay Debt Payment
Ecuador said that it would delay payment on $94 million in Brady bond interest due Saturday. President Jamil Mahuad said the nation would use a 30-day grace period to work out a restructuring agreement with creditors. C8.
 
Societe Generale to Return Shares
Societe Generale, the big French bank, will return to shareholders the minority stake in the investment bank Paribas that it won in its failed takeover attempt. Because of the merger defeat, Paribas's chairman, Andre Levy-Lang, left the bank. He was succeeded by Michel Pebereau, the chairman of Banque Nationale de Paris, which gained a 65.4 percent stake in Paribas. C4.

HEADLINE: Black Politicians Turn Against Planned Harlem Rally for Youth

BYLINE: By DAVID BARSTOW

 BODY:
Leading a wave of condemnation among the city's black politicians, Representative Charles B. Rangel, Harlem's most powerful political figure, yesterday called for a boycott of a planned youth rally, saying racially charged speeches and violent clashes with the police at last year's rally proved that "it is impossible for any good" to come out of the event.
"We hoped last year if there was an increase in the kids coming, the good would overcome the hatred of the organizers," Mr. Rangel said at a news conference in Harlem with Councilman Bill Perkins, who reported that he was assaulted on Monday by organizers of the Sept. 4 rally, called the Million Youth March. "But after the events of last year, we would not encourage anyone to get involved in the event." 
 Other prominent black politicians came forward yesterday to condemn both the march and its organizers. The statements marked a shift among the city's black leaders, who last year condemned the march's leader, Khallid Abdul Muhammad, for his derogatory remarks about Jews and whites, but grudgingly accepted the event as a way to mobilize young people, and in some cases even encouraged them to attend.
Assemblyman Keith L. T. Wright of Harlem, who last year tried to mediate between march organizers and city officials, issued a statement yesterday under the headline, "Enough is Enough -- Why the Million Youth March Should Not Take Place in Harlem."
The State Comptroller, H. Carl McCall, the only black holding statewide office, said in a statement yesterday: "I cannot abide by Khallid Muhammad's evil message, and I cannot support his march."
And C. Virginia Fields, the Manhattan Borough President who earlier this week spurned a plea for assistance from march organizers, issued an appeal for all residents to "douse" the "flames of divisiveness."
The efforts to isolate Mr. Muhammad were driven by outrage over last year's rally -- which resulted in injuries to 14 participants and 16 police officers -- and by anger at the treatment of Mr. Perkins, a Harlem Democrat who said supporters of Mr. Muhammad surrounded him at a political event on Monday night and shouted, "We are going to kill Uncle Toms like you." Mr. Perkins, who said he was considering pressing charges, was offered police protection by Commissioner Howard Safir during a meeting yesterday.
At a raucous news conference outside the Apollo Theater in Harlem last night, as his supporters mixed threats toward white reporters with chants of "black power," Mr. Muhammad and other organizers said the calls for a boycott did not reflect popular sentiment in the community, and they accused black political leaders of pandering to whites.
"Unfortunately, the black elected officials are so far removed from their own constituents that they are afraid to stand up for the people," said Shaunette Daniels, a spokeswoman for the march.
Mr. Muhammad again denied that his supporters had assaulted Mr. Perkins, but then he added: "Bill Perkins is my brother and he is a member of the black nation, but he is a Tom that bootlicks" white people.
The organizers have yet to secure a city permit for the Saturday rally, which is scheduled to be staged along the section of Lenox Avenue known as Malcolm X Boulevard. In their latest request to city officials, the rally's organizers have said that, starting at 11 A.M., they want to march from 135th Street to 118th Street, and then conduct a program of educational speeches from 2 to 6 P.M. between 118th and 124th Streets.
Mr. Muhammad vowed yesterday to march with or without a permit, warning that there "will be a state of emergency in Harlem" if the Police Department attempts to block the event. He said the organization was committed to focusing attention on high unemployment, high drop-out rates and "a raging asthma epidemic" among black youth. "We represent vision, self-determination and, above all, courage," Mr. Muhammad said.
At a City Hall news conference yesterday, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani denounced the organizers as "reprehensible," but declined to say whether the city will issue a permit. Instead, he blamed the news media for paying too much attention to Mr. Muhammad and his organization, the New Black Panther Party.
"You are creating them," he chided reporters. "They don't have support. They don't have political support, they don't have social support, they don't have support in the community. And by constantly focusing on them, you are creating them, and I want to say as little as possible to give them attention."
But for all the public criticism, Mr. Giuliani's aides have been quietly negotiating for weeks with Mr. Muhammad's lawyers over the terms of a rally.
Daniel S. Connolly, the city lawyer handling the negotiations, declined to discuss his conversations with the rally's lawyers. Mr. Connolly, however, has told march organizers that the city will abide by a Federal appeals court's decision last year that allowed the youth rally to assemble for four hours on six blocks of Malcolm X Boulevard.
"He says that the city is prepared to adhere to that decision," said Jomo Thomas, a lawyer for the rally's organizers. Mr. Thomas said the city's Corporation Counsel, Michael D. Hess, spoke with the organizers yesterday afternoon and said he hoped to avoid another court battle.
Last year, the rally's organizers sued the city, alleging that the Giuliani administration denied them a permit solely because city officials disagreed with their political message of militant black nationalism.
This year, the organizers have demanded that city officials reduce the police presence at the rally, and not move so swiftly to clear the area at the time the permit runs out. Police officers, some in riot gear, began to clear last year's rally at 4:05 P.M., five minutes after the permit expired. As they moved in, Mr. Muhammad called on the crowd to defend themselves in the event of an attack, and angry rally participants threw chairs and other objects at officers.
In a letter Monday to Mr. Connolly, Mr. Thomas said that police officers have shown far more flexibility at other large public events, like the St. Patrick's Day Parade. "None of these have ever been held to 'High Noon' conditions of 'end exactly at the designated time or else,' " Mr. Thomas wrote.
Mr. Hess promised to respond to the march organizer's demands by 1 P.M. today, Mr. Thomas said. But neither he nor any other lawyers for the march sounded the slightest bit optimistic that they would reach an agreement with the city on a rally permit. They accused Mr. Giuliani of stalling on the permit to curry favor with Jewish voters should he decide to run for the United States Senate. "This is the typical Giuliani way of operating," said Malik Z. Shabazz, an aide to Mr. Muhammad. "But I feel strongly that by him standing up to the Million Youth March he will appease Jewish voters."
Mr. Muhammad has outraged Jews by calling them "bloodsuckers" and "hook-nosed." At other times, he has called on black people to take up arms against the police.
Some officials, most notably the Council Speaker, Peter F. Vallone, called on the city to deny a permit. "People have a right to express themselves," he said yesterday, "but people do not have a right to foster and to engage in violence anymore than anyone has a right to stand up in a movie theater and yell 'Fire!' under the pretext of free speech."
Mr. Rangel said he believed that the First Amendment protected Mr. Muhammad's right to stage a rally, though perhaps only in a public park "where they are just speaking to themselves."
Asked how the city should handle the decision on whether to issue a permit, Mr. Rangel replied, "We want it handled in a fashion that respects the fact that this is a peace-loving community that will most likely be victimized by this event."
