HEADLINE: Hong Kong Journal;
Suzy Wong's Long Gone and Now, Sailors Begone!

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Aug. 25

 BODY:
Tony Wong dismisses many of the old chestnuts about American sailors on leave in exotic foreign ports.
"They don't go to girlie bars anymore, they buy computer equipment," said Mr. Wong, a tailor whose family has made clothing for sailors from visiting United States Navy ships since 1898, first in Shanghai and now in Hong Kong. 
 After a lifetime of fitting admirals for dinner jackets and ensigns for sport coats, Mr. Wong is steeped in the lore of American sailors on R & R. Despite a stern gaze that suggests he could command a destroyer as easily as outfitting its crew in worsted, he said, "I have a special affection for the Navy."
Which is why Mr. Wong took it hard in May when the Chinese Government banned Navy ships from visiting Hong Kong. The ban -- apparently in retaliation for NATO's bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade -- is a footnote in the larger struggle between a superpower and a rising power.
But for Mr. Wong and a circle of Hong Kong merchants, restaurant owners and barkeepers who depend on visiting American sailors for their livelihood, it is a potentially mortal blow.
"If the sailors don't come back, we'll have to think of new ways to survive," Mr. Wong said as he surveyed his empty store. "What's the buzzword in America? We'll re-engineer our business."
That may be difficult. Mr. Wong's shop is in the Fleet Arcade, a pocket-size shopping mall next to the pier in Victoria Harbor that exists primarily to serve ships. The Navy pays for the mall's upkeep under an agreement with a nonprofit organization, the Servicemen's Guides Association, to give sailors a place to eat, get a haircut, call home or even buy Chinese porcelain.
Mr. Wong thinks he can muddle through on the small number of local landlubbers who use the mall. But a nearby shop that sells porcelain closed its doors this week. "There's no business, so we had no choice," said the manager as he packed up mournfully.
The American Consulate here says that about 60 ships a year normally anchor in Hong Kong, pumping $50 million into the local economy. The bulk of that is spent on provisions like food and fuel. But with 45,000 crew members swarming into the streets, the sailors also spend a lot on food and shopping.
And, Mr. Wong's assertions notwithstanding, they still run up bar tabs in the enduringly seedy clubs of Wanchai.
"We view these stopovers as serving the interests of all parties," said Rob Laing, a spokesman for the consulate. "We're prepared to resume them as soon as the Chinese Government approves our requests."
Under the terms of the agreement that governed Hong Kong's return to China from Britain in 1997, Beijing controls Hong Kong's national security. So legal experts say it is entirely within its rights in curtailing the visits. It has allowed visits by naval ships from other countries to continue.
Mr. Laing said Beijing had not given a reason for denying the requests from American ships to dock, the first of which came in mid-May, soon after the embassy bombing. All told, it has turned down visits by 10 ships and 3 military planes.
But there are signs Beijing is softening its stance. It recently approved a request for a military plane to pick up a Congressional delegation. And it is allowing a visit by a Navy supply ship next month. The shopkeepers grouse that the vessel has a crew of only 90, most of whom are civilians.
The Rev. Ronald R. Saucci, a Maryknoll Catholic priest who runs the Servicemen's Guides Association, recently cornered a high-ranking mainland Chinese official at a diplomatic reception to ask him whether Beijing would lift the ban on the Navy visits. The official's response? "God will provide."
Father Saucci said he hoped China would relax its ban, if only to preserve Hong Kong's role as one of the Navy's favorite rest and recreation destinations. American ships have been dropping anchor here for decades, particularly since 1949, when the Communist victory in China's civil war closed off Shanghai and other mainland ports.
The merchants say they can trace the changing nature of the United States Navy to the things that sailors do and buy while ashore. Mr. Wong shows off a yellowed slip of paper that permitted his granduncle to board the U.S.S. New York in Shanghai in 1902 to measure the crew for tuxedos.
During the 1950's and 60's, Hong Kong became known as something of a den of sin, with its sloe-eyed bargirls and sharp-eyed pimps. But the British colony immortalized in the 1960 film "The World of Suzy Wong" has long since given way to a more wholesome and commercial place, where sailors shop for computers, stereo equipment and Oriental rugs.
People here worry that unless China allows visits to resume soon, Hong Kong could lose out to competitors like Singapore and Manila, which recently reopened its port to visiting American warships.
"I really hope it doesn't become a thing where China carefully assesses the world scene every time the U.S. requests a visit, because that could cut the heart out of our organization," Father Saucci said.
For now, the shopkeepers and barmen can only watch as China and the United States engage in a diplomatic pas de deux. Most are hopeful that as tensions between the countries cool, China will relent.
"China and the U.S. are like a couple: they fight with each other and then they make up," said Roger Sibnoni, who runs a hole in the wall that sells playing cards and a cologne scientifically designed to attract women.
At Club Hot Lips, a bar in Wanchai that was as quiet as a convent on a recent evening, the manager said plaintively, "Tell the Chinese Government to settle this so the Americans can come back and start drinking again."

HEADLINE: PHOTOGRAPHY REVIEW;
An American Century, Through the Government's Lens

BYLINE: By VICKI GOLDBERG 

 BODY:
Even though much in the 20th century has been a blight on the human record, we've been stuck with these 100 years and are about to lose them, so half the world seems to be competing to sum them up in photographs.
Right now, the American past in some of its blight, struggle, achievements (both real and dubious) and cagey habit of putting a good face on it all is summarized at the National Archives in Washington in a show called "Picturing the Century: 100 Years of Photographs From the National Archives." 
 Most people go to the Archives to see the great documents of America's history: the Declaration of Independence, the Constitution and Bill of Rights. They are still there in all their glory; the place fairly bristles with history.
One advantage of this show is that the photographs come from a near-bottomless collection. The National Archives and Records Administration has more than eight million still pictures and nine million aerial photographs in Washington alone, and it has more than 30 facilities around the country, including the 10 Presidential libraries. This means that most of the 190 pictures (along with some documents) in "Picturing the Century" are virtually unknown, and some of the history in them is, too.
When it comes to unknown, try a 1917 image of people "nature-sliding" down snowy slopes on the seats of what the contemporary caption calls their "famous tin trousers," said seats being waxed, of course. Or take a look at a World War I window display of dressed-up potatoes billed as "Potatriots." One is got up like Teddy Roosevelt, another like Woodrow Wilson; they illustrate a sign saying, "The Potato Is a Good Soldier. Eat It Uniform and All." (The Government was trying to conserve wheat at the time.)
As for history, the show offers some textbook facts like the Wright Brothers' first flight in 1903. (The brothers withheld this photograph for fear the competition would learn too much about their invention; no photograph was published until a photojournalist sneaked one in 1908.) There are also Depression-era bread lines, the D-Day landing (best known from Robert Capa's pictures but here in Robert F. Sargent's photograph for the Coast Guard), soldiers watching a nuclear blast in 1951 and V.I.P.'s in armchairs and goggles watching another that year.
The social history of America winds through "Picturing the Century" on a trail marked by bald fact and irony. In 1930, when radio was just achieving the status of a mass medium, George W. Ackerman took a picture of a farmer, his wife and daughter seated before their large console radio and watching it as intently as if it were television. Around 1960, an unknown photographer snapped female office workers admiring one woman's ring. The caption: "35 per cent of U.S. women hold daily jobs outside the home. The working woman may be an executive but 18 times oftener is a subordinate. And many a girl's happiest day at the office is the day she leaves to get married."
In 1970, Oliver F. Atkins photographed President Richard M. Nixon shaking hands with Elvis Presley at the meeting where Nixon presented Elvis with a pistol and asked that he be made a "Federal agent-at-large" in the Bureau of Narcotics and Dangerous Drugs. (Elvis looks as if he knew a lot about drugs.) In 1974, as the fuel crisis closed down gasoline stations and some stations were put to other uses, David Falconer photographed one that was converted to born-again Christianity, with pumps wearing pictures of Jesus and signs that say things like "Fill Up With the Holy Ghost and Fire."
History is in the details, which photographs supply in superabundance. And yet they speak a limited kind of language, and Bruce I. Bustard, the curator of the show, tells more than mere pictures can in an accompanying book.
He points out that the growth of photography coincidentally accompanied the expansion of the Federal Government. In 1900, there were 230,000 Federal employees, and by 1917 almost double that number. Photographs kept multiplying,too.
The Franklin D. Roosevelt Library has approximately 130,000 photographs of Franklin and Eleanor, including those from his 12 years as President. The Ronald Reagan Library has more than 10 times that many pictures, more than 1.5 million of Ronald and Nancy Reagan, including those from his eight years as President.
The Government's long and varied involvement with photography is a study in itself. When a child-labor law was under consideration in the House of Representatives in the first decade of the century, members used Lewis Hine's photographs to document their case. (They lost.) During World War I, an organized effort that included photographic imagery was made to rouse support for American participation. A 1917 photograph of "Sweethearts and relatives bidding 69th Infantry N.Y. a fond goodbye" looks candid enough but was actually posed with models, one of whom waves a flag as she busses a doughboy.
The photographs of the Farm Security Administration during the Depression are relatively well known, but other Government agencies, including the Works Progress Administration, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, the Civilian Conservation Corps, the National Youth Administration, the Public Works Administration and the Rural Electrification Administration had similar programs and employed fine photographers. Dorothea Lange worked for not one but three of those organizations. In 1941, Ansel Adams took photographs for some never-completed murals in the Department of Interior Building; the National Archives houses 226 of his prints.
The National Records and Archives Administration itself was set up in 1934, right in the middle of a great documentary era, and became the repository not only for Government-sponsored photographs but also for corporate and other photographs used by or donated to the Government.
After the war the Government continued to rely heavily on photography, with some changes in emphasis. Mr. Bustard writes that during the cold war "U.S. Government photography increasingly became an instrument of American foreign policy." The founders of the United States Information Agency in 1953 believed, as has long been believed in wartime, that public opinion in the enemy camp would make a difference.
A U.S.I.A. magazine called America Illustrated, aimed at the Soviet Union and Soviet-bloc countries, carried photo essays on American life, like happy mothers and daughters in dazzling kitchens or "Lunchbox Capitalists," which showed hard-hats reading The Wall Street Journal to check on stock they owned through employee stock-ownership plans. Another magazine, Topic, directed at sub-Saharan Africa, ran stories of American life and of African influence in such areas as fashion.
In 1972, the Environmental Protection Agency embarked on the most ambitious photography survey of America since the 1930's, Documerica. Meant to document environmental issues, the program gave its 75 employees so much leeway that they produced a range of telling reports on various aspects of American society before budget cuts killed the program.
Though some of the photographs in "Picturing the Century" don't look much like gold at first, nuggets of history lie everywhere. The show will be at the Archives till 2001, but don't wait too long: early in the next millennium other photographs will go up to replace most of these, putting yet another face on a century with more than its share of menacing scowls -- and photographs.
 "Picturing the Century: 100 Years of Photography From the National Archives," partly sponsored by the Eastman Kodak Company, is at the National Archives in Washington, Seventh Street and Pennsylvania Avenue N.W., (202) 501-5000, through July 4, 2001.

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
Plucking Warmth From Millet's Light

BYLINE: By MICHAEL KIMMELMAN 

DATELINE: WILLIAMSTOWN, MASS.

 BODY:
IT'S a good bet that the most satisfying exhibition anywhere in America at this moment is "Jean-Francois Millet: Drawn Into the Light," at the Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute here.
As its title implies, the show focuses on drawings. Millet's drawings are limpid and nuanced, with a remarkable feel for light and the weight of things. They owe debts to Poussin and Delacroix and have the silent, time-stopped quality of Vermeer. If Millet's fame rests on a few paintings, like "The Sower," "The Gleaners" and "Man With a Hoe," which are also on loan here (a feat for the Clark), no one was more adept at pastels than he was, or more skilled at exploiting the bumpiness of textured paper to create a soft, shimmering effect, or at the technique of rubbing the lines made by conte crayons. Seurat, whose drawings are also sublime, idolized Millet because, among other things, Millet virtually invented the vaporous silhouettes that Seurat drew. 
 So the exhibition reminds us why we should admire Millet beyond the textbook view of him as a painter of peasants. He was a first-rate landscapist whose experience of the countryside, where he spent most of his life (he was born in 1814 and died in 1875), is reflected in the precision of his perceptions of rural life. Drawings like "Twilight" and the watercolors of bucolic scenes he made near Vichy during the mid-1860's are not just drawn well, they're also perfectly true to nature, which is a rarer attribute.
The standard question about Millet comes up here: was he a sentimentalist? "The Gleaners," maybe his most famous and most sentimental picture, is so familiar that it's now hard to see fresh. Three women are stooping in a field, one rising just enough so that her back approaches the horizon line but doesn't break its plane. The effect is to make the figures look rooted to the earth, weighted down.
They are also shrouded -- we can't make out their faces -- and stony. Theophile Gautier once wrote about how Millet "trowels onto his dishcloth canvas, using no oil or turps, great masonries of color, paint so dry no varnish could quench its thirst," which is what we see here: the women seem like solid blocks, dense masses.
At a good distance from them, brightly lighted, men pitch huge forkfuls of grain into stacks. Two of the stacks, beside a laden wagon, mirror the configuration of the women, giving the picture a classical balance, front to back, while emphasizing the extreme poverty of the gleaners compared to the bounty behind them.
Gleaners, the rural equivalent of urban beggars, scrounged whatever scraps of grain escaped the reapers' sheaves. They constituted the absolute bottom rung of peasant society. Millet's goal -- to suggest the gravity of their existence through a kind of religious transfiguration -- involved remaking the Bible into pictures of modern realism. He knew the Old Testament story of Ruth, the gleaner, and Boaz, the landowner who falls in love with her, and he had already adapted it for another painting, "Harvesters Resting."
His "Gleaners" glorifies, through biblical implications, the backbreaking work of these women. It was a bold statement to be making at the time. Jittery after the revolution of 1848, the urban middle and upper classes, who were Millet's audience, genuinely feared these peasants, who hadn't benefited, as they had, from the economic upturn of the Second Empire. When "The Gleaners" was first shown in the 1850's, one art critic, speaking for other Parisians, perceived in it an alarming intimation of "the scaffolds of 1793."
That said, Millet was never a radical in the way that Courbet was a radical. His attachment to classical art and to biblical sources linked him to a tradition that reassured moderates. Critics could choose to focus on what was provocative about his art or on what was conventional, depending on their inclinations.
His political views, to the extent they're known, seem to have been contradictory, which is to say they were fairly normal. If others regarded him as a wild socialist troublemaker, he was actually one of those people whose public works and private beliefs didn't necessarily coincide. The socialists thought that Millet was on their side, but as Camille Pissarro wrote in 1887, Millet was just a bit too biblical. He was "another of those blind men, leaders or followers who, unconscious of the march of modern ideas, defend those ideas without knowing it, despite themselves."
That sounds right. Millet liked to say that he had been a peasant laborer until he was 21, but he was born to a prospering family in a tiny coastal hamlet called Gruchy, in Normandy. Although he worked with his father and great-uncle tilling the soil and tending animals, he was steeped in Virgil, Milton and Shakespeare; it's said that he was one of the best-educated painters of his generation.
He also drew and was sent, at 18, to study art in Cherbourg. Having received a stipend from the city fathers there, and with money from his family, he then became a student of the history painter Paul Delaroche at the Ecole des Beaux-Arts in Paris, aiming for a career as an academic painter of portraits, nudes and biblical subjects.
Gradually, however, his aspirations changed and he began to concentrate more on peasant life and landscapes. After staying a dozen years in Paris, through the revolution and despite the fact that he loathed city life, he opted in 1849 to settle permanently in Barbizon, 30 miles south of Paris, on the northern edge of the forest of Fontainebleau, where Theodore Rousseau, the painter, had also retreated a year earlier. Barbizon was close enough to Paris to stay in touch with the art business, but it was a world apart.
His ambition had become epic and posed a number of questions that are still fundamental to political art. Was it possible to convey the demeaning, mechanical quality of a task like gleaning or sowing and simultaneously dignify the people doing it? Could they be made to look particular and individual while doing such an anonymous job? What did it take to turn something commonplace into something mythic without distorting or softening it? Should brutality be made to look beautiful through art?
When Millet failed to resolve these sorts of issues, his art did slide toward sentimentalism. But generally he managed to extract from his classical sources an essential restraint, and notwithstanding the occasional maudlin effect, he tended mostly toward sobriety and a kind of obstinate awkwardness of pose and gesture, which mitigated melodrama. In the end, his works have heart. Sincerity and sentimentality are different things. Millet was sincere.
He was a painter of humanity for whom nature provided a context that was always larger than the people he described. His art was about harmony with the landscape. In "Faggot Gatherers Returning From the Forest," a winter scene of three woman laden with enormous bundles of twigs strapped to their backs, thin vertical lines designate the sticks they carry and the trees around them -- a kind of shorthand technique that merges the women with the land, reinforcing their connection. "My desire to make a winter landscape has passed to the point of true compulsion," Millet wrote, a little before he made the drawing. "There's a calm, a grandeur that's terrifying." This is conveyed here: a sense of awesome scale and silence.
His art is also neatly summed up in a drawing like "Woman Pasturing Her Cow." The woman was a poor itinerant. Itinerants were prohibited from using communal grazing land in France, so she leads her malnourished cow to feed on scraggy tufts of grass beside the roadway. In a big sunny field behind her, a landowner's fat herd grazes.
Trees are surrounding the woman and separating her from the field, like prison bars. But Millet doesn't push the point: the woman, plump-faced, standing erect, contentedly knitting, is not a cliche of poverty. The picture is as much about light and space as it is about justice or anything else. For Millet, everything returns to nature.
"Nature yields herself to those who trouble to explore her," he wrote. "But she demands an exclusive love. The works of art we love, we love only because they are derived from her. The rest are merely works of empty pedantry."
"Jean-Francois Millet: Drawn Into the Light" remains at the Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute, 225 South Street, Williamstown, Mass., (413) 458-9545, through Sept. 6. It travels to the Van Gogh Museum in Amsterdam (Oct. 26 through Jan. 4) and to the Frick Museum in Pittsburgh (Feb. 10 through mid-April).

HEADLINE: Allow Aluminum Merger

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Questionable Mergers in Aluminum" (editorial, Aug. 20): 
 As you note, the price of aluminum is at depressed levels. Not allowing the Alcoa-Reynolds merger to take place would stifle the ability to improve efficiency and would jeopardize the future of the American aluminum industry. Jobs have already been lost, and many more surely will be if American companies are not allowed to keep up with global competition.
In our random study of 553 mergers in regulated and unregulated industries that occurred between 1990 and 1998, Dr. Robert Ekelund and I found that regulators imposed costly delays on mergers, that the delay was twice as long in regulated industries as compared with unregulated industries, and that consumers gained nothing in the process.
 
MARK THORNTON
Auburn, Ala., Aug. 24, 1999
 
The writer is an associate professor of economics, Columbus State University.

HEADLINE: Unions and Technology

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Thomas L. Friedman (column, Aug. 20) argues that President Ronald Reagan's breakup of the air traffic controllers' strike in 1981 helped insure our technological superiority over Europe, since it "helped break the hold of organized labor over the U.S. economy" and allowed corporate managers to lay off workers and replace them with new technology. 
 To the contrary, United States manufacturing unions have never had much power to block layoffs, and with only 23 percent of the work force organized at the time, unions in the United States were already weaker than their European counterparts. Rather than block new technology, industrial unions negotiated for retraining, workplace safety and transfer rights to growing segments of their particular industries.
 
STEVE BABSON
Detroit, Aug. 20, 1999
 
The writer is a program specialist at the Labor Studies Center, Wayne State University.

HEADLINE: On My Mind;
Vote On Drugs

BYLINE: By A. M. ROSENTHAL 

 BODY:
Notice to the public:
Vote now on drugs, one of the only two ways. 
 1. If you support the war against drugs, vote now for pending Congressional legislation designed to wound major drug lords around the world. It cuts them off from all commerce with the U.S., now a laundry for bleaching the blood from drug-trade billions and turning them into investments in legitimate businesses.
Vote by telling your members of Congress that when the House-Senate bill authorizing intelligence funds comes up for final decision, probably next month, you want them to vote for the section called "blocking assets of major narcotics traffickers."
Insist they start now to tell the Administration not to try to water it down to satisfy any country for diplomatic or economic reasons -- including Mexico, the biggest drug entry point for America, already complaining about "negative consequences" of the proposal.
Turn yourself and your civil, labor or commercial organization, or religious congregation, into lobbies for the bill -- counterweight to the lobbies of drug-transfer nations and American companies beholden to them.
2. If you are against the war on drugs or just don't care about what drugs are doing to our country, then don't do a thing. That is a vote, too.
That's the way it is in Washington. Members of Congress introduce legislation, committees discuss it for months, votes are taken and then when the time comes to work out House-Senate differences, administrations on the fence and under professional lobbyists' pressure use their power to try to mold the legislation to their liking. That is exactly the time for ordinary Americans around the country to do their own lobbying.
The bill targeting drug lords extends throughout their vicious world the economic sanctions already directed at Colombian drug lords, by President Clinton's executive order. It will prohibit any U.S. commerce by specifically named drug operators, seize all their assets in the U.S., and ban trading with them by American companies.
The bill specifies that every year the U.S. Government list the major drug lords of the world, by name and nation. The lists are certain to include top drug traders from countries such as Afghanistan, Jamaica, the Dominican Republic, Thailand and Mexico.
In the Senate it was introduced by Paul Coverdell, a Georgia Republican, and Dianne Feinstein, Democrat from California, and passed with bipartisan support. In the House it also has support in both parties, including Porter Goss of Florida, a Republican and chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, and Charles Rangel, the New York Democrat. It awaits the final September House-Senate Joint Intelligence Committee vote.
For awhile I heard from within the Administration the kind of mutters that preceded the Clinton certification last year that Mexico was carrying out anti-drug commitments satisfactorily, which was certainly a surprise to Mexican drug lords.
Then, yesterday, the White House told me that it favored some target sanctions.
Its objection to the bill was that the Administration would have to list all major drug lords for the President to choose targets, and that could endanger investigations. The White House said it would be better for the President to select targets without having to choose from a list.
Bit of a puzzle. The bill already gives him the right to decide which of the drug lords to target from the Administration's unpublished list. But some members of Congress think the motive is to avoid a list that might include just a little too many from a "sensitive country."
No one bill will end the drug war. Only the determination of Americans to use every sort of resource will do that -- parental teaching, law enforcement with some compassion toward first offenders and none for career drug criminals, enough money for therapy in and out of jails, targeting drug lords -- and passionate leadership.
That would preclude Presidential candidates who mince around about whether they used drugs when they were younger -- unless they grow up publicly and quickly.
Dr. Mitchell S. Rosenthal, head of the Phoenix House therapeutic communities, says that the bill "reflects the kind of values that we don't hear enough these days." So vote -- one way or the other. 
http://www.nytimes.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (99%); COLOMBIA (79%); AFGHANISTAN (79%); DOMINICAN REPUBLIC (79%); THAILAND (51%);

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Whose Web Site Is This?

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: TAIPEI, Taiwan

 BODY:
You just knew something like this would happen. China, unable so far to occupy Taiwan on land, has done it in cyberspace. The Internet address Taiwan.com was recently claimed and registered by China.com, an Internet portal that is partially owned by China's state-run Xinhua news agency. According to The Asian Wall Street Journal, several hundred Taiwanese professors and lawmakers have petitioned the Taiwan government to reclaim the Taiwan.com domain name by taking the Nasdaq-traded China.com to court in the U.S. for misrepresentation.
One country, two Web sites. Not good. 
 This cyberdrama, though, is a perfect illustration of how all-consuming is the identity struggle between China and Taiwan -- a struggle that has made both states crazy. On one side, it has blinded the Taiwanese to their own strength. This remarkable country so clearly has the winds of history at its back. At a time when China is facing the huge task of modernizing a nation of 1.2 billion people, and could implode under the strain, Taiwan has already arrived. It has Asia's most dynamic economy. It is Silicon Valley's most feared competitor. And it is a thriving free-market democracy. As long as it can avoid provoking a war with China, Taiwan has everything going for it. But tell that to people here and all they will tell you is that China just beat them out of diplomatic relations with Tonga!
But if Taiwan can't see its strength, China can't see its weakness. China is so caught up in the principle that Taiwan is its renegade province that it has completely forgotten that Beijing has to court the Taiwanese people if it wants to win them back by anything other than force.
Beijing needs to try a strategy on Taiwan that it's never really tried before: a charm offensive. I know it's unlikely, but charming Taiwan would surely get Beijing a lot more than its present overture, which is: "Marry me or die." That is, without a doubt, history's worst pickup line.
"The way they talk to us about unification is like a traditional Chinese arranged marriage," said Antonio Chiang, publisher of The Taipei Times. "The father just tells the daughter, 'You will marry your cousin.' There is no love, no dating, no coffee. Look, we're a free country here. If people were attracted to China, there is no way the government could stop it. But they have not made their system attractive to us."
For now, the Chinese idea of a charm offensive is to suggest that the recent declaration by Taiwan's President, Lee Teng-hui, that Taiwan and China should deal with each other as two separate "states" is a formulation that only Mr. Lee believes in -- not the Taiwanese people. The fact is, Mr. Lee was following the public mood here, not leading it.
"Today the average Taiwanese has negative feelings toward China," said Bikhim Hsiao, 28, a pro-independence activist. "The word China means threats and squeezing Taiwan's international space. If the mainland wants us to unify with them, they should tell us the benefits. Look what the latest fad is here -- it's a Japanese doll called 'Hello Kitty' that McDonald's uses as a promotion. People stand in line all night at McDonald's to get them. A Japanese doll! The Japanese colonized us for 50 years, but Japan has a more favorable image here today than China."
Given the history, any overture by Beijing would be greeted here with suspicion. But if China were to speak about coming together with Taiwan in some sort of loose commonwealth, before unification, or if China were to let Taiwan have an observer seat at something as utterly innocuous as the annual World Health Assembly, it would have a big impact. Every poll shows that when China is less threatening, people here identify more as "Chinese"; when it is more threatening they identify as "Taiwanese." The longing for some kind of unity still exists, but it is buried under layers of scar tissue, and China has to decide whether to add to those layers or start peeling them away.
"If there were a soft sell for a change, a soft-pedaling . . . I think it would make a difference," Taiwan's Vice President, Lien Chan, said to me. "Why don't we start by having the two of us -- governments or non-governmental organizations -- study together how we establish a peace zone in the Taiwan Strait?"
Another Taiwanese politician was more blunt: "I could get China's President Jiang Zemin elected President here -- easy -- if they would just try a different approach."

HEADLINE: A Fed Dissenter From June Rate Rise

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve's decision on June 30 to raise interest rates for the first time in two years was not unanimous: One Fed policy committee member dissented on the ground that the move was not needed to keep inflation under control, according to minutes of the meeting released today.
Robert D. McTeer Jr., president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas and a member of the rate-setting Federal Open Market Committee, was the sole opponent of the decision to raise the Federal funds rate -- the interest that banks charge each other on overnight loans -- by a quarter of a point, to 5 percent. 
 Mr. McTeer "noted that most measures of current inflation remain low and he saw few signs of inflation in the pipeline," the minutes said.
Nine members, including the Fed's chairman, Alan Greenspan, supported the decision. Alice M. Rivlin, who was preparing to leave as vice chairman, did not attend the meeting.
On Tuesday, the Fed again nudged up interest rates by a quarter of a point. The minutes for that meeting will be released on Oct. 7.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasuries Fall as Investors Reassess What Fed Might Do

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Bond prices fell for the first time in a week yesterday as evidence of strong consumer spending and employment caused some investors to doubt whether the Federal Reserve can keep from raising interest rates again this year.
"We see the Fed ultimately being forced to move again," said Alan Kral, who helps invest the $1 billion under management at Trevor Stewart Burton & Jacobsen Inc. "There's potential inflation in the economy." 
 The price of the 30-year bond fell 23/32, to 103 6/32. Its yield rose to 5.90 percent, from 5.85 percent. Yields on two-year notes, more sensitive to Fed rate expectations, rose 11 basis points, to 5.58 percent -- the biggest one-day increase since Aug. 9.
"There's not going to be a high comfort level about the Federal Reserve being on hold until we see slower economic growth and slack in the labor market," said Mike Cloherty, a strategist at Credit Suisse First Boston.
But Michael Budd, the director of more than $50 billion of fixed-income investments at Bank of America Investment Management in Chicago, said he was holding to his view that "the Fed has stepped to the sidelines for the remainder of the year."
Trading was swift in a market burned by this year's performance of its benchmark bond, which has had losses of 7.4 percent, including price changes and reinvested interest.
Treasury notes took the biggest hit after the Government said consumer spending, which accounts for two-thirds of economic activity, rose at an annual 4.6 percent rate in the second quarter -- above the 4 percent pace it initially reported.

HEADLINE: Growth Slows, But Economy Is Still Robust

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 26

 BODY:
A swollen trade deficit helped slow the economy's growth in the second quarter, but consumers continued to spend briskly, the Government said today.
The Commerce Department reported that the nation's gross domestic product -- the total output of goods and services -- grew at an annual rate of 1.8 percent from April through June, down from 4.3 percent in the first quarter. The Government originally estimated the second quarter's growth rate at 2.3 percent. 
 The revised report comes two days after the Federal Reserve raised interest rates for the second time this summer in an effort to avert inflationary pressures. Though growth has slowed recently, the economy is still expected to increase by a robust rate of nearly 4 percent for the year. The total output of goods and services for the second quarter was $7.8 trillion, when adjusted for inflation.
"The report is a reflection of a strong economy, not a weak one," said Sung Won Sohn, Wells Fargo's chief economist. "Consumers are still on a spending spree. That's one of the reasons why businesses cannot keep inventories on the shelves and that imports are up so much."
The second-quarter trade deficit was $14.4 billion bigger than previously estimated and shaved 1.34 percentage points off the nation's economic growth.
Consumer spending, which accounts for two-thirds of total economic activity, rose in the second quarter at an annual rate of 4.6 percent. At the same time, business investment -- spending on new equipment and plants -- rose at an annual rate of 11.2 percent.
Given hearty spending by consumers and businesses, "I don't think the Fed will look at this report and say, 'Oh, our job is done, the economy is slowing,' " said Cynthia Latta, an economist with Standard & Poor's DRI. "I think they are going to be as vigilant as ever in watching for a possible acceleration of inflation."
Thus far, inflation remains contained. The Government did not revise an inflation gauge tied to second-quarter G.D.P., which rose 2.1 percent. In the first quarter that inflation measure rose 1.2 percent.
Rising labor costs resulting from the lowest unemployment rate in three decades have, however, cut into corporate profits, which fell at an annual rate of $9.2 billion in the second quarter, the biggest drop since the end of 1997. In the first quarter of the year, profits rose at a $47.1 billion rate.
The number of Americans filing for unemployment benefits last week fell by 5,000, to 283,000, the Labor Department said. The labor market is considered extremely tight whenever jobless claims fall below 300,000.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Broad Retreat on Wall St. In Wake of Rate Increase

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Stocks retreated broadly yesterday. A rally based on the belief that Tuesday's interest-rate increase would be the Federal Reserve's last for the year gave way, as traders began to suspect that might not be the case.
Interest rates climbed, especially on the actively traded two-year note, after the Government reported that consumer spending was even more robust than first estimated in the second quarter and that the job market remained taut last week. Some investors were moved to cash in their winnings. 
 After setting two records earlier in the week, the Dow Jones industrial average was on the defensive throughout the session and finished down 127.59 points, or 1.13 percent, at 11,198.45. The Nasdaq market, which had posted four consecutive gains, advanced in the early going but slumped in the afternoon to close down 30.98 points, or 1.1 percent, at 2,774.62.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index did the worst of the major gauges, skidding 19.78 points, or 1.43 percent, to close at 1,362.01.
"We had a pretty good run," said Andrew M. Brooks, senior equity trader at T. Rowe Price. "It shouldn't be cause for concern that the market's given some up today."
In fact, contended Todd E. Petzel, chief investment officer of the Commonfund Group, what was surprising was the market's optimism leading up to and immediately following the Federal Reserve move, not that there were sober second thoughts yesterday.
Technology, financial, oil, drug and airline stocks were among the chief casualties. The paper and forest products group, which was battered on Wednesday, was an isolated gaining sector after a recommendation by Merrill Lynch.
Activity was relatively light at 719 million shares on the new York Stock Exchange. In addition to the usual late-summer doldrums, flooding prevented many in the New York City area from getting to work yesterday.
Still, an initial public offering by Bamboo.com attracted lots of attention after underwriters marketed four million shares at 7. The company, based in Palo Alto, Calif., operates an Internet service that allows viewers of real estate to pan and zoom in on properties. Its stock opened at 9 1/8 and leaped to 17 9/16 at the close, with more than 24 million shares changing hands.
This made Bamboo the fourth most active stock of the day after Cisco Systems, Dell Computer and Microsoft and ahead of Intel.
Among the 30 Dow Jones blue chips, J. P. Morgan took the biggest toll, falling 4 3/8, to 134 7/8, in a weak bank group, as investors appraised Ecuador's hope of restructuring debt. Citigroup fell 1 5/16, to 47 11/16.
The next-biggest drags were Hewlett-Packard, down 2 7/16, to 102 5/8, and Procter & Gamble, down 2 3/8, to 100 1/4. They were followed by Chevron and Exxon, which lost 2 3/8 and 1 15/16, respectively.
Oil shares were weighed down by negative comment by an analyst at HSBC Securities in London who switched his view of Royal Dutch Petroleum to "reduce" from "add," helping drive the issue down 2 5/8, to 61 11/16.
Airlines, which often move opposite to oil shares, also fell yesterday, apparently in response to cuts of as much as 30 percent in seasonal leisure fares by UAL's United Airlines and Continental Airlines, resulting in the second industry sale this month. Delta Air Lines and AMR, American's parent, fell 3 3/16 each; U S Air was off 2 7/16, and UAL, Continental and Southwest Airlines slid more than a point.
The Bank of New York, the subject of a money laundering investigation, fell an additional 2 5/8, to 35 13/16.
Drug stocks declined after five consecutive advances, as analysts pointed to a rally in the dollar that tends to crimp export sales and shrinks the value of repatriated foreign profits.
Internet stocks were mostly lower, with Amazon.com losing 4 5/16, to 128 9/16, and Yahoo falling 5 7/8, to 152 11/16. Priceline.com was a conspicuous exception, jumping 7 7/16, to 72 5/8.
On the New York Stock Exchange 1,790 issues declined, while 1,191 advanced. New 52-week lows nearly doubled new highs, 85 to 43.
Stocks were narrowly mixed in major European markets but lower by more than 1 percent in Tokyo and Sao Paulo, Brazil

HEADLINE: Venezuelan Congress Fights Loss of Power

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: BRASILIA, Aug. 26

 BODY:
Venezuela braced today for a political showdown, as its Congress threatened to meet on Friday in defiance of a new Constitutional Assembly that effectively shut it down and as opposition leaders accused President Hugo Chavez of manipulating the assembly to bring down democratic rule.
"This is using the Constitution to carry out a coup," said Cesar Perez Vivas, a congressional deputy and the leader of the center-right Copei group, one of two parties that has dominated Venezuelan politics since a military dictatorship gave way to democracy in 1958. 
 On Wednesday evening, the assembly, which is dominated by supporters of President Chavez, decreed a "legislative emergency" and passed a measure that strips the opposition-controlled Congress of its authority to pass laws and ordains that all of its "ordinary and special sessions are suspended."
The move came barely a week after the assembly, which was elected last month to draft a new Constitution, took similar action against the judiciary, granting itself the authority to fire judges and overhaul the court system.
Today, opposition leaders criticized the assembly's latest action as an illegal usurpation of powers and vowed to resist. Mr. Chavez has maintained that the constitutional panel enjoys unlimited powers. Earlier this month, he symbolically offered the assembly his own resignation to demonstrate its power to dismiss or reconfirm him.
In a televised speech today that was largely devoted to analysis of an economic situation that has worsened considerably since he took office in February, Mr. Chavez defended the assembly.
"In Venezuela, democracy is being born," he said. "Venezuela is coming out of tyranny. The entire world should recognize that."
Mr. Chavez, 45, who was elected with a sweeping majority last December, is a former Army paratrooper who was cashiered and imprisoned in 1992 after leading an unsuccessful coup attempt in which dozens of people died. He has vowed to carry out a peaceful "social revolution" in his country, which has the largest reserves of oil outside the Middle East and is the United States' main source of imported oil.
His opponents accuse him of seeking to install a left-wing military dictatorship. Mr. Chavez has submitted a draft Constitution that would extend his term to six years, and allow him to succeed himself in office and to promote military officers without the Senate's approval.
Among ordinary Venezuelans, however, Mr. Chavez remains wildly popular, with an approval rating above 70 percent. In the July 25 balloting to elect the Constitutional Assembly, 121 of 131 seats went to his supporters, including his wife, a brother, several former military colleagues and five former members of his Cabinet.
At first, it was expected that the assembly would focus exclusively on drafting a new Constitution -- the 26th in the country's turbulent history. By law, the body is required to finish work within six months and submit the document to a referendum for approval. But the assembly has spent much of its first three weeks extending its control over existing branches of Government.
Popular dissatisfaction with the two dominant parties and Congress, which have been criticized as corrupt and inefficient, has mounted in recent years. After the assembly was elected last month, Congress, recognizing it had little support and wishing to avoid a confrontation, decided to go into recess until October and even offered the assembly its chamber as a meeting place.
"There are times when resistance just for the sake of resistance makes no sense," Enrique Capriles, 27, a Copei deputy and the speaker of the lower house, said in explaining the legislature's action. But he also contended that "the constituted powers retain their character until the new Constitution" goes into effect, and warned that if the assembly tried to dissolve Congress, "we will react."
Ignoring that warning, the assembly voted Wednesday to limit the legislature's work to matters such as supervising the budget and communications. Lawmakers immediately responded by declaring their summer recess ended, and said that they would reconvene on Friday.
Meanwhile, the assembly proceeded with its moves to restructure the judiciary. Nearly half of Venezuela's 4,700 judges, clerks and bailiffs are estimated to be facing accusations of corruption, and the assembly has vowed to resolve those cases.
"The Constitutional Assembly has absolute powers," said Manuel Quijada, a lawyer whom the assembly has placed in charge of a special commission to revamp the courts. "The objective is that the substitution of judges take place peacefully, but if the courts refuse to acknowledge the assembly's authority, we will proceed in a different fashion."
On Monday, the Supreme Court ruled, by an 8-6 vote, that the assembly did not act unconstitutionally in assuming judicial powers. The Chief Justice, Cecilia Sosa Gomez, resigned on Tuesday, lamenting the disintegration of what she called "the last control on constitutionality and legality that existed in Venezuela" and accusing judges and Congress of caving to political pressure.
"The court simply committed suicide to avoid being assassinated," she said in a nationally televised news conference. "The result is the same: it is dead."
In an interview published today in the Spanish newspaper El Pais, Carlos Andres Perez, the former President whose overthrow Mr. Chavez sought in 1992, predicted that Mr. Chavez would himself fall from power before his first term expires. Saying that "the concentration of powers is anti-democratic," he accused Mr. Chavez of seeking "a military government that will totally wipe out the triumphs of the Venezuelan people.
"I am not one to encourage coups or violent attitudes, but it is clear what is going to happen," said Mr. Perez, who ran for a seat in the assembly but suffered a humiliating defeat. "I think the upheaval we are in will last two years, and afterward Venezuela will begin to get back on its feet, but without Chavez at its head."

HEADLINE: Victoria Journal;
In Canada's 'Lotusland,' Unhappy Is Premier's Lot

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: VICTORIA, British Columbia, Aug. 25

 BODY:
Inside the hilltop mansion of the Queen's representative here, portraits of the royal family and gleaming gold maple leafs lent a traditional air as Dan Miller was sworn in today as the new Premier of Canada's Pacific province.
But even the neo-Westminster pomp, the crystal chandeliers and the gilded mirrors failed to distract from the political instability that makes this capital seem less like London and more like La Paz. Only days ago, Mr. Miller himself, a stoop-shouldered, sad-faced man, acidly described the Premier's job as the most dangerous in the province. 
 His predecessor, Glen Clark, resigned last week, the province's third Premier in a row to quit under a cloud of scandal. It has been 20 years since voters here elected a Premier who served out his term. The new Premier, Mr. Clark's former deputy, now vows to step down as soon as his party, the New Democrats, chooses a successor -- the province's sixth Premier in a decade.
"This has been crazy," Mr. Miller said after the ceremony, referring to the take-no-prisoners political culture of British Columbia, Canada's third most populous province. "The biggest advantage that I have in this job is that I don't really want it."
In Canada's nine other provinces, politics are no more unstable than in American states. But to the rest of Canada this province's instability is endemic to what they call "Lotusland" -- a final frontier peopled by dreamers who have cut ties of family, home and religion and drifted to the nation's left coast.
In a reference to strong green tendencies here, The National Post snickered this week from Toronto, "Perhaps the Sierra Club should declare the scandal-free B.C. Premier an endangered species." The Globe and Mail recalled that in 1872 the province's Premier legally changed his name to Amor de Cosmos, or lover of the universe. Mr. Clark, the newspaper suggested, should change his name to Amor de Chaos.
Unfortunately for residents here, provincial politicians keep living up to the wacky stereotype. Voters wince when they recall the evening when television cameras in the stately parliament building here caught the Finance Minister, a woman, placing a windup dancing penis doll on the desk of a male political adversary. Or when the local head of the Liberal Party had an extramarital affair with the leader of his parliamentary delegation, explaining that they had "identical brains."
"We just shake our heads," said Jacqueline Darmanin, a piano teacher who is a transplant from Alberta, the oil-and-gas province separated from British Columbia by the mountains of the Continental Divide. "We don't know why such a different type of people go into politics here. In Alberta, you just don't have the scandals, the back-stabbing."
For many voters, the latest political scandal will long be symbolized by a grainy television video taken one night last March. Mr. Clark can be seen pacing in his living room as detectives from the Royal Canadian Mounted Police searched his home for documents linking him to the granting of a casino license to an old friend, Dimitrios Pilarinos.
According to police documents supporting the request for the search warrant, the casino applicant provided "renovations" -- outdoor decks -- to Mr. Clark's house and vacation cottage. The city assessor's office later placed a $16,000 value on the decks.
Lawyers for Mr. Clark dispute the value of the decks, and say he gave Mr. Pilarinos a $5,000 check. After Mr. Pilarinos tore up the check, the lawyers say, Mr. Clark gave him an Indian hunting knife.
Mr. Clark might have survived this ambiguous case if pollsters had not ranked him the most unpopular Premier in Canada. In June, only 16 percent of respondents to a survey by the Angus Reid polling organization said they would vote for him.
To some political observers, Mr. Clark was only the latest British Columbia politician to rise and fall on populist rhetoric.
A former provincial Finance Minister, Mr. Clark campaigned in the May 1996 election saying that the provincial budget was balanced. One month after winning the election, he admitted that there was actually a $140 million deficit. This year, the deficit has ballooned to almost $600 million.
Enamored of megaprojects, Mr. Clark unveiled a plan to revive shipbuilding here by constructing fast ferryboats, vowing that he had crunched the numbers "right down to the toilet paper." To date, only one of those aluminum-hulled boats has been built, coming in at $140 million over budget. This year, when he proposed a half-billion dollar expansion to Vancouver's convention center, some voters started calling their 42-year-old Premier "Glennochhio."
Saddled with the highest unemployment west of Quebec, Mr. Clark attributed the province's woes to the economic implosion in Asia, a region that receives one-third of British Columbia's exports.
Desperate to drum up popular support, Mr. Clark played two cards that usually are crowd-pleasers in the Canadian West: Ottawa bashing and Washington bashing. Vowing to be "tough with the Americans," he tried to force Washington to cut American catches of Pacific salmon by refusing to renew a longstanding lease for a Canadian-American underwater missile testing range near here.
The federal Government in Ottawa responded by cutting him out of negotiations on a salmon treaty, which was finished in early June. At the same time, Ottawa dusted off a century-old, never-used expropriation law and moved to seize from the province the seabed area where the United States had invested $100 million for torpedo testing.
"British Columbians rush to leaders who promise simple solutions, then turn on them when they can't deliver," said Norman J. Ruff, a political scientist at the University of Victoria.
Others blame the harsh political language. Trading parting shots over the weekend, Mr. Clark called Gordon Campbell, a front-runner in polls for a provincial election next year, "the scariest guy around." In return, Mr. Campbell, a Liberal, said, "I think Glen Clark is going to go down in our province's history as the probably worst Premier we've had."
David Mitchell, a former member of the legislative assembly, blames the provincial press, saying it has evolved from "watchdog to attack dog." To that, Don Hauka, political reporter for The Province, a tabloid, groaned and said, "You have to cover the show."
"How often do you get a Premier named Vander Zalm who lives in a castle, above a moat and behind a drawbridge, in an amusement park called Fantasy Gardens?" he asked, referring to Bill Vander Zalm, a Premier here until 1991, who lived in a replica Dutch castle left over from Vancouver's 1986 world fair.
Despite instability here, undeclared candidates are lining up for the race. Immediately after the oath-taking ceremony at Government House here, the best attended news conference was given by Gordon Wilson, provincial minister, amateur playwright and author of the the "identical brains" remark.
In opinion polls, the leading New Democrat is Ujjal Dosanjh, the province's Indian-born Attorney General, who was nearly beaten to death here in 1985 by a Sikh radical wielding a steel bar. In an interview today, Mr. Dosanjh complained that local politics were no longer a battle of ideals or ideas, concluding, "Politics in B.C. has become a blood sport."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Sharing Ecuador's Debt Burden, but at What Cost?

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
As Ecuador is beginning the struggle to sell a restructuring plan for $6 billion of its debt to global investors, Wall Street is calculating how much the debtholders might lose. And, at the same time, investors are wondering whether this will set a precedent in future debt negotiations between troubled countries and their private creditors.
At issue is what former Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin called burden-sharing, which is simply seeing that private investors pay a larger share of the official bailouts of nations on the verge of financial collapse. 
 The push for burden-sharing began after the United States and the International Monetary Fund bailed out Mexico in 1995, saving many investors from huge losses. It picked up steam after the Asian financial crisis, during which financial assistance from the United States and the I.M.F. avoided or eased losses for many bondholders while local workers, who lost their jobs, suffered much more serious consequences.
But while the Clinton Administration supported Ecuador's effort yesterday, a senior Treasury official indicated that the resulting burden-sharing in this case should not be a precedent. "The market should not view Latin America or emerging markets generally through the prism of Ecuador," the Treasury official said.
The official's comments indicate that the Administration thinks Ecuador is a special case because its problems are atypical in Latin America. The comments also indicate that officials do not want to be hemmed in by guidelines that would prevent them from applying burden-sharing case by case.
The I.M.F., which has been in talks with Ecuador on the bond restructuring and on an economic plan to help the country get back on its feet, was also supportive.
One of the big concerns among officials and bondholders is whether Ecuador has the political will to make the policy changes, including spending reductions, that might turn its economy around. Without a viable economic plan that is backed by the I.M.F. and appears credible to investors, there is not much chance the country can work its way out of its current predicament.
Ecuador's debt restructuring -- which could lead to the first default on the popular Brady bonds that became the vehicle for revamping debt of emerging-market countries at the end of the 1980's -- began on Wednesday night. In a televised speech, President Jamil Mahuad said Ecuador would delay for 30 days a $96 million interest payment due Tuesday and ask bondholders to swap their Brady bonds for new debt.
Although the details of the swap were not provided, the Ecuadorean Government will ask bondholders to reduce the amount of money it owes them. Reducing the debt burden, including interest payments, is essential to any recovery; Ecuador's $13 billion in foreign debt alone exceeds the size of its gross national product.
Jose Luis Daza, managing director for emerging markets at J. P. Morgan Securities, estimates that Ecuador will seek debt reduction of about 30 percent. In trading yesterday, the country's three main types of Brady bonds were priced from 21 cents on the dollar to 32.5 cents, and down about a penny.
The Ecuadorean Finance Minister, Ana Lucia Armijos, was quoted by Bloomberg News as saying, "What we are doing with the Brady restructuring is asking bondholders to share the burden, as international organizations are doing through the granting of resources, as governments will do through the restructuring of Paris club debt." The Paris club is the group of nations, including the United States, that have made separate loans to the governments of many emerging-market countries. Ecuador will also seek some reduction of the more than $1 billion it owes these countries.
The senior Treasury official said the Administration would encourage Ecuador to work with the I.M.F. on "a strong economic program that will lay the basis for stability and economic recovery" and to work with its private creditors to reach arrangements that "best satisfy their common interest in economic recovery." The official added that "on that basis, we would be prepared to support an I.M.F. program and a restructuring of Ecuador's debt to Paris club creditors."
This means the Treasury wants an I.M.F. agreement before negotiations with Brady bondholders.
Mr. Rubin brought burden-sharing to the fore again in a speech last October, when the global financial crisis, deepened by Russian default, was at its worst and the Clinton Administration was talking of a new international financial architecture to deal with such problems. "Private-sector burden-sharing is critical," he said then, "not only because there will not be sufficient official money for all circumstances, but also because it is absolutely essential in inducing market discipline."
Since then, no one in the Administration has set out guidelines for burden-sharing. In April, not long before he announced his resignation, Mr. Rubin repeated the call but acknowledged that he did not know how this should be done. And it appears that the Administration is still loath to establish any guidelines.
A point that may have been overlooked in all this is that the Brady bonds Ecuador is trying to restructure have already been subject to burden-sharing, as all Brady bonds are.
The bonds, named for a Bush Administration Treasury Secretary, Nicholas F. Brady, were devised as a way to repackage the billions in bank loans to many Latin American countries that effectively defaulted on them in the early 1980's. The repackaging into bonds made the old loans more attractive to investors because they could be traded easily and came with various guarantees on the principal and interest.
But the essence of the Brady bond program was the agreement by the banks to reduce the the amount of debt owed them by the countries, led by Mexico, Brazil and Argentina. For example, Mexico, the first country to negotiate a Brady bond deal, got a 35 percent reduction in the face value of its outstanding bank loans.
Ecuador's Brady bond deal, which was issued in 1995, came with a 40 percent reduction.
Another issue is what kind of impact an Ecuadorean restructuring would have on other Brady bonds.
While any such reworking -- whether it results in default or not -- should have an impact on other countries' Brady's bonds, it is hard at this time to measure. Mr. Daza said one reason was that it was not yet clear how the restructuring would be done. A lot, he said, will depend on whether the exchange is carried out in a "market-friendly way."
But so far, the damage has not been that bad to other markets. According to J. P. Morgan's index of Latin American bonds, while the yield on Ecuador's bonds, compared with that on United States Treasury bonds, has skyrocketed since May, to a level 38.15 percentage points above Washington's, this so-called spread has stayed relatively stable against the debt of Brazil, Argentina and Mexico.
And Mr. Daza said he was surprised that the prices on Ecuador's debt had not fallen further, given the clear threat of default. Therefore, he said, prices have further to fall.

International Team Breaks Internet Security Codes
An international team of researchers has demonstrated that it is possible to break the security codes used to protect financial transactions over the Internet. 
 Although the five-month effort required a significant amount of computing power -- 292 computers at 11 sites worldwide -- it showed that the standard level of encryption for Internet transactions is not secure. Page C2.
 
Stocks Retreat on New Rate Fears
Stocks retreated broadly as a new suspicion that the Fed might raise interest rates again ended the recent rally. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 127.59 points, to 11,198.45. J. P. Morgan took the biggest toll, falling $4.375, to $134.875, on concerns about Ecuador's plan to restructure its debt. The Nasdaq composite index fell 30.98 points, to 2,774.62, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index skidded 19.78 points, to 1,362.01. C5.
 
Bonds fell for the first time in a week as evidence of strong consumer spending and employment caused some investors to doubt whether the Federal Reserve can keep from raising interest rates again this year. C5.
 
American Home in Cash Settlement
American Home Products has agreed to pay cash settlements to about 36,000 women who said they were not adequately warned about the possible side effects of the company's long-term Norplant contraceptive. A1.
 
Economic Growth Slowed in Quarter
A swollen trade deficit helped slow the economy's growth to an annual rate of 1.8 percent in the second quarter, but consumers continued to spend briskly. With the labor market tight, the number of Americans filing for jobless benefits last week fell by 5,000, to 283,000. C2.
 
A Dissenting Voice Within the Fed
When the Federal Reserve decided on June 30 to raise interest rates, one Fed policy committee member dissented. Robert D. McTeer Jr., president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Dallas, said that the move was not needed to avert inflation, meeting minutes show. C5.
 
Likelihood of Boeing Strike Grows
Boeing faces a growing likelihood of being struck when its four-year contract with the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers expires next week. A19.
 
Sorting Out Internet Name Claims
The Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers, the new oversight board, adopted a proposal to resolve competing claims to the names used for Internet addresses. But the rules will not go into effect until it can address concerns that they favor big companies. C2.
 
Cadillac Starts Its Makeover
Cadillac introduces a new badge for all its models today that is intended to herald a new era of challenging designs married to high-tech features. But the changes will not appear for two years, and Cadillac may face difficult times until then. Advertising. C4.
 
Mademoiselle Editor Resigns
Elizabeth Crow resigned as editor in chief of Mademoiselle this week after six years striving to make it a must-read magazine for smart women in their 20's. Conde Nast expects to name a new editor next week. C4.
 
Creditors Give Daewoo a Reprieve
South Korean creditors gave Daewoo, the nearly insolvent conglomerate, another reprieve, deferring debt repayments by 12 affiliates and providing new short-term loans. C3.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS -- 'Begols' and 'Dirty Water';
Fast-Food Chains Take U.S. Marketing to Europe

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: ROME, Aug. 23

 BODY:
Nobody knows when the custom began among travelers to Rome of turning your back to the Trevi Fountain and tossing in a coin over your left shoulder as a means of assuring your return.
Do it these days, however, and you will probably spy, over to the left and a few steps up the narrow Via di San Vincenzo, a row of tan awnings labeled Dunkin' Donuts. 
 Rome, the Eternal City, home to . . . Dunkin' Donuts? Yes. Only two months old, the little store that bears the bright colors is already selling 1,200 to 1,300 doughnuts a day to a mix of foreign tourists and Italians. For a store of only 690 square feet, a fraction of the size of the average Dunkin' Donuts in the United States, said Gianluigi Contin, president of the company that operates it, "that's not bad."
Why would Italians, raised on tasty cannoli, Neapolitan pastry and endless tiny cups of super-strong espresso, enjoy washing down fluffy donuts with American-style coffee? That is not easy to explain, but the timing seems just right as a fresh wave of fast-food establishments sweeps across not just Italy but much of Europe.
Not that selling skeptical Italians on doughnuts and drip coffee comes all that easy. The company has decked the store out in big pop plastic doughnuts, in garish shades of orange and hot pink, with fluorescent lighting. To amuse and inform customers, table-top folders ask provocatively, in Italian, "Ever tried American coffee?" then go on: "Do you think it's dirty water? If so, have an espresso. We'll never convince you." Another prods, "Ever tried a bagel? (It's pronounced 'begol')."
The fast-food chains' wave is gathering momentum as a result of a combination that includes a crisis in family-owned mom-and-pop food businesses, large fast-food franchises eager to expand into what they see as underserved territory, and investors on both sides of the Atlantic who are awash in money available at low cost and who can taste the prospect of quick growth and future earnings.
This fertile terrain prompted a group of international investors, including several from the United States, to bid enough to win the master franchise for Dunkin' Donuts in Italy and Germany, and possibly other countries. The store at the Trevi Fountain is the flagship, but the group, known as S & C International, plans to open about 110 stores in six years, roughly 70 in Germany and 40 in Italy. The first Dunkin' Donuts in Germany, in Berlin's fashionable Charlottenburg quarter, is to open by November. The next Italian store will open in October at the central Termini railway station in Rome.
The expected growth is partly a result of the realization that many big fast-food franchises have virtually saturated the United States, while Europe's fast-food map still shows large empty areas.
"There's a market there," said Mr. Contin, 35, of S & C International, noting that Italy's roughly 180,000 coffee bars are almost all individually owned, and many are in poor financial health.
And while market leaders like the McDonald's Corporation have fairly blanketed the European landscape, most other fast-food franchises are far more thinly spread. In Western Europe, for instance, Dunkin' Donuts had until now been limited to a fairly small number of stores in Britain, Greece, Ireland, the Netherlands and Spain, leaving big markets like France, Germany, Italy and Switzerland bereft.
Cheeky selling techniques, combined with the appeal of almost anything American, are breaking down European resistance to fast food in many places that had long been untouched. Earlier this month, Burger hKing opened its first restaurant in Italy, in Milan, and more are to come. In July, Autogrill S.p.A., a restaurant operator controlled by the Benetton clothing group, spent almost $1 billion to acquire its big American rival, the Host Marriott Services Corporation, which operates Pizza Hut, Starbucks and Sbarro franchises in North America. It plans to expand the reach of those names into new European nooks and crannies.
Tricon Global Restaurants Inc., which was spun off last year by Pepsico Inc., has said it sees tremendous growth potential in Europe for its franchise brands Pizza Hut and KFC. Other big chains, including Starbucks, are also looking closely at large European markets, notably Germany.
"We need to expand in Europe," said Lyne Mongrain, brand marketing director for Dunkin' Donuts International, which has been owned by the big British beverage group, Allied Domecq P.L.C., since 1989.
This second wave of fast-food expansion follows a hiatus in much of the 1990's, as European economies slumped and the 15-nation European Union struggled to introduce a single currency and integrate other countries into its earlier core.
In Toti Attanasio's hometown of Catania, a Sicilian city of 378,000, the first fast-food restaurant, a McDonald's, plans to open in October. On a recent trip to Rome, Mr. Attanasio, 28, a court magistrate, stumbled on the new Dunkin' Donuts while sightseeing with his girlfriend. They were so impressed by the doughnuts, he said, that after a four-day side trip to Bologna, they made a point of returning.
"We even bought three to take home, but then ate them while we were walking down the street," he said between bites of a French cruller.
The doughnuts, at the equivalent of 98 cents each, are more expensive than in New York, where they sell for about 85 cents. But Mr. Attanasio, who said he was a fan of American culture and a collector of Bruce Springsteen recordings, described the doughnuts as a treat because they were unlike anything Italian pastry had to offer. "We Italians like to try new things," he said.
Of course, not everyone is bubbling with enthusiasm over the arrival of Dunkin' Donuts in romantic corners of Europe like the Trevi Fountain, immortalized by the voluptuous Anita Ekberg frolicking with the heartthrob Marcello Mastroianni in its dark nighttime waters.
"As long as it creates jobs, it's all right with me," said Paolo Becker, a man in his 40's who for the last 10 years has sold accessories for smokers -- fancy pipes and cigar humidors -- in a store across the street. But he added, softly: "It's a typical product of American culture -- the colors, the fake plastic doughnuts. It's not my thing."
He admitted that he had taken his daughter, who is 13, to McDonald's. But like many Europeans, he is uneasy, partly for the threat to small independent retailers, partly for the changing character of historic inner cities. And it is not just American stores that raise a certain level of ire; so do locally owned chains.
"The neighborhood used to be traditionally Italian, but have you seen the Benetton on the square?" Mr. Becker said, waving toward the Italian clothing chain's large, modern outlet directly opposite the soaring fountain with its prancing marble horses. "It used to be a historic store, called Giusti, a family haberdashery, but it died because 95 percent of the people who pass here now are tourists, often groups, and groups don't have time to stop."
His own store, he said, relied on a loyal clientele of pipe and cigar smokers from throughout Rome, generating only about 5 percent of its sales from tourists.
But that raises a difficult choice for Europeans. While many bemoan the loss of charm in their historic cities, developers and retailers are persuading city planners that American-style franchising, and the job creation and promotional spending that go with it, can help keep central cities vibrant.
"We don't want to drive out the traditional coffee bar," said Leonardo Mainella, a 27-year-old law student who works part time at the Dunkin' Donuts. "We want to be here alongside them."
Indeed, Toni Impeduglia, the new store's manager, said the developers were at pains to give the store a bit of European flair. A star Milanese architect, Matteo Thun, was called in to impart to the design a vaguely retro look, with chrome tubular chairs and plastic accessories in bright colors. American customers, used to the more pedestrian homegrown variety of Dunkin' Donuts, were impressed.
"It's trendy," said Amelia Hindi, 25, who toured Switzerland and Italy this summer after graduating from Brooklyn Law School and admitted to being startled to find a Dunkin' Donuts at the Trevi Fountain.
"Back home," she said as she sipped a coolatta, "they don't have doughnuts with lights hanging from the ceiling."
Mr. Impeduglia, 35, who heads off this fall to the Boston area for a six-week course at the Dunkin' Donuts University there, acknowledged that given the rush of summer tourism, probably 70 percent to 80 percent of the store's daytime customers are foreign tourists, though the number of Italians increases in the evenings. Come autumn, he said, he expects the percentages to reverse.
He said Italian customers do not make unfavorable comparisons with local pastry. "In Italy, we have our own pastry tradition, but you shouldn't compare the two," he said.
The same holds true for American-style coffee, he argued. In the store's first months, sales of American coffee, which costs $1 for a regular cup, have been roughly double that of espresso, which costs only 70 cents.
"It's a bit of a fashion, particularly among Italian women in their 30's and 40's," Mr. Contin said.
"It's less hysterical, you sit down to drink it," unlike espresso, which Italians gulp on the run, he said. "And there's three times less caffeine, so there's a small but widening niche."
As for bagels, Mr. Impeduglia said, Italian customers tend to look on them "as just some kind of bread." The Trevi Fountain store stocks five varieties, including onion, sesame, cinnamon and plain, and serves them with five varieties of cream cheese, including dill, salmon and plain. This fall, bagel sandwiches will go on sale, with fillings like chicken salad and boiled ham.
But with so many investors rushing in, should the fast-food industry be afraid of a European glut?
Paolo de Spirt, chairman and one of the founders of S & C International, thinks not.
"On the simple numbers of it, the number of chains in Europe is far behind that in the United States," Mr. de Spirt, a former investment banker at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell, said. In Europe, he said, only 16 percent of food distribution is franchised, and in some major markets, like Italy, as little as 5 percent, compared with more than 50 percent in the United States.
"The potential for growth here is enormous," he said.
