HEADLINE: TV Judge Stars in Real Court Drama

BYLINE: By EMILY YELLIN 

DATELINE: MEMPHIS, Aug. 26

 BODY:
Louis Moore looked scared as he sat in Division 9 of the Shelby County Criminal Court here on a recent summer morning. Mr. Moore, a 19-year-old grill cook at McDonald's, knew he was going to have to go before Judge Joseph B. Brown Jr., plead guilty for his crime and hope that the judge would suspend his sentence and give him probation instead of prison.
That was nerve-racking enough. But Mr. Moore was worried further because while this was his first offense, and his first visit to court, he had seen Judge Brown in action many times before, on the year-old nationally syndicated television show "Judge Joe Brown." 
 "I'm afraid he is going to be hard and mean," Mr. Moore said, "like he is on TV."
Mr. Moore's situation illustrates the things that so many people applaud in Judge Brown. He is admired for reaching young people with his down-to-earth, tough-love approach to justice, which many believe can turn around people like Mr. Moore before they fall into a life of crime.
But the case also highlights one of the things that others criticize: he is the only judge on national television who is also a sitting judge. Many critics argue that he cannot do both jobs well.
In Memphis, where Judge Brown was a lawyer from 1974 until he became a Criminal Court judge in 1990, those two opinions about him are clashing furiously.
The Tennessee Supreme Court recently reviewed his court attendance and denied his request to have a regular substitute fill in while he is in Los Angeles taping his show.
The Commercial Appeal has written editorials criticizing his dual role, one of which began with this question: "Which court matters more to Judge Joe Brown -- the one that serves the Shelby Countians who elected him or the one created by the television executives who hired him to entertain viewers from a sound stage in Los Angeles?"
Among voters here, the judge is popular, being re-elected last year in a landslide to another eight-year term, for which he is paid $102,240 annually. Neither the producers of the show nor the judge would comment on his television salary.
Wherever he goes, including many community service events, he is asked for his autograph. His street-smart style, exemplified by the fact that he carries a pistol with him at all times, even wearing it on a holster under his robe in the courtroom, makes him a highly coveted speaker.
Recently, he told a group of women who were former convicts that by going to prison they had played into the hands of the rich, white establishment. "You are serving a great utility so that economic prosperity for the haves and the good old boys can be continued," he said.
"See, while we are acting damn fools being black against white, which we should not be since we all ought to work together, while we are distracted and polarized, what's really going on is those people are ripping us off economically."
Judge Brown, 52, who grew up in South-Central Los Angeles and graduated with honors from the U.C.L.A. Law School, has always been controversial here. He came to national attention for his creative use of alternative sentencing. It is a tactic he continues to use, routinely giving writing assignments or making defendants read "The Autobiography of Malcolm X" as part of their sentences. And most notably, he has let burglary victims take something from thieves' houses to illustrate to them how it feels to be robbed.
The judge also gained national attention when he presided over James Earl Ray's unsuccessful final efforts, before he died last year, to win a trial in the 1968 assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. The King family allied with Mr. Ray, who confessed to the murder and then recanted days later. Judge Brown was eventually removed from that case after an appeals court found that he was biased toward Mr. Ray.
During the Ray case, the producers of "Judge Judy" saw a profile of Judge Brown on the ABC program "Nightline." They contacted the judge, and his show was born. Last season it had five million viewers a day, second only to "Judge Judy" among the four national television courtroom shows at the time.
Stephen Gillers, professor of legal and judicial ethics at New York University Law School, said that although he did not doubt that Judge Brown was a good judge, he thought it was wrong for him to do both jobs.
"The judge must choose between court business and show business," Mr. Gillers said. "It is not fair to the court system or to the people of Tennessee."
Mr. Gillers cited several reasons for his dim view of Judge Brown's serving in both venues. "Inevitably, he will cut corners," he said. "In addition, he compromises the prestige of the court by exploiting his position outside the court."
Judge Brown disagrees, saying that argument represents a narrow interpretation of the code of ethics, and he believes he is doing nothing unethical.
"I am enhancing the public's respect for the courts," he said, "which is not as high as it has been. Judges have an obligation to advise the public about the law and judicial procedures, and my show does that. Through these shows, the public observes the application of common sense by judicial officials."
But in Judge Brown's courtroom, the concerns are more practical. For Mr. Moore, it had taken a long time for his case to come up because his lawyer had the hearing delayed while Judge Brown was taping the show, telling Mr. Moore it would be better to wait. Mr. Moore was not so sure, saying, "He's not real lenient."
When Mr. Moore finally sat down before Judge Brown, the judge told him to sit up straight. Mr. Moore explained that he had been helping a friend move last year and was unaware that the friend's car was stolen and that there was marijuana in it. Mr. Moore said the police stopped them and his friend ran, while he did not. Mr. Moore was charged with auto theft.
The judge sentenced Mr. Moore, an 11th-grade dropout, to two years of probation in the judicial diversion program, ordered that he complete his G.E.D. and take random drug tests as part of his sentence. And then, in his signature style, he said gruffly: "Quit blowing that herb, and concentrate and focus. Step down, young man, and get it together."

HEADLINE: Chances of Boeing Strike Appear to Grow

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
For more than a year, executives at the Boeing Company and leaders of the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, the union representing the largest number of Boeing employees, have been meeting regularly to trade ideas and work out disputes.
The not-so-subtle goal of what both sides said was a new era of cooperation between management and labor was to avoid a disruptive strike at a time when Boeing, the world's largest aerospace company, is recovering from some of the worst operational turmoil in its history. 
 But with Boeing poised to deliver its "best and final offer" to the machinists today for a contract to replace one that expires next Wednesday, the likelihood that the company will be struck for the third time in 10 years appears to be growing.
"Everything we've put together for months about working together has all been bogus as far as I am concerned," said Bill Johnson, a member of the union negotiating committee and president of the Seattle local that represents 31,000 of the 44,000 Boeing workers covered by the contract. "Nothing has come across the table that is going to satisfy our members if they are going to buy into a contract."
Of course, Cassandra-like warnings are not unusual as contract negotiations head into their endgame, especially if the union thinks, as now, that the company cannot afford a strike.
For its part, Boeing sounds more optimistic. "We have been making progress," said Peter Conte, a company spokesman. "The proposal as it is coming together will address all of the employees' issues and many of the union's concerns upon entering this round of bargaining."
Still, Mr. Conte acknowledged that the company was painting green lines around the entrances to its buildings to mark how close pickets can stand. It is also certifying some managers for technical work so they can help build its jetliners if the workers walk out.
The machinists' union represents about a quarter of Boeing's total work force of 200,000 but nearly half the 100,000 at its flagship commercial-airplane division. The union and the company have been negotiating intensively at a hotel in the Seattle area since Aug. 16.
After the machinists receive the company's final offer, they will present it to their members for a vote. If the proposal does not receive a simple majority, a second vote, requiring a two-thirds majority, will be held to decide whether to strike. A walkout could come as soon as 12:01 A.M. next Thursday. (If the strike vote fails, the company's offer is automatically accepted, even though it lacks majority support.)
The last time the machinists struck, in 1995, they were out for 69 days. The event rippled through the economy of the Seattle area, because factory workers at Boeing receive some of the region's highest wages. During that walkout, the union paid out only $17.6 million in strike benefits, compared with Boeing's normal payroll of $325 million during the same period.
A strike would also affect Wichita, Kan., where 11,500 machinists work for Boeing, making the fuselages for its single-aisle 737 jets, and Portland, Ore., where the company employs 1,800 members of the union.
The workers covered by the contract earn more than $40,000 a year on average -- not including overtime, which can swell wages to more than twice that level during periods of particularly heavy production. Although the union seeks a wage increase, neither side will discuss the size of the demand.
In any event, pay is not among the main issues, which the union has identified as job security and health and retirement benefits. A survey of its members by the union found that only 5 percent thought that their jobs were "very secure." More workers thought that subcontracting work to outsiders posed a greater threat to their jobs than did competition from Airbus Industrie, the European consortium that, other than Boeing, is the world's only remaining maker of large passenger jets.
The machinists would like a say in future decisions by the company to transfer manufacturing to outside suppliers. They also want Boeing to increase retirement benefits, which the union says average $16,200 a year after 30 years on the job.
The union is also resisting the company's efforts to reduce overtime by expanding production to seven days a week, from five, and to raise the amount workers pay for health insurance, which was the biggest issue in the 1995 strike.
Mr. Conte, the company spokesman, said Boeing simply wanted to explore how best to manage escalating health care costs.
"All our positions are subject to change up until the final offer," he said. "Those are among the positions that could yet change."
The machinists entered the negotiations with confidence, because Boeing is only beginning to emerge from a costly foul-up two years ago that forced it to halt airplane production for a month and led to its first annual loss in 50 years.
Boeing's stock price, which at first plunged, has since recovered, rising 36 percent this year. But it is still not back to where it was before the crisis began. Wall Street analysts think that Boeing must improve its efficiency on the factory floor if it is to increase its profits.
"You really need to see the work force actively increasing productivity at the company," said Byron K. Callan, an aerospace analyst at Merrill Lynch.
Some think that the union may be overplaying its hand, underestimating Boeing's willingness to fight.
"We don't want a strike," Harry C. Stonecipher, Boeing's president, said in an interview in June. "We don't expect a strike. I don't think the union wants a strike. But I think both sides are perfectly willing to strike, or take a strike, if anybody gets kind of stupid or forgets what the world's all about."

HEADLINE: Bank Called Long Unaware Of Big, Suspicious Transfers

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY L. O'BRIEN and RAYMOND BONNER 

 BODY:
Large sums of money were moved through accounts at the Bank of New York for at least six months before the bank was aware of it, according to individuals who have direct knowledge of an investigation into Russian money laundering.
They said today that nine New York accounts that are part of the inquiry became active before March 1998, much earlier than was previously believed. 
 More than $4.2 billion that investigators suspect was tied to organized crime and corporate embezzlement in Russia passed through these accounts between early 1998 and March 1999. The bank did not begin cooperating with a Federal investigation of money laundering at the bank until September 1998.
The fact that money was filtered through the bank for at least six months before any action was taken raises questions about how well accounts and employees were supervised at the bank before the investigation was begun and will undoubtedly concern regulators.
It also is not clear why the Government allowed the accounts to remain open so long after the investigation began.
The accounts are linked to Benex, a company incorporated in London, whose exact activities are unknown.
In March of this year, the British authorities who had initially notified the Federal Bureau of Investigation about a suspected money laundering operation in June 1998 expressed concern that the inquiry was moving too slowly. Federal and state bank regulators have declined to comment on the matter.
Investigators believe that as much as $10 billion may have been moved by Russian organized crime and members of the country's political and business elite through the Bank of New York in order to hide its origins.
Some news reports have suggested that some of that money may have been diverted from loans extended by the International Monetary Fund to Russia in 1998 as part of a failed effort to stop a series of bank collapses and the crash of the ruble.
But a senior Clinton Administration official said that Attorney General Janet Reno was given a detailed briefing yesterday on the investigation and that the Justice Department did not believe, at this point, that I.M.F. funds were involved in the suspected money laundering.
The official said the amount of money involved was so great that it almost certainly did not come only from the direct profits of criminal activities. Other areas, besides the I.M.F., that investigators are studying as potential sources for the money include looted state assets and corporate corruption.
People close to the investigation said the $4.2 billion initially moved slowly through the Benex accounts but then increased to sometimes very heavy volumes before the bank began cooperating with the investigation.
Thousands of pages of records pertaining to Benex were obtained through subpoenas sent to the bank, but it could not be determined when those subpoenas were issued, information that would help make the sequence of events less murky.
People close to the investigation said the Government had requested the accounts be left open from September 1998 until last week. The accounts were closed only after The New York Times wrote about the investigation last week, these people said.
Spokesmen for the F.B.I. and the United States Attorney's Office in New York declined to comment on any aspect of the matter yesterday.
Two bank employees have been suspended since the investigation became public. People close to the investigation said yesterday that no "smoking gun" had been discovered implicating the employees. Natasha Gurfinkel Kagalovsky, a Bank of New York executive who oversaw the bank's Russian business, was suspended from her job pending the outcome of the investigation.
No document has been discovered so far that directly links Ms. Kagalovsky to the suspected money laundering operation, an investigator said. But he added that it was "inconceivable," given her position, that she had not been aware of the large volumes of questionable money moving through the accounts.
Ms. Kagalovsky's lawyer has declined to comment, and she has not been charged with any wrongdoing.
The other bank executive who has been suspended, Lucy Edwards, worked in the bank's London office. Ms. Edwards has also not been charged with wrongdoing, and it has not been possible to reach her or her husband, Peter Berlin, who ran Benex, the company whose accounts are under investigation.
The people close to the investigation said the Bank of New York claimed that it did not know that Ms. Edwards was married to Mr. Berlin. They also said evidence had been found in Ms. Edwards' London home indicating that she used the Bank of New York name for dealings unrelated to her bank duties.
The name of Ms. Kagalovsky's husband, Konstantin, vice chairman of a large Russian oil company called Yukos, has also come up in connection with the Bank of New York investigation.
Mr. Kagalovsky is a former vice chairman at Menatep, a now insolvent Russian bank that once did business with Bank of New York. Investigators are examining whether Menatep accounts were laundered through the American bank.
Mr. Kagalovsky has declined repeated requests for an interview. In a statement yesterday, Menatep said that "neither the institution nor its esteemed former vice chairman can in any way reasonably be implicated" in charges of money laundering at the Bank of New York.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
Builders Prodding Rebirth of Beachfront in Queens

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
For three decades, city officials have struggled to find a way to develop the Arverne neighborhood in the Rockaways, a vast expanse of beachfront land in Queens that has lain fallow since its bungalows were cleared as part of urban renewal efforts in the late 1950's and early 1960's.
Now, with the demand for housing so high and the market so tight, new houses are finally going up in the area, which is one of the few urban neighborhoods along a beach that is served by mass transit. 
 Development has come to the 308-acre Arverne Urban Renewal Area even though several grand plans for the area -- including one for a $1.2 billion sports and entertainment complex -- have yet to materialize. In the past, many of the ambitious proposals for Arverne fell victim to market forces, or just plain bad timing. City officials say that new development in Arverne is testimony not only to the strength of the economy but also reflects the neighborhood's promise.
"It was a great seaside resort in the way that Coney Island was at the turn of the century, with grand Victorian hotels and bungalows," said James F. Lima, assistant commissioner for new construction in the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development.
The new construction is just a beginning: 40 two-family homes on vacant lots sprinkled among the remaining houses bounded by Beach 59th and 61st Streets, Rockaway Beach Boulevard and the ocean. The builder says he particularly wants to interest local residents in the solid masonry homes.
"Basically, we believe that most of our purchasers will have lived locally and rented locally," said Vincent L. Riso, president of the Briarwood Organization, the builder. "The only necessity is that we have a buyer with good credit, income above $40,000 and a 5 percent down payment."
Residents of the area are hoping that the development will erase what is perhaps the greatest eyesore of the Rockaways.
Standing by the bay window on her porch, Maizle Morris seemed almost joyful about the grinding of bulldozers and pounding of pile drivers across the street and down the block from her home near the development.
"It's progress; I feel so happy," Mrs. Morris said of the 40 homes now being built, which are the first market-rate construction in the area in 35 years. "It's like a dream come true."
Mrs. Morris, a member of both Community Board 14 and the 52-family Arverne Neighborhood Development Organization, has been fighting for revitalization of her community since the 1970's. "All these years, they promised us everything," she said of previous city efforts. "It all fell through the cracks."
Prices for the two-family houses -- a three-bedroom home with a garage for the owner and a two-bedroom unit for possible rental -- range from $250,000 to $285,000. "It's a situation where we are purchasing the property from the city at a substantial discount, $1,000 for the land," Mr. Riso said, "and passing that discount along to the purchaser."
Under what the city calls its Urban Development Action Assistance Program, a buyer would receive real estate tax exemptions for 20 years. During the first 11 years, taxes would be payable only on the land, not the home itself. In the 12th year, the home would be 90 percent exempt, with the exemption reduced by 10 percent each year after that. Contracts have been signed for 14 of the 40 homes, Mr. Riso said, with occupancy expected next spring.
Tobias Parker, 29, a customer service representative for a credit card company, is considering buying. Mr. Parker lives in Ocean Village, a complex of 18-story rental buildings adjacent to the new houses. "I need more room," he said one recent morning. "I've got two kids and one on the way. This gives me a chance to get out of these apartments. I'm going to look into it."
Mr. Parker is eager for further development of the Arverne area. "It'll be a better community," he said, "instead of an empty lot with all of the weeds."
Previous plans for the vast, contiguous Arverne parcel, said Mr. Lima, the assistant commissioner, "have just missed the market."
In particular, he recalled a plan in the late 1980's, "costing hundreds of millions," to build out the entire 308 acres with 10,000 units of mid-rise, market-rate residential development. But then the recession hit, and the plan was abandoned.
"What came out of that," Mr. Lima said, "was a plan by the city to permit incremental, mixed-used development of single-family to mid-rise buildings with a series of public access points to the beach and public parks."
In November 1996, the city settled on developers to build two distinct projects within the urban renewal area: One was Briarwood's initial plan for 161 two-family homes; the other was for a 75,000-square-foot shopping center at Beach 73d Street, which has not yet been started.
Beyond the 40 homes now scheduled for construction, the remainder of the Briarwood project has been placed on hold while the city considers a proposal by the Reichmann family of Canada to build a $1.2 billion sports and entertainment complex called Destination Technodome in the urban renewal area.
"The community was pretty clear about wanting to build the economic base of the Rockaways, particularly capitalizing on the site's potential as a tourist and recreation destination," Mr. Lima said. "There's a real interest in incorporating a golf course, between Beach 56th and 44th, as part of a park, and an option for movie theaters, a hotel."
Mrs. Morris is hopeful. "Property values will be accelerated," she said. "I bought this home, believe it or not, for $38,000 in 1972, and got reappraised for $260,000 in 1995 when I refinanced."
If promises are finally kept, she said, "it will be a community instead of vacant, barren lands."

ATTRACTIONS
 
Museums and Sites
 
ALICE AUSTEN HOUSE, 2 Hylan Boulevard, Rosebank, Staten Island. This 17th-century farmhouse, converted in the 19th century to a Victorian cottage, was the home of the photographer Alice Austen. The parlor is filled with period furniture. "A View From the Lawn: Ocean Liners in Focus," an exhibition focusing on turn-of-the-century ocean liners, including prints, models and photographs by Austen; through Aug. 29. Hours: Thursdays through Sundays, noon to 5 P.M.; closed today. Admission: $2; 12 and under, free. Information: (718) 816-4506. 

AMERICAN NUMISMATIC SOCIETY, Audubon Terrace, Broadway at 155th Street, Washington Heights. The society has the most extensive coin collection in North America; its library is open to the public. On permanent display is "American Numismatic Design: 1892-1922." Also on view is "The World of Coins," a history from 600 B.C. Free. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 9 A.M. to 4:30 P.M.; Sundays, 1 to 4 P.M. Information: (212) 234-3130.
 
HISTORIC RICHMONDTOWN, Staten Island Historical Society, 441 Clarke Avenue, Richmondtown. More than 25 buildings from the late 17th to the 19th century, restored and furnished. This village and outdoor museum depict the history of Staten Island and the surrounding region. In "Living History in the Village" costumed interpreters demonstrate the skills and trades of their earlier counterparts, including the tinsmith, the storekeeper, the doll maker and housewives. Through Sept. 6. The exhibition "Toys!" will run through December 2000. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Saturdays and Sundays, 1 to 5 P.M. Admission: $4; the elderly and those 6 to 18, $2.50; 5 and under, free. Information: (718) 351-1611.
 
MUSEUM OF CHINESE IN THE AMERICAS, 70 Mulberry Street, Chinatown. On permanent display is "Where Is Home? Chinese in the Americas," a collection of photographs and other artifacts, and "Family Portraits," photographs of Chinatown residents. "A Good Place to Land One's Feet: Brooklyn's New Chinese Community," documentary photographs. Through Oct. 2. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, noon to 5 P.M.; closed holidays. Admission: $3; the elderly and students, $1; 12 and under and museum members, free. Information: (212) 619-4785.
 
MUSEUM OF THE CITY OF NEW YORK, 1220 Fifth Avenue, at 103d Street. The museum collects, preserves and presents material related to the history of New York City. "Fashion on Stage: Couture for the Broadway Theater, 1910-55"; on view through Feb. 27. "Heritage of Care: The American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals" traces the history of the A.S.P.C.A. in New York City, highlighting the contributions of Henry Bergh, the founder and member of an aristocratic shipbuilding family in New York City. Through Oct. 31. "New New York Views: Recent Acquisitions," the museum's newest cityscapes, executed in various styles. Through Sept. 5. "Paul Robeson: Artist and Citizen," a multimedia exhibit celebrating the life and work of the politically engaged actor. Through Sept. 5. "Gotham Comes of Age: New York Through the Lens of the Byron Company, 1892-1942" remains on view through Sept. 26. "The Astor Place Riot: Looking Back 150 Years," an exhibition examining the causes of the riot of May 10, 1849, when a crowd outside the Astor Place Opera House protested the appearance of the English actor William Macready in a performance of "Macbeth." The exhibition runs through Oct. 24. "Younger Than Springtime: Celebrating 50 Years of 'South Pacific.' " Through Oct. 10. Hours: Tuesdays, 10 A.M. to 2 P.M. for registered groups only; Wednesdays through Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Sundays, noon to 5 P.M. Suggested admission: $5; the elderly, students and children, $4; families, $10. Information: (212) 534-1672.
 
MUSEUM OF JEWISH HERITAGE: A LIVING MEMORIAL TO THE HOLOCAUST, 18 First Place, at West Street and Battery Place, Battery Park City. Artifacts, documents, photographs, videos and film clips are included in exhibitions on the Holocaust and on Jewish life before and after World War II. Other exhibitions include "Jewish Life a Century Ago," with memorabilia from Jewish rituals and celebrations in Europe in the early 1900's; "War Against the Jews," detailing events from 1933 to 1945, and "Jewish Renewal," focusing on life after the Holocaust. "From Brooklyn to Bukhara: Jewish Portraits by Barbara Pfeffer," a photography exhibition of Jewish communities around the world; through Oct. 1. Summer hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 9 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Thursdays, 9 A.M. to 8 P.M.; Fridays and the eves of Jewish holidays, 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. (until Sept. 1); closed Saturdays. Admission: $7; students and the elderly, $5; 5 and under, free. Tickets can be bought in advance through Ticketmaster, (212) 307-4007, or by calling the museum the day of the visit, (212) 945-0039. Information: (212) 509-6130.
 
STATEN ISLAND INSTITUTE OF ARTS AND SCIENCES, 75 Stuyvesant Place, St. George. Cultural museum and library with artistic, scientific and environmental collections. "Chronicles of Nature: Prints by Herman Zaage," on view through Sunday. "Shelling Out: Shells From the Institute's Collection," an exhibition exploring the science, art and history of shells, locally and globally. Through Sept. 6. The Family Gallery Hands-On Exhibit features specimens, art, artifacts and activities. Information: call extension 39. Hours: Mondays through Saturdays, 9 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Sundays, 1 to 5 P.M. Suggested admission: $2.50; students and the elderly, $1.50; children under 12, $1.25. Information: (718) 727-1135.
 
Cruises
 
CIRCLE LINE CRUISES, leaving from Pier 83, 42d Street at the Hudson River, Clinton. A 90-minute 24-mile cruise around southern Manhattan, passing landmarks like Ellis Island and the United Nations. Daily at 9:30 A.M. and 6 P.M. Tickets: $18; children 12 and under, $10; the elderly, $16. A three-hour 35-mile cruise around all of Manhattan. Monday through Friday at 10 A.M., 11 A.M., noon, 1, 2, 2:45, 3:30 and 4:30 P.M.; Saturday and Sunday at 10 and 10:45, 11:30 A.M., 12:15, 1, 1:45, 2:30, 3:15, 4 and 4:45 P.M. Prices: $22; children 12 and under, $12; the elderly, $19. The Beast, a 30-minute speedboat ride around lower Manhattan. Daily every hour from 10:15 A.M. to 7:15 P.M. Prices: $15; children 12 and under: $10. There is also a two-hour Sunset Harbor Lights Cruise daily at 8 P.M. Prices: $18; children 12 and under, $10; the elderly, $16. Information: (212) 563-3200.
 
WORLD YACHT, leaving from Pier 81, 41st Street at the Hudson River, Clinton. Daily dinner cruises along the west side of Manhattan and New York Harbor, from 7 to 10 P.M., boarding at 6 P.M. Prices: Fridays, $75; Saturdays, $79; Sundays through Thursdays, $67 (does not include beverages, taxes or gratuities). Brunch cruises sail on Saturdays and Sundays from 12:30 to 2:30 P.M., boarding at 11:30 A.M.; on Wednesdays from 11 A.M. to 1 P.M., boarding at 10 A.M. Price: $39.95. Information: (212) 630-8100.
 
Gardens
 
BROOKLYN BOTANIC GARDEN, 900 Washington Avenue, Prospect Heights. More than 12,000 kinds of plants from around the world are displayed on 52 acres, including the Fragrance Garden and the Bonsai Museum, which is the largest collection of dwarf potted trees in the country. A children's art show, featuring works by more than 250 youngsters from this summer's education programs at the garden, will be on display beginning tomorrow and through Oct. 3. Throughout August the new tropical waterlily is on view in the garden's waterlily pools. Free guided tours at 1 P.M. on weekends. Admission: $3; $1.50 for students and the elderly; free for children 15 and under; free on Tuesdays, except holidays, and free from 10 A.M. to noon on Saturdays. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 8 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Saturdays, Sundays and holidays, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. The conservatory closes 30 minutes before the garden grounds. Information: (718) 623-7200.
 
STATEN ISLAND BOTANICAL GARDEN, 1000 Richmond Terrace, Livingston. The one-acre New York Chinese Scholar's Garden has recently opened; open Wednesdays through Sundays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Admission to the Chinese Scholar's Garden: $5; $4 for the elderly; $10 for families. The garden covers 83 acres, with neo-classical buildings that once housed retired seamen. Hours: daily, dawn to dusk. Free. Information: (718) 273-8200.
 
Zoos
 
CENTRAL PARK ZOO, Fifth Avenue at 64th Street. The zoo has rare tamarin monkeys, polar bears, colobus monkeys, gentoo penguins, chinstrap penguins and red pandas. Also sea lion feedings at 11:30 A.M., 2 and 4 P.M., and penguin feedings at 10:30 A.M. and 2:30 P.M. Adult courses are available; course information: (212) 439-6583. Wildlife theater, series of skits and shows about wildlife issues, approximately every 30 minutes daily through Labor Day. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M.; Saturdays, Sundays and holidays, 10:30 A.M. to 5:30 P.M. Admission: $3.50; the elderly, $1.25; children 3 to 12, 50 cents; under 3, free. Admission includes entry to the nearby Tisch Children's Zoo. General information: (212) 861-6030.
 
PROSPECT PARK ZOO, 450 Flatbush Avenue, near Empire Boulevard, Prospect Heights, Brooklyn. Geared to children, with sea lions, wallabies, baboons, farm animals and a discovery trail. Sea lion feedings daily at 11:30 A.M., 2 and 4 P.M. Open daily from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. weekdays; until 5:30 P.M. Saturdays, Sundays and holidays. Admission: $2.50; the elderly, $1.25; children 3 to 12, 50 cents; 2 and under, free. Information: (718) 399-7339.

HEADLINE: National News Briefs;
Atlanta Faces Lawsuit Over Affirmative Action

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Aug. 26

 BODY:
A nationwide anti-affirmative action group sued Atlanta today over its policy of setting aside a third of city contracts for businesses owned by women and minority members.
The group, the Southeastern Legal Foundation, had threatened for months to file the Federal suit, while Mayor Bill Campbell and other black politicians vowed to fight "to the death." 
 Atlanta, birthplace of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and a symbol of black economic achievement, started the program in 1975 under Maynard Jackson, the city's first black Mayor.
The foundation's president, Matthew J. Glavin, began his challenge on June 14 with a letter to Mayor Campbell demanding that the city abandon the program or face a lawsuit. Mr. Glavin said today that he was still willing to negotiate, though he said any settlement would require that the city abolish the program.

HEADLINE: Harlem Rally Permit Denied, But Organizers Are Defiant

BYLINE: By DAVID BARSTOW 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced yesterday that the city has denied a permit for a controversial youth rally in Harlem, but organizers of the event angrily vowed to proceed with or without the city's permission.
Mr. Giuliani said the permit was denied because the organizers, whom he has called "reprehensible" for their anti-white and anti-Semitic comments, failed to submit a proper application. "They had an opportunity to properly apply," he said. "They haven't. So as far as we're concerned it's over." The Mayor did not specify how the group's application was improper. 
 Khallid Abdul Muhammad, the primary organizer of the event, called the Million Youth March, said he will first seek to overturn the city's decision in court. But if that course fails, he added, the rally, scheduled for Sept. 4, will go forward anyway.
"I believe in the philosophy and the ideology of peace if possible, but violence when necessary," Mr. Muhammad said yesterday.
When the Million Youth March was held last year, after a court order permitting the rally, dozens of people were injured as hundreds of police officers and rally participants clashed.
While saying yesterday that the objective of the rally was to call attention to education and economic empowerment for black youths -- "We are not going for a war in the streets," he said -- he also insisted on his "God given" right to lead a rally of young blacks in the streets of Harlem.
"I will be there," he said, emphasizing each word. "For the sake of my people, for the sake of our youth, I will be there."
Just as firmly, Mr. Giuliani and Police Commissioner Howard Safir promised that the city would act to prevent the rally from being held without the required city permits.
"This is a group that talks about hurting people and hate," Mr. Safir said. "There is no permit. If they attempt to march, they won't be allowed to, and that will be the end of it." He did not elaborate on what methods the Police Department would use.
Yesterday's events -- announcement of the permit denial, the promised legal challenge, the charged words of confrontation -- mirrored the events leading up to last year's Million Youth March. Once again, Mr. Giuliani dismissed the march organizers as marginal hatemongers who are playing to the news media. Once again, Mr. Muhammad accused the Mayor of oppressing black people and pandering to Jews who resent Mr. Muhammad's history of anti-Semitic remarks -- epithets so extreme that he was suspended in 1994 from his position as spokesman for the Nation of Islam.
"Seems like deja vu," Mr. Muhammad said in an interview outside Sistas' Place, a jazz cafe in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn that is serving as the headquarters for the rally.
As he spoke, several passing cars honked, the drivers sticking out raised fists or calling words of support to Mr. Muhammad, who was dressed in combat boots and black fatigues.
One woman pulled over to tell him she planned to be at the event no matter what. "These devils won't write that," he told her, gesturing toward three reporters.
In his announcement yesterday, Mr. Giuliani said the permit was denied because Mr. Muhammad's group, the New Black Panther Party, had refused to "comply with the parameters" of a Federal appeals court ruling last year that gave the organization permission to demonstrate then for four hours on six blocks along a section of Lenox Avenue known as Malcolm X Boulevard.
There was confusion over the timing of the denial of the permit. Asked when the decision was made, Mr. Giuliani said yesterday that it was made "about three or four days ago."
Yet the day before, when asked by reporters whether the march should be allowed, Mr. Giuliani declined to answer, and he made no mention of the permit having been denied. Nor did City Corporation Counsel Michael D. Hess mention that there had been a decision when he spoke late Wednesday afternoon with Roger S. Wareham, an attorney for the march.
According to Mr. Wareham, Mr. Hess said that he wanted to work out an agreement and avoid the necessity of going to court. In an interview, Mr. Hess said the final decision was made yesterday, when the Mayor announced that the permit had been denied.
Mr. Muhammad said march organizers have agreed all along to abide by the terms of that ruling. In their most recent letter to the city, dated Monday, a lawyer for the march organizers said that they "fully intend to function within the spirit" of that court decision. But in the same letter, the lawyer went on to request additional city permits for a 17-block parade to the rally site at 118th Street and Malcolm X Boulevard.
"The conveners are only demanding equal treatment before the law," the lawyer, Jomo Thomas, wrote.
Mr. Muhammad said it was Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Safir who were defying the ruling and "now trying to rewrite the white Constitution of America." He said the two were "rattling the saber" to confuse and frighten those who might be inclined to attend the rally. "They are wickedly wise," he said. "They want to minimize this new black power movement."
But Mr. Giuliani yesterday pointedly noted that Mr. Muhammad has lost the backing of Harlem's leading politicians, who last year supported the march even as they condemned Mr. Muhammad for his comments about Jews and whites. On Wednesday, for example, the most powerful political figure in Harlem, Representative Charles B. Rangel, called on blacks to boycott the march.
"I have to commend all of the political leaders in the community for supporting the city's position," Mr. Giuliani said. "I think that it shows a great deal of independence and courage to do that, and a willingness to take a look again at a set of facts in which they had a different position last year."
Mr. Rangel, slightly uncomfortable at being the recipient of mayoral praise, declined yesterday to support Mr. Giuliani's decision to deny a permit for the march. "The city has done this before and the courts clearly overruled," he said. "Anybody has the right to do anything they want, but I think it is in the community's best interest to ignore these spokespeople for racism and hatred."
Yet Mr. Rangel's call for a boycott -- and the likelihood that a court will now decide the question of whether to grant a rally permit -- largely defused any potential political fallout for Mr. Giuliani, who is considering running for the United States Senate.
Mr. Giuliani's likely opponent, Hillary Rodham Clinton, announced yesterday that she, too, opposed the march. But through a spokesman, Mrs. Clinton declined to offer an opinion on whether the organizers should be denied a permit.
"That's up to the appropriate authorities to determine," the spokesman, Howard Wolfson, said. "Mrs. Clinton certainly joins with community leaders in opposing the march."

HEADLINE: Library Users Can't Afford to Pay

 BODY:

To the Editor:
John Derbyshire (Op-Ed, Aug. 24) wants to impose fees on library users to make reading a magazine on a library computer more like signing up for a subscription at home. While allowing "exemptions for kids, students and retirees," Mr. Derbyshire's proposal strikes at the heart of the free access -- for everyone -- that makes public libraries the engines for equality that they are today. 
 A Federal study released in July by the National Telecommunications and Information Administration revealed that unemployed Americans who use the Internet outside the home rely on public libraries at almost three times the rate of the general population. People earning less than $20,000 a year are more than twice as likely to rely on libraries for Internet access as are Mr. Derbyshire's "middle-class magazine addicts."
 
DAVID S. BIRDSELL
New York, Aug. 24, 1999
 
The writer is a professor of public affairs at Baruch College, CUNY.

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 33; Column 4; Leisure/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 4677 words

HEADLINE: ON THE ROAD;
Foreign, Not Far

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr. 

DATELINE: MONTREAL

 BODY:
In Paris, the familiar eight-sided red street signs say "STOP." The Academie Francaise, the guardian of linguistic purity, utters not a peep of complaint. But in Montreal, where these matters are deemed crucial to cultural identity, the signs say "ARRET."
The proud old Queen Elizabeth Hotel, which dates from Canada's days as a dominion, is now Le Reine Elizabeth, never mind what the chatelaine of Buckingham Palace calls herself. In Montreal, Eaton's department store, a Canadian tradition for generations, is now just plain Eaton; the possessive ending was amputated because the authorities ruled it too un-French. They even tried unsuccessfully to force a local stonecutter to take down his sign; it was bilingual, O.K., but the two languages were English and Hebrew. 
 There is a serious side to all of this opera bouffe, of course. It is a continuing manifestation of the deep frustration and resentment that Quebec's Francophones feel toward Canada's top-heavy Anglophone majority, which has always monopolized the economic high ground here. That there was widespread discrimination until fairly recently is beyond dispute; for years English-speaking clerks in some shops shunned French-speaking customers.
Twice in the last two decades hard feelings have pushed Quebec close to separation from Canada, with severe and lasting consequences for Montreal, even if the city itself voted no. The issue still percolates, never very far beneath the surface. "Je me souviens," the license plates on Quebec cars say, "I remember," as if warning that past slights will one day be avenged.
But the visiting, linguistically challenged American need not fear. Most of the Montrealers one encounters speak excellent English, though they delight in encountering an American with a smattering of French. Like us, they laugh at signboard Franglais that has escaped the language cops, like "Le Pit Stop" and "Poulet BBQ."
Often billed as the second-largest French-speaking city in the world, Montreal is delightfully, idiosyncratically "foreign." Yet under its skin, says Morley Safer, the Canadian-born CBS correspondent, it is a lot like New York, which is something no one would ever say about Toronto.
In summer, when the sun shines bright for a few precious weeks, the people of Montreal spill into parks and sidewalk cafes and onto boats in the broad St. Lawrence River, which lies at their doorstep. The jazz festival draws 1.5 million enthusiasts a year, and there are also festivals of bikes and jokes, hot-air balloons and chamber music. Dragon-boat races, fireworks competitions, a kite-flying derby, a Beer Mundial and the Carifiesta help pack the calendar from May to August. Sometimes you'd swear you were in Rio.
In winter, when as much as eight feet of snow often falls on the city, Montrealers move underground, into a well-lighted maze of passages that connect a half-dozen downtown malls, 30 movie theaters and 7 major hotels. People shrug at ice storms like one that knocked out power to 1.4 million households in January 1998. After a few days the good times roll on.
 
A Parade of Nationalities
The fact is, Montreal is one of the hemisphere's most cosmopolitan cities, a place that has room not only for Francophones and Anglophones but also for "Allophones" -- people whose first language is Arabic or Spanish or Russian or whatever. Brian Moore, the Ulster-born novelist who worked in Montreal for a decade as a reporter, always remembered something that caught his attention on his first trip in from the airport. It summed up the city for him: a shop calling itself the Notre-Dame-de-Grace Kosher Meat Market.
Drive or walk up Boulevard St.-Laurent, which climbs from the Old Port toward the distant Laurentians, and you will witness a grand march of nationalities: on the sidewalks, in the shops and above all in the restaurants of this food-mad city.
People call the boulevard "the Main," and in theory it separates the French east side of town from the English west side. But the barrier is porous at best, and the Main itself is polyglot. You will hear Chinese, Vietnamese and Malay spoken at the bottom, and then, higher up, especially between Roy and Duluth Streets, Thai, Slovak, Hungarian, Ukrainian, Portuguese.
A couple of blocks over, and you're on Rue St.-Urbain, the main stem of Duddy Kravitz's not entirely fictional world. It's no longer quite as Mordecai Richler described it in his 1959 novel "The Apprenticeship of Duddy Kravitz," with a cigar store, grocery store and fruit man on each corner, outside staircases everywhere and "an endless repetition of precious peeling balconies, and waste lots making the occasional gap here and there."
The Jews have moved up and on, and some of them, like the whisky-making Bronfmans, are now leading citizens of Montreal, Canada and the wider world. Other immigrants have taken their place and learned what it is like, as Mr. Cohen told Duddy, to "land in this country with three words of English and 50 cents in your pocket."
Not many Americans know it, and not many American schools teach it, but Montreal played a fascinating if minor role in the American Revolution. The rebellious colonists hoped to enlist Canadians in their struggle against Britain, and in November 1775, seven months after Lexington and Concord, Gen. Richard Montgomery captured Montreal without much of a struggle, forcing the British Governor of Quebec, Maj. Gen. Guy Carleton, to withdraw.
Presumably to vent their political passions, American troops defaced a bust of George III that stood in the Place d'Armes, where today stands a statue of Paul de Chomedey, Sieur de Maisonneuve, the founder of Montreal. In April 1776, a group of envoys sent by Congress, headed by Benjamin Franklin, took up temporary residence in Montreal. But even after he was reinforced by troops led by Benedict Arnold, Montgomery was unable to drive Carleton from Quebec City, and Franklin and company headed back south in 1777.
The house where the Americans lived and worked, known as Chateau Ramezay, has been preserved as a museum. It is one of the hundreds of handsome gray sandstone buildings that have made Vieux Montreal one of the most attractive 18th- and 19th-century neighborhoods anywhere on the continent, where you can easily trace the city's evolution from a trading post to a French town to a British city to today's modern, French-dominated metropolis.
Head first for the striking, brilliantly conceived new museum at Pointe-a-Calliere, where Montreal began. Built over extensive excavations, which you can visit, it mounts changing exhibitions on the city's history and boasts a bilingual multimedia show that is not only informative but also witty, in the style of Monty Python. Don't miss the lookout atop the museum's tower, where you can scan the city skyline and the site of the Expo '67 World's Fair.
A financial failure, the fair left behind one of Buckminster Fuller's geodesic domes, built as the United States exhibit, which now houses an environmental center; a French pavilion that has been turned into the Montreal Casino, and Habitat, Moshe Safdie's pioneering modular apartment block, a sensation at the time and highly popular with tenants ever since.
Stroll down Rue St.-Paul, a cobblestone street, to get the full flavor of Old Montreal, good and bad. Concentrate on the stout, honest architecture of the houses, churches and warehouses and try to ignore the cheesy souvenir shops that fill most of them. Among the highlights are the Marche Bonsecours, with a tin dome, and Place Jacques-Cartier, filled with tubs of geraniums in summer, and the Hotel de Ville, or City Hall, where Charles de Gaulle, ever the rabble-rouser, made a speech in 1967 that ended with the words, "Vive le Quebec libre!" ("Long Live Free Quebec!")
Just a few blocks away is the Place d'Armes, which for centuries was the city's focal point, near the heart of the old financial district. Around it stand the imposing neo-classical office of the Bank of Montreal; the Art Deco Aldred Building (1930), inspired by Rockefeller Center, then under construction, and the quite extraordinary Notre Dame Basilica, a Gothic Revival whoop-de-do in red, gold, white and a lot of sky-blue that can seat 3,800 worshipers.
 
Excellent Acoustics
When someone told me that the pop diva Celine Dion, a Quebec girl, had been married in a gala ceremony in the basilica, I could not resist the thought that it looked like a set for a Cecil B. De Mille movie, executed by A. W. N. Pugin, who decorated London's Houses of Parliament in a vividly polychromatic "Gothic" style. The church has excellent acoustics, if dubious esthetics, and my wife, Betsey, and I had the good fortune to hear a concert there this summer by the Montreal Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Charles Dutoit, its Swiss-born music director. In 22 years Maestro Dutoit has made the orchestra the most admired in Canada, while also serving as music director of major orchestras in Paris and Tokyo. The Montreal Symphony has played in Europe, Asia and Latin America during 16 foreign tours, almost one a year; and since 1982 it has appeared annually at Carnegie Hall. Its work is copiously represented on CD's.
The big counting houses began moving from Old Montreal in the 1970's to new buildings in the newer sections of the city or, in many cases, to Toronto. Even the Bank of Montreal now has a major headquarters there.
Bell Canada has stayed, ensconced in a tower near Dorchester Square, the heart of the new downtown. So has Molson, brewer and owner of the deeply beloved but recently floundering Montreal Canadiens, who play in the Molson Center (nickname: the Keg), having forsaken the sporting temple known as the Forum. There, Rocket Richard and Boom-Boom Geoffrion wrote hockey history. Over the years the Canadiens have won the Stanley Cup 24 times.
But one undeniable consequence of Quebec's repeated flirtation with independence has been an episodic flight of businesses from Montreal. When the political mood is calm, economic life flourishes; when referendums on separation loom, recession strikes. At the moment, with independence on the back burner after having been voted down decisively in 1980 and very narrowly in 1995 -- by only 52,000 votes, in fact -- Montreal is enjoying a mini-rebound.
Still, almost half a million "Anglos," as they are called here, have left town in the last 23 years, and the children of many Anglos who remain do not return after college. Investment dollars are hard to come by.
"Economically speaking, Montreal could be a huge, beautiful tree," said Derek H. Burney, the former Canadian Ambassador to the United States, who lives here. "But with the future in doubt, it's only a bonsai."
Some Montreal Anglos feel that they live under cultural siege, and it is certainly true that Montreal and Quebec stand well apart from the rest of Canada, and not just because of language. (Canadian French, by the way, is no more Parisian than American English is Oxonian. The word "depanneur," to take one example, means convenience store in Canada, repair man or repair shop in the old country.)
Quebecers smoke more and get divorced more than other Canadians. They are forbidden, unlike other Canadians, to turn right on red. But their isolation enriches their cultural life, in a way. In most of Canada television programming comes mostly from the United States, but in Quebec 70 percent is produced in Canada. French-Canadian theater flourishes, as does French-Canadian literature, partly because they meet such a great need.
The leading English theater in Montreal, the Centaur, is housed in the creatively adapted old stock exchange. In the coming season Gordon McCall, the artistic director, plans to mount several Irish and American works, including "The Crucible" by Arthur Miller, but also, in translation, a play by Michel Tremblay, the best known of French-Canadian playwrights. Mr. Tremblay is more often produced by the outstanding French-language Rideau Vert Theater.
The center of the performing arts in Montreal is the Place des Arts, a complex of five theaters and concert halls, begun at a time of growing French cultural awareness in the 1960's. It includes the Montreal Contemporary Arts Museum, which concentrates on Canadian and particularly Quebec artists, and the all-purpose, 2,982-seat Salle Wilfrid Pelletier.
This is the home base for Mr. Dutoit's musicians, the up-and-coming young Montreal Opera and Les Grands Ballets Canadiens, which was founded in 1958 by Ludmilla Chiriaeff, who more or less single-handedly created a lively dance scene in Montreal. It has been led since 1989 by Lawrence Rhodes, a highly regarded American dancer. Les Ballets Jazz de Montreal is another ornament of the local ballet stage.
The Montreal troupe best known abroad is the Cirque de Soleil, which has grown from modest origins -- a pooling of talents by street performers in 1984 -- into a global phenomenon, seen to date by 18 million people. It is a circus without animals, but not without genius. At the moment two of its seven companies are performing in Las Vegas, one at Disney World in Florida, one in Biloxi, Miss.; one is touring North America, one is touring Europe, and one is traveling in the Pacific. Next year is Montreal's chance.
But this city's well-developed taste for the innovative, the surreal, the avant-garde, lights up the Cirque's performances everywhere.
 
Shimmering Towers
To get a good picture of what Montreal has been up to in the last two decades, stand on the little platform on Rue Cathcart, with your back to I. M. Pei's Place Ville-Marie, which helped to establish the new, revitalized downtown when it opened in 1962. You will be looking up Avenue McGill College toward McGill, Canada's premier English-speaking university (its premier university of any kind, to venture into political incorrectness). It scrambles up the steep flank of the overgrown hill for which Montreal is named, Mount Royal, which was landscaped by the American Frederick Law Olmsted.
Most of Canada's best post-modern architects have been employed by the builders of the shimmering skyscrapers on either side of the avenue. Peter Rose, of whom more in a moment, helped design the rose-and-pale-blue Montreal Trust building at No. 1500. But nothing here matches the ninth-floor dining room of the Eaton store on Rue St.-Catherine, which crosses the avenue. Perfectly preserved, it was decorated in 1931 by the Frenchman Jacques Carlu in the Art Deco style of the trans-Atlantic liner "Ile-de-France." Eaton has just announced plans to liquidate; it is not yet clear what will happen to the spectacular dining room.
At the top of Avenue McGill College, just before the university gates, you will reach Rue Sherbrooke, Montreal's Fifth Avenue, which is lined with hotels, antiques shops and fashion outlets, many of which sell Canada's fine furs. Here, in the so-called Golden Square Mile, where once lived the Britons, most of them Scots, who controlled three-quarters of Canada's entire wealth at the turn of the last century, stand the McCord Museum, a historical collection with fine Indian artifacts, and the Museum of Fine Arts.
Mr. Safdie, the Israeli architect, designed the newer of the art museum's two buildings, which houses both its international collections and the superb special exhibitions in which it has specialized in recent years.
In the former you will find portraits by Memling and Rembrandt, a pair of riveting grisailles by Mantegna and a string of excellent 20th-century pictures by Picasso, Feininger and Leger, among many, many others.
The current temporary exhibition, which closes on Oct. 17, is "Cosmos: From Romanticism to the Avant-Garde," which traces artists' conceptions of, and reactions to, remoter corners of the world and outer space. Goya looks at balloons, Moran at Yellowstone, Church at icebergs, van Gogh at the sun and stars, Calder at the solar system, Kiefer at the heavens, all struggling for answers to questions that none of us understand, along with Malevich, Kupka, Delauney, Hartley and Balla.
It is a gem of insight.
 
Economic Plants
And the visual delights of this island city of 1.8 million, a port 994 miles from the Atlantic Ocean, run on and on. Beneath the Museum of Fine Arts (and hence a bit difficult to find) is an excellent Decorative Arts Museum. Sharply focused on the 20th century, it was designed by the Canadian-born Frank O. Gehry in a style as low-key as his Bilbao museum is flamboyant.
Mr. Rose was the architect of the Canadian Center for Architecture a few blocks away. Financed by Phyllis Lambert, a Bronfman heiress, it may well be the best of its kind anywhere. Its exhibitions (at the moment, Carlo Scarpa) and the exhibitions elsewhere to which it lends are enriched by a collection of more than a quarter-million books, prints, models and photos.
Fifteen minutes to the northeast, finally, is Montreal's fabulous Botanic Garden, exceeded in size only by Kew in London. Extensive greenhouses, including a wonderful array of "economic plants" -- did you know that strychnine grew in Burma? -- are followed by annuals, perennials and acres of trees, including Canada's birches, spruces and, of course, maples.
When beauty pales, you can visit the notably ugly Olympic Stadium nearby, which has the additional virtue of a retractable roof that no longer retracts. No wonder the Expos, who play there, are one of the sorriest teams in baseball, one that sometimes seems to exist mainly to sell the stars it develops to others. No wonder fewer than 10,000 show up for most home games. No wonder the team is seriously considering a move to Washington.
But hey, your greenback is worth $1.50 in Montreal. Who cares whether the stadium works or not?
 
Parlez Canadien?
 
Montreal is about 335 miles from Manhattan. Here is a sampling of attractions, and travel information. Prices are in United States dollars, figured at $1 to $1.50 Canadian.
 
Where to Stay
 
AUBERGE DU VIEUX PORT, 97 Rue de la Commune Est, (514) 876-0081. This 27-room package of charm, tucked into a waterfront building in Old Montreal, is marred only by a somewhat clamorous cafe on the ground floor. Guest rooms have exposed stone or brick walls, polished floors and brass headboards; an appealing little restaurant, Les Remparts, occupies the basement. Double rooms: $90 to $167.
 
BONAVENTURE HILTON, 1 Place Bonaventure, (514) 878-2332. The hotel sits atop a fortresslike exhibition complex in the city center, but once you take the express elevator to the three top floors, that seems irrelevant. There, a lobby decorated with bonsai and Japanese screens awaits you, plus an outdoor pool that you can enter from indoors in cold weather, and a lush two-acre garden, complete with waterfall. The rooms are fresh and modern. Double rooms: $148.
 
LOEWS HOTEL VOGUE, 1425 Rue de la Montagne, (514) 285-5555. A stylish, low-key hotel, rather European in style, lurks behind a pink facade across from Ogilvy, the carriage-trade department store, and down the street from the Museum of Fine Arts. The bedrooms boast silk fabrics, the bathrooms boast whirlpool tubs, and the snug little lobby bar welcomes one and all. Double room: $200 to $300.
 
RITZ-CARLTON, 1228 Rue Sherbrooke Ouest, (514) 842-4212. Montreal's grandest hotel, smack in the middle of the Square Mile, is an Edwardian dowager, built in 1912 and updated with style. Brass elevator doors in the lobby, country antiques in some rooms and proper keys, not plastic key cards, are all welcome reminders of the past; electronic safes bespeak the modern era. Elizabeth Taylor was once married there, but a lot of places can make that claim. Double room: $164 to $234.
 
Where to Eat
 
L'EXPRESS, 3927 Rue St.-Denis, (514) 845-5333. A mere sliver of a room where the buzz never stops. With marble tables, oxblood-red walls and checkerboard tiles on the floor, it's a convincing evocation of 1930's Paris. So is the food: pot-au-feu, calves' liver with tarragon, onglet with shallot butter and frites, to say nothing of a grandmother-worthy floating island under a dome of brittle caramel. If I lived in Montreal, I'd head to L'Express for lunch several times a week.
 
JONGLEUX CAFE, 3434 Rue St.-Denis, (514) 841-8080. This split-level restaurant (it's not really a cafe) is the latest venture of Nicolas Jongleux, a talented young Frenchman. The service is slow and the wine list needs work, but dishes like pork cheeks, braised with vegetables in tomato bouillon and topped with cheesy ravioli, combine finesse and peasant robustness.
 
MEDITERRANEO, 3500 Boulevard St.-Laurent, (514) 844-0027. California in Quebec, a brassy, trendy spot with decor faintly reminiscent of the Normandie and glass walls that slide back in summer. The glistening veal chop, big as a bass fiddle, resting on a hill of spinach, epitomizes the modern culinary approach, and the Italian and American wines match it perfectly.
 
LE PASSE-PARTOUT, 3857 Boulevard Decarie, (514) 487-7750. Trained by Charles Barrier, a legendary chef in the Loire Valley, New York-born James MacGuire is Montreal's premier baker. His incredibly moist sourdough puts San Francisco to shame. The modest restaurant next door, more Montparnasse than Montreal, serves "simple things," he says, but they are all perfect: gutsy salmon that he smokes himself, rilletes and terrines that he makes himself, maybe a masterly estouffade of lamb. Try the lovely little French country wines, like the apple-scented Cheverny, which cost three times nothing.
 
SCHWARTZ'S, 3895 Boulevard St.-Laurent, (514) 842-4813. Officially the Delicatessen Hebraique de Montreal, Schwartz's is the size of a luncheonette, and just as chic. The raison d'etre here is smoked meat, a dry-cured Montreal beef similar to pastrami. Piled high on mustard-smeared rye, it makes a delectable sandwich. Warning: the cholesterol-averse will wince.
 
TOQUE, 3842 Rue St.-Denis, (514) 499-2084. Unlike the critics, who raved, the New York public failed to embrace Normand LaPrise's Manhattan venture, Cena, which closed this summer. In Montreal he is the king of the mountain. In dining rooms decked out in primary colors, he serves inventive dishes based on adroit combinations of carefully chosen local products. The spice-glazed eel with green beans, the cold yellow tomato soup with rice vinegar and basil oil, and the caramelized fig tart all made me sigh with delight. The service is every bit as good as the food: young, savvy and jolly.
 
Attractions
 
CANADIAN CENTER FOR ARCHITECTURE, 1920 Rue Baile, (514) 939-7026. "Carlo Scarpa, Architect: Intervening With History," through Oct. 31. "32 Italian Photographers: A Tribute to Phyllis Lambert," through Sept. 26. Hours through September: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Thursdays to 9 P.M. Admission: $4; $2.75, the elderly; $2, students 12 and older. On weekends fee includes a one-hour guided tours in French at 2 P.M. and in English at 3:30 P.M.
 
DECORATIVE ARTS MUSEUM, 2200 Rue Crescent, (514) 284-1252. "Carlo Scarpa in Murano: Art Glass by an Architect (1926-1947)," through Oct. 3. "Italian Design From the Museum's Collection," through Oct. 3. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Wednesdays to 9 P.M. Free.
 
McCORD MUSEUM, 690 Rue Sherbrooke Ouest, (514) 398-7100. "Across Borders: Beadworks in Iroquois Life," through Jan. 9. HEADLINE: An Incandescent Coney Island of the Mind

BYLINE: By BLAINE HARDEN 

 BODY:
In the all-too-brief best of times at Coney Island, elephants in jeweled blankets sat on their tails and waved their plump forelegs in the warm Atlantic breeze.
Perched atop a water slide called Shoot the Chutes, the big-bottomed beasts came thundering down, one by one, to smack the water as only falling elephants can, drenching and delighting paying customers at an amusement park called Dreamland. 
 When Dreamland burned to the ground in 1911, a smaller, sadder water spectacle was built on the same stretch of beach. To control costs, pigs replaced pachyderms. Splashes were smaller and so were the crowds. As Coney Island slid still further into dereliction, pigs followed elephants into unemployment and the water slide disappeared. Carnival operators tried to delight New Yorkers with cockroach races.
The devolution of the amusement park in the American imagination can be quantified. In 1910, when there were 92 million people in the United States, there were 1,500 amusement parks. Today there are an estimated 273 million Americans and just 600 amusement parks, according to the National Amusement Park Historical Association.
Roller coasters, the signature contraption of the amusement-park era, also took a death-rattle dive. There were 1,520 in 1920, but just 145 by 1979. Nostalgic thrill-seeking has since pushed the number of roller coasters up to 550.
Numbers, though, cannot explain what has been lost at Coney Island, the amusement park that invented amusement parks, not to mention the hot dog. For a splendid decade at the turn of the century Coney Island transcended the sleazy carny craft of separating chumps from their money. It drew daily crowds of 90,000 at a time when 20,000 at a baseball game was a memorable event. Adorned by minarets and spires and bedizened by more than million lights, Coney Island embodied what has been called the "architecture of exhilaration." It connected with New York, America and the world in a way that no other amusement park has done before or since, offering visitors not just a good time, but a jolt of incandescent wonder.
To hear about what has been lost, one can drive to an apartment on the Upper West Side, pick up a novelist named Kevin Baker and head out to Coney Island. There, amid the cackling of sea gulls, the rumble of subway trains and the sick-sweet smell of deep-fat-fried clams, Mr. Baker, author of "Dreamland" (HarperCollins, 1999), will rhapsodize about a time when a visit to Coney Island was essential to understanding the American experience. "What got me writing was a show they had in Dreamland called 'Fighting Flames,' " he said.
"A fake tenement was set on fire and you would see the fake Fire Department run out and douse it. Fake tenants would dive from windows. New Yorkers who lived in constant fear of this happening in their own fire-trap tenements on the Lower East Side would actually pay money to come out here and see this. It really struck me that a lot of Coney Island had become the pageant of their lives, a pageant in which they would see their best hopes and worst fears for the future played out."
The decayed look of Coney Island gives Mr. Baker's stories an almost painful poignancy. It's a fallen city by the shore where weeds are swallowing a rotting roller coaster called the Thunderbolt, where a weather-bleached sign on a sideshow trailer advertises the "orld's smallest horse," where low-income housing projects tower over the garish remnants of a third-rate carnival.
In his novel, which draws heavily on his 10 years as chief historical researcher for Harold Evans's 1998 book "The American Century," Mr. Baker uses Coney Island as a device to illuminate what it was like to be alive in turn-of-the-century New York. What is most striking about the amusement-park world that Mr. Baker recreates is the cruelty that Coney Island routinely inflicted on its patrons.
A trick elevator sends people crashing to the ground. A greased floor induces fun-seekers of all ages to fall on their faces. Electrified benches shock patrons seeking rest, encouraging them to shake a leg and spend more money.
"There was a great deal of humiliation involved," said Mr. Baker, 41, whose novel has been optioned to Leonardo DiCaprio's film production company and who has a two-book contract with HarperCollins to write a prequel and sequel to "Dreamland." "The most amazing humiliation was after a ride called the Steeplechase. When you got off the horse, you would have to go across this area where jet streams of air would blow up women's skirts. A totally mad-looking dwarf would attack you with a cattle prod for the benefit of your fellow New Yorkers who were watching from the laughing gallery of the Blowhole Theater."
Mr. Baker contends that the periodic pain of having fun at Coney Island was an echo of the deeper and more persistent misery of living in New York when it was struggling to digest the largest influx of immigrants in its history. It was a time when fathers deserted families, when mothers worked 16-hour days, when struggling immigrants made ends meet by taking in roomerkehs, or boarders, three of whom would often rent eight-hour shifts in a single bed. And out on the streets there was a poisonous mix of gangsters, corrupt police officers and the politicians who used them.
The plot of "Dreamland" grows out of a made-up feud between two real New York gangsters, circa 1910. The bad guy is Gyp the Blood, whose real name was Harry Horrowitz and who was really a sadistic bouncer at cheap dance halls on the Lower East Side. Gyp's specialty was breaking a man's back by bending him backward over his knee.
Gyp is doing exactly that at the start of the novel when he gets whacked over the head by a shovel. The gangster with the shovel is Mr. Baker's hero, Kid Twist, whose real name was Max Zweibach and who really did kill six men. In "Dreamland," though, Kid has a sense of justice and a powerful love for a seamstress who turns out to be Gyp's sister.
After creasing Gyp's head with the shovel, Kid hides out in Coney Island. He takes a room in a hotel turned bordello that is shaped like an elephant. Like nearly everything in the novel, the elephant brothel was a real establishment.
Mr. Baker's exuberantly descriptive novel uses the gangster's exile as a device to walk readers through three spectacular amusement parks, Dreamland, Luna Park and Steeplechase, which opened in Coney Island from 1897 to 1904. Before movies and newsreels, they made Coney Island the place to go not only for rides, games and cheesy trips to the moon (where green dwarves served cheese), but also for a glimpse of how the real world worked. They re-enacted pivotal historical events like the Johnstown Flood and the Boer War. The line between reality and re-enactment was sometimes difficult to discern.
"When the Boer War was over in 1902, combatants came to Coney Island to star in a show about the war," said Mr. Baker. "The show went bust and the players went down to South American to fight as mercenaries. They went from real war, to fake war and back to real war."
Reality asserted itself with a vengeance when Dreamland burned down in 1911. The other two parks soon lost their shimmer. Huge crowds, often a million people a day, still came out to Coney Island until the late 1950's. They came to swim and play and cool off, but not to sate their imagination. Movies and television had long since stolen away that role.
Luna Park burned in 1944, and Steeplechase hung on until it was closed in 1964.
Before he was driven back to Manhattan and returned to Manhattan, Mr. Baker lamented the passing of what he called "hands-on entertainment."
"You listen to a radio, you watch a screen," he grumbled. "You don't have a dwarf poke you with a cattle prod."

HEADLINE: Trade-Deficit Dangers

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Alan S. Blinder (Op-Ed, Aug. 24) may have overlooked the real menace of the underlying trade deficit to our economic health. A combination of things, like reinvigoration of the world's economies and signs of trouble here (suggested by rising interest rates), could prompt at least some deficit-balancing capital to repatriate. Signs that others may lose confidence in the United States as the best store of wealth could prompt a "run on the bank" mentality, which could prompt further dollar weakness and capital withdrawal. 
 A weakening dollar could allow domestic producers to discover the pricing power that has been missing the last several years and be tempted to meet strong consumption at higher prices by bidding up for labor and other resources.
The trade deficit is not a problem as long as global investors think this is the best place to invest. It becomes a huge problem if investor confidence shifts.
 
DOUGLAS J. ROBBINS
Henniker, N.H., Aug. 24, 1999
 
The writer is an investment banker.

HEADLINE: U.N. Official Warns of Problems Undercutting Aid to Kosovo

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Aug. 27

 BODY:
Secretary General Kofi Annan's leading envoy in the Balkans said today that unless significant political and economic reforms are made in the region, much of the reconstruction aid promised to Kosovo by world leaders will be wasted.
In an interview here, the envoy, Carl Bildt, said that the inefficient use or diversion of aid is a "major impediment all over the entire region," not only in Bosnia, where there is rising concern about the misuse or waste of assistance.
The underlying problem, Mr. Bildt said, is the persistence of old-style socialist or Communist political and economic systems with all their built-in faults. Serbia, he said, has been the biggest drag on regional growth. But what Asians call crony capitalism is also found in Croatia and Bosnia, he added.
"There is a need for reconstruction, needless to say, but there is a far greater need for reform," said Mr. Bildt, a former Prime Minister of Sweden. "If we do reconstruction without reform, then we end up with an aid-dependent place. Bosnia is a good example of that."
Mr. Bildt said that Europe and the United States need to turn attention to long-term political as well as economic change, especially in Serbia. Success in Kosovo, he said, "is very much dependent on what's going to happen to Serbia."
"It's such a big chunk of land in the middle of the Balkans that if it does not reform itself it will be very difficult to do anything substantial with the rest," he said. "Serbia is the core nation of the region."
The United States has ruled out all but emergency assistance to Serbia as long as President Slobodan Milosevic, who has been indicted by the United Nations' war-crimes tribunal in The Hague, remains in power. Mr. Bildt, who said he believes that Mr. Milosevic will eventually stand trial, does not advocate waiting for that moment to begin dealing with the fundamental problems of Serbia, formerly an important regional trade hub.
"I don't think Milosevic will hang around for much longer," Mr. Bildt said. "The country is going so rapidly downhill. You have the economy contracting this year by either 30 or 40 percent. That's a collapse with major social consequences. That has to do to a very large extent with the bombing, but not only."
Yugoslavia, which was in many ways a pioneering socialist economy a few decades ago, has now fallen behind the rest of Eastern and Central Europe, he said, adding that it could take 15 or 20 years for Serbia and its neighbors just to go back to the economic levels of 1989, the year the Berlin wall came down.
"This is the least reformed economy in Europe next to Belarus," Mr. Bildt said. "The problem of Serbia is that it can't be discussed just in terms of the personality of Mr. Milosevic. That's only the tip of the iceberg when it comes to the problems of Serbia."
Mr. Bildt said that he welcomes the arrival at the United Nations of Richard C. Holbrooke, the new chief representative of the United States. The United Nations and the United States will be facing tough decisions on the Balkans in the months and years to come.
"He will make the U.S. a far more active player in the U.N.," Mr. Bildt said. "And he brings to the job not only a knowledge of the issues and a lot of personal contacts but a certain amount of political clout. That is good. He is highly respected."
Mr. Holbrooke, the architect of the accord that ended the war in Bosnia, will feel some pressures from Washington to speed up developments in Kosovo, some diplomats here say. They fear that the United Nations will be blamed if the situation goes awry.
"There is always a tendency to underestimate the challenges ahead," Mr. Bildt said, and when things go wrong, a search for culprits in international organizations follows.
Mr. Bildt, who was involved in ending the war in Bosnia, said he had learned from that experience that withdrawing troops or lowering the level of an international military presence too soon can be a mistake.
"I think it is way too early to discuss troops leaving Kosovo," he said. "We are there for the long haul. That was one of the mistakes that were made in Bosnia. There was this belief that you could go in very quickly and do it primarily as a military operation and be out after one year. That was a mistake."
In Kosovo, Mr. Bildt said, Americans, Europeans and Russians may have to stay for quite a while.
