HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Mortgage? Mexicans Sign Up for Monthly Raffle

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Aug. 21

 BODY:
When Javier Zavala and his wife, Jenny, began thinking about buying a house, they did not bother going to a bank to talk about getting a mortgage.
"We knew it would have been hopeless," said Mr. Zavala, 32, a marketing manager for his family's agro-chemical business here. 
 The banks in Mexico have been struggling with huge portfolios of failed loans since a sharp devaluation touched off soaring inflation nearly five years ago. With a few exceptions, they are lending only to the biggest corporations.
The richest Mexicans, who least need loans and often prefer to pay cash, can sometimes get mortgages. Some of the poorest Mexicans, in a form of political patronage, get subsidized loans through government agencies. But most Mexicans, like the Zavalas, are out of luck.
In this world of incredibly tight money, though, Mexican entrepreneurs have devised cooperative ventures that the Zavalas and tens of thousands of others are using in hopes of getting houses.
The entrepreneurs form groups of 500 home buyers, all of whom agree to make monthly payments for nearly 17 years toward homes valued at as much as roughly $200,000 each. A raffle is held each month and the pool of money goes to one lucky member to buy a house. That person, like the others, keeps paying for the rest of the nearly 17 years, and eventually everyone is supposed to end up with a house.
The entrepreneurs adjust monthly payments for inflation, which is running at an annual rate of 16 percent. Members pay no interest but are charged administrative fees of about 10 percent, compounded monthly. So the cost of financing through one of these groups works out to nearly 30 percent, or a little more than banks say they would charge if they were lending for mortgages.
The cooperative groups are not exactly a bargain. "But," Mrs. Zavala said, "the point is, the banks are not approving loans."
(In the United States, where inflation has been running at 2 percent, 30-year fixed-rate mortgages now cost a little more than 8 percent.)
One thing that the entrepreneurs do not point out is that members do not earn interest on money they are putting toward houses.
Financial experts say the cooperatives, known here as self-financing groups, are potentially dangerous for investors because they are not regulated by the banking authorities and monthly payments are not insured, as are deposits in Mexican banks.
"They are under God's protection," said Roberto del Cueto, a professor at Mexico's Autonomous Institute of Technology who specializes in banking law.
Yet, he and others following these groups say they know of none that have encountered financial trouble or turned out to be run by swindlers. Federico Castro Romo, the administrative director of Autofin, which is said to be the oldest and largest of the self-financing organizations, said the money paid by members was held in trust.
Adriana Campos, an official at Mexico's federal agency for consumer affairs, said several thousand participants in self-financing groups had complained of delays in getting the money for their houses after raffles. In a handful of disputes, she said, group administrators have paid fines of up to $10,000 and refunded the money of would-be homeowners. Ms. Campos said she knew of no cases in which group members had lost their money.
Ms. Campos estimated that more than 70,000 Mexicans were participating in these groups.
Similar cooperatives have been used in Korea, Taiwan and elsewhere, particularly for small businesses.
When the banks in Mexico do lend for a home, they demand pristine credit histories and down payments of up to 50 percent. "We're being very selective," said Ernesto Gomez-Gallardo, an executive vice president at Grupo Financiero Banamex-Accival, Mexico's largest bank.
When the peso was devalued, Mexico's banks were a disaster waiting to happen. After a decade under state ownership, the banks had been reprivatized in the early 1990's. Many of the new owners paid several times what analysts said were fair prices for the banks. Eager to earn their money back, they went on lending sprees. Some handed out credit cards in shopping malls, no questions asked. They accepted small down payments on mortgages, let people borrow more than their incomes would justify and relied on customers to disclose their total debt.
In keeping with Mexican practice, mortgages were issued with variable rates. Not long after inflation soared beyond 70 percent a year following the devaluation, home buyers found themselves owing interest equal to the amount of their loans. And many just walked away.
The banks tried to repossess the homes. But they were reminded that Mexican law greatly favors homeowners.
"In Texas, it takes an average of 90 days to repossess a house," said Professor del Cueto. "In Mexico, it may take six years."
The inability to repossess quickly is another reason the banks are reluctant to resume large-scale mortgage lending.
Mr. Zavala and his wife, the parents of a 2-month-old son, are doing business with Autofin. It started more than 20 years ago, financing cars, and moved into raising money for homes four years ago, shortly after Mexican banks stopped lending.
Mr. Zavala said he was a bit uneasy at first. "But once I found out they had been in the business such a long time I felt better," he said. "And it is working. We've been in the group about two years. We see people getting houses and more people keep coming into new groups. So I feel I will get my money out."
The Zavalas contracted for a house worth 450,000 pesos in 1997. Because of inflation it will now cost about 680,000 pesos, or about $73,500, to buy the same house. Their payments have been rising steadily to keep pace with inflation.
The lottery each month is tough on the nerves. "They run through all 500 numbers so you can see how you ranked," Mrs. Zavala said. "It's depressing if your number is way down there. But if you're close to the top, it's encouraging."

HEADLINE: Journal;
And the Winner Is . . . George W. Bush

BYLINE: By FRANK RICH

 BODY:
A bump in the road, a setback, a boon to his primary opponents? Puh-LEEZE! The people who dourly predicted dark consequences from George W. Bush's "mishandling" of Snortgate were the same geniuses who predicted Bill Clinton's imminent demise 20 months ago. After the avalanche of insinuations that the Texas Governor might have used cocaine and is now engaged in a cover-up, Mr. Bush is in fact, in the words of his campaign adviser Ralph Reed, "better off" than he was before the firestorm started. Far from bungling his first encounter with adversity, the front-runner handled it like a master.
Sure, his convoluted answers to the cocaine question were Clintonesque -- you need a Palm Pilot to chart the chronology of his non-drug use -- but the political dividends have proved Clintonesque in a positive sense. Mr. Bush has enjoyed an "uptick" in the polls, as Mr. Reed described it. He continues to best Democratic adversaries by double digits and swamps his closest Republican rival, Elizabeth Dole, by a factor of four. 
 This is true even though most voters with an opinion on the subject believe that he is guilty as rumored of the alleged felony -- just as most voters judged President Clinton guilty of non-felonious adultery from the outset of Monicagate. Yet no one cares. Only 11 percent in a CNN/Time poll feel cocaine use disqualifies Mr. Bush from the Presidency. More revealingly, the number of people who think a candidate should not even respond to questions about cocaine has gone up since the marathon cross-examining of Mr. Bush began.
Does this mean that Americans have once again proved themselves to be morally bankrupt, as was widely proclaimed last year? Has the rise in the Dow Jones average since then made them overlook hard drugs as well as reckless sex? If the Dow hits 13,000, could a politician suspected of grand theft auto run for President without fear of public condemnation? At 20,000, a serial killer?
No, but what this fracas did prove is that the best place a candidate can be in 2000 is in opposition to the fulminating moralists in public life, whether those of the press or of Mr. Bush's own party. Bill Clinton's bipartisan legacy is this: Given the choice between scolds and scamps, the country opts for scamps. The more the media pile on a politician over a private sin -- let alone a sin for which there is no evidence or accusations, despite major investigative efforts by both The Washington Post and The Wall Street Journal -- the more the public will rally around the targeted candidate. Just prior to the last push to bust Mr. Bush for drugs, there was a mini-storm in which our Puritan tribunes reprimanded him for using a four-letter word repeatedly in an interview in Talk magazine; that may have helped his poll numbers too. Should someone now come forward and actually accuse him of coke use, he may enjoy a poll bounce analogous to the one enjoyed by Mr. Clinton after Kathleen Willey appeared on "60 Minutes."
Mr. Bush's tormentors have tried to dress up the propriety of the cocaine question ex post facto by linking it to his hypocrisy on public policy. As Governor, he has signed on to Draconian laws in Texas that promote jail for first-time drug offenders caught in possession of minuscule amounts (though jail rarely befalls those of Mr. Bush's station, who can afford the right lawyers). But the many troubling questions raised by this hard line -- and the failed national war on drugs it epitomizes -- could have been asked of him before the cocaine rumors flared, whether he's a hypocrite or not. Now they'll likely be forgotten again, unless or until the questions about his own cocaine use get a second wind.
Such is our political culture, in which scandal usurps all else, that Mr. Bush has been able thus far to position himself as a don't-worry-be-happy candidate, a genial Chauncey Gardiner who seems to believe whatever a beholder hopes he believes. He has been able to skate by most policy questions, including those drowned out by Snortgate. Most of the media, for instance, ignored his response to a query by David Bloom of NBC News about the Kansas school board's decision to delete evolution from its recommended curriculum. Mr. Bush fudged it: "It's up to local districts to make decisions on how to achieve standards of excellence, as far as I'm concerned."
If this is how educational excellence is going to be promoted by a chief executive -- and the hapless Al Gore, seemingly following Mr. Bush's lead, is now also waffling on this question -- the policy implications go well beyond Kansas. How would a President respond to similar political pressures by creationists that could threaten Federal funding of scientific research (and academic institutions) exploring the frontiers of biology and medicine? Will taxpayers have to foot the bill in future welfare programs for graduates of evolution-free high schools sentenced to the bottom rungs of the new economy?
Some voters may be less concerned with what drugs, if any, passed through Mr. Bush's brain than with what other traffic, if any, did. Though otherwise cooperating with a seven-part Washington Post profile this summer, this would-be education President would not permit either Andover or Yale to release his grades. Asked by a South Carolina elementary-school kid at a campaign photo op this week to name his favorite book as a child, Mr. Bush responded, "I can't remember any specific books." Amidst all the crackhead cracks on late-night talk shows was David Letterman's chilling aside, "I have the feeling that this guy could turn out to be a colossal boob."
The good news for Mr. Bush is that he can deflect his critics for months to come. Not only can he ignore the scandal obsession of the Beltway media and capitalize on the national backlash against it, but he can also count on the abrupt flip-flop of G.O.P. moralists in the aftermath of their post-impeachment election setbacks. As Senator Robert Bennett, a Utah Republican, memorably put it -- in a formulation he has since regretted and then blamed on the movie version of "Primary Colors" -- Mr. Bush will be the nominee unless "he was hit by a bus or some woman comes forward, let's say some black woman comes forward, with an illegitimate child that he fathered within the last 18 months. . . ."
Actually, Mr. Bush may be the nominee even if this scenario does come to pass. For all the talk about the Governor's alleged hypocrisy, it is nothing compared with that of some of his supporters. Tom DeLay, the impeachment ayatollah who saw himself in a war of "relativism vs. absolute values," is now a born-again relativist, suggesting last week that what Mr. Bush has "done as a part-owner of the Texas Rangers" matters more than any youthful felony. Peggy Noonan, who last year inveighed against a President for prizing winning over telling the truth, has now called upon Mr. Bush to stonewall and expressed latent nostalgia for "the old tolerance" of "normal failings." According to the new relativism she posited in The Wall Street Journal, a sexual fling may be O.K. too, as long as it can be deemed a romantic "love affair" and doesn't involve a "sick manipulator being serviced in the hallway."
William Bennett, at least, deserves credit for consistency: he is the only major Republican to rue (and acknowledge) the news that his party's foremost champion of moral renewal, Newt Gingrich, carried on extramaritally with a Congressional aide 23 years his junior. Mr. Bennett has also called upon Mr. Bush to answer the cocaine question, though with a loophole: Cocaine use is "a serious matter," but "how serious depends on facts and circumstances."
After two decades of conservative campaigning against the 60's and "secular humanism" and boomer self-indulgence, what has happened to change the equation? The virtuecrats have a fresh-faced boomer of their own who might lead their party back into the White House. "I think we run the risk here of looking like when it's a liberal Democrat we're willing to be serious about these things, but when it's one of our own we're going to use a different standard," said Gary Bauer this week.
But Mr. Bauer, like Orrin Hatch, another G.O.P. Presidential wannabe still implicitly criticizing Mr. Bush's evasiveness on drug use, is a loser. For Republicans in 2000, much like Democrats in '92, when Bill Clinton parsed the Gennifer Flowers questions, winning is everything. And Mr. Bush -- having proved so early that only the despised press will call him on youthful indiscretions, real or imagined -- emerges from his first crisis in a position that is nothing if not win-win.

HEADLINE: U.S. Warns Indonesia Over Political Violence

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27

 BODY:
President Clinton has warned the President of Indonesia that relations with the United States will be seriously damaged if there is mass violence during next week's referendum on self-rule in East Timor, senior Administration officials said today. The United States effectively has veto power over international loans to Indonesia.
Officials said Mr. Clinton's letter to President B. J. Habibie was intended to put him on notice that he will be held responsible if the Indonesian military fails to crack down on the anti-independence militias that have been responsible for several recent killings in East Timor. 
 The former Portuguese colony, which was invaded and annexed by Indonesia in 1976, is scheduled to vote Monday on whether to become an independent nation or an autonomous region within Indonesia. Most experts on the territory are convinced that after two decades of repressive Indonesian rule, voters will seek independence.
Administration officials declined to reveal the exact wording of the President's warning, which was sent in a letter this week, but one senior official said the threat of curtailing international loans and other aid through the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank was not stated directly.
"But it's implicit," he said.
Another senior official said: "It's a very tough letter."
The Indonesian Government has been promised nearly $50 billion in loans from the I.M.F. to deal with the aftermath of the Asian economic crisis, which has crippled the economy of the vast archipelago nation.
A three-member Congressional delegation that just returned from East Timor said that mass violence was a strong possibility next week, especially given the close ties between the well-armed anti-independence militias and the Indonesian military and police.
"My worst fears are coming true," said Senator Tom Harkin, an Iowa Democrat, who led the delegation last week and who supports the immediate use of peacekeeping troops there, possibly including Americans. "I predicted this. The civilian forces, the Indonesian police, are not going to stop these thugs. They're openly associating with them."
Mr. Harkin said that if there is widespread violence next week, he would push the Administration to punish Indonesia under a 1977 law requiring the United States to vote against World Bank loans for countries that systematically violate human rights.
The State Department has largely brushed aside questions about the possibility of an armed peacekeeping force in East Timor, saying instead that it supports the use by the United Nations of unarmed civilian monitors and military observers. It has insisted that the Indonesian Government take responsibility for keeping the peace in East Timor.
"It's important to underline the fact that the Indonesian Government itself has placed its credibility on the line here," said James Foley, a department spokesman. "The responsibility for maintaining law and order is East Timor is very much the responsibility of the Indonesian authorities."
Representative Jim McGovern, a Massachusetts Democrat, who joined the delegation, said it was clear that the Indonesian military and police were working closely with the militias, and that an armed international peacekeeping force was vital. "I think we should have had it in there already," he said.
But the third member of the delegation, Senator Jack Reed, a Democrat from Rhode Island, said: "I think you've first got to make the strong, strong case that we expect the Indonesians to live up to their agreements and to provide a safe and secure environment for the elections. If they don't, then the consequences should be severe."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Share Prices Fall on Concern Over Greenspan Remarks

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stock prices fell yesterday as some investors took remarks by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, as a warning that shares may be overvalued.
Mr. Greenspan is "holding to the notion that one never knows a bubble until it bursts -- that's where the risk is" for stocks, said William Meehan, senior market analyst for Cantor Fitzgerald & Company. "Given the signs we've seen in the economy, there's a pretty good chance the Fed could raise rates again" later this year, he added. 
 In the bond market, prices had their biggest decline in three weeks as $7 billion in corporate debt sales sapped demand for Treasuries. The price of the benchmark 30-year issue fell 1 3/32, to 10 23/32, while its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 5.97 percent from 5.90 percent on Thursday.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 108.28 points, or 1 percent, to 11,090.17. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index declined 13.74 points, or 1 percent, to 1,348.27. The Nasdaq composite index fell 15.72 points, or six-tenths of a percent, to 2,758.90. On the New York Stock Exchange, 1,778 stocks fell and 1,140 rose.
Next week, Government reports on employment and hourly earnings will give investors fresh evidence on whether the economy is continuing to boom. The Fed raised interest rates a quarter of a percentage point on Tuesday to try to control inflation by slowing the economy.
While some investment professionals saw Mr. Greenspan's comments as ominous for stocks, others called the remarks a nonevent that depressed shares in an otherwise humdrum news day and said the market would soon resume its gains.
For the week, the Nasdaq advanced 4.2 percent, the best performance since the week ended July 2. The S.& P. 500 rose nine-tenths of 1 percent, and the Dow average was little changed.
American Home Products fell 3 7/8, to 42 1/8, and was the biggest decliner in the S.& P. 500 after a judge certified a class-action lawsuit over the diet drugs Pondimin and Redux, the so-called phen-fen combination. About six million people took the drugs, and the lawsuit seeks to have some of them medically monitored at American Home's expense. American Home Products has denied any wrongdoing in marketing the two-pill mixture and disputes contentions that the drugs caused serious heart-valve damage or lung disease.
Intel rose 1 15/16, to 83. Mark Edelstone, an analyst at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, raised his estimates for the semiconductor maker's 1999 and 2000 profits and said the stock could reach $95 within 12 months. Mr. Edelstone had previously forecast an $80 share price.
Ameritrade fell 1 7/16, to 21 5/16, and E*Trade Group was off 1 13/16, to 25 15/16, after the Internet brokers were reduced to "outperform" from "buy" at Lehman Brothers. As competition grows, Internet brokers are having to spend more to add accounts.
Hewlett-Packard rose 2, to 104 5/8, leading the Dow's advancers, after Steven Milunovich, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, said the company's new chief executive, Carleton S. Fiorina, was "hitting the ground running" and had set a goal of 13 to 20 percent revenue and earnings growth over the next three years, which would "at least" match Merrill's expectations.
Intuit jumped 8 3/16, to 9 11/16, after the company, a maker of personal-finance software, said its fourth-quarter earnings had beat expectations as its new small-business accounting software increased revenue. The company reported a pro-forma loss of 26 cents a share for the quarter ended July 31, narrower than the 33-cent loss forecast by Wall Street.
Northwest Airlines fell 2 7/16, to 29 1/2, after its flight attendants rejected a tentative labor contract, moving the airline closer to a strike.

HEADLINE: Bush Fund-Raising Machine Plows Ahead

BYLINE: By FRANK BRUNI

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Aug. 27

 BODY:
Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, the early front-runner for the Republican Presidential nomination, today wrapped up a three-state, three-day campaign swing through the Southeast that yielded what aides estimated was another $1.1 million in campaign contributions.
It was proof that the fund-raising juggernaut of the Bush campaign rolled on, undiminished by any sense among his supporters that Mr. Bush was so firmly in the lead, in terms of both national surveys and his first-place finish in the recent Iowa straw poll, that they could start breathing easy and closing their checkbooks. 
 Instead, they were looking ahead to the general election in November 2000, and they were going for broke.
"We need coattails in North Carolina, so we need him to have a landslide in North Carolina," said Randy D. Doub, a lawyer who was one of many hosts of a $1,000-a-head fund-raiser at the Sheraton Imperial Hotel in Durham, N.C., on Thursday night.
Mr. Doub was referring to Congressional and state races in 2000 that he wanted Republicans to win, and he seemed to be assuming already that Mr. Bush would end up in the White House, his path to glory smoothed by the treasury he was amassing.
Mr. Bush was expected to raise $500,000 today from a $1,000-a-plate luncheon here and a dinner in Plantation, Ga., with the same price tag. The federally mandated limit for individual donations to a campaign is $1,000.
The roughly $37 million that Mr. Bush had reported raising by June 30 was by far the most that any Presidential candidate had accumulated at such an early point in the race. It also raised the question of how quickly Mr. Bush could continue to rake in the cash, given the number of contributors he had already tapped.
This week's tally, from five $1,000-a-head events, provided the answer: There was plenty more where that came from.
"That spirit is still there," said Don Evans, a Texas oilman who is Mr. Bush's national finance chairman.
Mr. Evans and other officials with the Bush campaign said they would not specify how much additional money they had raised before the end of the quarter on Sept. 30.
But in remarks this week, Mr. Bush said that more than 105,000 people had now donated to his campaign; at the end of the last quarter, the figure was about 75,000. If the new donors gave at a similar rate, Mr. Bush has easily added more than $10 million to his treasury and may be over the $50 million mark at this point.
"They are keeping up a remarkable pace," said Ari Fleischer, a spokesman for Elizabeth Dole, who places a distant second behind Mr. Bush in most national polls of Republicans. In a four-day swing last week through Western states including California, Mrs. Dole raised about $165,000, Mr. Fleischer said.
This was hardly Mr. Bush's best week. In California at the end of June, Mr. Bush raised an estimated $5 million. But the terrain he traversed this time around -- South Carolina, North Carolina and Georgia -- is not as famously fertile with donors, and the Bush campaign had held fund-raising events here already.
The $1.1 million that aides said he had raised did not subtract what it cost Mr. Bush and his aides to put on and attend the events, but the Bush campaign is renowned for its fiscal prudence in such endeavors. The fund-raiser in Durham, N.C., for example, consisted of serve-yourself appetizers -- arrayed buffet-style under an ice sculpture of an elephant -- rather than a sit-down dinner.
Bill Graham, a co-chairman of the event, said that he has been amazed at the ease of raising money for Mr. Bush. To illustrate the point, he opened his suit jacket to reveal an inner pocket bulging with $1,000 checks.
Mr. Graham, a lawyer from Raleigh, N.C., said the humming economy was one explanation for the phenomenon, but that another, perhaps more potent reason was the hunger of people who did not like President Clinton to banish all traces of him, including Vice President Al Gore, the early front-runner for the Democratic Presidential nomination.
"We've got to get someone else in there, and this guy looks like a winner," Mr. Graham said, referring to Mr. Bush. Mr. Bush's swing through the Southeast included just as many events that raised no money at all, and the selection of places he stopped -- including a school in Florence, S.C., and a mostly privately funded social services center in Marietta, Ga. -- emphasized two of the principal themes of his campaign: improving education and encouraging religious organizations and charities to do more to help the needy.
Mr. Bush presented those efforts as the bulwarks of compassionate conservatism, a phrase that has become a linchpin of his identity and a mantra in his campaign.
As for all the contributions and support that have come his way, Mr. Bush said he was grateful but not complacent. "I also know that I've got a lot of work to do," he said.

HEADLINE: Consumption And Incomes Up Yet Again

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 27

 BODY:
Personal incomes rose for the seventh consecutive month in July, Government figures showed today, enabling consumer spending to continue to grow and pushing the economy toward its longest expansion ever.
Incomes grew two-tenths of a percent in July after rising seven-tenths of a percent in June, the Commerce Department said. Spending rose four-tenths of a percent after a gain of three-tenths of a percent a month earlier. 
 The July increase in income was the smallest since the end of last year because Federal disaster payments had increased farmers' income in June. Excluding farmers, personal incomes rose five-tenths of a percent last month, the same as in June.
"The economy will continue to grow with limited interruptions," said Richard Yamarone, a senior economist at the Argus Research Corporation in New York. If growth continues through January, the expansion will be 107 months old and the longest in United States history.
Pay increases at factories helped bring about a seven-tenths of a percent increase in wages and salaries, which account for about 60 percent of income. That was the biggest increase since January.
Wages and salaries at manufacturers, where pay tends to run higher than in service-producing jobs, rose eight-tenths of a percent. The rise last month in factory wages was the strongest since a 1.2 percent jump in August 1998, Government figures showed.
The increase in consumption was paced by a rise of six-tenths of a percent in spending on utilities and other services, "as air-conditioning use was boosted by the summer heat wave which enveloped much of the country," said Marilyn Schaja, a money market economist at Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities in New York.
Spending on durable goods was lifted by demand for autos, analysts said. Sales of cars and light trucks rose to 17.1 million units at an annual rate in July, up from 17 million units in June, auto makers reported earlier this month.
The nation's savings rate, meanwhile, came in at minus 1.4 percent, compared with minus 1.1 percent in June. The rate accounts for neither capital gains from investments nor improvement in home values, something that consumers may be counting on to pay for future expenses like retirement.
In addition, the report assumes that installment purchases that can be paid off in two or three years are one-day cash purchases. That is why many economists say they think Americans are saving more than the statistics indicate.
Separately, the University of Michigan's index of consumer confidence fell to 104.5 in August from 106 in July. The index, which fell to 97.4 last October, has ranged between 103.9 and 108.1 this year.

HEADLINE: Where Does Generation Y Go to Shop?;
70 Million Young Buyers Without a Thing to Wear

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
When Tony Shellman steps outside the midtown Manhattan offices of Enyce, a small clothing designer, he never knows what his trend-spotting antennae will hone in on.
Recently, Mr. Shellman, vice president for marketing and design at the company, went shopping for a new backpack. What he found instead, was a colorful, rugged, water-resistant fabric that his company turned into jackets for its fall men's line. 
 "We stumble across some of our inspiration by just walking down the street," Mr. Shellman said, explaining that he and the company's design team are as likely to find inspiration in a hardware or auto parts store as at a downtown nightclub.
Such vigilant design strategies, coupled with nontraditional apparel marketing techniques, are helping Enyce (pronounced eh-nee-chay) and other cutting-edge fashion companies attract the attention of the approximately 70 million American young people known as Generation Y.
Moreover, as department stores seek to lure back the rapidly growing numbers of younger shoppers, they are increasing floor space for teen-age styles and courting trendy urban clothing lines like FUBU, Mecca, P.N.B. Nation, Sean John, Ecko and Phat Farm, which once could only hope to find space at specialty shops.
For large retailers, the economic benefits of selling to young customers are too significant to ignore, according to Irma Zandl, president of the Zandl Group, a market research firm that tracks youth trends.
"It's the biggest number of teens since the baby boomers," she said.
As the back-to-school shopping season begins, the firm's research suggests that teen-agers will be clamoring for backpacks with large, comfortable straps, Velcro closings and lots of pockets, along with brightly colored sneakers. And the popularity of vests will be "huge," Ms. Zandl said, especially in bright hues and fabrics with a high-tech feel.
Generation Y -- the children of baby boomers, born mostly in the 1980's and 1990's and raised in a general age of affluence -- dwarfs its shorter-age-span predecessor, Generation X, the roughly 45 million people born between 1965 and 1978. Estimates are that this newest group of consumers already has about $150 billion to $250 billion in spending power each year -- with almost a third of that devoted to clothing.
And this fall, instead of spending as much on the widely popular urban clothing styles which had their origins as the baggy, oversized, logo- emblazoned fashions favored by rap musicians and black street gangs, teen-agers will see fashions that are a little more streamlined and stylish, combining elements of casual, athletic and dressier clothes.
Even traditional companies like Levi Strauss & Company are revamping their offerings and shifting their focus away from the baby boom generation that grew up on jeans.
As teen-agers browse among the clothing racks of department and specialty stores in search of what everybody else is wearing, many are likely to encounter Enyce's take on the de rigueur look: Button-front woven shirts come in muted oranges, blues and browns, while Hawaiian-style printed shirts feature leaf, taxi, stamp, skier and penguin designs.
Drawstring cargo pants are part of the offering, of course. So are loose-fitting jeans in raw, Belgian and waxed denim, available in colors ranging from khaki and dark rinse blue to chocolate and black. Waterproof red and gray snowboarding suits feature a hooded jacket lined with mesh fabric that absorbs sweat.
There is one item Enyce will not sell, though: vests. "We let everybody else do it," Mr. Shellman said.
But persuading teen-agers to buy what Enyce and other hip fashion houses are selling is no sure thing. Companies are making a big bet on one of the ficklest groups of consumers -- as Nike and Reebok have learned -- who have shown their ability to hurt a brand by turning away from a style or dismissing poor products.
"Big brands are at an inherent disadvantage when talking to teens," said J. Walker Smith, president of Yankelovich Partners, a research firm. "They have grown up distasteful and wary of a hard sell."
Indeed, courting a generation of skeptical consumers who have been weaned on the visual immediacy of MTV and the speed of the Internet requires apparel marketing strategies with new twists. These include enlisting high-profile musicians to wear specially designed outfits for concerts and in-store appearances. Within stores, music CD's are the product giveaway of choice, and disk jockeys even play records in the aisles between the clothing racks.
And, of course, as always, it helps if parents are befuddled by the music and the message and maybe even a little wary as well.
That is why it is all the harder for brands popular with baby boomers to win the allegiance of their children. Levi, in seeking to reinvigorate its trademark denim line, has picked up on the strategies pursued by newer apparel companies and has stepped up its sponsorship of music concerts and events. The company, the largest apparel maker in the world, sponsors tours for musicians, like Lauryn Hill, the Grammy award winner who has melded hip-hop with a smoother Caribbean-style music, and the band Sugar Ray, a surf 'n ska group. Performers often appear in clothing designed for them by the company, and may get involved in the design process, as Ms. Hill did.
The company also offers customers who buy any Levi's product a CD compilation of music by lesser known musicians who perform at Levi-sponsored concerts as well.
"All of the bands are totally relevant, but if you're outside of the demographic you probably haven't heard of them before," said Mitch Berk, president of Entertainment Marketing, which developed some of Levi's new promotions focused on teen-agers.
At many of the concerts that Levi sponsors, the company offers a special seating area for customers. And while teen-agers enjoy the music, Levi's trend spotters scan the area, paying close attention to what everyone is wearing, Mr. Berk added.
In-store promotions are part of the strategy as well. Earlier this month, at Macy's flagship store in New York City, teen-age girls screamed as Mark McGrath, lead singer of Sugar Ray, signed autographs, kissed cheeks and dutifully posed for photographers. Mr. McGrath wore a specially designed, sweat resistant black T-shirt and a pair of dark blue Levi's 501 jeans.
Trends change quickly. One of the things several companies and retailers are forecasting this year is that logos on clothing other than T-shirts will become smaller, eliminating the look of huge, billboard style banners everywhere.
"I call them the pieces you can only wear once a month because the logos are so big," said Jeffrey Tweedy, executive vice president of Sean John.
Customer surveys also help Sean John stay on top of teen-age preferences, Mr. Tweedy said, adding that the company uses surveys to help establish prices.
Thus far, Sean John, named after its founder, the rap impresario Sean (Puffy) Combs, has had strong sales since its clothes began appearing in March. Retailers said they had often racked up sales gains of more than 10 percent a week, above average for a new style.
Many companies, like Enyce, also have close ties to fashion stylists who follow trends and scout unique styles for their celebrity clients.
As a result of such efforts, Mr. Shellman can also offer a running list of celebrities and style setters who he says have worn the company's clothing, including 'N Sync, Cindy Crawford, Steven Spielberg, Jennifer Lopez, Brittney Spears, Usher, TLC and the Backstreet Boys.
Among retailers, Macy's executives say the company is willing to take a risk and try a variety of new styles in its stores. New products, however, must show strong sales quickly or they are removed from the store -- Enyce fell victim to this in late 1997 and was removed from the store. The company, which is owned by Fila Holding, hopes it will regain space in the store next year.
Trend spotters for Bloomingdale's cover fashion shows around the world. In addition, favorite trend- spotting spots in Manhattan include Balthazar and Fressen, two restaurants in lower Manhattan, as well as Jeffrey's Room, a small store in the Fashion District. "I'm in restaurants and clubs five nights a week, seeing what people are wearing," said Kal Ruttenstein, senior vice president for fashion direction at Bloomingdale's. "You have to cover it on the runways and on the street."
Mr. Ruttenstein predicts that vests will be popular items in a variety of fabrics. Hot colors will include earth tones, like green, brown, rust and rich reds. In addition, clothes will fit closer to the body. Also, cargo pants and anything with lots of pockets should do well.
Bloomingdale's is also gambling that a new generation of teen-agers will gravitate toward retro styles inspired by the coming Broadway musical "Saturday Night Fever." The musical is based on the popular movie from the 1970's, which glorified the disco nightclub culture.
But one thing from the line may be a tough sell: Bloomingdale's plans to offer an updated version of the trademark white suit that John Travolta wore in the movie.
"We're doing that white suit again, but in a white microfiber," he said.
Is Bloomingdale's afraid of making a fashion blunder? "If we make a mistake, we mark it down," Mr. Ruttenstein said.
At Sean John's, Mr. Tweedy forecasts that cashmere sweaters, and jean suits with long jackets will sell well.
In addition to some dressier styles, Sean John and Enyce are among several companies offering a new version of cargo pants with understated, zippered pockets.
After that, what is the next big must-have look that Generation Y will be clamoring for?
"I don't know," confessed Evan Davis, senior vice president of Enyce. "After this we probably have to do 3-D."

HEADLINE: Raymond Vernon, a Shaper Of Global Trade, Dies at 85

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR

 BODY:
Raymond Vernon, who helped shape the postwar system of international trade as a Government official and influenced thinking about the global economy as a scholar, died on Thursday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 85.
The cause was cancer, said his daughter, Heidi Vernon. 
 Mr. Vernon was a member of the Marshall Plan team that guided the economic revival of Europe after World War II, and worked on the development of the International Monetary Fund and the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. After serving in the Government in the Securities and Exchange Commission and the State Department for nearly two decades, he went to Harvard University in 1956 and never left.
At Harvard, Mr. Vernon first led an ambitious three-year research project on the New York metropolitan region that was regarded as a pioneering work in urban studies -- the work was supported by the Ford Foundation and the Rockefeller Brothers Fund. Afterward, at the Harvard Business School and later at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, Mr. Vernon focused for decades on the study of the international economy -- especially the increasing role played by multinational corporations and the limits to governmental power.
"Ray Vernon was the father of globalization long before people used that term," said Daniel Yergin, an author and business consultant. "His work has had a phenomenal effect on several generations of thinking about how the global economy works."
Mr. Vernon's books on these subjects -- including "Sovereignty at Bay" in 1973, "Storm Over the Multinationals" in 1977, and "Beyond Globalism" in 1989 -- were influential and often far-sighted.
In "The Commanding Heights," a 1998 best seller by Mr. Yergin and Joseph Stanislaw, the authors, recognizing the scholarly foundation laid by Mr. Vernon in the study of relations between Government and the global marketplace, wrote, "It is impossible to write about these issues without acknowledging the profound intellectual impact that Prof. Raymond Vernon has had on them over the half-century."
Kim B. Clark, dean of the Harvard Business School, called Mr. Vernon "one of the most influential scholars of his generation, a true pioneer in the study of multinational corporations and the international economy."
Born on Sept. 1, 1913, in New York City, Mr. Vernon was one of four children in a family of Jewish immigrants from Russia.
His father, Hyman, drove a truck delivering seltzer water to restaurants and bars in the Bronx, and Mr. Vernon and his two brothers helped their father heft the crates of seltzer on and off the truck.
Their family name was Visotsky, but the children changed it to Vernon, beginning with Raymond's older brother, Sidney. Recalling her uncle's explanation, Heidi Vernon said he changed his name to improve his chances of being accepted into medical school. All four of the siblings -- Sidney, Leo, Raymond and Corrine -- earned doctoral degrees.
Mr. Vernon received a bachelor's degree from the City College of New York in 1933, and earned a Ph.D. in economics from Columbia University in 1941.
At the S.E.C., where he worked from 1935 to 1946, Mr. Vernon handled various assignments from studying the behavior of floor traders and specialists on the New York Stock Exchange to planning securities enforcement programs.
While at the State Department, he was one of the negotiators who brought Japan into the GATT trade system and helped secure nondiscriminatory treatment for Japanese exports.
In the early 1950's, as acting director of the Office of Economic Defense and Trade Policy, he oversaw trade with the Soviet-bloc nations and encouraged their trade with non-Communist countries.
Mr. Vernon's economic perspective, according to Mr. Yergin, who knew him for many years, was shaped by having grown up in the Depression and by his years at the S.E.C. "He believed in markets, but he also saw the weaknesses -- where they can go wrong," Mr. Yergin said.
In 1956, Mr. Vernon went to Harvard to head the three-year study of the New York metropolitan region. His urban studies project concluded with a measured though prescient projection -- continued growth and prosperity for the three-state region, but decline for broad swathes of the region's inner cities.
Mr. Vernon began his research into multinational corporations in 1965. His early work anticipated that multinationals -- as efficiency-seeking enterprises -- would transfer labor-intensive work on standardized products to developing nations. In "Storm Over the Multinationals" he analyzed how the pragmatic decisions of increasingly global companies held a growing sway over economic forces once controlled by governments, like trade flows and levels of investment.
Later, when European nations tried to combat the power of American multinationals by fostering the creation of state-owned "national champion" corporations, Mr. Vernon predicted early on that the tactic would prove to be poor policy.
"His view was that state-owned enterprises could not compete with the investor-owned multinationals, which are more flexible," said Robert Stobaugh, a professor emeritus at the Harvard Business School. "His research became part of the foundation for the privatization push of the 1980's."
Short and wiry, Mr. Vernon was an athlete until cancer slowed him down last year. An avid oarsman, he could be seen daily at dawn on the Charles River in his single scull. He competed for decades in the annual Head of the Charles crewing competition. Icy winters did not cool his competitive zeal. In his 80's, in fact, he set a world record for his age group in one class of "indoor sprints," rowing machines with odometers attached. He was a member of the Cambridge Boat Club for 40 years.
"One of the great sadnesses of his life," said his daughter, Heidi, "was that he was not able to be on the river these last months."
Mr. Vernon's wife of 60 years, Josephine, died in 1995. Mr. Vernon is survived by his two brothers, Sidney and Leo, and his sister, Corinne; and by his two daughters, Heidi Vernon of Newton, Mass., and Susan Vernon Gerstenfeld, also of Newton, Mass., four grandchildren and seven great-grandchildren.
Mr. Vernon, the renowned student of multinationals, was once employed by a multinational-in-the-making. In 1954 he went to work for Forrest Mars Sr., who built the Mars candy empire. Mr. Vernon was placed in charge of planning, finance and new products. He oversaw the development effort that led to chocolate-covered peanut M & M's.
The new peanut variety was a success, and, in the candy industry, Mr. Vernon was called "the man who put the crunch in M & M's."
Mr. Vernon's foray into the private sector was short-lived, since he went to Harvard after less than two years in the candy business. But he would always talk of his M & M exploits at family gatherings, impressing the younger members of the Vernon clan, recalled his daughter, Heidi. "He told the grandchildren that he was the person who figured out how to get the letter M on each and every piece of candy," she said, "and they'd all believe him."

HEADLINE: Applicants for Police Test Are Down Despite Big Drive

BYLINE: By KEVIN FLYNN 

 BODY:
The largest Police Department recruitment drive ever fell far short of matching even the responses of recent years, but officials said yesterday that they would still consider the campaign a success if most of those who did sign up turn out to be city residents.
As of yesterday, the deadline to mail in applications, 10,328 people had signed up to take the qualifying test on Oct. 2. The total represents a 28 percent drop in applicants from last year's test and an even sharper decrease when compared with prior years, when the city routinely received more than 20,000 applications for the written exam, the first step toward becoming a police officer. 
 City officials said they expected only several hundred additional applications that were mailed in the last few days to arrive next week.
Nonetheless, police officials said the success of the drive, in which $10 million was spent on advertising and other efforts to encourage applications, should be measured by how many city residents it attracted to police work. The drive was initiated after the fatal shooting of Amadou Diallo, a West African immigrant, by white police officers, an incident that renewed criticism that the department's racial composition is not representative of the city's population.
"The purpose of the $10 million was not to get more numbers," said Police Commissioner Howard Safir. "The purpose of the $10 million was to get more city residents."
Personnel officials said it would take a few weeks for them to determine what percentage of the applicants live in New York City. About 60 percent of the 40,000-member force now lives in the city, officials said.
Even though department officials said attracting more applicants was never their focus, in previous briefings officials had dismissed reports of a low turnout by suggesting that the great bulk of applications traditionally do not come in until the final two weeks of a sign-up period. Yesterday, they explained the low number as the product of forces larger than the recruitment drive itself.
"It's a function of the economy," Mr. Safir said. "I have checked with police chiefs all around the world and they are seeing exactly the same thing. The economy is good. Police officer jobs are relatively low paying. You can't attract the number of people you have in the past."
The starting salary for a police officer is $34,970 a year.
Personnel officials confirmed that applications for other New York City uniformed services were also down sharply. The last firefighter test, in 1998, drew 41 percent fewer candidates than the previous one, according to Denise Collins, a spokeswoman for the Department of Citywide Administrative Services. The sanitation worker test given last year drew 45 percent fewer applicants than the previous one, she said.
But Thomas Scotto, president of the Detectives Endowment Association, offered an additional explanation. He said it was particularly difficult to recruit for the Police Department because so many officers were telling their friends and families that they feel underpaid and unappreciated. "The morale in this department is so low, it's nonexistent," Mr. Scotto said.
Mr. Safir also said negative publicity played a large part in driving potential applicants away from police work. "Part of the $10 million was to restore the image of police officers so people would apply," he said, "because the only public things young people have been hearing from the media is Louima, Diallo, profiling, all those negative spins that you guys love to do."
The department spent the recruitment budget on newspaper, television and radio advertisements, as well as on a 12-story banner that covers one side of Police Headquarters in lower Manhattan.
From the outset, the Rev. Al Sharpton had complained that too little money was spent advertising on media outlets owned by blacks and Hispanics. Yesterday he said the low number of applicants probably meant an equally lackluster draw of black and Hispanic applicants, many of whom he said distrust the department's treatment of members of minority groups. He accused Mr. Safir of "trying to put the best face on failure."
But the office of Manhattan Borough President C. Virginia Fields, who has supported the department's recruitment efforts, said their success could not be measured until the figures on residency were tabulated. "This could just be a low point for this time of year, a momentary lull," said Charles Walker, a spokesman for the borough president. "Nevertheless, because the numbers are so low," he said, the Police Department may "want to review their recruitment procedures."

HEADLINE: Greenspan Ties Debate on Rates to the Markets

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

DATELINE: JACKSON HOLE, Wyo., Aug. 27

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, said today that the booming stock market now plays an increasingly significant role in the Fed's debate over inflation but he stopped short of calling the market overvalued.
"We no longer have the luxury to look primarily to the flow of goods and services" when making decisions about interest rates, Mr. Greenspan said. In effect, he was labeling what he called the "extraordinary increase in stock prices over the past five years" as one of the major economic forces capable of pushing up the inflation rate. 
 Traditionally, a run-up in stock prices has been viewed as reflecting a strong economy and profitable companies. The economy drove the market. Now the opposite is more and more the case, Mr. Greenspan suggested.
The stock market, in response to Mr. Greenspan's remarks, which were delivered at an annual conference on monetary policy issues organized by the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City, fell moderately today. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 108.28 points, or nearly 1 percent, closing at 11,090.17 in light trading. Page C3.
The concern, mildly expressed in the day's trading, appeared to be that if the Fed saw an inflationary force in stock prices, it might raise rates again to slow the economy. Higher rates normally bring down stock prices because they raise the payoff from alternative investments, like Treasury bills.
The spectacular rise on Wall Street in recent years has added considerably to the wealth of millions of families and also to the value of the nation's publicly owned companies. Families and companies have spent -- or borrowed against -- part of the windfall from that gain as well as the increased value of real estate to buy additional goods and services. Their increased spending has helped make the economy boom.
Mr. Greenspan's remarks suggest that stock prices have become a more important target in the Fed's manipulation of interest rates. Controlling inflation remains the goal of interest rate changes, and that point was made repeatedly at the conference today. But Mr. Greenspan signaled that rising stock prices, and to a lesser extent rising real estate prices, must take their places alongside such traditional inflationary forces as tight labor markets, rising wages, shortages of goods and services that develop when demand outstrips supply, and the changing value of the dollar.
Despite the strong economic growth since 1996, inflation has remained unusually mild. The Fed, as a result, has been reluctant to push up interest rates very much -- a reluctance that helps feed the stock market. If a speculative bubble develops and the market finally crashes or declines sharply, the Fed's position is that it will step in then to minimize the damage by lowering rates and making money easier to borrow. Meanwhile the Fed will view the market as another potentially inflationary force, Mr. Greenspan said, but will not try to influence the market itself.
During a question-and-answer period, Mr. Greenspan elaborated on his speech. He said the Fed would intervene in financial markets only to correct sharp rises or falls in stock prices that might send shock waves through the rest of the economy. The real issue, he said, is a credit squeeze -- a sudden reluctance of lenders to lend -- whether markets are rising or falling.
"We don't respond to gradually rising or falling asset prices," he said. "We do respond to seizing up."
Some economists attending the conference here saw in Mr. Greenspan's speech a sort of addendum to the statement that the Fed issued on Tuesday, when it announced a quarter-point increase in the Federal funds rate at which banks lend each other money overnight, raising it to 5.25 percent, and pulling up other short-term interest rates with it.
The rate increase plus a similar one in June, the statement said, "should markedly diminish the risk of rising inflation going forward."
The financial markets initially saw in that statement a possible signal that the Fed was probably finished raising interest rates for a while. But for Alan Meltzer, an economist at Carnegie-Mellon Institute, Mr. Greenspan's explicit addition today of the stock market as an inflationary force might mean more rate increases in the coming months.
"Greenspan is saying, 'I am not certain I am all done or not all done, but you are making a mistake if you think I am all done,' " Mr. Meltzer said.
Having identified the booming stock market as a potentially inflationary force, Mr. Greenspan said that a lot more research needs to be done to determine why people are willing to make such risky investments and then, turning on a dime, flee them.
"If episodic recurrences of ruptured confidence are integral to the way our economy and our financial markets work now and in the future," he said, "it has significant implications for risk management and, by implication, macroeconomic modeling and monetary policy."
But Mr. Greenspan was careful to avoid going as far as he had in the past in worrying about the stock market. In December 1996, he questioned the "irrational exuberance" of investors on Wall Street, causing a brief but sharp selloff in markets around the world.
This time, he said that while stock prices seem unusually high, he could not conclude that the market was overvalued. Stock prices, for example, should reflect corporate profits, and Mr. Greenspan noted instances in which profits had been both overstated and understated in recent months, with the bottom line being that profits might be understated, thus helping to justify a rising market.
But he added an important caveat.
"It does not seem likely, however, even should all of the appropriate accounting adjustments to earnings be made," he said, "that such adjustments can be the central explanation of the extraordinary increase in stock prices in the past five years."

HEADLINE: Little Tribe, Casino Threatened, Battles U.S.

BYLINE: By PAM BELLUCK

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Aug. 27

 BODY:
A tiny Indian tribe in a sparse slice of northeastern Nebraska found itself today at the forefront of an increasingly heated national debate over the matter of where tribal sovereignty ends and state control begins.
The issue was the tribe's operation of a shoe-box casino on its reservation. Today that little casino nearly led a Federal district judge in Omaha to take an unprecedented step: the jailing of tribal leaders in a clash over reservation gambling. 
 Although the judge, William G. Cambridge, ultimately decided against jailing the leaders now, the tribe hardly won a conclusive victory. Judge Cambridge suggested that Federal prosecutors might want to pursue a criminal rather than civil case against them, and declared once more, as he had repeatedly, that the casino was illegal because it had lacked state approval ever since opening three and a half years ago.
The lack of such approval violates a Federal law, the Indian Gaming Regulatory Act of 1988, which requires an Indian tribe to strike an accord, or compact, with the state in which its reservation lies if it wants to open a casino. There are now about 145 such compacts between states and various tribes. But Nebraska, opposing any casinos within its borders, has refused to negotiate one with the Santee Sioux, the tribe with a stake in the proceeding today.
That proceeding was the latest in a series of recent skirmishes over the rights of tribes to operate casinos in states from Florida to California and, more broadly, over the ability of tribes to be exempt from state regulation and taxation.
Only Monday, the California Supreme Court overturned a ballot measure that would have allowed expansion of legalized gambling on Indian reservations. The decision dealt a severe blow to tribes' ambitions to build a gambling mecca to compete with Las Vegas. The tribes' position was supported by Gov. Gray Davis, but the court ruled that it conflicted with the State Constitution's ban on casino-style games like blackjack and 21.
In addition, Florida, Kansas and Alabama, trying to block the opening of Indian casinos within their borders, have sued the United States Interior Department with the aim of overturning new rules that allow the Federal Government to license tribal casinos in cases where states are reluctant to negotiate compacts.
And Wisconsin's Governor, Tommy G. Thompson, refused to renew one-year gambling agreements with that state's 11 tribes until they agreed to pay $22 million in lieu of taxes, up from $350,000 under the old one-year agreements.
"Before, when we didn't have any pie, nobody bothered with us," said Sheila Morago, a spokeswoman for the National Indian Gaming Association. "Now that we have a small piece of the pie, they want our filling. It's just a constant intrusion on the treaties that were signed long ago, on the tribes' sovereign rights. Every time you get a little farther, you take one step forward and two steps back."
David M. Rocchio, deputy legal counsel to Gov. Howard Dean of Vermont, who has been involved in discussions on Indian gambling through the National Governors' Association, said that "the concern that governors have is not with the benefit casinos bring to tribes." Rather, Mr. Rocchio said, "the concern is with the carve-out from state regulation, such as land use, police power and other ancillary concerns that arise when tribes have casinos -- and the impact on the residents not only on the tribal lands but also on other lands in the state." Like gambling venues everywhere, casinos attract crime, and can prey on compulsive gamblers.
The reservation of the Santee Sioux, the tribe involved in the court showdown in Nebraska today, lies on the Missouri River just across the border with South Dakota, and is home to about 1,000 tribal members.
In February 1996, the Santee Sioux opened the Ohiya Casino on reservation land, in a metal building not much bigger than a 7-Eleven store. It has 71 video gambling and slot machines, and attracts mostly elderly people from nearby farming communities. It takes in just $900,000 or so a year and employs only 23 people, but tribal leaders say it is an economic godsend for a reservation with 74 percent unemployment. Arthur Denny, the tribe's chairman, says the casino actually supports about four relatives of each employee and has brought a decline in alcohol abuse and domestic violence.
But Nebraska, which does not allow casino gambling anywhere in the state, has refused to negotiate a compact with the Santee Sioux.
Almost from the beginning, the United States Attorney's office in Omaha has tried to get the casino shut down. A Federal appeals court found the casino illegal in 1998, and the Supreme Court, without comment, let that ruling stand.
This February, Judge Cambridge began fining the tribe $3,000 a day, and in June he doubled the fine, to $6,000 a day. None of the debt, now totaling $726,000, has been paid by the Santee Sioux, and the purpose of the hearing today was for Judge Cambridge to consider whether to put the 11 members of the tribal council in jail for contempt.
In the end, he decided against doing so, saying that because the tribe voted in a referendum this month to keep the casino open, the leaders no longer had the authority to close it. He told the Federal prosecutors that to get the casino closed, they would have to pursue the case as a criminal matter, not a civil one. Why that would make any difference in a practical sense was not entirely clear.
In any event, the judge was hardly sympathetic to the Santee Sioux, saying the fines would continue.

HEADLINE: Panel May Rethink Charter Change to Avoid Affecting Green

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
The commission considering changes to the City Charter will probably soften a contentious proposal that could have thwarted the mayoral ambitions of Mark Green, the Public Advocate, if Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani left office early, administration officials said yesterday.
While the panel indicated yesterday that it would put a proposal on the November ballot to require a special election within 60 days if a mayor leaves office early, the officials said that the proposal would probably specify that such a change not take effect until after 2001. 
 This delay means that even if the proposal became law, Mr. Green would still serve a year as mayor should Mr. Giuliani be elected to the Senate in 2000, and would still have the advantage of incumbency during the mayoral election of 2001.
The reversal is surprising because when Mr. Giuliani, a Republican, appointed the Charter Revision Commission in June, he strongly hinted that his main goal was to keep Mr. Green, a liberal Democrat, from succeeding him. Under the current charter, the Public Advocate automatically fills a mayoral vacancy.
But the administration officials said yesterday that panel members had decided that changing the rules in the middle of an election cycle would be too controversial.
During a meeting yesterday, Randy M. Mastro, the panel's chairman and a former Deputy Mayor under Mr. Giuliani, said that he believed any change in the election laws should be effective immediately. But Mr. Mastro also acknowledged that the special election proposal had come under criticism, and he urged the panel members to "think long and hard" about when such a proposal should become effective.
"Sometimes it makes more sense to postpone the effective date of a proposal, to eliminate any question about why the proposal is being made at that point in time," Mr. Mastro told reporters after the meeting. "It is appropriate for us to consider that issue, based on public criticisms and issues that have been raised."
Mr. Giuliani's spokeswoman, Sunny Mindel, said yesterday that the Mayor would support whichever ballot proposals the charter commission recommended. On Wednesday, the panel is to vote on whether to put the special election proposal and 13 others on the ballot this fall.
The other proposals include merging the Department of Health with the Department of Mental Health, Retardation and Alcoholism Services; imposing a cap on year-to-year budget increases; banning guns within 1,000 feet of schools, and creating a commission to monitor organized crime.
Three other proposals would make the Human Rights Commission, the Office of Immigrant Affairs and the Administration for Children's Services permanent agencies under the charter, so that they could not be eliminated without voter approval.
Panel members already expressed strong support for most of the proposals at a meeting on Aug. 17. Yesterday, they focused on the questions of how the proposals should appear on the ballot, and when they should take effect, if they are approved.
Mr. Mastro said that it made sense for the proposals to appear as one big question because they all shared the goal of continuing the Giuliani administration's policies.
"It makes sense to present these proposals as a whole," Mr. Mastro said, "because they all relate to the same fundamental theme that we should make permanent those reforms that have served the city government so well in recent years."
But Mr. Green and several of the panel's other critics said they would fight any effort to combine the 14 proposals -- some of which involve complicated budgetary and procurement issues -- into one ballot question. The critics contended that the panel would be trying to make controversial proposals more palatable to voters by mixing them with innocuous recommendations.
Mr. Mastro said yesterday that the panel members had not decided whether to recommend delaying any change in succession rules, or even whether to put the special-election proposal on the ballot.
But the administration officials said that a delay was almost certain because there was too much public opposition to changing the rules immediately. In hearings this month, many elected officials and members of the public said changing the rules in the middle of an election cycle would be unfair.
Perhaps more significant is that several union leaders have sided with Mr. Green, and have threatened to mobilize their members and phone banks to fight the special election proposal. That kind of organized effort could insure the proposal's defeat, especially this year, when voter turnout for an election without major races is expected to be low.
Mr. Green said yesterday that he was pleased that Mr. Mastro had discussed the possibility of delaying any change in succession rules until after 2001. But he added that he was still not convinced that the panel would recommend such a delay.
"Hope springs eternal," Mr. Green said, "but I will wait to hear what they say on Wednesday before commenting."
 
REVISING THE CHARTER
Choosing Among 14 Proposals for the November Ballot
Here are the 14 proposals that the Charter Revision Commission is strongly considering placing on the ballot in November:
1. Imposing a cap, tied to the inflation rate, on increases in the city budget.
2. Requiring that at least half of any budget surplus be set aside for use in a fiscal emergency or other need that the Mayor and the City Council jointly decide is in the city's best interest.
3. Requiring at least a two-thirds vote of the City Council to impose a new tax or increase an existing tax, and requiring a four-fifths vote of the Council to override a mayoral veto of a new tax or tax increase.
4. Making the city's Human Rights Commission a permanent agency, and incorporating the city's Human Rights Law into the Charter.
5. Requiring that a special election be held within two months to fill any mayoral vacancy.
6. Making the Administration for Children's Services a permanent agency.
7. Merging the Department of Health and the Department of Mental Health, Mental Retardation and Alcoholism Services.
8. Creating an Organized Crime Control Commission to handle the regulatory, investigative and licensing functions of agencies that oversee the carting industry, public wholesale food markets and shipboard gambling.
9. Requiring that domestic violence services be coordinated through the Mayor's Office of Operations.
10. Making the Mayor's Office of Immigrant Affairs a permanent agency, and incorporating the city's laws protecting the rights of immigrants into the Charter
11. Eliminating from the Charter detailed requirements concerning bidding on city contracts, streamlining the city's procurement process.
12. Authorizing a centralized review of the integrity of vendors who want to do business with the city.
13. Creating gun-free zones within 1,000 feet of schools.
14. Making the failure to have safety locking devices on legally owned guns a crime.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Crisis Recedes In Hong Kong, With Economy Back in Black

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Aug. 27

 BODY:
Fifteen months after it spiraled downward into its worst recession in a generation, Hong Kong said today that its economy had stormed back to positive growth in the second quarter this year.
The government's estimate of growth of five-tenths of 1 percent from a year earlier puts Hong Kong in the ranks of other Asian economies, which appear to be recovering from the regional crisis as swiftly as they succumbed to it. South Korea, Thailand and Malaysia have all announced sharply better economic statistics in recent weeks. The Philippines said today that its economy had also beaten expectations -- growing by 3.6 percent in the second quarter. 
 The abruptness of Hong Kong's comeback caught economists here by surprise. Most had forecast that this former British colony would lag behind its neighbors in recovering from the regional crisis. Even after today's announcement, analysts remained wary of the territory's immediate prospects.
"It's an astonishing number," said Ian K. Perkin, chief economist for the Hong Kong General Chamber of Commerce. "But if you're coming out of recession, you want more than one quarter of growth."
Mr. Perkin said Hong Kong could still be hobbled by two things out of its control: its close ties to the weakening Chinese economy and its vulnerability to shifts in monetary policy in the United States.
The Hong Kong Association of Banks announced today that it would raise interest rates by a quarter of a percentage point -- mimicking an increase three days earlier by the Federal Reserve. Rates here closely track those of the United States because the Hong Kong dollar is linked to the United States dollar.
Though the rate increase was widely expected, it pushed down Hong Kong's stock market by 225.25 points, or 1.66 percent, to 13,383.13. The economic results were released after the market closed.
Despite all the caveats, officials here allowed themselves a sigh of relief after the relentless gloom of the last year.
"The worst time for Hong Kong occurred in the third quarter of last year," Sir Donald Tsang, Hong Kong's financial secretary, said. "Since then, we have seen some very robust recovery."
He added, "If you define a recession as negative growth, we are no longer in that area."
Sir Donald attributed the strong performance to revived consumer spending and tourism. Retail sales declined just 2 percent in the second quarter, following declines of 10 percent in the first quarter and 17 percent last year. Visitor arrivals rose 11.1 percent in the first seven months of this year.
Barring any rude shocks, Sir Donald said Hong Kong should eke out growth of five-tenths of 1 percent for the year. But he noted that the government had not raised that forecast, which was made earlier this year, despite the second-quarter numbers.
That is because Hong Kong is still surrounded by economic land mines.
On the government's list of dangers is a slowdown in the United States economy, a faltering recovery in Japan, overly high interest rates and, the most unpredictable, the tension between China and Taiwan.
"I have learned one thing," said Sir Donald, who has been lampooned here for predicting that the crisis would be over by last Christmas. "If I keep looking at the crystal ball, I will end up with a handful of broken glass."
Indeed, economists said Hong Kong's recovery differed from that of other Asian countries because it is still basically a trading post, packaging and shipping goods from China rather than producing its own exports.
"Hong Kong does not have the driving force that pushes other countries out of recession," said Dong Tao, an economist with Credit Suisse First Boston, who predicts that its economy will contract 1.5 percent in 1999.
Also, unlike Thailand or South Korea, Hong Kong does not have the benefit of a cheap currency. While those countries have devalued their currencies, the Hong Kong dollar rises and falls in lockstep with the United States dollar. That can make this a very expensive place to do business.
"A weak economy and a strong U.S. dollar is a painful combination for Hong Kong," said Guonan Ma, a regional economist with Merrill Lynch here. "Hong Kong is sandwiched between the tightening monetary policy of the United States and the slowing economic growth of China."
Hong Kong's currency is one reason that asset prices here rose to gravity-defying levels before the Asian crisis.
Now, the city is in a deflationary cycle, as the gaudy sale signs in store windows attest. Salaries and commercial rents are also falling. A report by Cushman & Wakefield, a real estate broker, said Hong Kong was now only Asia's third-most-expensive city for office rents, after Tokyo and Bombay.
"Deflation squeezes margins, so for corporations, Hong Kong is having a profitless recovery," Mr. Tao said.
Regardless of Hong Kong's peculiarities, its rebound will lend further credence to the perception that Asia is returning to health more quickly than almost anybody would have predicted last year. Rather than a protracted and painful convalescence, economists said Asia now looks more like Mexico, which snapped back from its currency crisis in late 1994 and early 1995.
"Virtually every Asian country reported an explosive second-quarter G.D.P. number," Mr. Tao said. He said the region was benefiting from sustained strong demand for its exports by the United States.
For Hong Kong, the big wild card is China. The country is grappling with deep deflation, which threatens to strangle its growth. Most analysts are expecting Beijing to devalue the currency, although few think it will act before Oct. 1, the 50th anniversary of the founding of the People's Republic of China.
A devaluation of China's currency would have unpredictable consequences for Hong Kong. It could put pressure on the link between the Hong Kong dollar and United States dollar. But it would also make China's exports more competitive.
And that could benefit China's middleman, Hong Kong.
