HEADLINE: In Basketball Heaven, All Summer Long;
Home-Grown Tournaments Lure Street Legends and College Stars

BYLINE: By AMY WALDMAN 

 BODY:
"I got $4.75 we win today. I got $4.75 in my pocket. Any bets? Any bets?"
Charles Faison was hanging on the chain-link fence at a playground in the Bronx on Sunday, haranguing players, coaches and anyone else within earshot. "I will bet a Happy Meal we win today," he said, cracking himself up. 
 He turned his sights on a young man in a technicolor shirt. "If you play ball as cool as you look you'd be in the N.B.A.," he crowed.
Just a few hours later, Mr. Faison, 26 -- known as Ese (ESS-ay), Mexican slang for "homeboy" -- would be in uniform and on the basketball court, his taunts being put to the test. But the hours before the Unlimited Tournament got under way were about warming up the attitude as much as the muscles.
For many city residents, summer in New York means one thing: basketball, specifically basketball tournaments, like the Rucker, the Entertainer's Basketball Classic and the Goat, all in Manhattan, and the Gunhill, also in the Bronx. For the tenants of the Forest Houses, a housing project in the Morrisania section of the Bronx, it means the Unlimited: a home-grown tournament played at the playground right across the street.
The court is cracked and buckled; the schedule is, well, loose. Players sometimes fill up on beer during courtside breaks, and teams occasionally struggle to find enough players to take the court. But for Mr. Faison and other Forest residents, the Unlimited is the high point of the year. Before this tournament started in 1997, the last tournament at this playground was held in 1985.
"It's good for the community," said Mr. Faison, who holds a paying job as a laborer at Montefiore Cemetery in Springfield Gardens, Queens. "I got something to look forward to in summer."
For now, the Unlimited is happy and sloppy enough to still be like a family event. But its patron, Lord Finesse, a successful rapper who grew up at Forest and took over running the tournament this year, has a vision. He sees the court resurfaced. He sees corporate banners hanging from the fence. And he sees big money flowing into the projects.
Tournaments like the Rucker and the Entertainer's Basketball Classic have become big money machines, driven by companies like Def Jam Records and Reebok. At the Entertainer's tournament, sponsors pay $10,500 to enter their team.
Finesse, 29, thinks that same machine could bring a badly needed boost to the neighborhood, where the biggest business opening in years was a new McDonald's that arrived this year.
"Give me $500,000 to $1 million," Finesse said, "and Forest will look like paradise."
He remembers his own childhood, when Friday field trips organized by the community center introduced him to more than the projects. "I just want kids to get out and see more," he said. "It would give kids a head start. They would see that maybe life isn't so one-sided as they see it in the projects."
For now, he is putting his own money into the tournament and charging each team $500 to participate. He bought new backboards and nets for the courts, and workers from the city's Parks and Recreation Department put them up. On nice days, he pays a deejay to pump music courtside. But he has his priorities clearly in order. "It's not like I'm not here for the community," he said. "But I want to win."
That means that his team, the X-Factor, must best the team of his longtime friend Fat Joe, a rapper who also grew up at Forest. The X-Factor and Fat Joe's team, the Terror Squad, have two of the best records in this summer's tournament; both are in the playoffs, which take place today. The tournament, which began late last month, ends Labor Day weekend, and the winners take home trophies.
Finesse said the strength of his team and Fat Joe's is not entirely coincidental. They recruit on courts and high school and college teams all over the city. "Being a rapper," Finesse said, "you have an advantage: everyone wants to play for you."
The players are college stars and playground legends; unemployed homeboys and juvenile counselors; teachers and bouncers. For those who never made it near college, Finesse said, it is their chance to prove themselves to those who did.
What they all share is talent that is both raw and showy. It is that talent, Finesse said, that made him want to run the tournament.
The players come from all over the city, but the fans definitely show hometown, or home project, favoritism. If Finesse leaves Ese, who plays on the X-Factor, on the bench too long, the crowd begins chanting his name. And when Chuck Dinkins, a k a the Hulk, a k a the Claw, a Forest resident known more for power than for smoothness, did some fancy footwork and then sank a three-pointer on Sunday, the 60 or so fans on the cement bleachers went wild.
Mr. Faison said he and his friend David (Spider Web) Webster are the backbone of Finesse's team.
"If we're on the court we vibe off each other," Mr. Webster said.
"And the team vibes off us," Mr. Faison said.
"We make 'em laugh," said Mr. Webster, 23, who spends most of his time caring for his twin daughters.
Some street basketball legends get paid to participate in this and other tournaments, because the competition for their presence is so fierce. But Mr. Faison and Mr. Webster said all they ask from Finesse is a good meal. (Mr. Faison prefers shrimp parmigiana; Mr. Webster, chicken parmigiana.)
If Ese and Spider Web, with their unceasing commentary, are the tournament's comic relief, Finesse and Fat Joe are its yin and yang. Finesse is a hands-on coach -- so much so that when his players bend their knees to take a shot, Finesse's knees bend too -- and a micromanager.
Fat Joe is as laid back as they come. By the time he rolled in on Sunday, his team was already playing. He cheered the players from the sidelines, then retired to the bleachers to relive his birthday party the night before with some friends. He signed autographs for children on little scraps of paper, and occasionally checked out the game.
"I'm not much of a coach," said Fat Joe, who also had a team in the Entertainer's tournament. "I'm more like a mascot."
His team in the Unlimited Tournament still won by 40 points that day.
"I love it when my players play like that," Fat Joe said.
Fat Joe owed his victory to one player in particular: Anthony Heyward, a 28-year-old from the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn. Off the court, Mr. Heyward is a math and science teacher who says he loves working with kids. On the court, he shows how he earned his nickname: Half Man, Half Amazing.
On Sunday, he was simply amazing, passing, rebounding and shooting with equal ease. He grabbed one rebound with arms that seemed to reach halfway to the sky; took the ball all the way down the court, navigating around defenders as if they were plastic traffic cones; and flew through the air to dunk the ball, easily his 10th dunk of the game. He finished with 35 points.
Mr. Heyward played three years of basketball at the Pratt Institute, then played in Europe and Latin America. His shot at the pros has not come, but he calls basketball "the love of my life." Every summer, he reconsummates that love, playing 60 or 70 games in multiple tournaments.
After his game, it was time for Ese and Spider Web to step up, as the X-Factor took on the Posse. "I'll buy you a whole chicken if you do your thing," Ese yelled to a teammate.
As the play continued, summer confected a moment of pure perfection. Little girls flew wildly on the swings next to the court, the girls shrieking, the swings creaking. Music from a Mr. Softee truck tinkled. The smell of grilling meat from a street vendor perfumed the air. A huge grin spread across Ese's face.
Then, suddenly, the peaceful rhythm was punctured. The referee ejected a player from the game after calling him for a technical foul, a delay of game, and a flagrant foul. The player, Master Rob, a playground legend on the Posse team, was not pleased, and when the referee had his back turned, Master Rob hit him on the back of the head.
Furious, the referee said he was ending the game, which was nearly tied in the third quarter. Angry players challenged him, saying he shouldn't punish the whole team for one player's actions. A plastic bottle flew through the air. The arguing escalated.
"He struck me in the back of the head," the referee, who did not want to be identified, told a player who was challenging his decision to end the game.
"C'mon man, this is the 'hood," the player said.
When the referee would not back down, the player told him not to show his face on the court again. "Next time, it will be different," the player warned.
It was the first time that a referee had been struck or threatened, players and coaches said, and suddenly, Finesse and the others realized that the future of their tournament was at stake: with referees too scared to return, or too scared to make tough calls, they would have nothing. They rallied around the referee.
"You don't mush the ref," Finesse said. "No one is going to touch my officials."
Even Fat Joe got off the bench and walked over to the scene of the argument with his friend Full Flex, another rapper who grew up at Forest. Full Flex yelled at the player who had threatened the referee: "It's my court! It's my court! You touch the ref and you'll walk out of here on crutches."
The player backed off and stalked away. The referee agreed to return for the playoffs. Master Rob was ejected from the tournament. The game was forfeited to Finesse's team. Peace returned, darkness fell, and the players, coaches and fans, all one for a moment, lingered, savoring summer's ebb.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Greenspan Says Stocks Influence Inflation Talks
Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, said that the booming stock market now played an increasingly significant role in the Fed's discussions of inflation. But he stopped well short of calling the market overvalued.
"We no longer have the luxury to look primarily to the flow of goods and services," when making decisions about interest rates, he said. The traditional view was that the economy drove the market. Now the opposite is more and more the case. Page A1. 

Stock and Bond Markets Decline
Stock prices fell as some investors interpreted the Federal Reserve chairman's remarks as a warning that shares may be overvalued. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 108.28 points, to 11,090.17. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 13.74 points, to 1,348.27, while the Nasdaq composite index slid 15.72 points, to 2,758.90. C3.
 
The Nasdaq stock market said that beginning Oct. 1 it would make its trade reporting and quotation systems available to organizations that intend to offer after-hours trading. C3.
 
Chicago Exchange Adds Options
Escalating the options trading war it started, the Chicago Board Options Exchange said that it would list options on 29 more stocks, including some contracts listed on the previously uninvolved Pacific Stock Exchange. C3.
 
Cell Phone Monitoring Standard Set
The F.C.C., over the objections of civil libertarians, announced technical standards for cellular phones that will give law enforcement agents expanded ability to monitor conversations and find criminal suspects. A1.
 
Regulators Reject French Bank
French bank regulators ruled that Banque Nationale de Paris could not keep its stake in its unwilling target, Societe Generale, effectively ending Banque Nationale's hopes of creating Europe's largest bank in terms of assets. C2.
 
Medtronic to Buy Xomed Surgical
Medtronic, which is known for its cardiac-rhythm-management products and is seeking to become the dominant maker of medical devices, agreed to pay $800 million in stock for Xomed Surgical Products, the leader in ear, nose and throat surgical products. C14.
 
Merrill Lynch Strategist Is Leaving
Merrill Lynch said that its chief investment strategist, Charles Clough, would leave the firm at year's end. During the bull market, he has favored a conservative strategy that has not been popular with many brokers. Nevertheless, the firm said it had wanted him to stay but he was leaving to spend more time with his family and help not-for-profit organizations. C3.
 
Trial Allowed for Diet-Drug Suit
A nationwide class-action lawsuit seeking medical monitoring for people who used the American Home Products diet drugs Pondimin and Redux has been certified by a Federal judge in Philadelphia. The drugs were frequently taken with phentermine in a combination popularly called fen-phen. C14.
 
Russian Officials Cited in Inquiry
A powerful Russian industrialist whose empire is under investigation in the Bank of New York money-laundering inquiry, Mikhail Khodorkovksy, said that a large part of the billions of dollars involved came from Russian officials trying to protect their fortunes from last year's collapse of the ruble. A1.
 
In Russia, Konstantin Kagalovsky, a businessman cited in the American money-laundering investigation, is becoming a celebrity. A6.
 
Ecuador Says It Will Get I.M.F. Loan
Ecuador said that it would receive a $400 million loan from the International Monetary Fund to help shore up its economy as it seeks to restructure nearly $6 billion in Brady bonds. In addition, the nation's Finance Minister, Ana Lucia Armijos, will step down. C2.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: August 29, 1999

SECTION: Section 7; Page 32; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 865 words

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

BYLINE: By Scott Veale

 BODY:

UNRAVELLING
By Elizabeth Graver. Harvest/Harcourt Brace, $13.
Aimee Slater is a nave New Hampshire farm girl who leaves home for a factory job in the 1840's, becomes impregnated by a mechanic and is exiled by her mother, forcing her to build a new life as an outcast and struggle to overcome her bitterness. In 1997 our reviewer, Benjamin DeMott, called this a "grave, winter-wise and absorbing first novel."
 
TITAN: THE LIFE OF JOHN D. ROCKEFELLER, SR.
By Ron Chernow. Vintage, $16.
The archcapitalist John D. Rockefeller Sr. (1839-1937) is portrayed as a complex figure whose lifelong devotion to making money was balanced by a deep religious conviction and devotion to his family. Rockefeller's Marxist analysis of the American economy put him and his fledgling company, Standard Oil, in ruthless pursuit of monopoly on an unparalleled scale before he was 30 years old. This evenhanded account, selected as one of the best books of 1998 by the editors of the Book Review, "is a triumph of the art of biography," Jack Beatty wrote in these pages. "Unflaggingly interesting," it brings its subject to life "through sustained narrative portraiture of the large-scale, 19th-century kind." 

SUMMER AT GAGLOW
By Esther Freud. Ecco, $15.
Shifting back and forth between contemporary London and Germany during and after World War I, this novel explores the fracturing of a Jewish family and how their notion of "home" is altered by their connection to their former summer estate. The result is "a near-seamless meshing of family feeling, history and imagination," Deborah Mason wrote here last year.
 
THE CLIMB: TRAGIC AMBITIONS ON EVEREST
By Anatoli Boukreev and G. Weston DeWalt.
St. Martin's Griffin, $13.95.
This haunting account of the 1996 storm that killed eight climbers from several groups focuses on the role played by the driven Russian guide for one of the teams, who saved three lives (and who died in an avalanche the following year). In 1997 our reviewer, Michael Parfit, called the book "raw but powerful." I MAY BE SOME TIME: Ice and the English Imagination, by Francis Spufford (Picador USA, $15), is a history of Arctic and Antarctic exploration centering on the exploits of great British adventurers like Robert Falcon Scott and James Cook. "With his book, just as with the endeavors of the polar pioneers, the journey might be worth it for its own sake," Robert R. Harris wrote here last year.
 
THE UNDISCOVERED COUNTRY
By Samantha Gillison. Owl/Holt, $13.
In this first novel, an American researcher takes his wife and young daughter to a remote village in Papua New Guinea, where their fragile family unit is tested after the girl joins the local culture, escaping more and more often into the rain forest. The result is an "exceptional story," Elizabeth Gaffney said here last year.
 
THE SPANISH INQUISITION: A HISTORICAL REVISION
By Henry Kamen. Yale University, $15.95.
The author argues that the popular image of the Inquisition as a barbaric, all-powerful scourge is a 19th-century myth, and that the tribunal was actually weak and its methods more humane than those of most secular courts. Last year our reviewer, Richard L. Kagan, called this "the best general book" on the subject "both for its range and its depth of information." The same publisher has reissued PHILIP OF SPAIN ($17.95), Kamen's biography of Philip II, who reigned during the Inquisition in the 16th century and who is often portrayed as an intolerant religious zealot. In presenting the monarch instead as a cultured Renaissance prince, this nuanced portrait is "a fine achievement," Hugh Thomas wrote here in 1997.
 
MAN WITHOUT A FACE:
The Autobiography of Communism's Greatest Spymaster
By Markus Wolf with Anne McElvoy. Public Affairs, $14.
The former chief of East German intelligence tells how he spent more than 30 years planting moles, running agents, orchestrating betrayals and living the secret life. He "comes across as a clever and cultivated man" who nonetheless "chose to follow a dark star," David Wise wrote here in 1997.
 
IDENTITY
By Milan Kundera. Harper Perennial, $13.
The hero of this dreamlike novel sends his girlfriend anonymous love letters to pick up her spirits, with disastrous results. "Kundera lucidly discloses the psychological obsessions of the two lovers and how these obsessions lead to repeated miscommunications," Robert Grudin wrote here last year. The same publisher has reissued LAUGHABLE LOVES ($13), a collection of the author's tales steeped in anger and fascination with the Communists running the show in Prague in the 60's. In 1974 our reviewer, Paul Theroux, called Kundera "a magnificent short-story writer" whose "best humor always seems to be rooted in authority situations."
 
THE HUNTERS
By James Salter. Vintage International, $13.
The author's first novel, originally published in 1956, is about a fighter pilot's harrowing tour of duty in the Korean War and the jealousies and competition among his fellow squadron members. Praising the book in these pages, George Barrett urged readers to "curl up for a flight . . . so 'clear you can see tomorrow.' "
 Scott Veale

LENGTH: 1464 words

HEADLINE: BOOKEND;
Imus, Oprah and the Literary Elite

BYLINE: By Martha Bayles; Martha Bayles teaches at Claremont McKenna College and is a correspondent for the PBS television series "Religion and Ethics Newsweekly."

 BODY:
Veterans BOULEVARD in Metairie, La., is like a million other commercial strips in America: zoned for business, not beauty. On this Sunday most people appear to be either shopping at the mall or going to the movies. The idea that they might be reading books seems remote.
But wait. The busiest place in sight is the Barnes & Noble superstore. I must circle for a parking spot, and when I enter the store I recall the economist Tyler Cowen's argument that the best way to sustain serious literature is through a vigorous market. Here is a table devoted to "The Complete Idiot's Guides." But here is another marked "New Selections From Small and University Presses." Is it true that a rising tide lifts all books? 
 Yet there must be drawbacks to treating books as commodities. One need not be a Marxist to share Ellen Goodman's qualms about "bookstores selling coffee, coffee shops selling books." Is it really O.K. to sell Godiva chocolate bars next to the cash registers?
Cowen would point out that this is nothing new. After all, the first lending libraries (which arose, along with commercial publishing, in 18th-century England) not only charged their middle-class (largely female) clientele a fee to borrow books but also turned a profit selling "hats, teas, perfumes, medicines and tobacco."
Next in line was the blockbuster. In 1862, Graham Robb writes in his recent biography of Victor Hugo, "the first part of 'Les Miserables' (Fantine') appeared in the wake of a mammoth advertising campaign in Paris, London, Brussels, Leipzig, Rotterdam, Madrid, Milan, Turin, Naples, Warsaw, Pest, St. Petersburg and Rio de Janeiro." Even before orchestrating that campaign, Hugo was a celebrity author.
Still, it may be objected that today the bubbliest hype is not lavished on writers of Hugo's stature. Consider Diet Coke's recent gambit: to attach excerpts of new novels to 12- and 24-packs, in the hope that millions of cola drinkers would get hooked and buy not only the books but more Diet Coke. The featured authors -- Maeve Binchy, Nora Roberts, Barbara Taylor Bradford and Elmore Leonard -- were about as market-tested as the beverage.
Moreover, ever since Thomas Whiteside wrote "The Blockbuster Complex" in 1981, it has been an article of faith among literary pessimists that an increasingly conglomerated publishing industry pursues mass market success to the detriment of the so-called midlist books that are often the lifeblood of the culture. This is worth worrying about but, moseying through the Metairie superstore, I find it hard to get too alarmed. There are so many titles on the shelves, I am tempted to agree with Alvin Kernan that "the Gutenberg age will come to an end" not with an "absence of books" but with a "bibliographic surplus."
This fear is not new either. Kernan quotes Diderot: "Eventually the world of learning -- our world -- may drown in books." Two centuries later there are more books in the world than Diderot ever dreamed of, and our heads are still (more or less) above water. Is it possible that the literary culture -- especially in America -- is simply doing what it has always done, which is to thrive without a single authoritative center?
During the last few years the country has seen an astonishing grass-roots revival of reading as a social activity. The publishing industry didn't create this revival, but it is doing its best to tap into it. Katherine Barrett, director of publicity for Vintage Books, says that the proliferation of book clubs, on-line chat rooms, and bookstore-based discussion groups constitutes "a whole new level of reading that is communal and pops up everywhere."
One sign of this revival is the willingness of certain media outlets to include programming about books. National Public Radio and C-Span have long done so because they reach a fairly upscale, literate audience. But soon the stores will be setting up displays of books mentioned in Tina Brown's new magazine, Talk. And Don Imus, the host of the nationally syndicated radio show "Imus in the Morning," not only flogs books but has joined Barnes & Noble and the A&E cable channel in bestowing four annual book awards, three for $50,000 and one for $100,000.
True to form, when Imus launched his awards a year ago, he also launched a pre-emptive strike against all those "elitists" who might knock the host of what he called a "hideous radio program" for posing as an authority on books. One prime target was Jonathan Yardley of The Washington Post (whom Imus called "an annoying little gnat"); Yardley responded that he had no problem with the prizes and in fact agreed with Imus that the traditional awards are "only rarely bestowed upon . . . books about subjects or ideas that do not dovetail with the ideological consensus of the intelligentsia."
Suddenly I feel the need for a latte. What exactly is literature's problem? Is it awash in an uncharted sea of text? Or is it gripped by "elitists" and "intelligentsia"? Whenever I feel this confusion, I recall what Irving Howe once said in reply to the standard complaint that the New York literary scene was "incestuous": "It only looks that way from the outside." The real problem is that Americans yearn for a center -- for a cultural capital, if you will -- but also resent the idea. So our centers (they are plural) keep forming, dissolving and forming again.
This ambivalence is brought into sharp relief by a display in the next aisle: "Oprah's Book Club." Imus sells thousands of books, but Winfrey is Queen Midas of the Midlist. For the past three years, every book she has recommended has experienced a significant bump in sales, and many have become runaway best sellers. "Once the announcement is made, it's like a tidal wave," Susan Fleming-Holland, a publicist for Simon & Schuster, observes. "All we can do is get out of the way."
"Oprah's Book Club" is a bit like the superstore itself -- a sign of popular enthusiasm for books that gives intellectuals the willies. The reasons are the same ones I was pondering this Sunday: commodification, the blockbuster mentality and the feeling that the culture either lacks a center or has surrendered its center to the wrong people.
But don't confuse Winfrey with Diet Coke. For all her power, she is not part of some blockbuster machine, engineering popularity in advance. On the contrary, she focuses on a category of books voted least likely to succeed in the marketplace: literary fiction. And the publicists say she is surprisingly immune to their appeals. Indeed, many of her selections are books that nobody is flogging because they have been in print for a number of years.
It doesn't help that Winfrey works in television. The comment of Richard Roeper, a columnist for The Chicago Sun-Times, who wrote about Winfrey's fans, is typical: "How wonderful that they're reading again. How sad, too, that it took a TV personality to change their ways." Why sad? Because all that television-watching has ruined them for reading, even when persuaded to pick up a book?
If this were so, then the human specimens in this superstore would be significantly different from those in Blockbuster Video half a mile away. But the only difference I can see is that the latter are less happy -- and no wonder. They and especially their children are being assaulted by loud commercials and by the candy and other junk food that Blockbuster pushes as the natural accompaniment to watching a film. Maybe what is in evidence here is not some McLuhanesque gap between print and electronic culture but rather the difference between pandering to the lowest common denominator and offering people something uplifting.
I use the word "uplifting" advisedly, knowing that it carries a load of condescension. But that is precisely my point. The secret of Winfrey's golden touch is her willingness to shoulder the mantle of cultural authority -- which, ironically, most literary people seem desperate to shrug off. She can do this because her appeal to viewers has never been based on the exploitation of their social and emotional problems (in the manner of Jerry Springer) but on self-help: a trendy term that nonetheless subsumes older and more deeply ingrained notions of self-improvement and (yes) moral uplift.
Winfrey's selections reflect a coherent sensibility: she favors novels about people, mostly women but some men, who are up against hard circumstances but who manage to endure, if not prevail, in the spirit of what Ralph Ellison called heroic optimism. This isn't how we are supposed to read literature in the late 20th century, but never mind. To say that is to raise a whole different set of worries about the decline of literary culture -- namely, all that serious writers and readers have been doing to hasten it.

HEADLINE: Mother: Free, Equal and Not at Home

BYLINE: By Robin Toner; Robin Toner is a Washington correspondent for The Times.

 BODY:

CARE AND EQUALITY
Inventing a New Family Politics.
By Mona Harrington.
206 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $24. 
 There is a category of issues in Washington that consists essentially of problems too big to solve. Long-term care for the elderly and disabled is one of them. The need is immense, the current system satisfies almost no one and almost nobody expects anything major to be done anytime soon.
Most of the problems-too-big-to-solve are tied to fundamental changes in how we live, but politicians have a hard time acknowledging this. All of which explains why Mona Harrington's "Care and Equality" is so bracing. Regardless of one's politics (and Harrington's are decidedly liberal), it is refreshing to witness someone actually struggling with the policy implications of real life.
Harrington, the author of three previous books on women and politics, begins with a simple observation: The country is suffering a caretaking crisis with an obvious cause -- the exodus of women from the home into the work force. Somebody else has to care for the children and the aging parents who were once the responsibility of stay-at-home wives and mothers. "We have patchwork systems," she writes, "but we have come nowhere near replacing the hours or the quality of care that the at-home women of previous generations provided for the country."
Most women, she argues, don't make enough for really first-rate child care. And only the truly affluent can handle the costs of long-term care; most Americans who enter a nursing home end up, sooner or later, on Medicaid, the health program for the poor. Yet Harrington notes that government and much of business still operate as if there were an unpaid army of caregivers at home. And the reigning ideology still holds that the family is responsible for the family, that barring some special circumstance like extreme poverty, caring for children and other dependents is a personal, not a public, concern.
This position, Harrington suggests, makes sense for traditionalists and conservatives, who essentially believe that the stay-at-home mother is the best of all possible choices, and one that society should do its best to promote. But it does not make sense for liberals. Which brings her to the main point of the book: a plea for a new "mainstream liberal politics of the family."
Harrington acknowledges that this will not be easy. Liberals are most comfortable with the defense of individual rights -- for example, the right of women to compete on equal terms in the work force -- and often apprehensive that the claims of the family will crowd out those rights. Yet because liberals have helped create this new world, she argues, they have an obligation to confront "the tortuous implications of moving women from the separate sphere of the home to a position of full, meaningful equality."
When it comes to actual policy prescriptions, Harrington often relies on liberal standbys (major subsidies for child care and health care; across-the-board subsidies for low-income workers) that would have a hard time passing in a Democratic Congress, let alone the current Republican one. Still, this book is not intended to provide an incremental agenda, but to be a call to arms. So, for example, she urges liberals to confront the idea that paid family leaves, which are the norm in many other countries, are simply impossible here. "The bar to paid leaves in the United States is not economic," she says. "It is ideological."
She is at her best and most passionate in writing about the values of care and equality: how they have almost inevitably collided in recent years, when so much has changed in the culture and so little in government and business. She broods over the welfare debate, and over the potential and the disappointments of the Clinton Administration.
Harrington sees the rise of a new, more feminized politics -- pioneered, in many ways, by President Clinton -- and applauds it, although she correctly understands that it could become a politics of small gestures. "To move beyond rhetoric to the reality of change, liberals need to be careful of substantively empty political appeals to women, encouraging the appeals but insisting on substance." And she brushes aside the notion that the needs of the family are not the stuff of politics, arguing that the country no longer requires the "warrior hero leaders" of the past. What could be more important, she demands, than building supports for the new families that, like it or not, women's equality has created?

HEADLINE: TRAVEL ADVISORY: CORRESPONDENT'S REPORT;
Panama Converting Canal Zone for Tourism

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO 

DATELINE: PANAMA

 BODY:
ON Dec. 31, the United States is scheduled to complete the transfer of the Panama Canal to Panama. The 50-mile passageway -- a wondrous feat of United States engineering -- transports more than 13,000 ships, including cruise vessels, and 190 million tons of cargo a year between the Pacific and the Atlantic.
But the transfer, which is being carried out in steps according to treaties signed in 1977 by President Carter and Brig. Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera of Panama, who died in a plane crash in 1981, also includes about $4 billion worth of property in what was known as the American Canal Zone. If Panama's ambitious plans are realized,232,278 acres occupied by American military installations to defend the canal will be transformed into an international hub of commerce closer to a mini-Singapore, with the potential of increasing tourism and exports and adding millions to the economy. 
 "The idea is to take advantage of the infrastructure we already have and use interesting concepts, looking for new markets," said Ricardo Icaza, marketing manager of the Interoceanic Region Authority, created in 1993 to manage the property relinquished under the canal treaties.
Buildings on the military bases -- barracks, hospitals, schools, houses and offices -- are already being turned into private housing, hotels, industrial parks, ports, universities and sports facilities. A new 310-room hotel, the Sol Melia, is scheduled to open this December in what used to be the School of the Americas, where Latin American military officers trained. The former military base of Amador is being turned into a tourism complex, set to open in 2001, that is meant to attract the passengers of more than 300 cruise ships that transit the canal annually but do not stop. The complex will offer hotels with views of Panama City and passing ships, casinos, golf courses, shopping centers and marinas.
Near the small town of Gamboa, at the canal's midpoint, a $25 million eco-tourism project over 91 acres, the Gamboa Tropical Rainforest Resort, is expected to open next year. The development on the banks of the Chagres River, about 45 minutes from Panama City by car, will include a 100-room hotel and marina in a natural setting that offers rain-forest trails, bird watching and fishing.
As the Canal Zone, which occupied close to 10 percent of the national territory after the waterway was completed in 1914, has gradually reverted to Panama under steps mandated by the treaties, some tourism projects have already been completed. Within the Soberania National Park not far from Gamboa, the privately run Canopy Tower hotel opened last January in a former military radar tower. In an ingenious conversion, the circular, galvanized-steel tower building topped by a 30-foot-high yellow dome is now a five-story, six-room "eco-lodge" with a 360-degree view of treetops. There are plans to add four guest rooms nearby.
"The potential is enormous for the adaptive re-use of facilities," said Pierre Cowart, a visitor from Chicago on his honeymoon, who with his wife was spotting birds through a telescope from the tower's observatory. A construction manager by profession, he commented, "It's an architectural challenge."
Both Panama and countries like Spain and Taiwan have already invested $1 billion, mostly in tourism and maritime projects due to be finished over the next five years, Panamanian officials say. More than 100 such projects are under way.
Still, there is also great uncertainty. Many Panamanians I talked to noted that some of the properties that have reverted to Panama since 1995 are already deteriorating. Most of the nine military bases that make up the most valuable property are being transferred this year. The property's fate hinges on the ability of Panama to attract more investors, Panamanian officials say.
It is a tall order for Panama, which has greeted the Americans' departure with a mixture of national pride and anxiety. Besides disposing of the valuable real estate the United States is leaving, Panama must replace the jobs and income earned from the American bases -- up to $350 million a year at one time -- and operate the canal, which brings in about $545 million a year in tolls. The Government must also oversee an expansion of the canal already under way and prevent deforestation of the watershed, under the scrutiny of both Panamanians and much of the world.
Historically, most of the canal's revenue has been invested in maintenance and modernization, but there are worries among Panamanians and Americans that governments here could be tempted to divert canal money for their own use or politicize its operation, lowering the canal's standards and safety. But the newly elected president, Mireya Moscoso, who will take office on Wednesday, has promised to keep the canal free of corruption and nepotism and use it to reduce high unemployment and poverty among the population of 2.8 million.
"All of Panama is monitoring very closely what will happen to the canal," an American official here said. "They all feel it's an asset that belongs to the whole country."
